tuple: ['What is it?', 'Think about all of the technological devices that you use on a regular basis.']
['What types of devices do you use?', 'Computers, wireless internet, smart phones, tablets, global positioning system (GPS), MP3 players, and satellite radio might come to mind.']

['What else can you think of that you have mentioned?', 'Next, think about the most exciting modern technologies that you have heard about in the news, such as trains that levitate above their tracks, invisibility cloaks that bend light around them, and microscopic robots that fight diseased cells in our bodies.']
['What do all of these advancements have in common?', 'All of these groundbreaking advancements rely on the principles of physics.']
['what is physics?', 'Physics is a branch of science.']

['what does science mean?', 'The word science comes from a Latin word that means having knowledge, and refers the knowledge of how the physical world operates, based on objective evidence determined through observation and experimentation.']

['what is the evidence of objective evidence determined through?', 'A key requirement of any scientific explanation of a natural phenomenon is that it must be testable; one must be able to devise and conduct an experimental investigation that either supports or refutes the explanation.']

['what does it require of an explanation?', 'It is important to note that some questions fall outside the realm of science precisely because they deal with phenomena that are not scientifically testable.']

['what happens after an explanation is determined to be objective evidence?', 'This need for objective evidence helps define the investigative process scientists follow, which will be described later in this chapter.']
['What does it mean to study Physics?', 'Physics is the science aimed at describing the fundamental aspects of our universe.']

['What fundamental aspects of the universe are described?', 'This includes what things are in it, what properties of those things are noticeable, and what processes those things or their properties undergo.']
['What does this description imply about the Universe?', 'In simpler terms, physics attempts to describe the basic mechanisms that make our universe behave the way it does.']
['What kinds of things can be described with physics?', 'For example, consider a smart phone.']
['What does physics describe about the smart phone?', 'Physics describes how electric current interacts with the various circuits inside the device.']
['What does this mean for the design of the smart phone?', 'This knowledge helps engineers select the appropriate materials and circuit layout when building the smart phone.']
['What other things can be described with physics?', 'Next, consider a GPS.']
['What does physics describe about GPS?', 'Physics describes the relationship between the speed of an object, the distance over which it travels, and the time it takes to travel that distance.']
['How is this applied to GPS?', 'When you use a GPS device in a vehicle, it utilizes these physics relationships to determine the travel time from one location to another.']
['What was the purpose of this document?', 'As our technology evolved over the centuries, physics expanded into many branches.']
['What was the early use of physics?', 'Ancient peoples could only study things that they could see with the naked eye or otherwise experience without the aid of scientific equipment.']
['What kinds of things did ancient people study?', 'This included the study of kinematics, which is the study of moving objects.']
['What was one example of a moving object?', 'For example, ancient people often studied the apparent motion of objects in the sky, such as the sun, moon, and stars.']
['What else did ancient people do with physics?', 'This is evident in the construction of prehistoric astronomical observatories, such as Stonehenge in England (shown in Figure 1.3).']

['When did the scientific study of physics start?', 'Ancient people also studied statics and dynamics, which focus on how objects start moving, stop moving, and change speed and direction in response to forces that push or pull on the objects.']
['Did this research lead to inventions?', 'This early interest in kinematics and dynamics allowed humans to invent simple machines, such as the lever, the pulley, the ramp, and the wheel.']
['What did they do with the simple machines?', 'These simple machines were gradually combined and integrated to produce more complicated machines, such as wagons and cranes.']

['What did the machine enable people to do?', 'Machines allowed humans to gradually do more work more effectively in less time, allowing them to create larger and more complicated buildings and structures, many of which still exist today from ancient times.']
['How many branches of physics have there been?', 'As technology advanced, the branches of physics diversified even more.']
['What are some of the branches?', 'These include branches such as acoustics, the study of sound, and optics, the study of the light.']

['When did the telescope become an important discovery?', 'In 1608, the invention of the telescope by a Germany spectacle maker, Hans Lippershey, led to huge breakthroughs in astronomy—the study of objects or phenomena in space.']
['Who was the first person to use it?', 'One year later, in 1609, Galileo Galilei began the first studies of the solar system and the universe using a telescope.']
['What is another notable discovery?', 'During the Renaissance era, Isaac Newton used observations made by Galileo to construct his three laws of motion.']
['What are the laws of motion?', 'These laws were the standard for studying kinematics and dynamics even today.']
['what is one thing you learned about physics?', 'Another major branch of physics is thermodynamics, which includes the study of thermal energy and the transfer of heat.']
['what is Joule?', 'James Prescott Joule, an English physicist, studied the nature of heat and its relationship to work.']

['what did Joule study?', 'Joule’s work helped lay the foundation for the first of three laws of thermodynamics that describe how energy in our universe is transferred from one object to another or transformed from one form to another.']
['what does this mean?', 'Studies in thermodynamics were motivated by the need to make engines more efficient, keep people safe from the elements, and preserve food.']
['What are some other aspects of the historical developments?', 'The 18th and 19th centuries also saw great strides in the study of electricity and magnetism.']
['What is electricity?', 'Electricity involves the study of electric charges and their movements.']

['What is magnetism?', 'Magnetism had long ago been noticed as an attractive force between a magnetized object and a metal like iron, or between the opposite poles (North and South) of two magnetized objects.']
['What did Oersted find?', 'In 1820, Danish physicist Hans Christian Oersted showed that electric currents create magnetic fields.']
['Who else discovered this?', 'In 1831, English inventor Michael Faraday showed that moving a wire through a magnetic field could induce an electric current.']

['How did this help humankind?', 'These studies led to the inventions of the electric motor and electric generator, which revolutionized human life by bringing electricity and magnetism into our machines.']
['What is the first name of the scientist who discovered radiactive substances?', 'The end of the 19th century saw the discovery of radioactive substances by the scientists Marie and Pierre Curie.']
['What is nuclear physics?', 'Nuclear physics involves studying the nuclei of atoms, the source of nuclear radiation.']
['What does fission mean?', 'In the 20th century, the study of nuclear physics eventually led to the ability to split the nucleus of an atom, a process called nuclear fission.']
['Why is nuclear fission important?', 'This process is the basis for nuclear power plants and nuclear weapons.']

['What are some other important concepts that were discovered during the 20th century?', 'Also, the field of quantum mechanics, which involves the mechanics of atoms and molecules, saw great strides during the 20th century as our understanding of atoms and subatomic particles increased (see below).']
["What's a key fact from this section?", 'Early in the 20th century, Albert Einstein revolutionized several branches of physics, especially relativity.']
['What was relativity about?', 'Relativity revolutionized our understanding of motion and the universe in general as described further in this chapter.']
['Did physics have an impact on society?', 'Now, in the 21st century, physicists continue to study these and many other branches of physics.']

['Why did you decide to give the material this title?', 'By studying the most important topics in physics, you will gain analytical abilities that will enable you to apply physics far beyond the scope of what can be included in a single book.']

['Are there any other benefits of studying this material?', 'These analytical skills will help you to excel academically, and they will also help you to think critically in any career you choose to pursue.']
['What is physics?', 'The word physics is thought to come from the Greek word phusis, meaning nature.']
['What was natural philosophy?', 'The study of nature later came to be called natural philosophy.']
['What did it encompass?', 'From ancient times through the Renaissance, natural philosophy encompassed many fields, including astronomy, biology, chemistry, mathematics, and medicine.']

['What was the future of physics?', 'Over the last few centuries, the growth of scientific knowledge has resulted in ever-increasing specialization and branching of natural philosophy into separate fields, with physics retaining the most basic facets.']
['Did it change?', 'Physics, as it developed from the Renaissance to the end of the 19th century, is called classical physics.']
['What was modern physics?', 'Revolutionary discoveries starting at the beginning of the 20th century transformed physics from classical physics to modern physics.']

['What kind of physics is this?', 'Classical physics is not an exact description of the universe, but it is an excellent approximation under the following conditions: (1) matter must be moving at speeds less than about 1 percent of the speed of light, (2) the objects dealt with must be large enough to be seen with the naked eye, and (3) only weak gravity, such as that generated by Earth, can be involved.']
['Is it used to explain anything else?', 'Very small objects, such as atoms and molecules, cannot be adequately explained by classical physics.']
['What else is it used to explain?', 'These three conditions apply to almost all of everyday experience.']
['What is it used to explain?', 'As a result, most aspects of classical physics should make sense on an intuitive level.']
['What else does that cover?', 'Many laws of classical physics have been modified during the 20th century, resulting in revolutionary changes in technology, society, and our view of the universe.']
['Can you tell me more about it?', 'As a result, many aspects of modern physics, which occur outside of the range of our everyday experience, may seem bizarre or unbelievable.']
['What makes these changes?', 'There are two main reasons.']
['What is the second reason?', 'The first is that knowledge of classical physics is necessary to understand modern physics.']
['Why is that?', 'The second reason is that classical physics still gives an accurate description of the universe under a wide range of everyday circumstances.']
['What is a key point about modern physics?', 'Modern physics includes two revolutionary theories: relativity and quantum mechanics.']
['What kind of things do those theories deal with?', 'These theories deal with the very fast and the very small, respectively.']
['Who developed the theory of relativity?', 'The theory of relativity was developed by Albert Einstein in 1905.']
['What did he discover?', 'By examining how two observers moving relative to each other would see the same phenomena, Einstein devised radical new ideas about time and space.']

['How did he prove relativity?', 'He came to the startling conclusion that the measured length of an object travelling at high speeds (greater than about one percent of the speed of light) is shorter than the same object measured at rest.']
['What else did he discover?', 'Perhaps even more bizarre is the idea the time for the same process to occur is different depending on the motion of the observer.']
['Why is it different?', 'Time passes more slowly for an object travelling at high speeds.']
['What are some examples of this?', 'A trip to the nearest star system, Alpha Centauri, might take an astronaut 4.5 Earth years if the ship travels near the speed of light.']
['How would they age?', 'However, because time is slowed at higher speeds, the astronaut would age only 0.5 years during the trip.']
['How did people respond to the theories?', 'Einstein’s ideas of relativity were accepted after they were confirmed by numerous experiments.']
['What is gravity?', 'Gravity, the force that holds us to Earth, can also affect time and space.']
['What affect does gravity have on time?', 'For example, time passes more slowly on Earth’s surface than for objects farther from the surface, such as a satellite in orbit.']
['What happens as a satellite orbits?', 'The very accurate clocks on global positioning satellites have to correct for this.']
["How does a satellite's clock keep up with the earth's?", 'They slowly keep getting ahead of clocks at Earth’s surface.']
['How does gravity affect time?', 'This is called time dilation, and it occurs because gravity, in essence, slows down time.']
['what is one important thing we know about space?', 'Large objects, like Earth, have strong enough gravity to distort space.']
['what does this mean?', 'To visualize this idea, think about a bowling ball placed on a trampoline.']
['what happens to the bowling ball?', 'The bowling ball depresses or curves the surface of the trampoline.']

['what happens after it hits the surface?', 'If you rolled a marble across the trampoline, it would follow the surface of the trampoline, roll into the depression caused by the bowling ball, and hit the ball.']
['What else did you learn about space?', 'Similarly, the Earth curves space around it in the shape of a funnel.']
['how does this affect things?', 'These curves in space due to the Earth cause objects to be attracted to Earth (i.e., gravity).']

["What is an example of a question you've received?", 'Because of the way gravity affects space and time, Einstein stated that gravity affects the space-time continuum, as illustrated in Figure 1.4.']
['What does gravity affect?', 'This is why time proceeds more slowly at Earth’s surface than in orbit.']
['Why would time pass so slowly in orbit?', 'In black holes, whose gravity is hundreds of times that of Earth, time passes so slowly that it would appear to a far-away observer to have stopped!']
['What is relativity?', 'In summary, relativity says that in describing the universe, it is important to realize that time, space and speed are not absolute.']
['What does it say?', 'Instead, they can appear different to different observers.']
['Are there any other interesting aspects of this article?', 'Einstein’s ability to reason out relativity is even more amazing because we cannot see the effects of relativity in our everyday lives.']
['What is quantum mechanics?', 'Quantum mechanics is the second major theory of modern physics.']
['What does it do?', 'Quantum mechanics deals with the very small, namely, the subatomic particles that make up atoms.']
['What are atoms?', 'Atoms are the smallest units of elements.']
['What are the subatomic particles?', 'However, atoms themselves are constructed of even smaller subatomic particles, such as protons, neutrons and electrons.']
['What do these particles do?', 'Quantum mechanics strives to describe the properties and behavior of these and other subatomic particles.']
['What does the quantum particles do?', 'Often, these particles do not behave in the ways expected by classical physics.']
['Why do they behave that way?', 'One reason for this is that they are small enough to travel at great speeds, near the speed of light.']

['What are particle colliders?', 'At particle colliders, such as the Large Hadron Collider on the France-Swiss border, particle physicists can make subatomic particles travel at very high speeds within a 27 kilometers (17 miles) long superconducting tunnel.']
['What can they do there?', 'They can then study the properties of the particles at high speeds, as well as collide them with each other to see how they exchange energy.']

['What kind of things can they study there?', 'This has led to many intriguing discoveries such as the Higgs-Boson particle, which gives matter the property of mass, and antimatter, which causes a huge energy release when it comes in contact with matter.']

['what is relativity?', 'Physicists are currently trying to unify the two theories of modern physics, relativity and quantum mechanics, into a single, comprehensive theory called relativistic quantum mechanics.']
['what does it help explain?', 'Relating the behavior of subatomic particles to gravity, time, and space will allow us to explain how the universe works in a much more comprehensive way.']
['What do you mean by application of physics?', 'You need not be a scientist to use physics.']
['What kind of applications does physics have?', 'On the contrary, knowledge of physics is useful in everyday situations as well as in nonscientific professions.']

['What are some examples of applications?', 'For example, physics can help you understand why you shouldn’t put metal in the microwave, why a black car radiator helps remove heat in a car engine, and why a white roof helps keep the inside of a house cool.']

['Do you have any other examples?', 'The operation of a car’s ignition system, as well as the transmission of electrical signals through our nervous system, are much easier to understand when you think about them in terms of the basic physics of electricity.']
['What is the application of physics?', 'Physics is the foundation of many important scientific disciplines.']
['What other disciplines rely on physics?', 'For example, chemistry deals with the interactions of atoms and molecules.']
['What is the foundation of chemistry?', 'Not surprisingly, chemistry is rooted in atomic and molecular physics.']
['What other applications of physics do scientists use?', 'Most branches of engineering are also applied physics.']
['What other uses of physics do scientists make?', 'In architecture, physics is at the heart of determining structural stability, acoustics, heating, lighting, and cooling for buildings.']

['What other uses of physics do scientists make?', 'Parts of geology, the study of nonliving parts of Earth, rely heavily on physics; including radioactive dating, earthquake analysis, and heat transfer across Earth’s surface.']
['What other uses of physics do scientists make?', 'Indeed, some disciplines, such as biophysics and geophysics, are hybrids of physics and other disciplines.']
['What kind of application does it describe?', 'Physics also describes the chemical processes that power the human body.']
['what else does it describe?', 'Physics is involved in medical diagnostics, such as x-rays, magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), and ultrasonic blood flow measurements.']
['What else?', 'Medical therapy Physics also has many applications in biology, the study of life.']
['What can you tell me about the last application described?', 'For example, physics describes how cells can protect themselves using their cell walls and cell membranes.']
['What else is covered in this study material?', 'Medical therapy sometimes directly involves physics, such as in using X-rays to diagnose health conditions.']
['What other applications are discussed?', 'Physics can also explain what we perceive with our senses, such as how the ears detect sound or the eye detects color.']
['What does physics do?', 'In summary, physics studies many of the most basic aspects of science.']
['Why is it important?', 'A knowledge of physics is, therefore, necessary to understand all other sciences.']
['Why is it necessary to understand all other sciences?', 'This is because physics explains the most basic ways in which our universe works.']
['Is there any other interesting information about physics?', 'However, it is not necessary to formally study all applications of physics.']
['What are some applications that people apply physics to?', 'A knowledge of the basic laws of physics will be most useful to you, so that you can use them to solve some everyday problems.']
['How can you use physics to solve everyday problems?', 'In this way, the study of physics can improve your problem-solving skills.']
['What are scientific methods?', 'Scientists often plan and carry out investigations to answer questions about the universe around us.']
['What do scientists investigate?', 'These investigations may lead to natural laws.']
['What are some natural laws?', 'Such laws are intrinsic to the universe, meaning that humans did not create them and cannot change them.']
['Can we change them?', 'We can only discover and understand them.']
['What did scientists discover?', 'Their discovery is a very human endeavor, with all the elements of mystery, imagination, struggle, triumph, and disappointment inherent in any creative effort.']
['What are some examples of scientific discoveries?', 'The cornerstone of discovering natural laws is observation.']
['What does observation lead to?', 'Science must describe the universe as it is, not as we imagine or wish it to be.']
['What else is of interest?', 'We all are curious to some extent.']
['What are the ways we discover things?', 'We look around, make generalizations, and try to understand what we see.']
['What are examples of this?', 'For example, we look up and wonder whether one type of cloud signals an oncoming storm.']
['How else do we discover things?', 'As we become serious about exploring nature, we become more organized and formal in collecting and analyzing data.']
['What else do we try to discover?', 'We attempt greater precision, perform controlled experiments (if we can), and write down ideas about how data may be organized.']
['Do we publish our findings?', 'We then formulate models, theories, and laws based on the data we have collected, and communicate those results with others.']
['What does this all lead to?', 'This, in a nutshell, describes the scientific method that scientists employ to decide scientific issues on the basis of evidence from observation and experiment.']
['What is an investigation?', 'An investigation often begins with a scientist making an observation.']
['What does the scientist observe?', 'The scientist observes a pattern or trend within the natural world.']
['What happens next?', 'Observation may generate questions that the scientist wishes to answer.']
['What should the scientist do to get more information?', 'Next, the scientist may perform some research about the topic and devise a hypothesis.']
['What is a hypothesis?', 'A hypothesis is a testable statement that describes how something in the natural world works.']
['How does it work?', 'In essence, a hypothesis is an educated guess that explains something about an observation.']
['What are some of the scientific methods?', 'Scientists may test the hypothesis by performing an experiment.']
['What do they observe during the experiment?', 'During an experiment, the scientist collects data that will help them learn about the phenomenon they are studying.']
['What happens when they gather the data?', 'Then the scientists analyze the results of the experiment (that is, the data), often using statistical, mathematical, and/or graphical methods.']
['What do they learn from the analysis?', 'From the data analysis, they draw conclusions.']
['What do they draw conclusions about?', 'They may conclude that their experiment either supports or rejects their hypothesis.']
['What do they decide next?', 'If the hypothesis is supported, the scientist usually goes on to test another hypothesis related to the first.']

['If the hypothesis is rejected, what happens next?', 'If their hypothesis is rejected, they will often then test a new and different hypothesis in their effort to learn more about whatever they are studying.']
['What are scientific processes?', 'Scientific processes can be applied to many situations.']
['What examples do you give?', 'Let’s say that you try to turn on your car, but it will not start.']
['What do you try to find out?', 'You ask yourself, "Why won’t my car start?"']
['Why is this important?', 'You can now use scientific processes to answer this question.']
['What steps do you take next?', 'First, you generate a hypothesis such as, "The car won’t start because it has no gasoline in the gas tank."']
['What do you try next?', 'To test this hypothesis, you put gasoline in the car and try to start it again.']
['Why do you need to do this?', 'If the car starts, then your hypothesis is supported by the experiment.']
["What happens if it doesn't?", 'If the car does not start, then your hypothesis is rejected.']
['What will you do next?', 'You will then need to think up a new hypothesis to test such as, "My car won’t start because the fuel pump is broken."']
["What happens if it's broken?", 'Hopefully, your investigations lead you to discover why the car won’t start and enable you to fix it.']
['What is modeling?', 'A model is a representation of something that is often too difficult (or impossible) to study directly.']
['What can be modeled?', 'Models can take the form of physical models, equations, computer programs, or simulations—computer graphics/animations.']

['What are some examples of modeling?', 'Models are tools that are especially useful in modern physics because they let us visualize phenomena that we normally cannot observe with our senses, such as very small objects or objects that move at high speeds.']
['What are some examples of modeling in practice?', 'For example, we can understand the structure of an atom using models, despite the fact that no one has ever seen an atom with their own eyes.']
['What are some characteristics of models?', 'Models are always approximate, so they are simpler to consider than the real situation; the more complete a model is, the more complicated it must be.']
['How does modeling help?', 'Models put the intangible or the extremely complex into human terms that we can visualize, discuss, and hypothesize about.']
['What are some important things about modeling?', 'Scientific models are constructed based on the results of previous experiments.']
['Are there limitations on the models?', 'Even still, models often only describe a phenomenon partially or in a few limited situations.']
['How do you know a model is incomplete?', 'Some phenomena are so complex that they may be impossible to model them in their entirety, even using computers.']

['What kind of models are there?', 'An example is the electron cloud model of the atom in which electrons are moving around the atom’s center in distinct clouds, that represent the likelihood of finding an electron in different places.']
['Why is this model useful?', 'This model helps us to visualize the structure of an atom.']
['What limitations does it have?', 'However, it does not show us exactly where an electron will be within its cloud at any one particular time.']
['What are models?', 'As mentioned previously, physicists use a variety of models including equations, physical models, computer simulations, etc.']
['What is the biggest example of a model in this chapter?', 'For example, three-dimensional models are often commonly used in chemistry and physics to model molecules.']

['What kind of functions are models used for?', 'Properties other than appearance or location are usually modelled using mathematics, where functions are used to show how these properties relate to one another.']
['What kind of simulations do physicists use?', 'Processes such as the formation of a star or the planets, can also be modelled using computer simulations.']

['What is the purpose of computer simulations?', 'Once a simulation is correctly programmed based on actual experimental data, the simulation can allow us to view processes that happened in the past or happen too quickly or slowly for us to observe directly.']
['What else can we do with computer simulations?', 'In addition, scientists can also run virtual experiments using computer-based models.']

['What are some other examples of computer simulations?', 'In a model of planet formation, for example, the scientist could alter the amount or type of rocks present in space and see how it affects planet formation.']
['What is modeling?', 'Scientists use models and experimental results to construct explanations of observations or design solutions to problems.']
['What can modeling be used for?', 'For example, one way to make a car more fuel efficient is to reduce the friction or drag caused by air flowing around the moving car.']
['How can you reduce friction or drag?', 'This can be done by designing the body shape of the car to be more aerodynamic, such as by using rounded corners instead of sharp ones.']
['How do you test this?', 'Engineers can then construct physical models of the car body, place them in a wind tunnel, and examine the flow of air around the model.']
['How do you examine the flow of air around the model?', 'This can also be done mathematically in a computer simulation.']
['Can you tell something about the air flow pattern?', 'The air flow pattern can be analyzed for regions smooth air flow and for eddies that indicate drag.']
['What are the benefits of analyzing this pattern?', 'The model of the car body may have to be altered slightly to produce the smoothest pattern of air flow (i.e., the least drag).']
['Can you tell me how this alteration is done?', 'The pattern with the least drag may be the solution to increasing fuel efficiency of the car.']
['How can you test this?', 'This solution might then be incorporated into the car design.']
['What is a scientific law?', 'A scientific law is a description of a pattern in nature that is true in all circumstances that have been studied.']
['What else is significant about this?', 'That is, physical laws are meant to be universal, meaning that they apply throughout the known universe.']
['What else?', 'Laws are often also concise, whereas theories are more complicated.']
['What else?', 'A law can be expressed in the form of a single sentence or mathematical equation.']

['What is an example of a scientific law?', 'For example, Newton’s second law of motion, which relates the motion of an object to the force applied (F), the mass of the object (m), and the object’s acceleration (a), is simply stated using the equation']
['What are principles?', 'Scientific ideas and explanations that are true in many, but not all situations in the universe are usually called principles.']
['What kinds of principles are there?', 'An example is Pascal’s principle, which explains properties of liquids, but not solids or gases.']
['What does the distinction between laws and principles mean?', 'However, the distinction between laws and principles is sometimes not carefully made in science.']
['What is a theory?', 'A theory is an explanation for patterns in nature that is supported by much scientific evidence and verified multiple times by multiple researchers.']

['Can you give me more information about this?', 'While many people confuse theories with educated guesses or hypotheses, theories have withstood more rigorous testing and verification than hypotheses.']

['What is the importance of science to society?', 'As a closing idea about scientific processes, we want to point out that scientific laws and theories, even those that have been supported by experiments for centuries, can still be changed by new discoveries.']
['What is the most important discovery of the last century?', 'This is especially true when new technologies emerge that allow us to observe things that were formerly unobservable.']

['What new technology has emerged?', 'Imagine how viewing previously invisible objects with a microscope or viewing Earth for the first time from space may have instantly changed our scientific theories and laws!']
['What is the best thing you learned about science?', 'The constant retesting and perfecting of our scientific laws and theories allows our knowledge of nature to progress.']
['What does science help us accomplish?', 'For this reason, many scientists are reluctant to say that their studies prove anything.']
['Why?', 'By saying support instead of prove, it keeps the door open for future discoveries, even if they won’t occur for centuries or even millennia.']
['What are the most important concepts in physics?', 'Physicists, like other scientists, make observations and ask basic questions.']
['How do they answer these basic questions?', 'To answer these questions, they make measurements with various instruments (e.g., meter stick, balance, stopwatch, etc.).']
['What are units?', 'The measurements of physical quantities are expressed in terms of units, which are standardized values.']

['What types of physical quantities are measured in units?', 'For example, the length of a race, which is a physical quantity, can be expressed in meters (for sprinters) or kilometers (for long distance runners).']
['What is significant about the units we have studied?', 'Without standardized units, it would be extremely difficult for scientists to express and compare measured values in a meaningful way.']
['What is the SI unit system?', 'In any system of units, the units for some physical quantities must be defined through a measurement process.']
['What physical quantities must be defined?', 'These are called the base quantities for that system and their units are the system’s base units.']
['What other physical quantities can be expressed with the base units?', 'All other physical quantities can then be expressed as algebraic combinations of the base quantities.']
['What are the derived quantities?', 'Each of these physical quantities is then known as a derived quantity and each unit is called a derived unit.']

['Are the base quantities essential for the system?', 'The choice of base quantities is somewhat arbitrary, as long as they are independent of each other and all other quantities can be derived from them.']
['Is there a criteria for choosing the base quantities?', 'Typically, the goal is to choose physical quantities that can be measured accurately to a high precision as the base quantities.']
['How do these base quantities define the system?', 'The reason for this is simple.']

['What is the greatest limitation of these base quantities?', 'Since the derived units can be expressed as algebraic combinations of the base units, they can only be as accurate and precise as the base units from which they are derived.']
['What is an SI unit?', 'Based on such considerations, the International Standards Organization recommends using seven base quantities, which form the International System of Quantities (ISQ).']
['What are these base quantities?', 'These are the base quantities used to define the SI base units.']
['What are these base quantities and their SI base units?', 'lists these seven ISQ base quantities and the corresponding SI base units.']
['What is the SI unit for length?', 'The SI unit for length is the meter (m).']
['How is it measured?', 'The definition of the meter has changed over time to become more accurate and precise.']
['What is the first definition?', 'The meter was first defined in 1791 as 1/10,000,000 of the distance from the equator to the North Pole.']
['What was the second definition?', 'This measurement was improved in 1889 by redefining the meter to be the distance between two engraved lines on a platinum-iridium bar.']
['Where is the bar located?', '(The bar is now housed at the International Bureau of Weights and Meaures, near Paris).']
['Why did they change it?', 'By 1960, some distances could be measured more precisely by comparing them to wavelengths of light.']
['What wavelengths?', 'The meter was redefined as 1,650,763.73 wavelengths of orange light emitted by krypton atoms.']
['What is the most recent definition?', 'In 1983, the meter was given its present definition as the distance light travels in a vacuum in 1/ 299,792,458 of a second.']

['What is the kilogram?', 'The SI unit for mass is the kilogram (abbreviated kg); it was previously defined to be the mass of a platinum-iridium cylinder kept with the old meter standard at the International Bureau of Weights and Measures near Paris.']

['Where else are the kilograms kept?', 'Exact replicas of the previously defined kilogram are also kept at the United States’ National Institute of Standards and Technology, or NIST, located in Gaithersburg, Maryland outside of Washington D.C., and at other locations around the world.']
['Why does the kilogram have so much significance?', 'The determination of all other masses could be ultimately traced to a comparison with the standard mass.']

['How can the kilogram be affected by environmental conditions?', 'Even though the platinum-iridium cylinder was resistant to corrosion, airborne contaminants were able to adhere to its surface, slightly changing its mass over time.']
['How did the kilogram change in 2019?', 'In May 2019, the scientific community adopted a more stable definition of the kilogram.']

['What else is changing with the kilogram?', "The kilogram is now defined in terms of the second, the meter, and Planck's constant, h (a quantum mechanical value that relates a photon's energy to its frequency)."]
['What is The Second?', 'The SI unit for time, the second (s) also has a long history.']
['What is it defined as?', 'For many years it was defined as 1/86,400 of an average solar day.']
['What are the solar days?', 'However, the average solar day is actually very gradually getting longer due to gradual slowing of Earth’s rotation.']
['Why is this important?', 'Accuracy in the fundamental units is essential, since all other measurements are derived from them.']
['How did this affect the second?', 'Therefore, a new standard was adopted to define the second in terms of a non-varying, or constant, physical phenomenon.']
['What was the new standard?', 'One constant phenomenon is the very steady vibration of Cesium atoms, which can be observed and counted.']
['Why did they choose Cesium?', 'This vibration forms the basis of the cesium atomic clock.']
['Did anything else occur in this period?', 'In 1967, the second was redefined as the time required for 9,192,631,770 Cesium atom vibrations.']
['What is the ampere?', 'Electric current is measured in the ampere (A), named after Andre Ampere.']
['What are amps?', 'You have probably heard of amperes, or amps, when people discuss electrical currents or electrical devices.']
['Why are amps used?', 'Understanding an ampere requires a basic understanding of electricity and magnetism, something that will be explored in depth in later chapters of this book.']
['What is magnetism?', 'Basically, two parallel wires with an electric current running through them will produce an attractive force on each other.']

['What is the current?', 'One ampere is defined as the amount of electric current that will produce an attractive force of 2.7  $$\\(\\times\\)$$  10–7 newton per meter of separation between the two wires (the newton is the derived unit of force).']
['What is the SI unit of temperature?', 'The SI unit of temperature is the kelvin (or kelvins, but not degrees kelvin).']
['Who established this scale?', 'This scale is named after physicist William Thomson, Lord Kelvin, who was the first to call for an absolute temperature scale.']
['What is the kelvin scale based on?', 'The Kelvin scale is based on absolute zero.']
['What is absolute zero?', 'This is the point at which all thermal energy has been removed from all atoms or molecules in a system.']
['What is the temperature at absolute zero?', 'This temperature, 0 K, is equal to −273.15 °C and −459.67 °F.']
['How does the kelvin scale change?', 'Conveniently, the Kelvin scale actually changes in the same way as the Celsius scale.']
['Is there anything interesting I should know about this section?', 'For example, the freezing point (0 °C) and boiling points of water (100 °C) are 100 degrees apart on the Celsius scale.']
['How is this the same on the kelvin scale?', 'These two temperatures are also 100 kelvins apart (freezing point = 273.15 K; boiling point = 373.15 K).']
['What is the definition of variables?', 'Physical objects or phenomena may vary widely.']
['What are some examples?', 'For example, the size of objects varies from something very small (like an atom) to something very large (like a star).']
['What is a standard measurement of size?', 'Yet the standard metric unit of length is the meter.']
['What prefixes can we use?', 'So, the metric system includes many prefixes that can be attached to a unit.']
['How do they work?', 'Each prefix is based on factors of 10 (10, 100, 1,000, etc., as well as 0.1, 0.01, 0.001, etc.).']
['What is the table called?', 'Table 1.2 gives the metric prefixes and symbols used to denote the different various factors of 10 in the metric system.']
['What is the most common metric unit?', 'The metric system is convenient because conversions between metric units can be done simply by moving the decimal place of a number.']
['Why is that?', 'This is because the metric prefixes are sequential powers of 10.']
['How many centimeters are in one meter?', 'There are 100 centimeters in a meter, 1000 meters in a kilometer, and so on.']

['What does 1 foot equal?', 'In nonmetric systems, such as U.S. customary units, the relationships are less simple—there are 12 inches in a foot, 5,280 feet in a mile, 4 quarts in a gallon, and so on.']

['What else is notable about the metric system?', 'Another advantage of the metric system is that the same unit can be used over extremely large ranges of values simply by switching to the most-appropriate metric prefix.']
['How does that differ from other systems?', 'For example, distances in meters are suitable for building construction, but kilometers are used to describe road construction.']

['How does the metric system differ from other systems?', 'Therefore, with the metric system, there is no need to invent new units when measuring very small or very large objects—you just have to move the decimal point (and use the appropriate prefix).']
['What are some known ranges?', 'Table 1.3 lists known lengths, masses, and time measurements.']
['What else is notable about the material?', 'You can see that scientists use a range of measurement units.']
['Why is this important?', 'This wide range demonstrates the vastness and complexity of the universe, as well as the breadth of phenomena physicists study.']

['What other things should we know?', 'As you examine this table, note how the metric system allows us to discuss and compare an enormous range of phenomena, using one system of measurement (Figure 1.16 and Figure 1.17).']
['What is scientific notation?', 'Scientific notation is a way of writing numbers that are too large or small to be conveniently written as a decimal.']
['What is a specific example?', 'For example, consider the number 840,000,000,000,000.']
['How does it sound?', 'It’s a rather large number to write out.']
['How is it written out?', 'The scientific notation for this number is 8.40  $$\\(\\times\\)$$  1014.']
['How else does the number look?', 'Scientific notation follows this general format']
['What can I understand from this text?', 'In this format x is the value of the measurement with all placeholder zeros removed.']
['What does x represent?', 'In the example above, x is 8.4.']
['What else can I learn from the text?', 'The x is multiplied by a factor, 10y, which indicates the number of placeholder zeros in the measurement.']
['What are placeholder zeros?', 'Placeholder zeros are those at the end of a number that is 10 or greater, and at the beginning of a decimal number that is less than 1.']
['What is the factor?', 'In the example above, the factor is 1014.']
['What does 1014 mean?', 'This tells you that you should move the decimal point 14 positions to the right, filling in placeholder zeros as you go.']

['What happens if you move the decimal point 14 places?', 'In this case, moving the decimal point 14 places creates only 13 placeholder zeros, indicating that the actual measurement value is 840,000,000,000,000.']
['What are fractions?', 'Numbers that are fractions can be indicated by scientific notation as well.']
['How do you do scientific notation?', 'Consider the number 0.0000045.']
['What is the scientific notation of this number?', 'Its scientific notation is 4.5  $$\\(\\times\\)$$  10–6.']
['What about the number 10.000004?', 'Its scientific notation has the same format']
['Which is the first number in the series of numbers, x?', 'Here, x is 4.5.']
['What is the value of y in the 10y factor?', 'However, the value of y in the 10y factor is negative, which indicates that the measurement is a fraction of 1.']
['What else should you know about this information?', 'Therefore, we move the decimal place to the left, for a negative y.']

['What happens after moving the decimal place to the left?', 'In our example of 4.5  $$\\(\\times\\)$$  10–6, the decimal point would be moved to the left six times to yield the original number, which would be 0.0000045.']
['What is the meaning of order of magnitude?', 'The term order of magnitude refers to the power of 10 when numbers are expressed in scientific notation.']

['What is the relationship among the three sides of a right-angled triangle according to the Py', 'Quantities that have the same power of 10 when expressed in scientific notation, or come close to it, are said to be of the same order of magnitude.']
['What are some examples of magnitudes?', 'For example, the number 800 can be written as 8  $$\\(\\times\\)$$  102, and the number 450 can be written as 4.5  $$\\(\\times\\)$$  102.']
['What do these two numbers have in common?', 'Both numbers have the same value for y.']
['What does that mean?', 'Therefore, 800 and 450 are of the same order of magnitude.']
['How many magnitudes?', 'Similarly, 101 and 99 would be regarded as the same order of magnitude, 102.']
['What can you tell me about magnitudes?', 'Order of magnitude can be thought of as a ballpark estimate for the scale of a value.']
['Can you give me some examples of magnitudes?', 'The diameter of an atom is on the order of 10−9 m, while the diameter of the sun is on the order of 109 m.']
['What are the orders of magnitude for these values?', 'These two values are 18 orders of magnitude apart.']
['What are the unit conversions?', 'It is often necessary to convert from one type of unit to another.']

['For example, how can you determine what is a liter and what is a cup', 'For example, if you are reading a European cookbook in the United States, some quantities may be expressed in liters and you need to convert them to cups.']

['What other examples can you give of conversion?', 'A Canadian tourist driving through the United States might want to convert miles to kilometers, to have a sense of how far away his next destination is.']
['How about kilograms to pounds?', 'A doctor in the United States might convert a patient’s weight in pounds to kilograms.']
["What's the next step?", 'Let’s consider a simple example of how to convert units within the metric system.']
['When do you use the conversion factor?', 'First, we need to determine a conversion factor.']
['How does a conversion factor work?', 'A conversion factor is a ratio expressing how many of one unit are equal to another unit.']
['What does a conversion factor equal?', 'A conversion factor is simply a fraction which equals 1.']
['What else can you tell me about the conversion factor?', 'You can multiply any number by 1 and get the same value.']
['What happens if we multiply a number by 1 instead of multiplying it by the conversion', 'When you multiply a number by a conversion factor, you are simply multiplying it by one.']

['How can you use conversion factors to solve problems?', 'For example, the following are conversion factors: (1 foot)/(12 inches) = 1 to convert inches to feet, (1 meter)/(100 centimeters) = 1 to convert centimeters to meters, (1 minute)/(60 seconds) = 1 to convert seconds to minutes.']
['What will the next question be?', 'Now we can set up our unit conversion.']
['What do we have to do?', 'We will write the units that we have and then multiply them by the conversion factor (1 km/1,000m) = 1, so we are simply multiplying 80m by 1:']
['What does unit cancel mean?', 'When there is a unit in the original number, and a unit in the denominator (bottom) of the conversion factor, the units cancel.']
['What does this mean?', 'In this case, hours and minutes cancel and the value in seconds remains.']

['I am also asking you to give me more information about this material. What is the unit of', 'You can use this method to convert between any types of unit, including between the U.S. customary system and metric system.']
['What is the result you get after using this method?', 'Notice also that, although you can multiply and divide units algebraically, you cannot add or subtract different units.']
['Does this mean that you cannot add or subtract units?', 'An expression like 10 km + 5 kg makes no sense.']
['What is the difference between kg and km?', 'Even adding two lengths in different units, such as 10 km + 20 m does not make sense.']
['How do you express these lengths?', 'You express both lengths in the same unit.']
['What else can you tell me about units?', 'See Appendix C for a more complete list of conversion factors.']
['What is the basis of accuracy?', 'Science is based on experimentation that requires good measurements.']
['How do you determine accuracy?', 'The validity of a measurement can be described in terms of its accuracy and its precision (see Figure 1.19 and Figure 1.20).']
['What is accuracy?', 'Accuracy is how close a measurement is to the correct value for that measurement.']
['What type of measurement do you need to determine accuracy?', 'For example, let us say that you are measuring the length of standard piece of printer paper.']
['How do you determine the length of printer paper?', 'The packaging in which you purchased the paper states that it is 11 inches long, and suppose this stated value is correct.']
['How do you determine accuracy?', 'You measure the length of the paper three times and obtain the following measurements: 11.1 inches, 11.2 inches, and 10.9 inches.']
['What are the results?', 'These measurements are quite accurate because they are very close to the correct value of 11.0 inches.']
['What is correct about this measurement?', 'In contrast, if you had obtained a measurement of 12 inches, your measurement would not be very accurate.']
['What is the significance of accuracy?', 'This is why measuring instruments are calibrated based on a known measurement.']
['How is accuracy determined?', 'If the instrument consistently returns the correct value of the known measurement, it is safe for use in finding unknown values.']
['What is precision?', 'Precision states how well repeated measurements of something generate the same or similar results.']
['How does precision compare to accuracy?', 'Therefore, the precision of measurements refers to how close together the measurements are when you measure the same thing several times.']
['How do you test for precision?', 'One way to analyze the precision of measurements would be to determine the range, or difference between the lowest and the highest measured values.']
['What was the lowest and highest measurement values for printer paper?', 'In the case of the printer paper measurements, the lowest value was 10.9 inches and the highest value was 11.2 inches.']
['How big was the range between those values?', 'Thus, the measured values deviated from each other by, at most, 0.3 inches.']
['What were the results?', 'These measurements were reasonably precise because they varied by only a fraction of an inch.']

['What else can you tell me about the precision of the measurements?', 'However, if the measured values had been 10.9 inches, 11.1 inches, and 11.9 inches, then the measurements would not be very precise because there is a lot of variation from one measurement to another.']

['What is the most important concept to understand from this document?', 'The measurements in the paper example are both accurate and precise, but in some cases, measurements are accurate but not precise, or they are precise but not accurate.']
['What is a notable example that you have learned about?', 'Let us consider a GPS system that is attempting to locate the position of a restaurant in a city.']
['How would you describe the location of the restaurant?', 'Think of the restaurant location as existing at the center of a bull’s-eye target.']
['What is the Bulls-eye target?', 'Then think of each GPS attempt to locate the restaurant as a black dot on the bull’s eye.']

['What is the second figure in Figure 1.21?', 'In Figure 1.21, you can see that the GPS measurements are spread far apart from each other, but they are all relatively close to the actual location of the restaurant at the center of the target.']
['Why are these measurements spread apart?', 'This indicates a low precision, high accuracy measuring system.']

['Are there any other significant figures in the article?', 'However, in Figure 1.22, the GPS measurements are concentrated quite closely to one another, but they are far away from the target location.']
['What is the significance of this figure?', 'This indicates a high precision, low accuracy measuring system.']
['What else can you tell me about the figures?', 'Finally, in Figure 1.23, the GPS is both precise and accurate, allowing the restaurant to be located.']
['What is uncertainty?', 'The accuracy and precision of a measuring system determine the uncertainty of its measurements.']
['What is uncertainty used for?', 'Uncertainty is a way to describe how much your measured value deviates from the actual value that the object has.']
['What else should I know about uncertainty?', 'If your measurements are not very accurate or precise, then the uncertainty of your values will be very high.']
['What is uncertainty considered?', 'In more general terms, uncertainty can be thought of as a disclaimer for your measured values.']
['Can you give me an example of uncertainty in measurement?', 'For example, if someone asked you to provide the mileage on your car, you might say that it is 45,000 miles, plus or minus 500 miles.']
['How is the plus or minus amount measured?', 'The plus or minus amount is the uncertainty in your value.']

['What are you saying by indicating that your value is plus or minus 500 miles?', 'That is, you are indicating that the actual mileage of your car might be as low as 44,500 miles or as high as 45,500 miles, or anywhere in between.']
['Is there any more information about uncertainty in measurement?', 'All measurements contain some amount of uncertainty.']
['What are some more examples?', 'In our example of measuring the length of the paper, we might say that the length of the paper is 11 inches plus or minus 0.2 inches or 11.0 ± 0.2 inches.']
['What is A?', 'The uncertainty in a measurement, A, is often denoted as δA ("delta A"),']
['Observational error', 'Limitations of the measuring device']
['The measuring instrument itself', 'The skill of the person making the measurement Irregularities in the object being measured']
['Anything else that affects the results (highly dependent on the situation)', 'Any other factors that affect the outcome (highly dependent on the situation)']

['', 'In the printer paper example uncertainty could be caused by: the fact that the smallest division on the ruler is 0.1 inches, the person using the ruler has bad eyesight, or uncertainty caused by the paper cutting machine (e.g., one side of the paper is slightly longer than the other.)']
['', 'It is good practice to carefully consider all possible sources of uncertainty in a measurement and reduce or eliminate them,']
['What is percent uncertainty?', 'One method of expressing uncertainty is as a percent of the measured value.']
['What is a percent uncertainty?', 'If a measurement, A, is expressed with uncertainty, δA, the percent uncertainty is']
['What does uncertainty mean?', 'There is an uncertainty in anything calculated from measured quantities.']
['How is it determined?', 'For example, the area of a floor calculated from measurements of its length and width has an uncertainty because the both the length and width have uncertainties.']
['How do we reduce uncertainty?', 'If the measurements in the calculation have small uncertainties (a few percent or less), then the method of adding percents can be used.']

['How does this method work?', 'This method says that the percent uncertainty in a quantity calculated by multiplication or division is the sum of the percent uncertainties in the items used to make the calculation.']

['How can we calculate this?', 'For example, if a floor has a length of 4.00 m and a width of 3.00 m, with uncertainties of 2 percent and 1 percent, respectively, then the area of the floor is 12.0 m2 and has an uncertainty of 3 percent (expressed as an area this is 0.36 m2, which we round to 0.4 m2 since the area of the floor is given to a tenth of a square meter).']
['What does precision have to do with measurement?', 'An important factor in the accuracy and precision of measurements is the precision of the measuring tool.']
['What are some examples of precise tools?', 'In general, a precise measuring tool is one that can measure values in very small increments.']
['What kind of measurements do precise tools make?', 'For example, consider measuring the thickness of a coin.']

['What are the most precise measurement tools available?', 'A standard ruler can measure thickness to the nearest millimeter, while a micrometer can measure the thickness to the nearest 0.005 millimeter.']
['Why is a micrometer considered more precise?', 'The micrometer is a more precise measuring tool because it can measure extremely small differences in thickness.']
['What else does precision have to do with measurements?', 'The more precise the measuring tool, the more precise and accurate the measurements can be.']

['What is the main idea of this article?', 'When we express measured values, we can only list as many digits as we initially measured with our measuring tool (such as the rulers shown in Figure 1.24).']
['What example is used to illustrate the principle?', 'For example, if you use a standard ruler to measure the length of a stick, you may measure it with a decimeter ruler as 3.6 cm.']

['Why would you use this measurement instead of the centimeters?', 'You could not express this value as 3.65 cm because your measuring tool was not precise enough to measure a hundredth of a centimeter.']
['What is the last digit of the measurement?', 'It should be noted that the last digit in a measured value has been estimated in some way by the person performing the measurement.']

['What is an example of how to estimate the digit?', 'For example, the person measuring the length of a stick with a ruler notices that the stick length seems to be somewhere in between 36 mm and 37 mm.']
['How does the person perform the measurement?', 'He or she must estimate the value of the last digit.']
['What is the rule?', 'The rule is that the last digit written down in a measurement is the first digit with some uncertainty.']
['How many significant figures does the measurement have?', 'For example, the last measured value 36.5 mm has three digits, or three significant figures.']
['What is significant figures?', 'The number of significant figures in a measurement indicates the precision of the measuring tool.']
['What is the most precise measurement?', 'The more precise a measuring tool is, the greater the number of significant figures it can report.']
['what is the topic?', 'Special consideration is given to zeros when counting significant figures.']
['what happens if they are zeros?', 'For example, the zeros in 0.053 are not significant because they are only placeholders that locate the decimal point.']
['how many significant figures are there?', 'There are two significant figures in 0.053—the 5 and the 3.']
['can you tell me more?', 'However, if the zero occurs between other significant figures, the zeros are significant.']
['do you know how?', 'For example, both zeros in 10.053 are significant, as these zeros were actually measured.']
['do you have any other questions?', 'Therefore, the 10.053 placeholder has five significant figures.']
['what else is interesting?', 'The zeros in 1300 may or may not be significant, depending on the style of writing numbers.']
['what does it mean to mean the number is known to the last zero?', 'They could mean the number is known to the last zero, or the zeros could be placeholders.']
['does that mean a significance?', 'So 1300 could have two, three, or four significant figures.']
['can you tell me more about this?', 'To avoid this ambiguity, write 1300 in scientific notation as 1.3 × 103.']

['what else is significant about 0?', 'In summary, zeros are significant except when they serve only as placeholders.']

['What are the results of this?', 'The answer should have the same number places (e.g. tens place, ones place, tenths place, etc.) as the least-precise starting value.']
['Does anything else interesting happen in this article?', 'Suppose that you buy 7.56 kg of potatoes in a grocery store as measured with a scale having a precision of 0.01 kg.']
['What happens to the results of this?', 'Then you drop off 6.052 kg of potatoes at your laboratory as measured by a scale with a precision of 0.001 kg.']
['What happens to the results of this?', 'Finally, you go home and add 13.7 kg of potatoes as measured by a bathroom scale with a precision of 0.1 kg.']

['Does this mean anything?', 'Thus, the answer should be rounded to the tenths place, giving 15.2 kg.']
['Is there anything else you found interesting?', 'The same is true for non-decimal numbers.']

['What is significant?', 'It is a good idea to keep extra significant figures while calculating, and to round off to the correct number of significant figures only in the final answers.']
['Why?', 'The reason is that small errors from rounding while calculating can sometimes produce significant errors in the final answer.']

['What is the result of keeping all significant?', 'Keeping all significant during the calculation gives 48.']

['What else is noteworthy?', 'You would similarly avoid rounding in the middle of the calculation in counting and in doing accounting, where many small numbers need to be added and subtracted accurately to give possibly much larger final numbers.']
['What is significant figures in this text?', 'In this textbook, most numbers are assumed to have three significant figures.']
['What is consistent numbers of significant figures?', 'Furthermore, consistent numbers of significant figures are used in all worked examples.']
['What does the three digits refer to?', 'You will note that an answer given to three digits is based on input good to at least three digits.']
['How many significant figures?', 'If the input has fewer significant figures, the answer will also have fewer significant figures.']
['What is the three digits refer to?', 'Care is also taken that the number of significant figures is reasonable for the situation posed.']
['What is the rational figure number?', 'In some topics, such as optics, more than three significant figures will be used.']
['What is the four digits refer to?', 'Finally, if a number is exact, such as the 2 in the formula,  $$\\(c = 2\\pi r\\)$$, it does not affect the number of significant figures in a calculation.']

['What kind of graphs do scientists use?', 'Most results in science are presented in scientific journal articles using graphs.']
['Why do they use graphs?', 'Graphs present data in a way that is easy to visualize for humans in general, especially someone unfamiliar with what is being studied.']
['Are there other reasons scientists use graphs?', 'They are also useful for presenting large amounts of data or data with complicated trends in an easily-readable way.']

['What type of graph is most commonly used in physics?', 'One commonly-used graph in physics and other sciences is the line graph, probably because it is the best graph for showing how one quantity changes in response to the other.']
['What is an example of a line graph?', 'Let’s build a line graph based on the data in Table 1.5, which shows the measured distance that a train travels from its station versus time.']
['What is the data we are analyzing?', 'Our two variables, or things that change along the graph, are time in minutes, and distance from the station, in kilometers.']
['What mistakes could we make while analyzing the data?', 'Remember that measured data may not have perfect accuracy.']
['What is the first step in solving this problem?', 'Draw the two axes.']
['What is a horizontal axis?', 'The horizontal axis, or x-axis, shows the independent variable, which is the variable that is controlled or manipulated.']
['What is a vertical axis?', 'The vertical axis, or y-axis, shows the dependent variable, the non-manipulated variable that changes with (or is dependent on) the value of the independent variable.']
['What is the data for the graph?', 'In the data above, time is the independent variable and should be plotted on the x-axis.']
['What is the dependent variable?', 'Distance from the station is the dependent variable and should be plotted on the y-axis.']
['What are the other steps to be taken in this lesson?', 'Label each axes on the graph with the name of each variable, followed by the symbol for its units in parentheses.']
['What else should you do?', 'Be sure to leave room so that you can number each axis.']
['What should you label for the x-axis?', 'In this example, use Time (min) as the label for the x-axis.']
['How should you number the axes?', 'Next, you must determine the best scale to use for numbering each axis.']
['What is the best scale to use?', 'Because the time values on the x-axis are taken every 10 minutes, we could easily number the x-axis from 0 to 70 minutes with a tick mark every 10 minutes.']
['What else should you do?', 'Likewise, the y-axis scale should start low enough and continue high enough to include all of the distance from station values.']
['What is the best scale to use?', 'A scale from 0 km to 160 km should suffice, perhaps with a tick mark every 10 km.']
['What else should you do?', 'In general, you want to pick a scale for both axes that 1) shows all of your data, and 2) makes it easy to identify trends in your data.']
['How large should the scale be?', 'If you make your scale too large, it will be harder to see how your data change.']
['What else should you do?', 'Likewise, the smaller and more fine you make your scale, the more space you will need to make the graph.']
['What else should you do?', 'The number of significant figures in the axis values should be coarser than the number of significant figures in the measurements.']
['What else should you do?', 'Now that your axes are ready, you can begin plotting your data.']
['What do you do to start your graph?', 'For the first data point, count along the x-axis until you find the 10 min tick mark.']
['What else should you do?', 'Then, count up from that point to the 10 km tick mark on the y-axis, and approximate where 22 km is along the y-axis.']
['What should you do?', 'Place a dot at this location.']
['What should you do next?', 'Repeat for the other six data points.']
['What should you do next?', 'Figure 1.26']
['What is this?', 'The graph of the train’s distance from the station versus time from the exercise above.']
['What should you do next?', 'Add a title to the top of the graph to state what the graph is describing, such as the y-axis parameter vs. the x-axis parameter.']
['What is the title?', 'In the graph shown here, the title is train motion.']
['What is the title of your graph?', 'It could also be titled distance of the train from the station vs. time.']
['What should you do next?', 'Finally, with data points now on the graph, you should draw a trend line.']
['What does this mean?', 'The trend line represents the dependence you think the graph represents, so that the person who looks at your graph can see how close it is to the real data.']
['What should you do next?', 'In the present case, since the data points look like they ought to fall on a straight line, you would draw a straight line as the trend line.']
['What should you do next?', 'Draw it to come closest to all the points.']
['What else can you tell me about this article?', 'Real data may have some inaccuracies, and the plotted points may not all fall on the trend line.']
['What should you do next?', 'In some cases, none of the data points fall exactly on the trend line.']
['What should you do next?', 'Figure 1.27']
['What is this?', 'The completed graph with the trend line included.']
['What was your first question?', 'One way to get a quick snapshot of a dataset is to look at the equation of its trend line.']
['How do you get that?', 'If the graph produces a straight line, the equation of the trend line takes the form']
['What is the b in the equation?', 'The b in the equation is the y-intercept while the m in the equation is the slope.']
['What does the y-intercept tell you?', 'The y-intercept tells you at what y value the line intersects the y-axis.']
['Does the y-intercept change with the slope of the line?', 'In the case of the graph above, the y-intercept occurs at 0, at the very beginning of the graph.']
['Does it give you any other information about the plot line?', 'The y-intercept, therefore, lets you know immediately where on the y-axis the plot line begins.']
['What is m in the equation?', 'The m in the equation is the slope.']
['What does slope describe?', 'This value describes how much the line on the graph moves up or down on the y-axis along the line’s length.']
['How is the slope found?', 'The slope is found using the following equation']
['What is the equation?', 'In order to solve this equation, you need to pick two points on the line (preferably far apart on the line so the slope you calculate describes the line accurately).']

['What else does it contain?', 'The quantities Y2 and Y1 represent the y-values from the two points on the line (not data points) that you picked, while X2 and X1 represent the two x-values of the those points.']

['What are some important things I should know about this material?', 'The slope of a perfectly horizontal line will equal zero, while the slope of a perfectly vertical line will be undefined because you cannot divide by zero.']
['What else should I know?', 'A positive slope indicates that the line moves up the y-axis as the x-value increases while a negative slope means that the line moves down the y-axis.']
['How do they move up and down?', 'The more negative or positive the slope is, the steeper the line moves up or down, respectively.']
['How do I calculate slope?', 'The slope of our graph in Figure 1.26 is calculated below based on the two endpoints of the line']
['What did you learn from the passage?', '$$\\[\\begin{matrix}\nm & = & \\frac{Y_{2} - Y_{1}}{X_{2} - X_{1}} \\\\\nm & = & \\frac{\\text{']

['What else was interesting in the passage?', '(80~km)~–~(20~km)}}{\\text{(40~min)~–~(10~min)}} \\\\\nm & = & \\frac{\\text{60~km}}{\\text{30~min}} \\\\\nm & = & {\\text{2}\\text{.0~km/min}\\text{.}} \\\\\n\\end{matrix}\\]$$']
['What is the equation for t?', 'The formula  $$\\(y = mx + b\\)$$  only applies to linear relationships, or ones that produce a straight line.']
['What kind of line?', 'Another common type of line in physics is the quadratic relationship, which occurs when one of the variables is squared.']

['What is an example of a quadratic relation?', 'One quadratic relationship in physics is the relation between the speed of an object its centripetal acceleration, which is used to determine the force needed to keep an object moving in a circle.']
['What is another kind of relationship?', 'Another common relationship in physics is the inverse relationship, in which one variable decreases whenever the other variable increases.']
['What is an example of that?', 'An example in physics is Coulomb’s law.']
['What does that law say?', 'As the distance between two charged objects increases, the electrical force between the two charged objects decreases.']
['What is another inverse relationship?', 'Inverse proportionality, such the relation between x and y in the equation']
['What is a function with a special type of inverse relationship?', 'for some number k, is one particular kind of inverse relationship.']

['What type of inverse relationship is this?', 'A third commonly-seen relationship is the exponential relationship, in which a change in the independent variable produces a proportional change in the dependent variable.']
['What is the proportional change in the dependent variable?', 'As the value of the dependent variable gets larger, its rate of growth also increases.']
['What are some examples of exponential relationships?', 'For example, bacteria often reproduce at an exponential rate when grown under ideal conditions.']
['How is this example relevant?', 'As each generation passes, there are more and more bacteria to reproduce.']
['Why is this beneficial?', 'As a result, the growth rate of the bacterial population increases every generation.']
['What is a logarithmic scale?', 'Sometimes a variable can have a very large range of values.']
['Why might a variable have a very large range of values?', 'This presents a problem when you’re trying to figure out the best scale to use for your graph’s axes.']
['What are the options?', 'One option is to use a logarithmic (log) scale.']
['What is a logarithmic scale?', 'In a logarithmic scale, the value each mark labels is the previous mark’s value multiplied by some constant.']
['What does it multiply by?', 'For a log base 10 scale, each mark labels a value that is 10 times the value of the mark before it.']
['What are the numbers?', 'Therefore, a base 10 logarithmic scale would be numbered: 0, 10, 100, 1,000, etc.']

['What is the advantage of using logarithmic scales?', 'You can see how the logarithmic scale covers a much larger range of values than the corresponding linear scale, in which the marks would label the values 0, 10, 20, 30, and so on.']
['What is the first concept that you have a hard time explaining?', 'If you use a logarithmic scale on one axis of the graph and a linear scale on the other axis, you are using a semi-log plot.']
['What type of graphs do scientists use?', 'The Richter scale, which measures the strength of earthquakes, uses a semi-log plot.']

['How do you find the scale of an earthquake?', 'The degree of ground movement is plotted on a logarithmic scale against the assigned intensity level of the earthquake, which ranges linearly from 1-10 (Figure 1.29 (a)).']
['What type of plots do log-log charts make?', 'If a graph has both axes in a logarithmic scale, then it is referred to as a log-log plot.']
['What are some examples of log-log charts?', 'The relationship between the wavelength and frequency of electromagnetic radiation such as light is usually shown as a log-log plot (Figure 1.29 (b)).']
['What other types of log-log plots are used?', 'Log-log plots are also commonly used to describe exponential functions, such as radioactive decay.']
['What is definition of motion?', 'Our study of physics opens with kinematics—the study of motion without considering its causes.']
['What are causes of motion?', 'Objects are in motion everywhere you look.']
['What does motion mean?', 'Everything from a tennis game to a space-probe flyby of the planet Neptune involves motion.']
['What happens when your heart is moving?', 'When you are resting, your heart moves blood through your veins.']
['What are some other things that are moving?', 'Even in inanimate objects, atoms are always moving.']
['What is position?', 'The location of an object at any particular time is its position.']
['What else is important about the definition of position?', 'More precisely, you need to specify its position relative to a convenient reference frame.']
['Does the earth have a reference frame?', 'Earth is often used as a reference frame, and we often describe the position of an object as it relates to stationary objects in that reference frame.']

['What other objects are stationary in reference frame?', 'For example, a rocket launch would be described in terms of the position of the rocket with respect to Earth as a whole, while a professor’s position could be described in terms of where she is in relation to the nearby white board.']
['What is another example?', 'In other cases, we use reference frames that are not stationary but are in motion relative to Earth.']
['Do all reference frames have to be earth based?', 'To describe the position of a person in an airplane, for example, we use the airplane, not Earth, as the reference frame.']
['What is another example?', '(See Figure 2.2.)']

['What are the other two factors in determining position?', "Thus, you can only know how fast and in what direction an object's position is changing against a background of something else that is either not moving or moving with a known speed and direction."]
['What is a reference frame?', 'The reference frame is the coordinate system from which the positions of objects are described.']
['What are the four parts of a triangle?', 'Your classroom can be used as a reference frame.']
['What happens to the walls in your classroom?', 'In the classroom, the walls are not moving.']
['What happens to you as you walk?', 'Your motion as you walk to the door, can be measured against the stationary background of the classroom walls.']
['How can you tell if others are moving?', 'You can also tell if other things in the classroom are moving, such as your classmates entering the classroom or a book falling off a desk.']
['What direction do you think the book is moving?', 'You can also tell in what direction something is moving in the classroom.']
['What can you say about the teacher?', 'You might say, “The teacher is moving toward the door.”']
['What can you do to determine direction?', 'Your reference frame allows you to determine not only that something is moving but also the direction of motion.']
['What is motion?', 'You could also serve as a reference frame for others’ movement.']
['What does that mean?', 'If you remained seated as your classmates left the room, you would measure their movement away from your stationary location.']
['What else can you say about the reference frame?', 'If you and your classmates left the room together, then your perspective of their motion would be change.']
['What else can you tell me about this concept?', 'You, as the reference frame, would be moving in the same direction as your other moving classmates.']
