['What else can you tell me about the reference frame?', 'As you will learn in the Snap Lab, your description of motion can be quite different when viewed from different reference frames.']
['What can you tell me about this article?', 'As we study the motion of objects, we must first be able to describe the object’s position.']
["What's a good example?", 'Before your parent drives you to school, the car is sitting in your driveway.']
['What is the driveway?', 'Your driveway is the starting position for the car.']
['Why is that?', 'When you reach your high school, the car has changed position.']
['What is the new position?', 'Its new position is your school.']
['What is variables?', 'Physicists use variables to represent terms.']
['What is d?', 'We will use d to represent car’s position.']
['What is subscript?', 'We will use a subscript to differentiate between the initial position, d0, and the final position, df.']
['What else is important about variables?', 'In addition, vectors, which we will discuss later, will be in bold or will have an arrow above the variable.']
['What else can you tell me about variables?', 'Scalars will be italicized.']
['What can you tell me about Distance vs. Displacement?', "Now imagine driving from your house to a friend's house located several kilometers away."]
['How long does it take to drive?', 'The distance an object moves is the length of the path between its initial position and its final position.']
['What else do you tell me about Distance vs. Displacement?', "The distance you drive to your friend's house depends on your path."]
['Does the equation of a line have to be straight?', 'As shown in Figure 2.5, distance is different from the length of a straight line between two points.']
['Why is this?', "The distance you drive to your friend's house is probably longer than the straight line between the two houses."]
['Why is that?', 'We often want to be more precise when we talk about position.']
['Why would we describe something like displacement?', 'The description of an object’s motion often includes more than just the distance it moves.']
["What's an example?", 'For instance, if it is a five kilometer drive to school, the distance traveled is 5 kilometers.']
['How would you calculate the displacement?', 'After dropping you off at school and driving back home, your parent will have traveled a total distance of 10 kilometers.']
['Where will you end up at after the drive?', 'The car and your parent will end up in the same starting position in space.']
['What is displacement?', 'The net change in position of an object is its displacement, or  $$\\(\\text{Δ}\\mathbf{d}\\text{.}\\)$$']
['What does delta mean?', 'The Greek letter delta,  $$\\(\\text{Δ}\\)$$, means change in.']
['What is the relation between distance and displacement?', 'If you are describing only your drive to school, then the distance traveled and the displacement are the same—5 kilometers.']
['How do they differ in other cases?', 'When you are describing the entire round trip, distance and displacement are different.']
['What are other differences between distance and displacement?', 'When you describe distance, you only include the magnitude, the size or amount, of the distance traveled.']

['What else do you include when describing distance?', 'However, when you describe the displacement, you take into account both the magnitude of the change in position and the direction of movement.']

['What did you find most interesting about this?', 'In our previous example, the car travels a total of 10 kilometers, but it drives five of those kilometers forward toward school and five of those kilometers back in the opposite direction.']
['What is the result?', 'If we ascribe the forward direction a positive (+) and the opposite direction a negative (–), then the two quantities will cancel each other out when added together.']

['What are the differences between displacement and distance?', 'A quantity, such as distance, that has magnitude (i.e., how big or how much) but does not take into account direction is called a scalar.']
['What is displacement?', 'A quantity, such as displacement, that has both magnitude and direction is called a vector.']
['I have asked you the following questions: what are distance and displacement?', 'Hopefully you now understand the conceptual difference between distance and displacement.']
['Can you help me understand the meaning of these concepts?', 'Understanding concepts is half the battle in physics.']
['Is there another part of physics to learn?', 'The other half is math.']
['What is the math of physics?', 'A stumbling block to new physics students is trying to wade through the math of physics while also trying to understand the associated concepts.']
['Why is that?', 'This struggle may lead to misconceptions and answers that make no sense.']
['Can you explain this further?', 'Once the concept is mastered, the math is far less confusing.']
['Why is it important to understand displacement?', 'So let’s review and see if we can make sense of displacement in terms of numbers and equations.']
['How can displacement be calculated?', "You can calculate an object's displacement by subtracting its original position, d0, from its final position df."]
['What does this mean?', 'In math terms that means']
['How do we determine these quantities?', 'To assign numbers and/or direction to these quantities, we need to define an axis with a positive and a negative direction.']

['In Figure 2.6, the axis is in a straight line with home at zero', 'We also need to define an origin, or O. In Figure 2.6, the axis is in a straight line with home at zero and school in the positive direction.']
['What is the positive direction?', 'If we left home and drove the opposite way from school, motion would have been in the negative direction.']
['How is this defined?', 'We would have assigned it a negative value.']
['How are the two quantities related?', 'In the round-trip drive, df and d0 were both at zero kilometers.']
['What is the opposite?', 'In the one way trip to school, df was at 5 kilometers and d0 was at zero km.']
['How do we find out this distance?', 'So,  $$\\(\\Delta\\mathbf{d}\\)$$  was 5 kilometers.']
['What is Speed?', 'There is more to motion than distance and displacement.']
['What else is involved in motion?', 'Questions such as, “How long does a foot race take?” and “What was the runner’s speed?” cannot be answered without an understanding of other concepts.']
['What other concepts?', 'In this section we will look at time, speed, and velocity to expand our understanding of motion.']
['what is speed?', 'A description of how fast or slow an object moves is its speed.']
['what is it used for?', 'Speed is the rate at which an object changes its location.']
['what does speed mean?', 'Like distance, speed is a scalar because it has a magnitude but not a direction.']
['how does it change?', 'Because speed is a rate, it depends on the time interval of motion.']
['what is the time interval?', 'You can calculate the elapsed time or the change in time,  $$\\(\\Delta t\\)$$, of motion as the difference between the ending time and the beginning time']
['What do you mean by average?', "When you describe an object's speed, you often describe the average over a time period."]
['What is average speed?', 'Average speed, vavg, is the distance traveled divided by the time during which the motion occurs.']
['What are the important things I need to know about this?', 'Suppose, for example, a car travels 150 kilometers in 3.2 hours.']
['What does the car travel at?', 'Its average speed for the trip is']
['What is an example of this in practice?', "A car's speed would likely increase and decrease many times over a 3.2 hour trip."]
['What is important to know about the distance/time formula?', 'Its speed at a specific instant in time, however, is its instantaneous speed.']
["What does a car's speedometer mean?", "A car's speedometer describes its instantaneous speed."]
['What is velocity?', 'The vector version of speed is velocity.']
['What does it describe?', 'Velocity describes the speed and direction of an object.']
['What else does it describe?', 'As with speed, it is useful to describe either the average velocity over a time period or the velocity at a specific moment.']
['What is average velocity?', 'Average velocity is displacement divided by the time over which the displacement occurs.']
['What is a vector?', 'Velocity, like speed, has SI units of meters per second (m/s), but because it is a vector, you must also include a direction.']

['What else is interesting?', 'Furthermore, the variable v for velocity is bold because it is a vector, which is in contrast to the variable v for speed which is italicized because it is a scalar quantity.']
['What are the questions that you have for your teacher?', 'Suppose a passenger moved toward the back of a plane with an average velocity of –4 m/s.']
['How did the passenger get there?', 'We cannot tell from the average velocity whether the passenger stopped momentarily or backed up before he got to the back of the plane.']
['What is the next step?', 'To get more details, we must consider smaller segments of the trip over smaller time intervals such as those shown in Figure 2.9.']
['What is the next step?', 'If you consider infinitesimally small intervals, you can define instantaneous velocity, which is the velocity at a specific instant in time.']
['Are there any other factors that affect instantaneous velocity?', 'Instantaneous velocity and average velocity are the same if the velocity is constant.']
['Is there anything else that you have to do?', 'Earlier, you have read that distance traveled can be different than the magnitude of displacement.']
['How does this relate to the speed?', 'In the same way, speed can be different than the magnitude of velocity.']
['What are some examples?', 'For example, you drive to a store and return home in half an hour.']
['What is the distance between you and the store?', 'If your car’s odometer shows the total distance traveled was 6 km, then your average speed was 12 km/h.']
['How does this compare to your average velocity?', 'Your average velocity, however, was zero because your displacement for the round trip is zero.']
['Are there any other important things to know about the material?', 'A graph, like a picture, is worth a thousand words.']
['What else can you tell me about the graph?', 'Graphs not only contain numerical information, they also reveal relationships between physical quantities.']
['What are you investigating?', 'In this section, we will investigate kinematics by analyzing graphs of position over time.']
['What axes are perpendicular?', 'Graphs in this text have perpendicular axes, one horizontal and the other vertical.']

['What is the difference between horizontal and vertical?', 'When two physical quantities are plotted against each other, the horizontal axis is usually considered the independent variable, and the vertical axis is the dependent variable.']
['Are there any other important things to know?', 'In algebra, you would have referred to the horizontal axis as the x-axis and the vertical axis as the y-axis.']
['What else should I know?', 'As in Figure 2.10, a straight-line graph has the general form  $$\\(y = mx + b\\)$$ .']
['What is the meaning of slope and direction?', 'Here m is the slope, defined as the rise divided by the run (as seen in the figure) of the straight line.']
['What is the letter b?', 'The letter b is the y-intercept which is the point at which the line crosses the vertical, y-axis.']
['What are the values for x?', 'In terms of a physical situation in the real world, these quantities will take on a specific significance, as we will see below.']
['What is the figure showing the graph?', '(Figure 2.10.)']
['What does time mean in physics?', 'In physics, time is usually the independent variable.']
['what is an independent variable?', 'Other quantities, such as displacement, are said to depend upon it.']
['What is position?', 'A graph of position versus time, therefore, would have position on the vertical axis (dependent variable) and time on the horizontal axis (independent variable).']
['What is an example of this?', 'Let’s look back at our original example when studying distance and displacement.']
['What happened after the drive to school?', 'The drive to school was 5 km from home.']
['What time did it take you to drive there?', 'Let’s assume it took 10 minutes to make the drive and that your parent was driving at a constant velocity the whole time.']
['How did you get to school?', 'The position versus time graph for this section of the trip would look like that shown in Figure 2.11.']
['What does the question ask?', 'As we said before, d0 = 0 because we call home our O and start calculating from there.']
['What is the formula?', 'In Figure 2.11, the line starts at d = 0, as well.']
['What does b mean?', 'This is the b in our equation for a straight line.']
['What is X?', 'Our initial position in a position versus time graph is always the place where the graph crosses the x-axis at t = 0.']
['What are rise and run?', 'The rise is the change in position, (i.e., displacement) and the run is the change in time.']
['What is the formula?', 'This relationship can also be written']
['What does the relationship between distance and speed mean?', 'This relationship was how we defined average velocity.']
['What is the average velocity?', 'Therefore, the slope in a d versus t graph, is the average velocity.']
['What did you do next?', 'Let’s look at another example.']
['What did you find interesting in the example?', 'Figure 2.12 shows a graph of position versus time for a jet-powered car on a very flat dry lake bed in Nevada.']

['What was the question?', 'Using the relationship between dependent and independent variables, we see that the slope in the graph in Figure 2.12 is average velocity, vavg and the intercept is displacement at time zero—that is, d0.']
['What did you use the relationship between dependent and independent variables for?', 'Substituting these symbols into y = mx + b gives']

['What is a graph of position versus time?', 'Thus a graph of position versus time gives a general relationship among displacement, velocity, and time, as well as giving detailed numerical information about a specific situation.']
['What are the other relationships?', 'From the figure we can see that the car has a position of 400 m at t = 0 s, 650 m at t = 1.0 s, and so on.']
['What else can we learn about the car from the graph?', 'And we can learn about the object’s velocity, as well.']
['Why do you want to know how it works?', 'Let’s take another look at the jet-powered car.']
['Does the graph show anything else interesting?', 'The graph in Figure 2.13 shows its motion as it is getting up to speed after starting at rest.']

['Did you see that there are two displacements in the graph?', 'Time starts at zero for this motion (as if measured with a stopwatch), and the displacement and velocity are initially 200 m and 15 m/s, respectively.']
['What happens when the equation of motion is expressed as a graph?', 'The graph of position versus time in Figure 2.13 is a curve rather than a straight line.']
['What happens when you graph velocity?', 'The slope of the curve becomes steeper as time progresses, showing that the velocity is increasing over time.']
['Does this tell us something about the instantaneous velocity?', 'The slope at any point on a position-versus-time graph is the instantaneous velocity at that point.']
['How is this found?', 'It is found by drawing a straight line tangent to the curve at the point of interest and taking the slope of this straight line.']
["What's the example of this line?", 'Tangent lines are shown for two points in Figure 2.13.']
["What's the average velocity?", 'The average velocity is the net displacement divided by the time traveled.']
['what did we already study together?', 'Earlier, we examined graphs of position versus time.']
['what did we find out?', 'Now, we are going to build on that information as we look at graphs of velocity vs. time.']
['what is velocity?', 'Velocity is the rate of change of displacement.']
['what is acceleration?', 'Acceleration is the rate of change of velocity; we will discuss acceleration more in another chapter.']
['how do the three concepts relate?', 'These concepts are all very interrelated.']
['What is the topic of this lesson?', 'Let’s return to our drive to school, and look at a graph of position versus time as shown in Figure 2.15.']
['what was the assumption?', 'We assumed for our original calculation that your parent drove with a constant velocity to and from school.']
['what was the factual assumption?', 'We now know that the car could not have gone from rest to a constant velocity without speeding up.']
['what happened?', 'So the actual graph would be curved on either end, but let’s make the same approximation as we did then, anyway.']
['What did you learn about this graph?', 'Looking at this graph, and given what we learned, we can see that there are two distinct periods to the car’s motion—the way to school and the way back.']
['what is the average velocity of the car?', 'The average velocity for the drive to school is 0.5 km/minute.']
['how is the distance of the car?', 'We can see that the average velocity for the drive back is –0.5 km/minute.']
['how do you compare the two graphs?', 'If we plot the data showing velocity versus time, we get another graph:']
['What are we supposed to learn from that?', 'We can learn a few things.']
['What are the three things that we can learn from that?', 'First, we can derive a v versus t graph from a d versus t graph.']
['What else is important about the graph?', 'Second, if we have a straight-line position–time graph that is positively or negatively sloped, it will yield a horizontal velocity graph.']
['What is the third thing that you can learn from that graph?', 'There are a few other interesting things to note.']
['What are those other things that you could note?', 'Just as we could use a position vs. time graph to determine velocity, we can use a velocity vs. time graph to determine position.']
['What else can you tell me about velocity and position?', 'We know that v = d/t.']

['What else do you know about the equation?', 'If we use a little algebra to re-arrange the equation, we see that d = v $$\\(\\times\\)$$ t. In Figure 2.16, we have velocity on the y-axis and time along the x-axis.']
['What happened after the motion?', 'Let’s take just the first half of the motion.']
['What was the total distance in metres that we found?', 'We get 0.5 km/minute  $$\\(\\times\\)$$  10 minutes.']
['What were the units for minutes?', 'The units for minutes cancel each other, and we get 5 km, which is the displacement for the trip to school.']
['How long did it take to get to school?', 'If we calculate the same for the return trip, we get –5 km.']

['What did you do after you got to school?', 'If we add them together, we see that the net displacement for the whole trip is 0 km, which it should be because we started and ended at the same place.']
['What is the area under a velocity curve?', 'The area under a velocity curve represents the displacement.']
['Does the displacement tell us anything else about this?', 'The velocity curve also tells us whether the car is speeding up.']
['Is the car moving faster or slower?', 'In our earlier example, we stated that the velocity was constant.']
['Does the car need to speed up?', 'So, the car is not speeding up.']
["How else do you know that the car isn't speeding up?", 'Graphically, you can see that the slope of these two lines is 0.']
['Does the slope tell us something else?', 'This slope tells us that the car is not speeding up, or accelerating.']
['Does this answer your question?', 'We will do more with this information in a later chapter.']
['Do you have any other questions?', 'For now, just remember that the area under the graph and the slope are the two important parts of the graph.']

['What else does this have to do with the linear equation?', 'Just like we could define a linear equation for the motion in a position vs. time graph, we can also define one for a velocity vs. time graph.']
['What is the slope equal to?', 'As we said, the slope equals the acceleration, a.']
['What is the y-intercept equal to?', 'And in this graph, the y-intercept is v0.']
['Does this explain the formula for the line?', 'Thus,  $$\\(\\mathbf{v} = \\mathbf{v}_{0} + \\mathbf{a}t\\)$$ .']
['What are the basic terms?', 'Let’s look back at our jet-car example.']
['What happens to the position of the car as it accelerates?', 'At the beginning of the motion, as the car is speeding up, we saw that its position is a curve, as shown in Figure 2.17.']
['Is there anything else you would like to know about this exercise?', 'You do not have to do this, but you could, theoretically, take the instantaneous velocity at each point on this graph.']
['What would the result be?', 'If you did, you would get Figure 2.18, which is just a straight line with a positive slope.']
['What else is important about this content?', 'Again, if we take the slope of the velocity vs. time graph, we get the acceleration, the rate of change of the velocity.']
['How does the slope relate to displacement?', 'And, if we take the area under the slope, we get back to the displacement.']
['What are the different types of velocity vs. time graphs?', 'Most velocity vs. time graphs will be straight lines.']
['Are there other types of graphs?', 'When this is the case, our calculations are fairly simple.']
['What are the graphs about?', 'Most of the velocity vs. time graphs we will look at will be simple to interpret.']
['What graphs will we look at?', 'Occasionally, we will look at curved graphs of velocity vs. time.']
['What do they indicate?', 'More often, these curved graphs occur when something is speeding up, often from rest.']
['What was your next question?', 'Let’s look back at a more realistic velocity vs. time graph of the jet car’s motion that takes this speeding up stage into account.']
['What are the other terms in the section?', 'Throughout this chapter we will use the following terms: time, displacement, velocity, and acceleration.']
['Are there any other important terms?', 'Recall that each of these terms has a designated variable and SI unit of measurement as follows:']
["What are some of the terms we'll be using?", 'Time: t, measured in seconds (s) Displacement:']

['d, measured in meters (m)', 'Δd, measured in meters (m) Velocity: v, measured in meters per second (m/s) Acceleration: a, measured in meters per second per second (m/s2, also called meters per second squared)']
['What else should you know about the terms?', 'Also note the following:Δ means change inThe subscript 0 refers to an initial value; sometimes subscript i is instead used to refer to initial value.']
['The subscript  denotes exponential change', 'The subscript f refers to final valueA bar over a symbol, such as  a¯a¯a¯, means average']
['What is acceleration?', 'Acceleration is the change in velocity divided by a period of time during which the change occurs.']
['How is it defined?', 'The SI units of velocity are m/s and the SI units for time are s, so the SI units for acceleration are m/s2.']
['How is it calculated?', 'Average acceleration is given by']
['What is average acceleration?', 'Average acceleration is distinguished from instantaneous acceleration, which is acceleration at a specific instant in time.']
['Why is it not constant?', 'The magnitude of acceleration is often not constant over time.']
['Why is it not constant?', 'For example, runners in a race accelerate at a greater rate in the first second of a race than during the following seconds.']
['How do you calculate the average acceleration?', 'You do not need to know all the instantaneous accelerations at all times to calculate average acceleration.']

['Why not?', 'All you need to know is the change in velocity (i.e., the final velocity minus the initial velocity) and the change in time (i.e., the final time minus the initial time), as shown in the formula.']
['What is the result?', 'Note that the average acceleration can be positive, negative, or zero.']
['What is negative acceleration?', 'A negative acceleration is simply an acceleration in the negative direction.']
['What is acceleration?', 'Keep in mind that although acceleration points in the same direction as the change in velocity, it is not always in the direction of the velocity itself.']
['What is opposite to the direction of velocity?', 'When an object slows down, its acceleration is opposite to the direction of its velocity.']
['What is acceleration?', 'In everyday language, this is called deceleration; but in physics, it is acceleration—whose direction happens to be opposite that of the velocity.']
['What is a positive displacement?', 'For now, let us assume that motion to the right along the x-axis is positive and motion to the left is negative.']
['What are the examples of displacement?', 'Figure 3.2 shows a car with positive acceleration in (a) and negative acceleration in (b).']
['What is the definition of acceleration?', 'The arrows represent vectors showing both direction and magnitude of velocity and acceleration.']
['What are vector quantities?', 'Velocity and acceleration are both vector quantities.']
['What else are vector quantities?', 'Recall that vectors have both magnitude and direction.']
['What is acceleration?', 'An object traveling at a constant velocity—therefore having no acceleration—does accelerate if it changes direction.']
['What causes it to accelerate?', 'So, turning the steering wheel of a moving car makes the car accelerate because the velocity changes direction.']
['What is the equation for average acceleration?', 'Look back at the equation for average acceleration.']
['What are the values in the equation?', 'You can see that the calculation of average acceleration involves three values: change in time, (Δt); change in velocity, (Δv); and acceleration (a).']

['How is change in time stated in terms of the unit?', 'Change in time is often stated as a time interval, and change in velocity can often be calculated by subtracting the initial velocity from the final velocity.']
['How is average acceleration determined?', 'Average acceleration is then simply change in velocity divided by change in time.']
['What else is important to know before we begin?', 'Before you begin calculating, be sure that all distances and times have been converted to meters and seconds.']
['What are some examples of acceleration?', 'Look at these examples of acceleration of a subway train.']
["What are the concepts that we're studying?", 'We are studying concepts related to motion: time, displacement, velocity, and especially acceleration.']
["What is the dimension of motion we're looking at?", 'We are only concerned with motion in one dimension.']
['What are the kinematic equations?', 'The kinematic equations apply to conditions of constant acceleration and show how these concepts are related.']
['What is constant acceleration?', 'Constant acceleration is acceleration that does not change over time.']
['What is the first kinematic equation?', 'The first kinematic equation relates displacement d, average velocity  $$\\(\\overline{v}\\)$$, and time t.']
['What is the relation between average velocity and displacement?', 'This equation says that average velocity is displacement per unit time.']
['What unit of time are we using to express the displacement?', 'We will express velocity in meters per second.']
['How can you see this relationship?', 'If we graph displacement versus time, as in Figure 3.6, the slope will be the velocity.']
['Is time the independent variable?', 'Whenever a rate, such as velocity, is represented graphically, time is usually taken to be the independent variable and is plotted along the x axis.']
['Which formulas describe motion with constant acceleration?', 'Now we come to our main focus of this chapter; namely, the kinematic equations that describe motion with constant acceleration.']

['What is acceleration?', 'In the third kinematic equation, acceleration is the rate at which velocity increases, so velocity at any point equals initial velocity plus acceleration multiplied by time']
['what is this?', 'Note that this third kinematic equation does not have displacement in it.']
['does this have a purpose?', 'Therefore, if you do not know the displacement and are not trying to solve for a displacement, this equation might be a good one to use.']
['what other information can we get from this?', 'Note that, in reality, knowns and unknowns will vary.']
['what else can you tell me about the kinematic equation?', 'Sometimes you will want to rearrange a kinematic equation so that the knowns are the values on the axes and the unknown is the slope.']
['what else can you tell me about the kinematic equation?', 'Sometimes the intercept will not be at the origin (0,0).']
["why won't it be at the origin?", 'This will happen when v0 or d0 is not zero.']

['how do we know the displacement is not zero?', 'This will be the case when the object of interest is already in motion, or the motion begins at some point other than at the origin of the coordinate system.']
['What is a problem-solving skill?', 'Problem-solving skills are essential to success in a science and life in general.']
['How can one acquire these skills?', 'The ability to apply broad physical principles, which are often represented by equations, to specific situations is a very powerful form of knowledge.']
['What is the power of this knowledge?', 'It is much more powerful than memorizing a list of facts.']

['What can memorizing facts help you with?', 'Analytical skills and problem-solving abilities can be applied to new situations, whereas a list of facts cannot be made long enough to contain every possible circumstance.']

['Are there any other interesting aspects in this text?', 'Essential analytical skills will be developed by solving problems in this text and will be useful for understanding physics and science in general throughout your life.']

['What is one step in solving a problem?', 'While no single step-by-step method works for every problem, the following general procedures facilitate problem solving and make the answers more meaningful.']
['What are other steps?', 'A certain amount of creativity and insight are required as well.']
['What are the steps?', 'Examine the situation to determine which physical principles are involved.']
['What other steps can you think of that involve physical principles?', 'It is vital to draw a simple sketch at the outset.']
['How do you draw the sketch?', 'Decide which direction is positive and note that on your sketch.']
['What are the other steps you can think of?', 'Identify the knowns:']
['What are the knowns?', 'Make a list of what information is given or can be inferred from the problem statement.']
['What else can you do with the knowns?', 'Remember, not all given information will be in the form of a number with units in the problem.']
['What else can you do with the knowns?', 'If something starts from rest, we know the initial velocity is zero.']
['What else can you do with the knowns?', 'If something stops, we know the final velocity is zero.']
['What else can you do with the knowns?', 'Identify the unknowns: Decide exactly what needs to be determined in the problem.']
['What other steps can you think of?', 'Find an equation or set of equations that can help you solve the problem.']
['What steps can you do after finding the equation?', 'Your list of knowns and unknowns can help here.']
['What else can you do with this information?', 'For example, if time is not needed or not given, then the fifth kinematic equation, which does not include time, could be useful.']
['What else can you do with the knowns?', 'Insert the knowns along with their units into the appropriate equation and obtain numerical solutions complete with units.']
['How do you write the solution?', 'This step produces the numerical answer; it also provides a check on units that can help you find errors.']
['What can you do with the units?', 'If the units of the answer are incorrect, then an error has been made.']
['What else can you do with the equations?', 'Check the answer to see if it is reasonable:']
['How do you correct for the errors?', 'This final step is extremely important because the goal of physics is to accurately describe nature.']
['What does a reasonable answer look like?', 'To see if the answer is reasonable, check its magnitude, its sign, and its units.']
['What is the first step to problem solving?', 'Determine the knowns and unknowns.']
['What happens when you have identified the knowns and unknowns?', 'Find an equation that expresses the unknown in terms of the knowns.']
['What does finding an equation mean?', 'More than one unknown means more than one equation is needed.']
['What else happens at this point?', 'Solve the equation or equations.']
['What else happens?', 'Be sure units and significant figures are correct.']
['What else happens at this point?', 'Check whether the answer is reasonable.']
['Why is the acceleration not uniform?', 'In many cases, acceleration is not uniform because the force acting on the accelerating object is not constant over time.']
['What situation has constant acceleration?', 'A situation that gives constant acceleration is the acceleration of falling objects.']
['What speed does an object falling at the ground have?', 'When air resistance is not a factor, all objects near Earth’s surface fall with an acceleration of about 9.80 m/s2.']
['What does air resistance have to do with this?', 'Although this value decreases slightly with increasing altitude, it may be assumed to be essentially constant.']
['What is the value of m/s2?', 'The value of 9.80 m/s2 is labeled g and is referred to as acceleration due to gravity.']
['What does gravity mean?', 'Gravity is the force that causes nonsupported objects to accelerate downward—or, more precisely, toward the center of Earth.']
['What does weight have to do with gravity?', 'The magnitude of this force is called the weight of the object and is given by mg where m is the mass of the object (in kg).']
['What else is interesting in the study?', 'In places other than on Earth, such as the Moon or on other planets, g is not 9.80 m/s2, but takes on other values.']
['What did the negative sign mean?', 'When using g for the acceleration a in a kinematic equation, it is usually given a negative sign because the acceleration due to gravity is downward.']
['what is force?', 'Force is the cause of motion, and motion draws our attention.']
['why do we want to pay attention?', 'Motion itself can be beautiful, such as a dolphin jumping out of the water, the flight of a bird, or the orbit of a satellite.']
['what is motion?', 'The study of motion is called kinematics, but kinematics describes only the way objects move—their velocity and their acceleration.']
['what is dynamics?', 'Dynamics considers the forces that affect the motion of moving objects and systems.']
['who is the foundation of dynamics?', 'Newton’s laws of motion are the foundation of dynamics.']
['what does this mean?', 'These laws describe the way objects speed up, slow down, stay in motion, and interact with other objects.']
['what are the laws about?', 'They are also universal laws: they apply everywhere on Earth as well as in space.']
['What is a force?', 'A force pushes or pulls an object.']
['What is the object being moved by a force?', 'The object being moved by a force could be an inanimate object, a table, or an animate object, a person.']
['Who is pushing or pulling the object?', 'The pushing or pulling may be done by a person, or even the gravitational pull of Earth.']
['What are different magnitudes?', 'Forces have different magnitudes and directions; this means that some forces are stronger than others and can act in different directions.']
['What kind of force causes an object to move?', 'For example, a cannon exerts a strong force on the cannonball that is launched into the air.']
['What is an example of a weak force?', 'In contrast, a mosquito landing on your arm exerts only a small force on your arm.']
['What kind of forces are mentioned in this article?', 'When multiple forces act on an object, the forces combine.']
['What are the two terms used to describe the sum of the forces acting on an object?', 'Adding together all of the forces acting on an object gives the total force, or net force.']
['What are external forces?', 'An external force is a force that acts on an object within the system from outside the system.']
['Why is this different?', 'This type of force is different than an internal force, which acts between two objects that are both within the system.']
['Are the two considered the same?', 'The net external force combines these two definitions; it is the total combined external force.']
['What else is this article about?', 'We discuss further details about net force, external force, and net external force in the coming sections.']
['What type of force is defined in the first section?', 'In mathematical terms, two forces acting in opposite directions have opposite signs (positive or negative).']
['What does negative sign mean?', 'By convention, the negative sign is assigned to any movement to the left or downward.']

['What does opposite signs mean?', 'If two forces pushing in opposite directions are added together, the larger force will be somewhat canceled out by the smaller force pushing in the opposite direction.']

['How are the two forces related?', 'It is important to be consistent with your chosen coordinate system within a problem; for example, if negative values are assigned to the downward direction for velocity, then distance, force, and acceleration should also be designated as being negative in the downward direction.']
['What kind of forces do they describe?', 'For our first example of force, consider an object hanging from a rope.']
['What do we learn about the object from this example?', 'This example gives us the opportunity to introduce a useful tool known as a free-body diagram.']
['What does a free-body diagram represent?', 'A free-body diagram represents the object being acted upon—that is, the free body—as a single point.']
['What is the form of this force?', 'Only the forces acting on the body (that is, external forces) are shown and are represented by vectors (which are drawn as arrows).']
['Why are they the only forces shown?', 'These forces are the only ones shown because only external forces acting on the body affect its motion.']
['How are the internal forces canceled out?', 'We can ignore any internal forces within the body because they cancel each other out, as explained in the section on Newton’s third law of motion.']
['What can we learn about forces from a free-body diagram?', 'Free-body diagrams are very useful for analyzing forces acting on an object.']
['what are some other important things you should know about this section?', 'Figure 4.2 shows the force of tension in the rope acting in the upward direction, opposite the force of gravity.']

['what else is interesting about this section?', 'The forces are indicated in the free-body diagram by an arrow pointing up, representing tension, and another arrow pointing down, representing gravity.']
['what else can you tell me about this section?', 'In a free-body diagram, the lengths of the arrows show the relative magnitude (or strength) of the forces.']
['what else is important in this section?', 'Because forces are vectors, they add just like other vectors.']
['how do the arrows relate to each other?', 'Notice that the two arrows have equal lengths in Figure 4.2, which means that the forces of tension and weight are of equal magnitude.']

['how does the length of the arrows relate to the force?', 'Because these forces of equal magnitude act in opposite directions, they are perfectly balanced, so they add together to give a net force of zero.']
['What is the primary force that is responsible for moving the ball from left to right?', 'Not all forces are as noticeable as when you push or pull on an object.']

["What is a force that can't be seen?", 'Some forces act without physical contact, such as the pull of a magnet (in the case of magnetic force) or the gravitational pull of Earth (in the case of gravitational force).']

['What is the example of forces?', 'In the next three sections discussing Newton’s laws of motion, we will learn about three specific types of forces: friction, the normal force, and the gravitational force.']
['What are free-body diagrams?', 'To analyze situations involving forces, we will create free-body diagrams to organize the framework of the mathematics for each individual situation.']
['What was the first law of motion?', 'Newton’s first law considered bodies at rest or bodies in motion at a constant velocity.']

['What was the other state of motion?', 'The other state of motion to consider is when an object is moving with a changing velocity, which means a change in the speed and/or the direction of motion.']
['What was the second law?', 'This type of motion is addressed by Newton’s second law of motion, which states how force causes changes in motion.']

['What did this law describe?', 'Newton’s second law of motion is used to calculate what happens in situations involving forces and motion, and it shows the mathematical relationship between force, mass, and acceleration.']
['What else is important about this law?', 'Mathematically, the second law is most often written as']
['What is the relation that determines a formula?', 'where Fnet (or ∑F) is the net external force, m is the mass of the system, and a is the acceleration.']
['Is there anything else interesting?', 'Note that Fnet and ∑F are the same because the net external force is the sum of all the external forces acting on the system.']

['What is the first topic to be covered?', 'A change in motion is simply a change in velocity: the speed of an object can become slower or faster, the direction in which the object is moving can change, or both of these variables may change.']
['What does a change in velocity mean?', 'A change in velocity means, by definition, that an acceleration has occurred.']
['What causes acceleration?', 'Newton’s first law says that only a nonzero net external force can cause a change in motion, so a net external force must cause an acceleration.']
['What happens if we slow down?', 'Note that acceleration can refer to slowing down or to speeding up.']

['Is there any other way to know what it means?', 'Acceleration can also refer to a change in the direction of motion with no change in speed, because acceleration is the change in velocity divided by the time it takes for that change to occur, and velocity is defined by speed and direction.']
['What can you tell me about this?', 'From the equation $$\\(\\text{F}_{\\text{net}} = m\\text{a},\\)$$ we see that force is directly proportional to both mass and acceleration, which makes sense.']
['What makes that so?', 'To accelerate two objects from rest to the same velocity, you would expect more force to be required to accelerate the more massive object.']
['Is this true?', 'Likewise, for two objects of the same mass, applying a greater force to one would accelerate it to a greater velocity.']
['What was the next question?', 'Now, let’s rearrange Newton’s second law to solve for acceleration.']
['What does the symbol mean?', 'This proportionality mathematically states what we just said in words: acceleration is directly proportional to the net external force.']
['What can you tell me about the relationships?', 'When two variables are directly proportional to each other, then if one variable doubles, the other variable must double.']
['Is there anything else important that I should know about this?', 'Likewise, if one variable is reduced by half, the other variable must also be reduced by half.']
['What else can you tell me?', 'In general, when one variable is multiplied by a number, the other variable is also multiplied by the same number.']

['Does the proportionality make sense?', 'It seems reasonable that the acceleration of a system should be directly proportional to and in the same direction as the net external force acting on the system.']
['What else can you tell me about this?', 'An object experiences greater acceleration when acted on by a greater force.']
['What is inversely proportional?', 'Inversely proportional means that if one variable is multiplied by a number, the other variable must be divided by the same number.']
['Are there any other concepts that are inversely proportional?', 'Now, it also seems reasonable that acceleration should be inversely proportional to the mass of the system.']
['What does this mean?', 'In other words, the larger the mass (the inertia), the smaller the acceleration produced by a given force.']

['What is an example of this?', 'This relationship is illustrated in Figure 4.5, which shows that a given net external force applied to a basketball produces a much greater acceleration than when applied to a car.']
['What else do we need to know about the content?', 'Before putting Newton’s second law into action, it is important to consider units.']

['What units should we consider?', 'The equation $$\\(\\mathbf{F}_{\\text{net}} = m\\mathbf{a}\\)$$ is used to define the units of force in terms of the three basic units of mass, length, and time (recall that acceleration has units of length divided by time squared).']
['What is the SI unit?', 'The SI unit of force is called the newton (abbreviated N) and is the force needed to accelerate a 1-kg system at the rate of 1 m/s2.']
['What is the first law?', 'That is, because  $$\\(\\mathbf{F}_{\\text{net}} = m\\mathbf{a},\\)$$  we have']
['What is weight?', 'One of the most important applications of Newton’s second law is to calculate weight (also known as the gravitational force), which is usually represented mathematically as W.']
['How does he describe gravity?', 'When people talk about gravity, they don’t always realize that it is an acceleration.']
['What acceleration?', 'When an object is dropped, it accelerates toward the center of Earth.']
['What forces affect acceleration?', 'Newton’s second law states that the net external force acting on an object is responsible for the acceleration of the object.']
['What is the force?', 'If air resistance is negligible, the net external force on a falling object is only the gravitational force (i.e., the weight of the object).']
['What is a vector?', 'Weight can be represented by a vector because it has a direction.']
['What direction does weight have?', 'Down is defined as the direction in which gravity pulls, so weight is normally considered a downward force.']
['What is the equation?', 'By using Newton’s second law, we can figure out the equation for weight.']
['What are some other problems you can see in the study material?', 'Consider an object with mass m falling toward Earth.']

['What happens to the object as it falls?', 'It experiences only the force of gravity (i.e., the gravitational force or weight), which is represented by W. Newton’s second law states that  $$\\(\\mathbf{F}_{\\text{net}} = m\\mathbf{a}.\\)$$']
["Does Newton's second law apply in both cases?", 'Because the only force acting on the object is the gravitational force, we have  $$\\(\\mathbf{F}_{\\text{net}} = \\mathbf{W}.\\)$$']
['What does the acceleration of an object due to gravity equate to?', 'We know that the acceleration of an object due to gravity is g, so we have  $$\\(\\mathbf{a} = \\mathbf{g}.\\)$$']
['What does the acceleration of an object due to gravity equate to?', 'Substituting these two expressions into Newton’s second law gives']
['What is this equation for?', 'This is the equation for weight—the gravitational force on a mass m.']

["How does that relate to the Earth's gravity?", 'On Earth,  $$\\(\\mathbf{g} = 9.80\\text{~m/s}^{\\text{2}},\\)$$  so the weight (disregarding for now the direction of the weight) of a 1.0-kg object on Earth is']

['What direction does the earth travel?', 'Recall that although gravity acts downward, it can be assigned a positive or negative value, depending on what the positive direction is in your chosen coordinate system.']
['Does this affect weight?', 'Be sure to take this into consideration when solving problems with weight.']
['Does this change if you move in any other direction?', 'When the downward direction is taken to be negative, as is often the case, acceleration due to gravity becomes g = −9.8 m/s2.']
['What is the relationship between weight and force?', 'When the net external force on an object is its weight, we say that it is in freefall.']
['What is the relationship between weight and force when an object is in freefall?', 'In this case, the only force acting on the object is the force of gravity.']

['Is freefall the same everywhere?', 'On the surface of Earth, when objects fall downward toward Earth, they are never truly in freefall because there is always some upward force due to air resistance that acts on the object (and there is also the buoyancy force of air, which is similar to the buoyancy force in water that keeps boats afloat).']
['What else do you find interesting about the topic?', 'Gravity varies slightly over the surface of Earth, so the weight of an object depends very slightly on its location on Earth.']
['Do objects weigh less or more than they do in outer space?', 'Weight varies dramatically away from Earth’s surface.']
['How does it vary?', 'On the moon, for example, the acceleration due to gravity is only 1.67 m/s2.']
['Does it make a difference if you are on the moon?', 'Because weight depends on the force of gravity, a 1.0-kg mass weighs 9.8 N on Earth and only about 1.7 N on the moon.']
['What is a pound of force?', 'It is important to remember that weight and mass are very different, although they are closely related.']
['What is mass?', 'Mass is the quantity of matter (how much stuff) in an object and does not vary, but weight is the gravitational force on an object and is proportional to the force of gravity.']

['Why do they have this difference?', 'It is easy to confuse the two, because our experience is confined to Earth, and the weight of an object is essentially the same no matter where you are on Earth.']

['Do mass and weight share a common vocabulary?', 'Adding to the confusion, the terms mass and weight are often used interchangeably in everyday language; for example, our medical records often show our weight in kilograms, but never in the correct unit of newtons.']

['What is one way to explain a force?', 'If you have ever stubbed your toe, you have noticed that although your toe initiates the impact, the surface that you stub it on exerts a force back on your toe.']

['What does this demonstrate?', 'Although the first thought that crosses your mind is probably “ouch, that hurt” rather than “this is a great example of Newton’s third law,” both statements are true.']

['What does it mean?', 'This is exactly what happens whenever one object exerts a force on another—each object experiences a force that is the same strength as the force acting on the other object but that acts in the opposite direction.']
['How is it important?', 'Everyday experiences, such as stubbing a toe or throwing a ball, are all perfect examples of Newton’s third law in action.']

['Does it say anything else?', 'Newton’s third law of motion tells us that forces always occur in pairs, and one object cannot exert a force on another without experiencing the same strength force in return.']

['What happens in pairs?', 'We sometimes refer to these force pairs as action-reaction pairs, where the force exerted is the action, and the force experienced in return is the reaction (although which is which depends on your point of view).']
["What is the biggest thing we need to know about Newton's Third law?", 'Newton’s third law is useful for figuring out which forces are external to a system.']
['What is external forces?', 'Recall that identifying external forces is important when setting up a problem, because the external forces must be added together to find the net force.']
['Where can we see this law in action?', 'We can see Newton’s third law at work by looking at how people move about.']
['What can you tell me about the swimmer?', 'Consider a swimmer pushing off from the side of a pool, as illustrated in Figure 4.8.']
['What does she do after pushing off?', 'She pushes against the pool wall with her feet and accelerates in the direction opposite to her push.']
['How does the wall feel about this?', 'The wall has thus exerted on the swimmer a force of equal magnitude but in the direction opposite that of her push.']

["What is significant about the swimmer's force?", 'You might think that two forces of equal magnitude but that act in opposite directions would cancel, but they do not because they act on different systems.']
['What is our goal with this investigation?', 'In this case, there are two different systems that we could choose to investigate: the swimmer or the wall.']

['What is the swimmer?', 'If we choose the swimmer to be the system of interest, as in the figure, then  $$\\(\\text{F}_{\\text{wall~on~feet}}\\)$$  is an external force on the swimmer and affects her motion.']
['Is she moving in a straight line?', 'Because acceleration is in the same direction as the net external force, the swimmer moves in the direction of  $$\\(\\text{F}_{\\text{wall~on~feet}}.\\)$$']

['What is the wall?', 'Because the swimmer is our system (or object of interest) and not the wall, we do not need to consider the force $$\\(\\text{F}_{\\text{feet~on~wall}}\\)$$ because it originates from the swimmer rather than acting on the swimmer.']

['Do we have to consider it?', 'Therefore, $$\\(\\text{F}_{\\text{feet~on~wall}}\\)$$ does not directly affect the motion of the system and does not cancel $$\\(\\text{F}_{\\text{wall~on~feet}}.\\)$$']
['What is her movement?', 'Note that the swimmer pushes in the direction opposite to the direction in which she wants to move.']
["What other examples of Newton's third law can you give me?", 'Other examples of Newton’s third law are easy to find.']
['What can you give me one example of this law?', 'As a teacher paces in front of a whiteboard, he exerts a force backward on the floor.']
['What happens to the teacher in this case?', 'The floor exerts a reaction force in the forward direction on the teacher that causes him to accelerate forward.']
['What else is important about the example?', "Similarly, a car accelerates because the ground pushes forward on the car's wheels in reaction to the car's wheels pushing backward on the ground."]
['What are some other examples?', 'You can see evidence of the wheels pushing backward when tires spin on a gravel road and throw rocks backward.']
['What is one example of this law?', 'Another example is the force of a baseball as it makes contact with the bat.']
['What other examples are there?', 'Helicopters create lift by pushing air down, creating an upward reaction force.']
['How do birds fly?', 'Birds fly by exerting force on air in the direction opposite that in which they wish to fly.']
['Do they make a difference?', 'For example, the wings of a bird force air downward and backward in order to get lift and move forward.']
['What other examples do you see?', 'An octopus propels itself forward in the water by ejecting water backward through a funnel in its body, which is similar to how a jet ski is propelled.']
['How does it work?', 'In these examples, the octopus or jet ski push the water backward, and the water, in turn, pushes the octopus or jet ski forward.']
['How are forces classified?', 'Forces are classified and given names based on their source, how they are transmitted, or their effects.']
['What are some of the common types of forces?', 'In previous sections, we discussed the forces called push, weight, and friction.']
['What are some other types of forces?', 'In this section, applying Newton’s third law of motion will allow us to explore three more forces: the normal force, tension, and thrust.']

['What are some examples of two-dimensional and three-dimensional forces?', 'However, because we haven’t yet covered vectors in depth, we’ll only consider one-dimensional situations in this chapter.']
['What is a vector?', 'Another chapter will consider forces acting in two dimensions.']
["What's the gravitational force?", 'The gravitational force (or weight) acts on objects at all times and everywhere on Earth.']
["What's the normal force?", 'The answer is the normal force.']
['What is this force?', 'The normal force is the force that a surface applies to an object to support the weight of that object; it acts perpendicular to the surface upon which the object rests.']

['When an object is stationary?', 'If an object on a flat surface is not accelerating, the net external force is zero, and the normal force has the same magnitude as the weight of the system but acts in the opposite direction.']
['How is it written?', 'In equation form, we write that']
['Where does the word tension come from?', 'The word tension comes from the Latin word meaning to stretch.']
['What is tension?', 'Tension is the force along the length of a flexible connector, such as a string, rope, chain, or cable.']

['What are some other examples?', 'Regardless of the type of connector attached to the object of interest, one must remember that the connector can only pull (or exert tension) in the direction parallel to its length.']
['What does tension do to the object?', 'Tension is a pull that acts parallel to the connector, and that acts in opposite directions at the two ends of the connector.']

['What is opposite directions at the two ends?', 'This is possible because a flexible connector is simply a long series of action-reaction forces, except at the two ends where outside objects provide one member of the action-reaction forces.']
['What is the tension in the rope?', 'Tension in the rope must equal the weight of the supported mass, as we can prove by using Newton’s second law.']
['What is the weight of the mass?', 'If the 5.00 kg mass in the figure is stationary, then its acceleration is zero, so $$\\(\\mathbf{F}_{\\text{net}} = 0.\\)$$']
['What other forces act on the mass?', 'The only external forces acting on the mass are its weight W and the tension T supplied by the rope.']
['What is the net force?', 'Summing the external forces to find the net force, we obtain']
['What is the F and W signs?', 'where T and W are the magnitudes of the tension and weight, respectively, and their signs indicate direction, with up being positive.']
['What does it do?', 'By substituting mg for Fnet and rearranging the equation, the tension equals the weight of the supported mass, just as you would expect']
['What else is an example of Newton’s third law in action?', 'Another example of Newton’s third law in action is thrust.']
['What happens as the rocket moves forward?', 'Rockets move forward by expelling gas backward at a high velocity.']

['Why does the rocket expell gas backward?', 'This means that the rocket exerts a large force backward on the gas in the rocket combustion chamber, and the gas, in turn, exerts a large force forward on the rocket in response.']
['What is the reaction force?', 'This reaction force is called thrust.']
['What is a vector?', 'Recall that a vector is a quantity that has magnitude and direction.']
['What are some examples of vectors?', 'For example, displacement, velocity, acceleration, and force are all vectors.']
['What is the direction of a vector?', 'In one-dimensional or straight-line motion, the direction of a vector can be given simply by a plus or minus sign.']

['What are the terms for positive and negative?', 'Motion that is forward, to the right, or upward is usually considered to be positive (+); and motion that is backward, to the left, or downward is usually considered to be negative (−).']
['What do vectors describe?', 'In two dimensions, a vector describes motion in two perpendicular directions, such as vertical and horizontal.']
['What do the vectors refer to?', 'For vertical and horizontal motion, each vector is made up of vertical and horizontal components.']
['What does this mean?', 'In a one-dimensional problem, one of the components simply has a value of zero.']
['How are vectors applied?', 'For two-dimensional vectors, we work with vectors by using a frame of reference such as a coordinate system.']

['Does the method use any other representations?', 'Just as with one-dimensional vectors, we graphically represent vectors with an arrow having a length proportional to the vector’s magnitude and pointing in the direction that the vector points.']
['What else was interesting about the graph?', 'Figure 5.2 shows a graphical representation of a vector; the total displacement for a person walking in a city.']
['What else does the graph show?', 'The person first walks nine blocks east and then five blocks north.']
['What else was interesting about the graph?', 'Her total displacement does not match her path to her final destination.']
['What did you discover about the graph?', 'The displacement simply connects her starting point with her ending point using a straight line, which is the shortest distance.']
['What else can you tell me about the graph?', 'We use the notation that a boldface symbol, such as D, stands for a vector.']
['What is the notation?', 'Its magnitude is represented by the symbol in italics, D, and its direction is given by an angle represented by the symbol $$\\(\\theta.\\)$$']
['Was there anything else interesting that you found?', 'Note that her displacement would be the same if she had begun by first walking five blocks north and then walking nine blocks east.']
['what is the head-to-tail method?', 'The head-to-tail method is a graphical way to add vectors.']
['what is the difference between head and tail?', 'The tail of the vector is the starting point of the vector, and the head (or tip) of a vector is the pointed end of the arrow.']
['what is the head to tail method?', 'The following steps describe how to use the head-to-tail method for graphical vector addition.']
['What axis do we use to represent the vector?', 'Let the x-axis represent the east-west direction.']
["What does 'a' represent?", 'Using a ruler and protractor, draw an arrow to represent the first vector (nine blocks to the east), as shown in Figure 5.3(a).']
['What is 5.3?', 'Figure 5.3']
['What is 5.3?', 'The diagram shows a vector with a magnitude of nine units and a direction of 0°.']
['What axis do we use to represent the vector?', 'Let the y-axis represent the north-south direction.']
["What does 'b' represent?", 'Draw an arrow to represent the second vector (five blocks to the north).']
['What is 5.4?', 'Place the tail of the second vector at the head of the first vector, as shown in Figure 5.4(b).']
['What is 5.4?', 'Figure 5.4']
['What is 5.5?', 'A vertical vector is added.']
['What is 5.6?', 'If there are more than two vectors, continue to add the vectors head-to-tail as described in step 2.']
['What is 5.7?', 'In this example, we have only two vectors, so we have finished placing arrows tip to tail.']
['What is 5.6?', 'Draw an arrow from the tail of the first vector to the head of the last vector, as shown in Figure 5.5(c).']
['What is 5.5?', 'This is the resultant, or the sum, of the vectors.']
['What is 5.5?', 'Figure 5.5']
['What is 5.6?', 'The diagram shows the resultant vector, a ruler, and protractor.']
['What is 5.7?', 'To find the magnitude of the resultant, measure its length with a ruler.']
['What is 5.7?', 'When we deal with vectors analytically in the next section, the magnitude will be calculated by using the Pythagorean theorem.']
['What is 5.7?', 'To find the direction of the resultant, use a protractor to measure the angle it makes with the reference direction (in this case, the x-axis).']
['What is 5.7?', 'When we deal with vectors analytically in the next section, the direction will be calculated by using trigonometry to find the angle.']
['What is vector subtraction?', 'Vector subtraction is done in the same way as vector addition with one small change.']
["What's the change?", 'We add the first vector to the negative of the vector that needs to be subtracted.']

['Why do you need to add the first vector to the negative of the vector that needs to be', 'A negative vector has the same magnitude as the original vector, but points in the opposite direction (as shown in Figure 5.6).']
['What does a negative vector have?', 'Subtracting the vector B from the vector A, which is written as A − B, is the same as A + (−B).']
['What else is unique about vector subtraction?', 'Since it does not matter in what order vectors are added, A − B is also equal to (−B) + A.']
['What else is unique about vector subtraction?', 'This is true for scalars as well as vectors.']
['What does this mean?', 'For example, 5 – 2 = 5 + (−2) = (−2) + 5.']
['What is counterclockwise direction?', 'Global angles are calculated in the counterclockwise direction.']
['What is clockwise direction?', 'The clockwise direction is considered negative.']

['What is positive x-axis?', 'For example, an angle of $$\\(30^{\\circ}\\)$$ south of west is the same as the global angle $$\\(210^{\\circ},\\)$$ which can also be expressed as $$\\(-150^{\\circ}\\)$$ from the positive x-axis.']

['What is vector addition?', 'Now that we have the skills to work with vectors in two dimensions, we can apply vector addition to graphically determine the resultant vector, which represents the total force.']
['What does it represent?', 'Consider an example of force involving two ice skaters pushing a third as seen in Figure 5.7.']

['What did you find most interesting about the text?', 'In problems where variables such as force are already known, the forces can be represented by making the length of the vectors proportional to the magnitudes of the forces.']
['What steps do you need to take to do this?', 'For this, you need to create a scale.']
['What does the scale look like?', 'For example, each centimeter of vector length could represent 50 N worth of force.']
['What else did you learn?', 'Once you have the initial vectors drawn to scale, you can then use the head-to-tail method to draw the resultant vector.']
['What else did you learn?', 'The length of the resultant can then be measured and converted back to the original units using the scale you created.']

["What are some of the examples we're studying?", 'You can tell by looking at the vectors in the free-body diagram in Figure 5.7 that the two skaters are pushing on the third skater with equal-magnitude forces, since the length of their force vectors are the same.']
['Are they both moving in the same direction?', 'Note, however, that the forces are not equal because they act in different directions.']

['How are the forces equal to each other?', 'If, for example, each force had a magnitude of 400 N, then we would find the magnitude of the total external force acting on the third skater by finding the magnitude of the resultant vector.']
['What other information do we need to know about this problem?', 'Since the forces act at a right angle to one another, we can use the Pythagorean theorem.']
['What does the Pythagorean theorem tell us?', 'For a triangle with sides a, b, and c, the Pythagorean theorem tells us that']

['What can you tell me about this example?', 'Note that, if the vectors were not at a right angle to each other  $$\\((90^{\\circ}\\)$$ to one another), we would not be able to use the Pythagorean theorem to find the magnitude of the resultant vector.']

['What other things can you tell me about this example?', 'Another scenario where adding two-dimensional vectors is necessary is for velocity, where the direction may not be purely east-west or north-south, but some combination of these two directions.']
['How do you go about solving this type of problem?', 'In the next section, we cover how to solve this type of problem analytically.']
['What can you tell me about this section?', 'For now let’s consider the problem graphically.']

['What type of mathematics is used for the analytical method?', 'For the analytical method of vector addition and subtraction, we use some simple geometry and trigonometry, instead of using a ruler and protractor as we did for graphical methods.']
['Is the graphical method still needed?', 'However, the graphical method will still come in handy to visualize the problem by drawing vectors using the head-to-tail method.']
['Why does the analytical method have more accuracy?', 'The analytical method is more accurate than the graphical method, which is limited by the precision of the drawing.']
['Why did you include the definitions?', 'For a refresher on the definitions of the sine, cosine, and tangent of an angle, see Figure 5.17.']

['Can you tell me how to determine the angle between any two vectors?', 'Since, by definition,  $$\\(\\text{cos}\\theta = x/h\\)$$, we can find the length x if we know h and  $$\\(\\theta\\)$$  by using  $$\\(x = h\\text{cos}\\theta\\)$$ .']
['What else can you tell me about how to determine the angle between the vectors?', 'Similarly, we can find the length of y by using  $$\\(y = h\\text{sin}\\theta\\)$$ .']
['How do the trigonometric relationships relate to adding vectors?', 'These trigonometric relationships are useful for adding vectors.']
['What is one thing you can tell me about this material?', 'When a vector acts in more than one dimension, it is useful to break it down into its x and y components.']
['How are the two components related?', 'For a two-dimensional vector, a component is a piece of a vector that points in either the x- or y-direction.']
['How can you describe a vector in terms of its components?', 'Every 2-d vector can be expressed as a sum of its x and y components.']

['What are the basic concepts of vectors?', 'For example, given a vector like $$\\(\\mathbf{A}\\)$$ in Figure 5.18, we may want to find what two perpendicular vectors, $$\\(\\mathbf{A}_{x}\\)$$ and $$\\(\\mathbf{A}_{y}\\)$$, add to produce it.']
['What does that mean?', 'In this example, $$\\(\\mathbf{A}_{x}\\)$$ and $$\\(\\mathbf{A}_{y}\\)$$ form a right triangle, meaning that the angle between them is 90 degrees.']
['Did they help explain any of the material?', 'This is a common situation in physics and happens to be the least complicated situation trigonometrically.']
["What's a component of vector?", '$$\\(\\mathbf{A}_{x}\\)$$ and $$\\(\\mathbf{A}_{y}\\)$$ are defined to be the components of $$\\(\\mathbf{A}\\)$$ along the x- and y-axes.']
['Why do you call it a component?', 'The three vectors, $$\\(\\mathbf{A}\\)$$, $$\\(\\mathbf{A}_{x}\\)$$, and $$\\(\\mathbf{A}_{y}\\)$$, form a right triangle.']

['What is the relationship among the three sides of a right-angled triangle?', 'If the vector $$\\(\\mathbf{A}\\)$$ is known, then its magnitude $$\\(A\\)$$ (its length) and its angle $$\\(\\theta\\)$$ (its direction) are known.']

['Does this mean that the relationship between magnitude and direction changes?', 'An example of this is the case below, where the vectors  $$\\(\\mathbf{A}\\)$$  and  $$\\(\\mathbf{B}\\)$$  are added to produce the resultant  $$\\(\\mathbf{R}\\text{,}\\)$$  as illustrated in Figure 5.22.']
['', 'If $$\\(\\mathbf{A}\\)$$ and $$\\(\\mathbf{B}\\)$$ represent two legs of a walk (two displacements), then $$\\(\\mathbf{R}\\)$$ is the total displacement.']
['What happens as the person walks?', 'The person taking the walk ends up at the tip of $$\\(\\mathbf{R}\\)$$ .']
['What else is important about the material?', 'There are many ways to arrive at the same point.']
['Why is this?', 'The person could have walked straight ahead first in the x-direction and then in the y-direction.']
['Where are the paths that reach the same point?', 'Those paths are the x- and y-components of the resultant, $$\\(\\mathbf{R}_{x}\\)$$ and $$\\(\\mathbf{R}_{y}.\\)$$']

['What else is unique about this part of the material?', 'If we know $$\\(\\mathbf{R}_{x}\\)$$ and $$\\(\\mathbf{R}_{y}\\)$$, we can find $$\\(R\\)$$ and $$\\(\\theta\\)$$ using the equations $$\\(R = \\sqrt{R_{\\text{x}}{}^{2} + R_{\\text{y}}{}^{2}}\\)$$ and $$\\(\\theta = tan^{–1}(R_{y}/R_{x})\\)$$ .']

['Do you explain what these components are?', 'In Figure 5.23, these components are $$\\(A_{x}\\)$$, $$\\(A_{y}\\)$$, $$\\(B_{x}\\)$$, and $$\\(B_{y}.\\)$$ Vector $$\\(\\mathbf{A}\\)$$ makes an angle of $$\\(\\theta_{A}\\)$$ with the x-axis, and vector $$\\(\\mathbf{B}\\)$$ makes and angle of $$\\(\\theta_{B}\\)$$ with its own x-axis (which is slightly above the x-axis used by vector A).']

['What is the magnitude of the resultant?', 'To get the magnitude of the resultant R, use the Pythagorean theorem.']

['Why does it use the Pythagorean theorem?', 'To get the direction of the resultant          $$\\[\\theta = \\tan^{- 1}(R_{y}/R_{x})\\text{.}\\]$$']
['What is projectile motion?', 'Projectile motion is the motion of an object thrown (projected) into the air.']
['What force is involved?', 'After the initial force that launches the object, it only experiences the force of gravity.']
['What is the object called?', 'The object is called a projectile, and its path is called its trajectory.']
['What else is involved?', 'As an object travels through the air, it encounters a frictional force that slows its motion called air resistance.']
['Is air resistance something that has any effect?', 'Air resistance does significantly alter trajectory motion, but due to the difficulty in calculation, it is ignored in introductory physics.']

['What are some interesting aspects of this study material?', 'The most important concept in projectile motion is that horizontal and vertical motions are independent, meaning that they don’t influence one another.']

['What else can you tell me about this property of projectile motion?', 'Figure 5.27 compares a cannonball in free fall (in blue) to a cannonball launched horizontally in projectile motion (in red).']
['What else can you tell me about the figure?', 'You can see that the cannonball in free fall falls at the same rate as the cannonball in projectile motion.']

['What is the significance of this information?', 'Keep in mind that if the cannon launched the ball with any vertical component to the velocity, the vertical displacements would not line up perfectly.']
['What do you think is the main point of this section?', 'Since vertical and horizontal motions are independent, we can analyze them separately, along perpendicular axes.']
['How does this effect the results?', 'To do this, we separate projectile motion into the two components of its motion, one along the horizontal axis and the other along the vertical.']
['What are the three sides of a right triangle?', 'We’ll call the horizontal axis the x-axis and the vertical axis the y-axis.']
['What else do we call these axes?', 'For notation, d is the total displacement, and x and y are its components along the horizontal and vertical axes.']
['What are the magnitudes?', 'The magnitudes of these vectors are x and y, as illustrated in Figure 5.28.']
['What are the three parameters of projectile motion?', 'As usual, we use velocity, acceleration, and displacement to describe motion.']
['How do we find velocity?', 'We must also find the components of these variables along the x- and y-axes.']
['How do we find acceleration?', 'The components of acceleration are then very simple ay = –g = –9.80 m/s2.']
['What is positive displacement?', 'Note that this definition defines the upwards direction as positive.']
['What does ax =?', 'Because gravity is vertical, ax = 0.']
['How are the acceleration and displacement measured?', 'Both accelerations are constant, so we can use the kinematic equations.']
['What are the kinematic equations?', 'For review, the kinematic equations from a previous chapter are summarized in Table 5.1.']
['Use the tangent function to convert the velocity to the acceleration vector.', 'Separate the motion into horizontal and vertical components along the x- and y-axes.']

['Separate the speed of the object into its radians of motion along the x-', 'These axes are perpendicular, so  $$\\(A_{x} = A\\text{cos}\\theta\\)$$  and  $$\\(A_{y} = A\\text{sin}\\theta\\)$$ are used.']
['What is the magnitude of displacement along these axes?', 'The magnitudes of the displacement $$\\(\\mathbf{\\text{s}}\\)$$ along x- and y-axes are called $$\\(x\\)$$ and $$\\(y.\\)$$']

['What is the magnitude of velocity along these axes?', 'The magnitudes of the components of the velocity $$\\(\\mathbf{\\text{v}}\\)$$ are $$\\(v_{x} = v\\cos\\theta\\)$$ and $$\\(v_{y} = v\\sin\\theta\\)$$, where $$\\(v\\)$$ is the magnitude of the velocity and $$\\(\\theta\\)$$ is its direction.']
['What is the magnitude of acceleration along these axes?', 'Initial values are denoted with a subscript 0.']
['What happens after these radians are substracted?', 'Treat the motion as two independent one-dimensional motions, one horizontal and the other vertical.']

['()', 'The kinematic equations for horizontal and vertical motion take the following forms        $$\\[\\begin{array}{l}\n{\\text{Horizontal~Motion}(\\mathbf{a}_{x} = 0)} \\\\\n{x = x_{0} + v_{x}t} \\\\\n{v_{x} = v_{0x} = \\mathbf{\\text{v}}_{\\text{x}} = \\text{velocity~~is~a~constant.}} \\\\\n\\end{array}\\]$$        Vertical motion (assuming positive is up $$\\(\\mathbf{a}_{y} = - \\mathbf{g} = - 9.80\\text{~m/s}^{2}\\)$$ )        $$\\[\\begin{array}{rcl}\ny & = & {y_{0} + \\frac{1}{2}(v_{0y} + v_{y})t} \\\\\nv_{y} & = & {v_{0y} - \\mathbf{g}t} \\\\\ny & = & {y_{0} + v_{0y}t - \\frac{1}{2}\\mathbf{g}t^{2}} \\\\\nv_{y}^{2} & = & {v_{0y}^{2} - 2g(y - y_{0})} \\\\\n\\end{array}\\]$$']
['What happens after the system has been locked?', 'Solve for the unknowns in the two separate motions (one horizontal and one vertical).']
['What is the value of t?', 'Note that the only common variable between the motions is time $$\\(t\\)$$ .']
['What is the solution?', 'The problem solving procedures here are the same as for one-dimensional kinematics.']
['Is the final solution the same?', 'Recombine the two motions to find the total displacement $$\\(\\mathbf{\\text{s}}\\)$$ and velocity $$\\(\\mathbf{\\text{v}}\\)$$ .']

['What is the method?', 'We can use the analytical method of vector addition, which uses $$\\(A = \\sqrt{A_{x}{}^{2} + A_{y}{}^{2}}\\)$$ and $$\\(\\theta = \\tan^{- 1}(A_{y}/A_{x})\\)$$ to find the magnitude and direction of the total displacement and velocity.']

['', '$$\\[\\begin{array}{l}\n\\text{Displacement} \\\\\n{\\mathbf{d} = \\sqrt{x^{2} + y^{2}}} \\\\\n{\\theta = \\tan^{- 1}(y/x)} \\\\\n\\text{Velocity} \\\\\n{\\mathbf{v} = \\sqrt{\\mathbf{v}_{x}^{2} + \\mathbf{v}_{y}^{2}}} \\\\\n{\\theta_{v} = \\tan^{- 1}(\\mathbf{v}_{y}/\\mathbf{v}_{x})} \\\\\n\\end{array}\\]$$ $$\\(\\theta\\)$$ is the direction of the displacement $$\\(\\mathbf{\\text{d}}\\)$$, and $$\\(\\theta_{\\text{v}}\\)$$ is the direction of the velocity $$\\(\\mathbf{\\text{v}}\\)$$ .']
