['What is friction?', 'Recall from the previous chapter that friction is a force that opposes motion, and is around us all the time.']
['What does friction cause?', 'Friction allows us to move, which you have discovered if you have ever tried to walk on ice.']
['What type of friction is this?', 'There are different types of friction—kinetic and static.']
['What is kinetic friction?', 'Kinetic friction acts on an object in motion, while static friction acts on an object or system at rest.']
['How is static friction different?', 'The maximum static friction is usually greater than the kinetic friction between the objects.']
['What is static friction?', 'Imagine, for example, trying to slide a heavy crate across a concrete floor.']
['What happens?', 'You may push harder and harder on the crate and not move it at all.']
['What is it doing?', 'This means that the static friction responds to what you do—it increases to be equal to and in the opposite direction of your push.']
['Is there anything you can do about it?', 'But if you finally push hard enough, the crate seems to slip suddenly and starts to move.']

['Is there anything else important to note about static friction?', 'Once in motion, it is easier to keep it in motion than it was to get it started because the kinetic friction force is less than the static friction force.']

['What else do you need to know about static friction?', 'If you were to add mass to the crate, (for example, by placing a box on top of it) you would need to push even harder to get it started and also to keep it moving.']
['What do you need to know about the concrete?', 'If, on the other hand, you oiled the concrete you would find it easier to get the crate started and keep it going.']

["What's the most important concept in our study material?", 'We discussed previously that when an object rests on a horizontal surface, there is a normal force supporting it equal in magnitude to its weight.']

['What does the text say about the normal force?', 'Up until now, we dealt only with normal force in one dimension, with gravity and normal force acting perpendicular to the surface in opposing directions (gravity downward, and normal force upward).']

['What are some of the most important parts of this document?', 'When an object rests on an incline that makes an angle $$\\(\\theta\\)$$ with the horizontal, the force of gravity acting on the object is divided into two components:']

['What happens to the angular momentum of an object as it changes from vertical to horizontal?', 'The perpendicular force of weight, $$\\(\\mathbf{w}_{\\bot}\\)$$, is typically equal in magnitude and opposite in direction to the normal force, $$\\(\\mathbf{N}.\\)$$']
['What happens after the object starts to accelerate?', 'The force acting parallel to the plane, $$\\(\\mathbf{w}_{||}\\)$$, causes the object to accelerate down the incline.']
['What happens after the object has accelerated down the incline?', 'The force of friction, $$\\(\\mathbf{f}\\)$$, opposes the motion of the object, so it acts upward along the plane.']
['What else is of note in this document?', 'It is important to be careful when resolving the weight of the object into components.']
['Why is that?', 'If the angle of the incline is at an angle $$\\(\\theta\\)$$ to the horizontal, then the magnitudes of the weight components are']

['What are the angles?', 'Knowing this property, you can use trigonometry to determine the magnitude of the weight components']

['Do you have the forces acting on the object?', 'Write Newton’s second law in the horizontal and vertical directions and add the forces acting on the object.']
['How does the equation of motion show the acceleration of the object?', 'If the object does not accelerate in a particular direction (for example, the x -direction) then Fnet x = 0.']
['Is the incline of the plane equal to 0?', 'If the object does accelerate in that direction, Fnet x = ma.']
['Do you know the value of m?', 'Check your answer.']

['What happens?', 'If a bulldozer pushes the car into the wall, the car will not move but it will noticeably change shape.']
["What was the car's shape before it was pushed into the wall?", 'A change in shape due to the application of a force is a deformation.']
['What kind of force?', 'Even very small forces are known to cause some deformation.']
['How does the car react to the small force?', 'For small deformations, two important things can happen.']
['What else does the article say about this?', 'First, unlike the car and bulldozer example, the object returns to its original shape when the force is removed.']
['What else do we know about this?', 'Second, the size of the deformation is proportional to the force.']
['What is this known as?', 'This second property is known as Hooke’s law.']
["What is the equation of Hooke's law?", 'In equation form, Hooke’s law is']

['what is it about?', 'where x is the amount of deformation (the change in length, for example) produced by the restoring force F, and k is a constant that depends on the shape and composition of the object.']

['what is the restoring force?', 'The restoring force is the force that brings the object back to its equilibrium position; the minus sign is there because the restoring force acts in the direction opposite to the displacement.']
['what else does it mean?', 'Note that the restoring force is proportional to the deformation x.']
['what else is it known for?', 'The deformation can also be thought of as a displacement from equilibrium.']
['what is displacement?', 'It is a change in position due to a force.']
['what is the absence of force?', 'In the absence of force, the object would rest at its equilibrium position.']
['what else is related to the force constant k?', 'The force constant k is related to the stiffness of a system.']
['what is stiffness?', 'The larger the force constant, the stiffer the system.']
['what is more important to know about stiffness?', 'A stiffer system is more difficult to deform and requires a greater restoring force.']
['how is k measured?', 'The units of k are newtons per meter (N/m).']
['what else was covered in this article?', 'One of the most common uses of Hooke’s law is solving problems involving springs and pendulums, which we will cover at the end of this section.']
['What do all of these things have in common?', 'They all oscillate.']
['What does oscillate mean?', 'That is, they move back and forth between two points, like the ruler illustrated in Figure 5.37.']
['What force is involved?', 'All oscillations involve force.']
['What else can you tell me about the force?', 'For example, you push a child in a swing to get the motion started.']
['What does this mean?', 'Newton’s first law implies that an object oscillating back and forth is experiencing forces.']
['How do we know?', 'Without force, the object would move in a straight line at a constant speed rather than oscillate.']
['What kind of examples do you have for this?', 'Consider, for example, plucking a plastic ruler to the left as shown in Figure 5.38.']
['What kind of force?', 'The deformation of the ruler creates a force in the opposite direction, known as a restoring force.']
["What happens to the ruler after it's released?", 'Once released, the restoring force causes the ruler to move back toward its stable equilibrium position, where the net force on it is zero.']
['What happens next?', 'However, by the time the ruler gets there, it gains momentum and continues to move to the right, producing the opposite deformation.']
['What happens after that?', 'It is then forced to the left, back through equilibrium, and the process is repeated until it gradually loses all of its energy.']
['What else did you say?', 'The simplest oscillations occur when the restoring force is directly proportional to displacement.']
['How do you know this?', 'Recall that Hooke’s law describes this situation with the equation F = −kx.']
['What else did you say?', 'Therefore, Hooke’s law describes and applies to the simplest case of oscillation, known as simple harmonic motion.']
['What is a simple example?', 'When you pluck a guitar string, the resulting sound has a steady tone and lasts a long time.']
['What happens to the string while it vibrates?', 'Each vibration of the string takes the same time as the previous one.']

['What is a Periodic Motion?', 'Periodic motion is a motion that repeats itself at regular time intervals, such as with an object bobbing up and down on a spring or a pendulum swinging back and forth.']
['What is the period?', 'The time to complete one oscillation (a complete cycle of motion) remains constant and is called the period T.']
['What is the units of time?', 'Its units are usually seconds.']
['What is the significance of frequency?', 'Frequency f is the number of oscillations per unit time.']
['What is the SI unit for frequency?', 'The SI unit for frequency is the hertz (Hz), defined as the number of oscillations per second.']
['What is the relationship between frequency and period?', 'The relationship between frequency and period is']
['Why is this important?', 'As you can see from the equation, frequency and period are different ways of expressing the same concept.']
['What do these terms mean?', 'For example, if you get a paycheck twice a month, you could say that the frequency of payment is two per month, or that the period between checks is half a month.']

['What is a definition of tangent function?', 'If there is no friction to slow it down, then an object in simple motion will oscillate forever with equal displacement on either side of the equilibrium position.']
['What is the equilibrium position?', 'The equilibrium position is where the object would naturally rest in the absence of force.']
['What is the maximum displacement from equilibrium?', 'The maximum displacement from equilibrium is called the amplitude X.']
['Is displacement and amplitude different?', 'The units for amplitude and displacement are the same, but depend on the type of oscillation.']
['What type of oscillation?', 'For the object on the spring, shown in Figure 5.39, the units of amplitude and displacement are meters.']
['What is the most important information in this paragraph?', 'The mass m and the force constant k are the only factors that affect the period and frequency of simple harmonic motion.']
['How is the period determined?', 'The period of a simple harmonic oscillator is given by']
['What is the first step that you need to take?', 'Before solving problems with springs and pendulums, it is important to first get an understanding of how a pendulum works.']
['What is an example?', 'Figure 5.40 provides a useful illustration of a simple pendulum.']
['What is an example of a pendulum?', 'Everyday examples of pendulums include old-fashioned clocks, a child’s swing, or the sinker on a fishing line.']

['What is the force acting on it?', 'For small displacements of less than 15 degrees, a pendulum experiences simple harmonic oscillation, meaning that its restoring force is directly proportional to its displacement.']
['What is a simple pendulum?', 'A pendulum in simple harmonic motion is called a simple pendulum.']
['How does it move?', 'A pendulum has an object with a small mass, also known as the pendulum bob, which hangs from a light wire or string.']
['What is the equilibrium position?', 'The equilibrium position for a pendulum is where the angle $$\\(\\theta\\)$$ is zero (that is, when the pendulum is hanging straight down).']
['Why is the equilibrium position important?', 'It makes sense that without any force applied, this is where the pendulum bob would rest.']
['What displacement of the pendulum bob is mentioned in the section?', 'The displacement of the pendulum bob is the arc length s.']
['What are the two components of the weight mg?', 'The weight mg has components mg cos $$\\(\\theta\\)$$ along the string and mg sin $$\\(\\theta\\)$$  tangent to the arc.']
['What happens to the string tension?', 'Tension in the string exactly cancels the component mg cos $$\\(\\theta\\)$$ parallel to the string.']
['What is left from the weight?', 'This leaves a net restoring force back toward the equilibrium position that runs tangent to the arc and equals −mg sin $$\\(\\theta\\)$$ .']
['What is the relationship between the period of a simple pendulum and its length?', 'The only things that affect the period of a simple pendulum are its length and the acceleration due to gravity.']
['What other factors affect the period of a simple pendulum?', 'The period is completely independent of other factors, such as mass or amplitude.']
['Is there anything else important to know?', 'However, note that T does depend on g.']
['What does g represent?', 'This means that if we know the length of a pendulum, we can actually use it to measure gravity!']
['What will this lead to?', 'This will come in useful in Measuring Acceleration due to Gravity: The Period of a Pendulum.']
['What is rotation?', 'Rotational motion is the circular motion of an object about an axis of rotation.']
['What else are we talking about?', 'We will discuss specifically circular motion and spin.']
['What is circular motion?', 'Circular motion is when an object moves in a circular path.']

['What other examples of circular motion are there?', 'Examples of circular motion include a race car speeding around a circular curve, a toy attached to a string swinging in a circle around your head, or the circular loop-the-loop on a roller coaster.']

['What is spin?', 'Spin is rotation about an axis that goes through the center of mass of the object, such as Earth rotating on its axis, a wheel turning on its axle, the spin of a tornado on its path of destruction, or a figure skater spinning during a performance at the Olympics.']

['Do the two motions interfere with each other?', 'Sometimes, objects will be spinning while in circular motion, like the Earth spinning on its axis while revolving around the Sun, but we will focus on these two motions separately.']

['What is rotational motion?', 'When solving problems involving rotational motion, we use variables that are similar to linear variables (distance, velocity, acceleration, and force) but take into account the curvature or rotation of the motion.']

['What does angle of rotation mean?', 'Here, we define the angle of rotation, which is the angular equivalence of distance; and angular velocity, which is the angular equivalence of linear velocity.']
['What is an arc length?', 'The arc length,  , is the distance traveled along a circular path.']
['What is the radius of curvature?', 'The radius of curvature, r, is the radius of the circular path.']
['How are these concepts shown in this section?', 'Both are shown in Figure 6.3.']
['What are the angles for each of these points?', 'Consider a line from the center of the CD to its edge.']
["What is the line's angle of inclination?", 'In a given time, each pit (used to record information) on this line moves through the same angle.']
['What is the angle of rotation?', 'The angle of rotation is the amount of rotation and is the angular analog of distance.']
['What is the angular analog of distance?', 'The angle of rotation  $$\\(\\text{Δ}\\theta\\)$$  is the arc length divided by the radius of curvature.']
['What is a radian?', 'The angle of rotation is often measured by using a unit called the radian.']
['How is the radian defined?', '(Radians are actually dimensionless, because a radian is defined as the ratio of two distances, radius and arc length.)']
['What is a revolution?', 'A revolution is one complete rotation, where every point on the circle returns to its original position.']

['What is one revolution?', 'One revolution covers  $$\\(2\\pi\\)$$  radians (or 360 degrees), and therefore has an angle of rotation of  $$\\(2\\pi\\)$$  radians, and an arc length that is the same as the circumference of the circle.']
['Can you explain how radians and revolutions can be converted?', 'We can convert between radians, revolutions, and degrees using the relationship']
['What is a revolution?', '1 revolution =  $$\\(2\\pi\\)$$ rad = 360°.']
['How many radians are in 1 revolution?', 'See Table 6.1 for the conversion of degrees to radians for some common angles.']
['How do we find the distance that a ship travels?', 'We can answer this question by using the concept of angular velocity.']
['How is angular speed related to distance?', 'Consider first the angular speed  $$\\((\\omega)\\)$$  is the rate at which the angle of rotation changes.']
['How do we know the angular speed?', 'In equation form, the angular speed is']
['What is the tangent of an angle?', 'which means that an angular rotation  $$\\((\\Delta\\theta)\\)$$  occurs in a time,  $$\\(\\text{Δ}t\\)$$ .']
['What does the term angular speed mean?', 'If an object rotates through a greater angle of rotation in a given time, it has a greater angular speed.']
['What are the units for angular speed?', 'The units for angular speed are radians per second (rad/s).']
['What was the first question?', 'Now let’s consider the direction of the angular speed, which means we now must call it the angular velocity.']
['What was the direction of the angular velocity?', 'The direction of the angular velocity is along the axis of rotation.']
['How did it relate to an object rotating clockwise?', 'For an object rotating clockwise, the angular velocity points away from you along the axis of rotation.']
['What did it relate to an object rotating counterclockwise?', 'For an object rotating counterclockwise, the angular velocity points toward you along the axis of rotation.']
['What is tangential velocity?', 'Angular velocity (ω) is the angular version of linear velocity v. Tangential velocity is the instantaneous linear velocity of an object in rotational motion.']

['Why is the relationship between tangential velocity and angular velocity important?', 'To get the precise relationship between angular velocity and tangential velocity, consider again a pit on the rotating CD.']
['What happens to the pit in the rotating CD?', 'This pit moves through an arc length  $$\\[(\\Delta s)\\]$$  in a short time  $$\\[(\\Delta t)\\]$$  so its tangential speed is']

['What did you discover in your investigation?', 'From the definition of the angle of rotation,  $$\\(\\text{Δ}\\theta = \\frac{\\text{Δ}s}{r}\\)$$, we see that  $$\\(\\text{Δ}s = r\\text{Δ}\\theta\\)$$ .']
['What else did you discover?', 'Substituting this into the expression for v gives']
['What does the equation mean?', 'The equation  $$\\(v = r\\omega\\)$$  says that the tangential speed v is proportional to the distance r from the center of rotation.']

['What does that mean for a CD?', 'Consequently, tangential speed is greater for a point on the outer edge of the CD (with larger r) than for a point closer to the center of the CD (with smaller r).']
['Why is that?', 'This makes sense because a point farther out from the center has to cover a longer arc length in the same amount of time as a point closer to the center.']

['Why is that different from the case in which the tangential speed is equal?', 'Note that both points will still have the same angular speed, regardless of their distance from the center of rotation.']
['What else can you tell me?', 'See Figure 6.4.']
['Okay, for now, I want you to answer the following questions: 1. What is the definition', 'Now, consider another example: the tire of a moving car (see Figure 6.5).']
['How does this compare to the previous example?', 'The faster the tire spins, the faster the car moves—large  $$\\(\\omega\\)$$  means large v because  $$\\(v = r\\omega\\)$$ .']

['Does it matter which one of these is larger?', 'Similarly, a larger-radius tire rotating at the same angular velocity,  $$\\(\\mathbf{\\omega}\\)$$, will produce a greater linear (tangential) velocity, v, for the car.']
['Why is this the case?', 'This is because a larger radius means a longer arc length must contact the road, so the car must move farther in the same amount of time.']
['What is linear velocity?', 'However, there are cases where linear velocity and tangential velocity are not equivalent, such as a car spinning its tires on ice.']
['What happens in this case?', 'In this case, the linear velocity will be less than the tangential velocity.']

['What is the arc length?', 'Due to the lack of friction under the tires of a car on ice, the arc length through which the tire treads move is greater than the linear distance through which the car moves.']
['What does this mean?', 'It’s similar to running on a treadmill or pedaling a stationary bike; you are literally going nowhere fast.']
['What is the previous section called?', 'In the previous section, we defined circular motion.']
['What are some examples of circular motion?', 'The simplest case of circular motion is uniform circular motion, where an object travels a circular path at a constant speed.']

['What happens when the object goes from one direction to another?', 'Note that, unlike speed, the linear velocity of an object in circular motion is constantly changing because it is always changing direction.']
['What are acceleration and deceleration?', 'We know from kinematics that acceleration is a change in velocity, either in magnitude or in direction or both.']
['What is constant velocity?', 'Therefore, an object undergoing uniform circular motion is always accelerating, even though the magnitude of its velocity is constant.']
['How does this affect everyday life?', 'You experience this acceleration yourself every time you ride in a car while it turns a corner.']
['What happens to you in the car?', 'If you hold the steering wheel steady during the turn and move at a constant speed, you are executing uniform circular motion.']
['What happens when the speed changes?', 'What you notice is a feeling of sliding (or being flung, depending on the speed) away from the center of the turn.']

['Is this a physical reaction?', 'This isn’t an actual force that is acting on you—it only happens because your body wants to continue moving in a straight line (as per Newton’s first law) whereas the car is turning off this straight-line path.']
['How does this feel to you?', 'Inside the car it appears as if you are forced away from the center of the turn.']
['What is the force called?', 'This fictitious force is known as the centrifugal force.']
['What else can you tell me about this?', 'The sharper the curve and the greater your speed, the more noticeable this effect becomes.']
['What do you find in Figure 6.7?', 'Figure 6.7 shows an object moving in a circular path at constant speed.']
['What does the figure show?', 'The direction of the instantaneous tangential velocity is shown at two points along the path.']
['What is the acceleration in centripetal?', 'Acceleration is in the direction of the change in velocity; in this case it points roughly toward the center of rotation.']
['Is the center of rotation a point?', '(The center of rotation is at the center of the circular path).']

['Does the acceleration change?', 'If we imagine  $$\\(\\text{Δ}s\\)$$  becoming smaller and smaller, then the acceleration would point exactly toward the center of rotation, but this case is hard to draw.']
['Why is the acceleration called centripetal?', 'We call the acceleration of an object moving in uniform circular motion the centripetal acceleration ac because centripetal means center seeking.']

['What does centripetal acceleration mean?', 'Now that we know that the direction of centripetal acceleration is toward the center of rotation, let’s discuss the magnitude of centripetal acceleration.']
['What is the magnitude of centripetal acceleration?', 'For an object traveling at speed v in a circular path with radius r, the magnitude of centripetal acceleration is']

['What is centripetal acceleration?', 'Centripetal acceleration is greater at high speeds and in sharp curves (smaller radius), as you may have noticed when driving a car, because the car actually pushes you toward the center of the turn.']
['What else is significant about ac?', 'But it is a bit surprising that ac is proportional to the speed squared.']
['What does this mean?', 'This means, for example, that the acceleration is four times greater when you take a curve at 100 km/h than at 50 km/h.']
['What is the ac defined as?', 'We can also express ac in terms of the magnitude of angular velocity.']
['What is the magnitude of angular velocity?', 'Substituting  $$\\(v = r\\omega\\)$$  into the equation above, we get  $$\\(a_{c} = \\frac{{(r\\omega)}^{2}}{r} = r\\omega^{2}\\)$$ .']
['What is the significance of this equation?', 'Therefore, the magnitude of centripetal acceleration in terms of the magnitude of angular velocity is']
['What is the governing equation?', 'Any force or combination of forces can cause a centripetal acceleration.']

['What is an example of a force?', 'Just a few examples are the tension in the rope on a tether ball, the force of Earth’s gravity on the Moon, the friction between a road and the tires of a car as it goes around a curve, or the normal force of a roller coaster track on the cart during a loop-the-loop.']
['What kind of force is this?', 'Any net force causing uniform circular motion is called a centripetal force.']
['What direction does it point?', 'The direction of a centripetal force is toward the center of rotation, the same as for centripetal acceleration.']
['How does it cause acceleration?', 'According to Newton’s second law of motion, a net force causes the acceleration of mass according to Fnet = ma.']
['What is the acceleration?', 'For uniform circular motion, the acceleration is centripetal acceleration: a = ac.']
['What is the magnitude of the force?', 'Therefore, the magnitude of centripetal force, Fc, is  $$\\(\\mathbf{F}_{\\text{c}} = m\\mathbf{a}_{\\text{c}}\\)$$ .']

['Why is the force constant?', 'By using the two different forms of the equation for the magnitude of centripetal acceleration,  $$\\(\\mathbf{a}_{\\text{c}} = {v^{2}/r}\\)$$  and  $$\\(\\mathbf{a}_{c} = r\\omega^{2}\\)$$, we get two expressions involving the magnitude of the centripetal force Fc.']

['Are the expressions related to each other?', 'The first expression is in terms of tangential speed, the second is in terms of angular speed:  $$\\(\\mathbf{F}_{\\text{c}} = m\\frac{v^{2}}{r}\\)$$  and  $$\\(\\mathbf{F}_{\\text{c}} = mr\\omega^{2}\\)$$ .']
['What else can you tell me about the constant net external force?', 'Both forms of the equation depend on mass, velocity, and the radius of the circular path.']
['What is centripetal force?', 'You may use whichever expression for centripetal force is more convenient.']
['What else can you tell me about constant net external force?', 'Newton’s second law also states that the object will accelerate in the same direction as the net force.']
['What is centripetal force?', 'By definition, the centripetal force is directed towards the center of rotation, so the object will also accelerate towards the center.']

['What are the other important points about constant net external force?', 'A straight line drawn from the circular path to the center of the circle will always be perpendicular to the tangential velocity.']
['What else can you tell me about centripetal force?', 'Note that, if you solve the first expression for r, you get']

['What is the first thing you should know before we continue?', 'To get a feel for the typical magnitudes of centripetal acceleration, we’ll do a lab estimating the centripetal acceleration of a tennis racket and then, in our first Worked Example, compare the centripetal acceleration of a car rounding a curve to gravitational acceleration.']
["What are the next few things we'll be doing?", 'For the second Worked Example, we’ll calculate the force required to make a car round a curve.']
['What are some of the more important points?', 'In the section on uniform circular motion, we discussed motion in a circle at constant speed and, therefore, constant angular velocity.']
['Why is it different from a constant velocity?', 'However, there are times when angular velocity is not constant—rotational motion can speed up, slow down, or reverse directions.']

['What are some examples?', 'Angular velocity is not constant when a spinning skater pulls in her arms, when a child pushes a merry-go-round to make it rotate, or when a CD slows to a halt when switched off.']
['How does acceleration occur?', 'In all these cases, angular acceleration occurs because the angular velocity  $$\\(\\mathbf{\\text{ω}}\\)$$  changes.']
['What is an acceleration?', 'The faster the change occurs, the greater is the angular acceleration.']
['What is it related to?', 'Angular acceleration  $$\\(\\mathbf{\\text{α}}\\)$$  is the rate of change of angular velocity.']
['What else is important about rotational kinematics?', 'In equation form, angular acceleration is']
['What is the function?', 'where  $$\\(\\text{Δ}\\mathbf{\\text{ω}}\\)$$  is the change in angular velocity and  $$\\(\\text{Δ}t\\)$$  is the change in time.']
['What are the units of acceleration?', 'The units of angular acceleration are (rad/s)/s, or rad/s2.']
['What is positive acceleration?', 'If  $$\\(\\mathbf{\\text{ω}}\\)$$  increases, then  $$\\(\\mathbf{\\text{α}}\\)$$  is positive.']
['What is negative acceleration?', 'If  $$\\(\\mathbf{\\text{ω}}\\)$$  decreases, then  $$\\(\\mathbf{\\text{α}}\\)$$  is negative.']
['What else can you tell me about acceleration?', 'Keep in mind that, by convention, counterclockwise is the positive direction and clockwise is the negative direction.']
['What else can you tell me about acceleration?', 'For example, the skater in Figure 6.9 is rotating counterclockwise as seen from above, so her angular velocity is positive.']
['What is negative acceleration?', 'Acceleration would be negative, for example, when an object that is rotating counterclockwise slows down.']
['What is positive acceleration?', 'It would be positive when an object that is rotating counterclockwise speeds up.']
['What did these equations mean?', 'These equations mean that the magnitudes of tangential acceleration and angular acceleration are directly proportional to each other.']
['How does this relate to other forces?', 'The greater the angular acceleration, the larger the change in tangential acceleration, and vice versa.']
['What is an example of this?', 'For example, consider riders in their pods on a Ferris wheel at rest.']

['Why would the riders have greater acceleration than the resting ones?', 'A Ferris wheel with greater angular acceleration will give the riders greater tangential acceleration because, as the Ferris wheel increases its rate of spinning, it also increases its tangential velocity.']
['Why does this matter?', 'Note that the radius of the spinning object also matters.']
['What else does this mean?', 'For example, for a given angular acceleration  $$\\(\\mathbf{\\text{α}}\\)$$, a smaller Ferris wheel leads to a smaller tangential acceleration for the riders.']
['What are your thoughts on the rotational variables?', 'So far, we have defined three rotational variables:  $$\\(\\theta\\)$$,  $$\\(\\mathbf{\\text{ω}}\\)$$, and  $$\\(\\mathbf{\\text{α}}\\)$$.']
['How does this help the discussion?', 'These are the angular versions of the linear variables x, v, and a.']

['What are these equations for?', 'The following equations in the table represent the magnitude of the rotational variables and only when the radius is constant and perpendicular to the rotational variable.']
['Do they work in tandem?', 'Table 6.2 shows how they are related.']

['What is the purpose of the document?', 'We can now begin to see how rotational quantities like  $$\\(\\theta\\)$$,  $$\\(\\mathbf{\\text{ω}}\\)$$, and  $$\\(\\mathbf{\\text{α}}\\)$$   are related to each other.']

['What is an example of a rotational quantity?', 'For example, if a motorcycle wheel that starts at rest has a large angular acceleration for a fairly long time, it ends up spinning rapidly and rotates through many revolutions.']

['How does it rotate?', 'Putting this in terms of the variables, if the wheel’s angular acceleration  $$\\(\\mathbf{\\text{α}}\\)$$  is large for a long period of time t, then the final angular velocity  $$\\(\\mathbf{\\text{ω}}\\)$$  and angle of rotation  $$\\(\\theta\\)$$  are large.']

['How does this apply to linear motion?', 'In the case of linear motion, if an object starts at rest and undergoes a large linear acceleration, then it has a large final velocity and will have traveled a large distance.']
['What is kinematics?', 'The kinematics of rotational motion describes the relationships between the angle of rotation, angular velocity, angular acceleration, and time.']
['Why is it important?', 'It only describes motion—it does not include any forces or masses that may affect rotation (these are part of dynamics).']
['What does it look like?', 'Recall the kinematics equation for linear motion:  $$\\(\\mathbf{v} = \\mathbf{v}_{0} + \\mathbf{a}t\\)$$  (constant a).']

['What else is important in this material?', 'As in linear kinematics, we assume a is constant, which means that angular acceleration  $$\\(\\mathbf{\\text{α}}\\)$$  is also a constant, because  $$\\(\\mathbf{a} = r\\mathbf{\\text{α}}\\)$$ .']
['Is there anything else important that you learned in this section?', 'The equation for the kinematics relationship between  $$\\(\\mathbf{\\text{ω}}\\)$$,  $$\\(\\mathbf{\\text{α}}\\)$$, and t is']
['What is the relationship among the three sides of a right-angled triangle according to the Py', 'where  $$\\(\\mathbf{\\text{ω}}_{0}\\)$$  is the initial angular velocity.']
['What is the angular velocity?', 'Notice that the equation is identical to the linear version, except with angular analogs of the linear variables.']
['What is the analogs of the linear variables?', 'In fact, all of the linear kinematics equations have rotational analogs, which are given in Table 6.3.']

['Can you provide me with the details of these equations?', 'These equations can be used to solve rotational or linear kinematics problem in which a and  $$\\(\\mathbf{\\text{α}}\\)$$  are constant.']
['What is torque?', 'If you have ever spun a bike wheel or pushed a merry-go-round, you know that force is needed to change angular velocity.']
['What is torque?', 'The farther the force is applied from the pivot point (or fulcrum), the greater the angular acceleration.']
['What is another example?', 'For example, a door opens slowly if you push too close to its hinge, but opens easily if you push far from the hinges.']
['What is another example?', 'Furthermore, we know that the more massive the door is, the more slowly it opens; this is because angular acceleration is inversely proportional to mass.']
['What else is interesting in this material?', 'These relationships are very similar to the relationships between force, mass, and acceleration from Newton’s second law of motion.']

['Is there anything else that you want to know?', 'Since we have already covered the angular versions of distance, velocity and time, you may wonder what the angular version of force is, and how it relates to linear force.']
['What is torque?', 'The angular version of force is torque $$\\(\\mathbf{\\tau}\\)$$, which is the turning effectiveness of a force.']
['What else are you learning?', 'See Figure 6.11.']
['What else do you know about torque?', 'The equation for the magnitude of torque is']

['What is the function used to write this equation?', 'where r is the magnitude of the lever arm, F is the magnitude of the linear force, and  $$\\(\\theta\\)$$  is the angle between the lever arm and the force.']
['What is the lever arm?', 'The lever arm is the vector from the point of rotation (pivot point or fulcrum) to the location where force is applied.']
['What are the units for this?', 'Since the magnitude of the lever arm is a distance, its units are in meters, and torque has units of N⋅m.']
['What else is significant about the equation?', 'Torque is a vector quantity and has the same direction as the angular acceleration that it produces.']
['What is torque?', 'Applying a stronger torque will produce a greater angular acceleration.']
['What causes an object to accelerate?', 'For example, the harder the man pushes the merry-go-round in Figure 6.11, the faster it accelerates.']
['What causes the acceleration to be slower than it would otherwise?', 'Furthermore, the more massive the merry-go-round is, the slower it accelerates for the same torque.']

['What are the lever arm and leverage?', 'If the man wants to maximize the effect of his force on the merry-go-round, he should push as far from the center as possible to get the largest lever arm and, therefore, the greatest torque and angular acceleration.']
['What else are they used for?', 'Torque is also maximized when the force is applied perpendicular to the lever arm.']
['What are the linear and rotational forces?', 'Just as linear forces can balance to produce zero net force and no linear acceleration, the same is true of rotational motion.']

['What is the difference between rotational and linear force?', 'When two torques of equal magnitude act in opposing directions, there is no net torque and no angular acceleration, as you can see in the following video.']
['How do the two forces interact?', 'If zero net torque acts on a system spinning at a constant angular velocity, the system will continue to spin at the same angular velocity.']
['What kinds of orbits does Kepler describe?', 'Examples of orbits abound.']
['What kinds of objects are orbiting the Earth?', 'Hundreds of artificial satellites orbit Earth together with thousands of pieces of debris.']
["What is the moon's orbit?", 'The moon’s orbit around Earth has intrigued humans from time immemorial.']
['What are the orbits of other objects?', 'The orbits of planets, asteroids, meteors, and comets around the sun are no less interesting.']

['How do the orbits of other objects compare?', 'If we look farther, we see almost unimaginable numbers of stars, galaxies, and other celestial objects orbiting one another and interacting through gravity.']
['What does the formula A = 1/2 + 2?', 'All these motions are governed by gravitational force.']
['What else did Kepler say?', 'The orbital motions of objects in our own solar system are simple enough to describe with a few fairly simple laws.']
['How did they come about?', 'The orbits of planets and moons satisfy the following two conditions:']
["Which of the following is an example of Kepler's laws?", 'The orbit of each planet around the sun is an ellipse with the sun at one focus.']
["Which of the following is an example of Kepler's second law?", 'Each planet moves so that an imaginary line drawn from the sun to the planet sweeps out equal areas in equal times.']

["Which of the following is an example of Kepler's third law?", 'The ratio of the squares of the periods of any two planets about the sun is equal to the ratio of the cubes of their average distances from the sun.']
['What are the laws?', 'These descriptive laws are named for the German astronomer Johannes Kepler (1571–1630).']
['Who devised them?', 'He devised them after careful study (over some 20 years) of a large amount of meticulously recorded observations of planetary motion done by Tycho Brahe (1546–1601).']
['What was the study based on?', 'Such careful collection and detailed recording of methods and data are hallmarks of good science.']
['What are these data for?', 'Data constitute the evidence from which new interpretations and meanings can be constructed.']
['Is there anything else interesting in the article?', 'Let’s look closer at each of these laws.']
['What was the first law?', 'The orbit of each planet about the sun is an ellipse with the sun at one focus, as shown in Figure 7.2.']
['What is the ellipse?', 'The planet’s closest approach to the sun is called perihelion and its farthest distance from the sun is called aphelion.']
['What is Kepler’s Third Law?', 'The ratio of the periods squared of any two planets around the sun is equal to the ratio of their average distances from the sun cubed.']
["What else is true about Kepler's Third Law?", 'In equation form, this is']
['What is the equation?', 'where T is the period (time for one orbit) and r is the average distance (also called orbital radius).']
['What is special about this equation?', 'This equation is valid only for comparing two small masses orbiting a single large mass.']
['What is it for?', 'Most importantly, this is only a descriptive equation; it gives no information about the cause of the equality.']
['How did you get to the point that you are now at?', 'Refer back to Figure 7.2 (a).']
['What is the result of this simple equation?', 'Notice which distances are constant.']
['How did the answer come about?', 'The foci are fixed, so distance  $$\\(\\overline{f_{1}f_{2}}\\)$$  is a constant.']
['What else is constant?', 'The definition of an ellipse states that the sum of the distances  $$\\(\\overline{f_{1}m} + \\overline{mf_{2}}\\)$$  is also constant.']
['What else is constant?', 'These two facts taken together mean that the perimeter of triangle  $$\\(\\Delta f_{1}mf_{2}\\)$$  must also be constant.']
['What other facts are constant?', 'Knowledge of these constants will help you determine positions and distances of objects in a system that includes one object orbiting another.']
['What was the first question that popped up?', 'Refer back to Figure 7.4.']
['What was the second law?', 'The second law says that the segments have equal area and that it takes equal time to sweep through each segment.']
['What did it mean?', 'That is, the time it takes to travel from A to B equals the time it takes to travel from C to D, and so forth.']
['What else did you learn about this?', 'Velocity v equals distance d divided by time t:  $$\\(\\mathbf{v} = {d/t}\\)$$ .']
['What is it a constant for?', 'Then,  $$\\(t = {d/\\mathbf{v}}\\)$$, so distance divided by velocity is also a constant.']
['How does this relate to the earth?', 'For example, if we know the average velocity of Earth on June 21 and December 21, we can compare the distance Earth travels on those days.']
['What are the terms and definitions?', 'The degree of elongation of an elliptical orbit is called its eccentricity (e).']
['How is this calculated?', 'Eccentricity is calculated by dividing the distance f from the center of an ellipse to one of the foci by half the long axis a.']
['What is the area of an ellipse?', 'The area of an ellipse is given by  $$\\(A = \\pi ab\\)$$, where b is half the short axis.']

['What is an example of calculating the area of the Earth in an orbit?', 'If you know the axes of Earth’s orbit and the area Earth sweeps out in a given period of time, you can calculate the fraction of the year that has elapsed.']

["What is Kepler's Third Law?", 'Kepler’s third law states that the ratio of the squares of the periods of any two planets (T1, T2) is equal to the ratio of the cubes of their average orbital distance from the sun (r1, r2).']
['What is the mathematical representation of the Law?', 'Mathematically, this is represented by']
['What does the equation tell us?', 'From this equation, it follows that the ratio r3/T2 is the same for all planets in the solar system.']
['What is the relationship between these constants?', 'Later we will see how the work of Newton leads to a value for this constant.']
['Who is Newton?', 'Sir Isaac Newton was the first scientist to precisely define the gravitational force, and to show that it could explain both falling bodies and astronomical motions.']
['What is a significant part of this document?', 'See Figure 7.7.']
['Why did he discover the same force?', 'But Newton was not the first to suspect that the same force caused both our weight and the motion of planets.']
['Who was the first one to believe this?', 'His forerunner, Galileo Galilei, had contended that falling bodies and planetary motions had the same cause.']
['What are some examples of this theory?', 'Some of Newton’s contemporaries, such as Robert Hooke, Christopher Wren, and Edmund Halley, had also made some progress toward understanding gravitation.']

['What is the first mathematical form?', 'But Newton was the first to propose an exact mathematical form and to use that form to show that the motion of heavenly bodies should be conic sections—circles, ellipses, parabolas, and hyperbolas.']
['What was the significance of this?', 'This theoretical prediction was a major triumph.']

['How did this form relate to the movement of bodies?', 'It had been known for some time that moons, planets, and comets follow such paths, but no one had been able to propose an explanation of the mechanism that caused them to follow these paths and not others.']
['What is the gravitational force?', 'The gravitational force is relatively simple.']
['What are some ways of describing this?', 'It is always attractive, and it depends only on the masses involved and the distance between them.']

['What does this explain about objects and bodies?', 'Expressed in modern language, Newton’s universal law of gravitation states that every object in the universe attracts every other object with a force that is directed along a line joining them.']
['How does this force affect objects?', 'The force is directly proportional to the product of their masses and inversely proportional to the square of the distance between them.']
['Is there anything else you would like to know about the gravitational force?', 'This attraction is illustrated by Figure 7.8.']
['What is the formula?', 'where F is the magnitude of the gravitational force and G is a proportionality factor called the gravitational constant.']
['Why is G constant?', 'G is a universal constant, meaning that it is thought to be the same everywhere in the universe.']
['How has it been measured?', 'It has been measured experimentally to be  $$\\(G = 6.673 \\times 10^{- 11}\\text{N} \\cdot \\text{m}^{\\text{2}}\\text{/kg}^{\\text{2}}\\)$$ .']
["I'll start with this. Tell me the first three numbers.", 'G is given above, Earth’s mass M is 5.97 × 1024 kg, and the radius r of Earth is 6.38 × 106 m.']
["What's the relation between G and M and r?", 'Putting these values into Newton’s universal law of gravitation gives']
['What else is relevant to this study?', 'You may remember that g, the acceleration due to gravity, is another important constant related to gravity.']
['How does it effect the equation?', 'By substituting g for a in the equation for Newton’s second law of motion we get  $$\\(\\mathbf{F} = m\\mathbf{g}\\)$$ .']
['What are the results of the second law of motion?', 'Combining this with the equation for universal gravitation gives']
['Why is it important to note that m = kg?', 'This is a good point to recall the difference between mass and weight.']
['How is mass different from weight?', 'Mass is the amount of matter in an object; weight is the force of attraction between the mass within two objects.']
['Why can weight change?', 'Weight can change because g is different on every moon and planet.']
["What is an object's mass?", 'An object’s mass m does not change but its weight mg can.']
["What is the Kepler's third law?", 'It is possible to derive Kepler’s third law from Newton’s law of universal gravitation.']

['Why can it be derived?', 'Applying Newton’s second law of motion to angular motion gives an expression for centripetal force, which can be equated to the expression for force in the universal gravitation equation.']
['Does it have any other properties?', 'This expression can be manipulated to produce the equation for Kepler’s third law.']
['Are there any other facts about it?', 'We saw earlier that the expression r3/T2 is a constant for satellites orbiting the same massive object.']
['What is the equation?', 'The derivation of Kepler’s third law from Newton’s law of universal gravitation and Newton’s second law of motion yields that constant:']
['', 'where M is the mass of the central body about which the satellites orbit (for example, the sun in our solar system).']
['Why is this so important?', 'The usefulness of this equation will be seen later.']
['How is the universal gravitational constant G determined?', 'The universal gravitational constant G is determined experimentally.']

['When did this experimental definition take place?', 'This definition was first done accurately in 1798 by English scientist Henry Cavendish (1731–1810), more than 100 years after Newton published his universal law of gravitation.']
['What is important about the measurement of G?', 'The measurement of G is very basic and important because it determines the strength of one of the four forces in nature.']

['How was it determined?', 'Cavendish’s experiment was very difficult because he measured the tiny gravitational attraction between two ordinary-sized masses (tens of kilograms at most) by using an apparatus like that in Figure 7.9.']
['Did this result in a change in the equation?', 'Remarkably, his value for G differs by less than 1% from the modern value.']
['What is it about?', 'Einstein’s theory of general relativity explained some interesting properties of gravity not covered by Newton’s theory.']
['What was important about his theory?', 'Einstein based his theory on the postulate that acceleration and gravity have the same effect and cannot be distinguished from each other.']
['What else is significant about his theory?', 'He concluded that light must fall in both a gravitational field and in an accelerating reference frame.']
['What did he discover after the revolution of the Earth?', 'Figure 7.10 shows this effect (greatly exaggerated) in an accelerating elevator.']
['Is there anything else interesting about the article?', 'In Figure 7.10 (a), the elevator accelerates upward in zero gravity.']
['What else happens in the figure?', 'In Figure 7.10 (b), the room is not accelerating but is subject to gravity.']
['What happens to light?', 'The effect on light is the same: it “falls” downward in both situations.']
['How does a person see the situation?', 'The person in the elevator cannot tell whether the elevator is accelerating in zero gravity or is stationary and subject to gravity.']
['What else did he learn?', 'Thus, gravity affects the path of light, even though we think of gravity as acting between masses, while photons are massless.']
['What happened in 1919?', 'Einstein’s theory of general relativity got its first verification in 1919 when starlight passing near the sun was observed during a solar eclipse.']
['What are some of the other things in the document that you like?', '(See Figure 7.11.)']
['What happens during the eclipse?', 'During an eclipse, the sky is darkened and we can briefly see stars.']
['What happens to the stars?', 'Those on a line of sight nearest the sun should have a shift in their apparent positions.']
['What else happened with the eclipse?', 'Not only was this shift observed, but it agreed with Einstein’s predictions well within experimental uncertainties.']
['Was this a popular discovery?', 'This discovery created a scientific and public sensation.']
['What was he known for?', 'Einstein was now a folk hero as well as a very great scientist.']
['What was the theory about?', 'The bending of light by matter is equivalent to a bending of space itself, with light following the curve.']
['What else was different about this theory?', 'This is another radical change in our concept of space and time.']
['What else does this theory prove?', 'It is also another connection that any particle with mass or energy (e.g., massless photons) is affected by gravity.']
['What are the two views of gravity?', 'To summarize the two views of gravity, Newton envisioned gravity as a tug of war along the line connecting any two objects in the universe.']
['What did Einstein envision gravity as?', 'In contrast, Einstein envisioned gravity as a bending of space-time by mass.']
['What is the mass of an object?', 'The mass of an object is constant, but its weight varies with the strength of the gravitational field.']
['What does this mean?', 'This means the value of g varies from place to place in the universe.']
['What is the g of an object?', 'The relationship between force, mass, and acceleration from the second law of motion can be written in terms of g.']
["What does the 'force' refer to?", 'In this case, the force is the weight of the object, which is caused by the gravitational attraction of the planet or moon on which the object is located.']
['What is the value of this expression?', 'We can use this expression to compare weights of an object on different moons and planets.']
['What is a significant concept within this study material?', 'Two equations involving the gravitational constant, G, are often useful.']
['What are these equations?', 'The first is Newton’s equation,  $$\\(\\mathbf{F} = G\\frac{mM}{r^{2}}\\)$$ .']
['Why is this useful?', 'Several of the values in this equation are either constants or easily obtainable.']
['What is F?', 'F is often the weight of an object on the surface of a large object with mass M, which is usually known.']
['What is the larger object?', 'The mass of the smaller object, m, is often known, and G is a universal constant with the same value anywhere in the universe.']
['Why do you need the equation?', 'This equation can be used to solve problems involving an object on or orbiting Earth or other massive celestial object.']
['Why not use mg?', 'Sometimes it is helpful to equate the right-hand side of the equation to mg and cancel the m on both sides.']
['What other math is this about?', 'The equation  $$\\(\\frac{r^{3}}{T^{2}} = \\frac{GM}{4\\pi^{2}}\\)$$  is also useful for problems involving objects in orbit.']
['How is the equation used for orbiting objects?', 'Note that there is no need to know the mass of the object.']
['What else do we need to know?', 'Often, we know the radius r or the period T and want to find the other.']
['How do we find the other?', 'If these are both known, we can use the equation to calculate the mass of a planet or star.']
['What is linear momentum?', 'Linear momentum is the product of a system’s mass and its velocity.']
['How is linear momentum expressed?', 'In equation form, linear momentum p is']
['What is momentum?', 'You can see from the equation that momentum is directly proportional to the object’s mass (m) and velocity (v).']
['What does this mean?', 'Therefore, the greater an object’s mass or the greater its velocity, the greater its momentum.']
['What happens if both are greater than zero?', 'A large, fast-moving object has greater momentum than a smaller, slower object.']

['What is momentum?', 'Momentum is a vector and has the same direction as velocity v. Since mass is a scalar, when velocity is in a negative direction (i.e., opposite the direction of motion), the momentum will also be in a negative direction; and when velocity is in a positive direction, momentum will likewise be in a positive direction.']
['What SI unit for momentum is mentioned?', 'The SI unit for momentum is kg m/s.']
['What is momentum?', 'Momentum is so important for understanding motion that it was called the quantity of motion by physicists such as Newton.']
['What is a force?', 'Force influences momentum, and we can rearrange Newton’s second law of motion to show the relationship between force and momentum.']
['What else can you tell me about the material?', 'Recall our study of Newton’s second law of motion (Fnet = ma).']
['What else is important about the law of motion?', 'Newton actually stated his second law of motion in terms of momentum:']
['How does momentum relate to the net external force?', 'The net external force equals the change in momentum of a system divided by the time over which it changes.']
['What is the change in momentum?', 'The change in momentum is the difference between the final and initial values of momentum.']
['What else do we know about impulse?', '$$\\(\\mathbf{\\text{F}}_{\\text{net}}\\text{Δ}t\\)$$is known as impulse and this equation is known as the impulse-momentum theorem.']
['What is impulse used for?', 'From the equation, we see that the impulse equals the average net external force multiplied by the time this force acts.']
['What else does impulse equal?', 'It is equal to the change in momentum.']
['What else can you tell me about impulse?', 'The effect of a force on an object depends on how long it acts, as well as the strength of the force.']
['What can we learn about impulse?', 'Impulse is a useful concept because it quantifies the effect of a force.']
['What is a case in point?', 'A very large force acting for a short time can have a great effect on the momentum of an object, such as the force of a racket hitting a tennis ball.']
['What else do you know about impulse?', 'A small force could cause the same change in momentum, but it would have to act for a much longer time.']

['What can it be used for?', 'When Newton’s second law is expressed in terms of momentum, it can be used for solving problems where mass varies, since  $$\\(\\text{Δ}\\mathbf{\\text{p}} = \\text{Δ}(m\\mathbf{\\text{v}})\\)$$ .']
['How is the law expressed differently?', 'In the more traditional form of the law that you are used to working with, mass is assumed to be constant.']
['What was the traditional form?', 'In fact, this traditional form is a special case of the law, where mass is constant.']
['What was the equation used to derive it?', '$$\\(\\mathbf{\\text{F}}_{\\text{net}} = m\\mathbf{\\text{a}}\\)$$  is actually derived from the equation:']
['What does the conservation of momentum mean?', 'It is important we realize that momentum is conserved during collisions, explosions, and other events involving objects in motion.']
['What does this mean?', 'To say that a quantity is conserved means that it is constant throughout the event.']
['What does this mean?', 'In the case of conservation of momentum, the total momentum in the system remains the same before and after the collision.']
['What is conservation of momentum?', 'You may have noticed that momentum was not conserved in some of the examples previously presented in this chapter.']
['Where was momentum not conserved?', 'where forces acting on the objects produced large changes in momentum.']
['What was wrong with those examples?', 'The systems of interest considered in those problems were not inclusive enough.']
["Why wasn't momentum conserved?", 'If the systems were expanded to include more objects, then momentum would in fact be conserved in those sample problems.']

['What can happen when momentum is conserved in larger systems?', 'It is always possible to find a larger system where momentum is conserved, even though momentum changes for individual objects within the system.']
['What is a force?', 'For example, if a football player runs into the goalpost in the end zone, a force will cause him to bounce backward.']
['What happens to the football player when he bounces back?', 'His momentum is obviously greatly changed, and considering only the football player, we would find that momentum is not conserved.']
['How much momentum is conserved?', 'However, the system can be expanded to contain the entire Earth.']
['What happens to the Earth?', 'Surprisingly, Earth also recoils—conserving momentum—because of the force applied to it through the goalpost.']
['How large is the earth?', 'The effect on Earth is not noticeable because it is so much more massive than the player, but the effect is real.']

['What was the first question?', 'Next, consider what happens if the masses of two colliding objects are more similar than the masses of a football player and Earth—in the example shown in Figure 8.4 of one car bumping into another.']
['What happened in the example?', 'Both cars are coasting in the same direction when the lead car, labeled m2, is bumped by the trailing car, labeled m1.']
['How is the friction?', 'The only unbalanced force on each car is the force of the collision, assuming that the effects due to friction are negligible.']
['What else happened during the collision?', 'Car m1 slows down as a result of the collision, losing some momentum, while car m2 speeds up and gains some momentum.']
['What happened after the collision?', 'If we choose the system to include both cars and assume that friction is negligible, then the momentum of the two-car system should remain constant.']
['How did the examples help?', 'Now we will prove that the total momentum of the two-car system does in fact remain constant, and is therefore conserved.']

['Which cars are involved in the collision?', 'Similarly, the change in momentum of car 2 is  $$\\(\\text{Δ}\\mathbf{p}_{2} = \\mathbf{F}_{2}\\text{Δ}t\\)$$  where F2 is the force on car 2 due to car 1, and we assume the duration of the collision  $$\\(\\text{Δ}t\\)$$  is the same for both cars.']

["What's the significance of this equation?", 'We know from Newton’s third law of motion that F2 = –F1, and so  $$\\(\\text{Δ}\\mathbf{p}_{2} = - \\mathbf{F}_{1}\\text{Δ}t = - \\text{Δ}\\mathbf{p}_{1}\\)$$ .']
['Why is the total momentum constant?', 'Because the changes in momentum add to zero, the total momentum of the two-car system is constant.']
['How do they balance?', 'That is,']

['Let m = the momentum of car 1 before the collision.', 'This result that momentum is conserved is true not only for this example involving the two cars, but for any system where the net external force is zero, which is known as an isolated system.']
['What are some other relevant facts?', 'The law of conservation of momentum states that for an isolated system with any number of objects in it, the total momentum is conserved.']
['How is the law of conservation of momentum written in terms of its equation?', 'In equation form, the law of conservation of momentum for an isolated system is written as']

['What are some applications of this principle?', 'The conservation of momentum principle can be applied to systems as diverse as a comet striking the Earth or a gas containing huge numbers of atoms and molecules.']
['What else is significant about the article?', 'Conservation of momentum appears to be violated only when the net external force is not zero.']
['What happens in a vacuum?', 'But another larger system can always be considered in which momentum is conserved by simply including the source of the external force.']

['What are some examples of systems that violate this principle?', 'For example, in the collision of two cars considered above, the two-car system conserves momentum while each one-car system does not.']
['What can happen when two objects collide?', 'When objects collide, they can either stick together or bounce off one another, remaining separate.']
['What are elastic and inelastic collisions?', 'In this section, we’ll cover these two different types of collisions, first in one dimension and then in two dimensions.']
['What is an elastic collision?', 'In an elastic collision, the objects separate after impact and don’t lose any of their kinetic energy.']
['What is kinetic energy?', 'Kinetic energy is the energy of motion and is covered in detail elsewhere.']
['Why does it stay kinetic?', 'The law of conservation of momentum is very useful here, and it can be used whenever the net external force on a system is zero.']
['What are the examples?', 'Figure 8.6 shows an elastic collision where momentum is conserved.']

['What is the video about?', 'It replicates the elastic collisions between balls of varying masses.']
['What was this question about?', 'Perfectly elastic collisions can happen only with subatomic particles.']

['What do subatomic particles have to do with this question?', 'Everyday observable examples of perfectly elastic collisions don’t exist—some kinetic energy is always lost, as it is converted into heat transfer due to friction.']

['What is friction?', 'However, collisions between everyday objects are almost perfectly elastic when they occur with objects and surfaces that are nearly frictionless, such as with two steel blocks on ice.']
['What are some things we should know about this?', 'Now, to solve problems involving one-dimensional elastic collisions between two objects, we can use the equation for conservation of momentum.']

['', 'Now, let us turn to the second type of collision.']
['What is the second type of collision?', 'An inelastic collision is one in which objects stick together after impact, and kinetic energy is not conserved.']

['Why is that important?', 'This lack of conservation means that the forces between colliding objects may convert kinetic energy to other forms of energy, such as potential energy or thermal energy.']
['How does that relate to the concept of energy?', 'The concepts of energy are discussed more thoroughly elsewhere.']
['What else is important to know?', 'For inelastic collisions, kinetic energy may be lost in the form of heat.']
['What else did you learn?', 'Figure 8.7 shows an example of an inelastic collision.']
['How does the figure show this?', 'Two objects that have equal masses head toward each other at equal speeds and then stick together.']
['What happens when the two objects stick together?', 'The two objects come to rest after sticking together, conserving momentum but not kinetic energy after they collide.']
['What happens if the two objects stay together after colliding?', 'Some of the energy of motion gets converted to thermal energy, or heat.']
['What else do you need to know?', 'Since the two objects stick together after colliding, they move together at the same speed.']
['What does this mean?', 'This lets us simplify the conservation of momentum equation from']

['How do you solve two-dimensional collisions?', 'These are two-dimensional collisions, and just as we did with two-dimensional forces, we will solve these problems by first choosing a coordinate system and separating the motion into its x and y components.']
['What problems are they trying to solve?', 'One complication with two-dimensional collisions is that the objects might rotate before or after their collision.']
['What are some examples?', 'For example, if two ice skaters hook arms as they pass each other, they will spin in circles.']
['What is a possible way to solve for this?', 'We will not consider such rotation until later, and so for now, we arrange things so that no rotation is possible.']
['What is the best solution to this problem?', 'To avoid rotation, we consider only the scattering of point masses—that is, structureless particles that cannot rotate or spin.']

['What else can you tell me about the simplest collision?', 'The simplest collision is one in which one of the particles is initially at rest.']

['How does the simplest collision differ from other examples?', 'The best choice for a coordinate system is one with an axis parallel to the velocity of the incoming particle, as shown in Figure 8.8.']

['What is py and px?', 'With the chosen coordinate system, py is initially zero and px is the momentum of the incoming particle.']
['What is this?', 'The components of the velocities along the x-axis have the form v cos θ .']
['What is the second equation?', 'Because particle 1 initially moves along the x-axis, we find v1x = v1.']
['What is the third equation?', 'Conservation of momentum along the x-axis gives the equation']

['What is the equation for m2?', 'Because particle 2 is initially at rest, v2y is also zero.']
['What is the equation for m3?', 'The equation for conservation of momentum along the y-axis becomes']
