['How is momentum calculated?', 'Therefore, conservation of momentum along the y-axis gives the following equation:']
['How is work defined?', 'In physics, the term work has a very specific definition.']
['What is the definition?', 'Work is application of force,  $$\\(\\mathbf{f}\\)$$, to move an object over a distance, d, in the direction that the force is applied.']
['How is it measured?', 'Work, W, is described by the equation']
['What is the content of the second part?', 'Some things that we typically consider to be work are not work in the scientific sense of the term.']
['How do you know this?', 'Let’s consider a few examples.']
['How does physics apply to everyday life?', 'Think about why each of the following statements is true.']
['Do you want to do homework?', 'Homework is not work.']
['Are you free to go elsewhere?', 'Lifting a rock upwards off the ground is work.']
['Are you free to go elsewhere?', 'Carrying a rock in a straight path across the lawn at a constant speed is not work.']
['what are some of the examples?', 'The first two examples are fairly simple.']
['what is the topic of homework?', 'Homework is not work because objects are not being moved over a distance.']
['does that mean everything is work?', 'Lifting a rock up off the ground is work because the rock is moving in the direction that force is applied.']
["what's the last example?", 'The last example is less obvious.']
['how does the last example work?', 'Recall from the laws of motion that force is not required to move an object at constant velocity.']
['is this correct?', 'Therefore, while some force may be applied to keep the rock up off the ground, no net force is applied to keep the rock moving forward at constant velocity.']
['What is the relationship between work and energy?', 'Work and energy are closely related.']
['What causes energy to change?', 'When you do work to move an object, you change the object’s energy.']
['What happens to your own energy?', 'You (or an object) also expend energy to do work.']
['How do you define energy?', 'In fact, energy can be defined as the ability to do work.']
['What else is important about energy?', 'Energy can take a variety of different forms, and one form of energy can transform to another.']
['Which forms do we study in this chapter?', 'In this chapter we will be concerned with mechanical energy, which comes in two forms: kinetic energy and potential energy.']
['What is kinetic energy?', 'Kinetic energy is also called energy of motion.']
['Does a moving object have kinetic energy?', 'A moving object has kinetic energy.']
['What is potential energy?', 'Potential energy, sometimes called stored energy, comes in several forms.']
['What is gravitational potential energy?', 'Gravitational potential energy is the stored energy an object has as a result of its position above Earth’s surface (or another object in space).']
['What do you find interesting about gravitational potential energy?', 'A roller coaster car at the top of a hill has gravitational potential energy.']
['What is one of the most important concepts in this document?', 'Let’s examine how doing work on an object changes the object’s energy.']
['How does work change an object’s energy?', 'If we apply force to lift a rock off the ground, we increase the rock’s potential energy, PE.']
['What happens if we drop the rock?', 'If we drop the rock, the force of gravity increases the rock’s kinetic energy as the rock moves downward until it hits the ground.']
['What was the question you wanted to test yourself on?', 'The work we do on the rock equals the force we exert multiplied by the distance, d, that we lift the rock.']
['What else is this formula equal to?', 'The work we do on the rock also equals the rock’s gain in gravitational potential energy, PEe.']
['What are kinetic and gravitational energies?', 'When we drop the rock the force of gravity causes the rock to fall, giving the rock kinetic energy.']

['What is an example of a gravitational force causing the rock to fall?', 'When work done on an object increases only its kinetic energy, then the net work equals the change in the value of the quantity $$\\(\\frac{1}{2}m\\mathbf{v}^{2}\\)$$ .']
['What is this statement about?', 'This is a statement of the work–energy theorem, which is expressed mathematically as']
['What is important about this?', 'The subscripts 2 and 1 indicate the final and initial velocity, respectively.']
['Who developed this?', 'This theorem was proposed and successfully tested by James Joule, shown in Figure 9.2.']
['What is the joule?', 'The joule (J) is the metric unit of measurement for both work and energy.']

['Why does a J serve as a unit for both work and energy?', 'The measurement of work and energy with the same unit reinforces the idea that work and energy are related and can be converted into one another.']
['How is force calculated?', '1.0 J = 1.0 N∙m, the units of force multiplied by distance.']
['What is distance?', '1.0 N = 1.0 kg∙m/s2, so 1.0 J = 1.0 kg∙m2/s2.']
['What else is involved in the calculation of work?', 'Analyzing the units of the term (1/2)mv2 will produce the same units for joules.']
['What are calculations involving work and power?', 'In applications that involve work, we are often interested in how fast the work is done.']

['How are these speed measurements used in everyday life?', 'For example, in roller coaster design, the amount of time it takes to lift a roller coaster car to the top of the first hill is an important consideration.']
['What is an example of how speed can be considered important?', 'Taking a half hour on the ascent will surely irritate riders and decrease ticket sales.']
['Are there any other examples of speed calculations?', 'Let’s take a look at how to calculate the time it takes to do work.']
['What is a rate?', 'Recall that a rate can be used to describe a quantity, such as work, over a period of time.']
['What is power?', 'Power is the rate at which work is done.']
['What does rate mean?', 'In this case, rate means per unit of time.']
['How is power calculated?', 'Power is calculated by dividing the work done by the time it took to do the work.']
['What is a difference between work, force, and power?', 'Let’s consider an example that can help illustrate the differences among work, force, and power.']

['What is the example?', 'Suppose the woman in Figure 9.3 lifting the TV with a pulley gets the TV to the fourth floor in two minutes, and the man carrying the TV up the stairs takes five minutes to arrive at the same place.']

['How do they get to the same place?', 'They have done the same amount of work  $$\\(\\left( {\\mathbf{f}d} \\right)\\)$$  on the TV, because they have moved the same mass over the same vertical distance, which requires the same amount of upward force.']
['How does she know that?', 'However, the woman using the pulley has generated more power.']
['Why is this?', 'This is because she did the work in a shorter amount of time, so the denominator of the power formula, t, is smaller.']
["How do you know the man's force?", '(For simplicity’s sake, we will leave aside for now the fact that the man climbing the stairs has also done work on himself.)']
['What kind of units are used to measure power?', 'Power can be expressed in units of watts (W).']
['What do watts mean?', 'This unit can be used to measure power related to any form of energy or work.']
['What is the biggest use for this unit?', 'You have most likely heard the term used in relation to electrical devices, especially light bulbs.']
['What can you tell me about energy?', 'Multiplying power by time gives the amount of energy.']
['What are kilowatt-hours?', 'Electricity is sold in kilowatt-hours because that equals the amount of electrical energy consumed.']
['What is Watt?', 'The watt unit was named after James Watt (1736–1819) (see Figure 9.4).']
['Who was James Watt?', 'He was a Scottish engineer and inventor who discovered how to coax more power out of steam engines.']
["What's the recitation?", 'Before proceeding, be sure you understand the distinctions among force, work, energy, and power.']
['What is work?', 'Force exerted on an object over a distance does work.']
['What can work do?', 'Work can increase energy, and energy can do work.']
['What is power?', 'Power is the rate at which work is done.']
['Which kind of energy is that?', 'We saw earlier that mechanical energy can be either potential or kinetic.']
['What can we do with potential energy?', 'We will also see that, in a closed system, the sum of these forms of energy remains constant.']
['What kind of energy is gained on a roller coaster?', 'Quite a bit of potential energy is gained by a roller coaster car and its passengers when they are raised to the top of the first hill.']
['What does potential energy mean?', 'Remember that the potential part of the term means that energy has been stored and can be used at another time.']
['What does potential energy lead to?', 'You will see that this stored energy can either be used to do work or can be transformed into kinetic energy.']
['Does this mean anything?', 'For example, when an object that has gravitational potential energy falls, its energy is converted to kinetic energy.']
['What units does this mean?', 'Remember that both work and energy are expressed in joules.']
['What are the three sides of a right-angled triangle according to the Pythago', 'Refer back to Figure 9.3.']

['What is the result of this law?', 'The amount of work required to raise the TV from point A to point B is equal to the amount of gravitational potential energy the TV gains from its height above the ground.']
['Is this true for the TV only?', 'This is generally true for any object raised above the ground.']
['What is the reason for this law?', 'If all the work done on an object is used to raise the object above the ground, the amount work equals the object’s gain in gravitational potential energy.']
['Are there any other explanations for this law?', 'However, note that because of the work done by friction, these energy–work transformations are never perfect.']
['What causes friction?', 'Friction causes the loss of some useful energy.']
['How does friction affect the energy–work transformations?', 'In the discussions to follow, we will use the approximation that transformations are frictionless.']
['What is the most important fact about Mechanical Energy?', 'Now, let’s look at the roller coaster in Figure 9.7.']

['What is the role of work on the roller coaster?', 'Work was done on the roller coaster to get it to the top of the first rise; at this point, the roller coaster has gravitational potential energy.']
['What other energy does the roller coaster have?', 'It is moving slowly, so it also has a small amount of kinetic energy.']
['Why does the car have potential energy?', 'As the car descends the first slope, its PE is converted to KE.']
['How does the car reach its lowest point?', 'At the low point much of the original PE has been transformed to KE, and speed is at a maximum.']
['How is the car able to maintain this speed?', 'As the car moves up the next slope, some of the KE is transformed back into PE and the car slows down.']
['What does kinetic energy mean?', 'On an actual roller coaster, there are many ups and downs, and each of these is accompanied by transitions between kinetic and potential energy.']
['What is the difference between friction and potential energy?', 'Assume that no energy is lost to friction.']
['What are the properties of mechanical energy?', 'At any point in the ride, the total mechanical energy is the same, and it is equal to the energy the car had at the top of the first rise.']
['How does the energy have to stay the same?', 'This is a result of the law of conservation of energy, which says that, in a closed system, total energy is conserved—that is, it is constant.']
['How is this determined?', 'Using subscripts 1 and 2 to represent initial and final energy, this law is expressed as']
['What is the relationship between the three sides of a right-angled triangle?', 'Either side equals the total mechanical energy.']
['What is a closed system?', 'The phrase in a closed system means we are assuming no energy is lost to the surroundings due to friction and air resistance.']
['What is a good assumption to make?', 'If we are making calculations on dense falling objects, this is a good assumption.']
['What are two other cases of the closed system assumption?', 'For the roller coaster, this assumption introduces some inaccuracy to the calculation.']
['What are simple machines?', 'Simple machines make work easier, but they do not decrease the amount of work you have to do.']
['Do they reduce energy?', 'Recall that in closed systems the total amount of energy is conserved.']

['Are there other factors involved with these machines?', 'Although it cannot change the amount of work you do, a simple machine can change the amount of force you must apply to an object, and the distance over which you apply the force.']
['What can be done with these machines?', 'In most cases, a simple machine is used to reduce the amount of force you must exert to do work.']

['Why must you exert force over a greater distance?', 'The down side is that you must exert the force over a greater distance, because the product of force and distance, fd, (which equals work) does not change.']
["What's the topic of our discussion?", 'Let’s examine how this works in practice.']

['What is one example of this in practice?', 'In Figure 9.8(a), the worker uses a type of lever to exert a small force over a large distance, while the pry bar pulls up on the nail with a large force over a small distance.']
["What's another example of this?", 'Figure 9.8(b) shows the how a lever works mathematically.']
['What else is interesting about this section?', 'The effort force, applied at Fe, lifts the load (the resistance force) which is pushing down at Fr.']

["What's the next step?", 'The triangular pivot is called the fulcrum; the part of the lever between the fulcrum and Fe is the effort arm, Le; and the part to the left is the resistance arm, Lr. The mechanical advantage is a number that tells us how many times a simple machine multiplies the effort force.']

['What is the ideal mechanical advantage?', 'The ideal mechanical advantage, IMA, is the mechanical advantage of a perfect machine with no loss of useful work caused by friction between moving parts.']
['How can this be calculated?', 'The equation for IMA is shown in Figure 9.8(b).']
['What is this about?', 'Getting back to conservation of energy, for any simple machine, the work put into the machine, Wi, equals the work the machine puts out, Wo.']
['What happens with respect to a given machine?', 'Combining this with the information in the paragraphs above, we can write']
['What is lever?', 'Some levers exert a large force to a short effort arm.']
['What happens when the resistance arm is long?', 'This results in a smaller force acting over a greater distance at the end of the resistance arm.']
['What type of levers do they make?', 'Examples of this type of lever are baseball bats, hammers, and golf clubs.']
['What is another example?', 'In another type of lever, the fulcrum is at the end of the lever and the load is in the middle, as in the design of a wheelbarrow.']
['What kind of simple machines are there?', 'The simple machine shown in Figure 9.9 is called a wheel and axle.']
['What is a wheel and axle?', 'It is actually a form of lever.']
["What's different about the wheel and axle from a lever?", 'The difference is that the effort arm can rotate in a complete circle around the fulcrum, which is the center of the axle.']
['What are the forces acting on this wheel?', 'Force applied to the outside of the wheel causes a greater force to be applied to the rope that is wrapped around the axle.']
['What is the ideal mechanical advantage?', 'As shown in the figure, the ideal mechanical advantage is calculated by dividing the radius of the wheel by the radius of the axle.']
['What is an example of a wheel and axle?', 'Any crank-operated device is an example of a wheel and axle.']
['What is a simple machine?', 'An inclined plane and a wedge are two forms of the same simple machine.']
['What is a wedge?', 'A wedge is simply two inclined planes back to back.']
['What are the formulas?', 'Figure 9.10 shows the simple formulas for calculating the IMAs of these machines.']
['What is an inclined plane?', 'All sloping, paved surfaces for walking or driving are inclined planes.']
['What are some examples of wedges?', 'Knives and axe heads are examples of wedges.']
['What is an example of a simple machine?', 'The screw shown in Figure 9.11 is actually a lever attached to a circular inclined plane.']
['What is an example of screw?', 'Wood screws (of course) are also examples of screws.']
['What is an example of lever?', 'The lever part of these screws is a screw driver.']
['What is the formula for IMA?', 'In the formula for IMA, the distance between screw threads is called pitch and has the symbol P.']
['What is the first figure in this section?', 'Figure 9.12 shows three different pulley systems.']
['What can you tell me about pulleys?', 'Of all simple machines, mechanical advantage is easiest to calculate for pulleys.']
['How do you calculate it?', 'Simply count the number of ropes supporting the load.']
['What is the total distance over which a force is applied?', 'That is the IMA.']
['What happens to the force with more ropes?', 'Once again we have to exert force over a longer distance to multiply force.']
['Why do we have to exert force over a longer distance?', 'To raise a load 1 meter with a pulley system you have to pull N meters of rope.']
['What else does the article say about pulleys?', 'Pulley systems are often used to raise flags and window blinds and are part of the mechanism of construction cranes.']
['What is a complex machine?', 'A complex machine is a combination of two or more simple machines.']
['What type of machine is an example?', 'The wire cutters in Figure 9.13 combine two levers and two wedges.']
['What type of machines are included in bicycles?', 'Bicycles include wheel and axles, levers, screws, and pulleys.']
['What type of machines are included in cars?', 'Cars and other vehicles are combinations of many machines.']
['Why are these equations useful?', 'No simple or complex machines have the actual mechanical advantages calculated by the IMA equations.']
['Why do complex machines have more mechanical advantages?', 'In real life, some of the applied work always ends up as wasted heat due to friction between moving parts.']
['What are the IMA equations?', 'Both the input work (Wi) and output work (Wo) are the result of a force, F, acting over a distance, d.']
['What is efficiency?', 'Look back at the pictures of the simple machines and think about which would have the highest efficiency.']
['What else should you know about efficiency?', 'Efficiency is related to friction, and friction depends on the smoothness of surfaces and on the area of the surfaces in contact.']
['What is relativity?', 'Relativity is not new.']
['When did Galileo write the theory of relativity?', 'Way back around the year 1600, Galileo explained that motion is relative.']
['What does he mean?', 'Wherever you happen to be, it seems like you are at a fixed point and that everything moves with respect to you.']
['What about others?', 'Everyone else feels the same way.']
['Does it always have to be this way?', 'Motion is always measured with respect to a fixed point.']
['What is the fixed point?', 'This is called establishing a frame of reference.']
['Is it the same for everyone?', 'But the choice of the point is arbitrary, and all frames of reference are equally valid.']

['What is an example of relative motion?', 'A passenger in a moving car is not moving with respect to the driver, but they are both moving from the point of view of a person on the sidewalk waiting for a bus.']
['How fast are they moving?', 'They are moving even faster as seen by a person in a car coming toward them.']
['Do the car drivers have to respect any particular frame of reference?', 'It is all relative.']

['What else does the document cover?', 'Light is involved in the discussion of relativity because theories related to electromagnetism are inconsistent with Galileo’s and Newton’s explanation of relativity.']
['What was the controversy about?', 'The true nature of light was a hot topic of discussion and controversy in the late 19th century.']
['What did most people think?', 'At the time, it was not generally believed that light could travel across empty space.']
['Why did they think that?', 'It was known to travel as waves, and all other types of energy that propagated as waves needed to travel though a material medium.']
['What else was said about the nature of light?', 'It was believed that space was filled with an invisible medium that light waves traveled through.']
['What was this imaginary material called?', 'This imaginary (as it turned out) material was called the ether (also spelled aether).']
['What else did people think about this material?', 'It was thought that everything moved through this mysterious fluid.']
['What else did they think about this mysterious fluid?', 'In other words, ether was the one fixed frame of reference.']
['Did the experiment prove that?', 'The Michelson–Morley experiment proved it was not.']
['What were the names of some famous experiments?', 'In 1887, Albert Michelson and Edward Morley designed the interferometer shown in Figure 10.2 to measure the speed of Earth through the ether.']
['How does the interferometer work?', 'A light beam is split into two perpendicular paths and then recombined.']

['What else is done with the light beam?', 'Recombining the waves produces an inference pattern, with a bright fringe at the locations where the two waves arrive in phase; that is, with the crests of both waves arriving together and the troughs arriving together.']
['Are there any other patterns?', 'A dark fringe appears where the crest of one wave coincides with a trough of the other, so that the two cancel.']
['What does the cancellation represent?', 'If Earth is traveling through the ether as it orbits the sun, the peaks in one arm would take longer than in the other to reach the same location.']
['How is the interference pattern determined?', 'The places where the two waves arrive in phase would change, and the interference pattern would shift.']
['Why is this important?', 'But, using the interferometer, there was no shift seen!']
['What was the result of this?', 'This result led to two conclusions: that there is no ether and that the speed of light is the same regardless of the relative motion of source and observer.']
['What was this experiment called?', 'The Michelson–Morley investigation has been called the most famous failed experiment in history.']
['What was the experiment that was intended to test?', 'To see what Michelson and Morley expected to find when they measured the speed of light in two directions, watch this animation.']

['Did they actually measure the speed of light in a particular direction?', 'In the video, two people swimming in a lake are represented as an analogy to light beams leaving Earth as it moves through the ether (if there were any ether).']
['What was the analogy?', 'The swimmers swim away from and back to a platform that is moving through the water.']
['What did the swimmers do in relation to the platform?', 'The swimmers swim in different directions with respect to the motion of the platform.']
['How did the swims work?', 'Even though they swim equal distances at the same speed, the motion of the platform causes them to arrive at different times.']
['What are the first two postulates?', 'A radical new theory was needed, and Albert Einstein, shown in Figure 10.3, was about to become everyone’s favorite genius.']
['What were the first two postulates about?', 'Einstein began with two simple postulates based on the two things we have discussed so far in this chapter.']
['What are the four postulates?', 'The laws of physics are the same in all inertial reference frames.']
['What else?', 'The speed of light is the same in all inertial reference frames and is not affected by the speed of its source.']
['What is the speed of light?', 'The speed of light is given the symbol c and is equal to exactly 299,792,458 m/s.']
['What else should I know about the speed of light?', 'This is the speed of light in vacuum; that is, in the absence of air.']
['How does it compare to other values?', 'For most purposes, we round this number off to  $$\\(3.00\\  \\times \\ 10^{8}\\text{~m/s}\\)$$']
['What is an inertial reference frame?', 'The term inertial reference frame simply refers to a frame of reference where all objects follow Newton’s first law of motion:']
['What does the first law state?', 'Objects at rest remain at rest, and objects in motion remain in motion at a constant velocity in a straight line, unless acted upon by an external force.']
['What are some examples of inertial reference frames?', 'The inside of a car moving along a road at constant velocity and the inside of a stationary house are inertial reference frames.']
["What are some of the things that he's postulated?", 'Einstein’s postulates were carefully chosen, and they both seemed very likely to be true.']

['Was it easy to prove these things were true?', 'Einstein proceeded despite realizing that these two ideas taken together and applied to extreme conditions led to results that contradict Newtonian mechanics.']
['What did he do when the results contradicted Newtonian mechanics?', 'He just took the ball and ran with it.']
['What were the velocities in general?', 'In the traditional view, velocities are additive.']
['What is an example of adding velocities?', 'If you are running at 3 m/s and you throw a ball forward at a speed of 10 m/s, the ball should have a net speed of 13 m/s.']
['What does Einstein say about velocities?', 'However, according to relativity theory, the speed of a moving light source is not added to the speed of the emitted light.']

['What is the purpose of these postulates?', 'In addition, Einstein’s theory shows that if you were moving forward relative to Earth at nearly c (the speed of light) and could throw a ball forward at c, an observer at rest on the earth would not see the ball moving at nearly twice the speed of light.']
['What is the significance of these postulates?', 'This result conforms to both of Einstein’s postulates:']
['What else can you tell me about the Postulates?', 'The speed of light has a fixed maximum and neither reference frame is privileged.']
["What is the first step to understanding Einstein's Postulates?", 'Consider how we measure elapsed time.']
['What are different methods for measuring elapsed time?', 'One method is to use the arrival of light from the event, such as observing a light turn green to start a drag race.']
['What else is important about this method?', 'The timing will be more accurate if some sort of electronic detection is used, avoiding human reaction times and other complications.']
['What is the first of these questions?', 'Now suppose we use this method to measure the time interval between two flashes of light produced by flash lamps on a moving train.']
['How would this affect the distances?', '(See Figure 10.4)']
['What is the question?', 'A woman (observer A) is seated in the center of a rail car, with two flash lamps at opposite sides equidistant from her.']
['What does the observer see?', 'Multiple light rays that are emitted from the flash lamps move towards observer A, as shown with arrows.']
['What are the arrows?', 'A velocity vector arrow for the rail car is shown towards the right.']
['Who else is there?', 'A man (observer B) standing on the platform is facing the woman and also observes the flashes of light.']

['What are the postulates?', 'Observer A moves with the lamps on the rail car as the rail car moves towards the right of observer B. Observer B receives the light flashes simultaneously, and sees the bulbs as both having flashed at the same time.']
['What is the importance of this observation?', 'However, he sees observer A receive the flash from the right first.']
['What is the difference?', 'Because the pulse from the right reaches her first, in her frame of reference she sees the bulbs as not having flashed simultaneously.']
['How does this postulate relate to time?', 'Here, a relative velocity between observers affects whether two events at well-separated locations are observed to be simultaneous.']
['What else can you tell me about this postulate?', 'Simultaneity, or whether different events occur at the same instant, depends on the frame of reference of the observer.']
['How does this relate to motion?', 'Remember that velocity equals distance divided by time, so t = d/v.']
['What else does this mean?', 'If velocity appears to be different, then duration of time appears to be different.']
['What is your first question about the material?', 'This illustrates the power of clear thinking.']

['What did he say that illustrates the power of clear thinking?', 'We might have guessed incorrectly that, if light is emitted simultaneously, then two observers halfway between the sources would see the flashes simultaneously.']
['What did he say wrong?', 'But careful analysis shows this not to be the case.']
['What is the most important detail in this article for you?', 'Einstein was brilliant at this type of thought experiment (in German, Gedankenexperiment).']
['How was he brilliant?', 'He very carefully considered how an observation is made and disregarded what might seem obvious.']
['What was the most important thing that this article taught?', 'The validity of thought experiments, of course, is determined by actual observation.']
['What evidence did Einstein have of his genius?', 'The genius of Einstein is evidenced by the fact that experiments have repeatedly confirmed his theory of relativity.']
['How have experiments confirmed it?', 'No experiments after that of Michelson and Morley were able to detect any ether medium.']

['What else did he find?', 'We will describe later how experiments also confirmed other predictions of special relativity, such as the distance between two objects and the time interval of two events being different for two observers moving with respect to each other.']
['What are the postulates about?', 'In summary: Two events are defined to be simultaneous if an observer measures them as occurring at the same time (such as by receiving light from the events).']
['What else do you want to know about this postulate?', 'Two events are not necessarily simultaneous to all observers.']

['What are the discrepancies between Newtonian mechanics and relativity theory?', 'The discrepancies between Newtonian mechanics and relativity theory illustrate an important point about how science advances.']
["What was the difference between Einstein's theory and Newton's?", 'Einstein’s theory did not replace Newton’s but rather extended it.']
['Why did Einstein need to develop a new theory?', 'It is not unusual that a new theory must be developed to account for new information.']
['What were some theories that made this happen?', 'In most cases, the new theory is built on the foundation of older theory.']
['What else can be said about this theory?', 'It is rare that old theories are completely replaced.']

['What does the chapter cover?', 'In this chapter, you will learn about the theory of special relativity, but, as mentioned in the introduction, Einstein developed two relativity theories: special and general.']
['What does the chapter teach?', 'Table 10.1 summarizes the differences between the two theories.']
['What kind of relativistic effects are involved?', 'Consideration of the measurement of elapsed time and simultaneity leads to an important relativistic effect.']
['What is time dilation?', 'Time dilation is the phenomenon of time passing more slowly for an observer who is moving relative to another observer.']
['What is a related concept?', 'For example, suppose an astronaut measures the time it takes for light to travel from the light source, cross her ship, bounce off a mirror, and return.']
['What does that tell us?', '(See Figure 10.5.)']
['What is a possible result for the astronaut?', 'Asking this question (another thought experiment) produces a profound result.']
['What is the profound result?', 'We find that the elapsed time for a process depends on who is measuring it.']
['What is the relationship between time and distance?', 'In this case, the time measured by the astronaut is smaller than the time measured by the earth bound observer.']
['Why is that?', 'The passage of time is different for the two observers because the distance the light travels in the astronaut’s frame is smaller than in the earth bound frame.']
['What happens when we put the frames together?', 'Light travels at the same speed in each frame, and so it will take longer to travel the greater distance in the earth bound frame.']
['What was the main result of this equation?', 'Notice that when the velocity v is small compared to the speed of light c, then v/c becomes small, and $$\\(\\gamma\\)$$ becomes close to 1.']
['What happens when the velocity v is small?', 'When this happens, time measurements are the same in both frames of reference.']

['Is there any other significant aspect of this article?', 'Relativistic effects, meaning those that have to do with special relativity, usually become significant when speeds become comparable to the speed of light.']
['What is this used for?', 'This is seen to be the case for time dilation.']

['What is the relationship between these two speeds?', 'You may have seen science fiction movies in which space travelers return to Earth after a long trip to find that the planet and everyone on it has aged much more than they have.']

['What is this scenario based on?', 'This type of scenario is a based on a thought experiment, known as the twin paradox, which imagines a pair of twins, one of whom goes on a trip into space while the other stays home.']
['What happens after they return home?', 'When the space traveler returns, she finds her twin has aged much more than she.']
['What causes the paradox?', 'This happens because the traveling twin has been in two frames of reference, one leaving Earth and one returning.']
['What is the evidence?', 'Time dilation has been confirmed by comparing the time recorded by an atomic clock sent into orbit to the time recorded by a clock that remained on Earth.']
['What else is interesting about the article?', 'GPS satellites must also be adjusted to compensate for time dilation in order to give accurate positioning.']
['What is the quickest way to find a formula for v?', 'If you look ahead, you might say you have about 10 km left to go.']
['Why does it say 10 km?', 'Another traveler might say the road ahead looks like it is about 15 km long.']
['Why do they disagree?', 'If you both measured the road, however, you would agree.']
['What happens if you change the speed of the car?', 'Traveling at everyday speeds, the distance you both measure would be the same.']
['What is the relativistic speed of light?', 'You will read in this section, however, that this is not true at relativistic speeds.']
['What are relativistic speeds?', 'Close to the speed of light, distances measured are not the same when measured by different observers moving with respect to one other.']
['What did everyone agree upon?', 'One thing all observers agree upon is their relative speed.']
['What is relative speed?', 'When one observer is traveling away from another, they both see the other receding at the same speed, regardless of whose frame of reference is chosen.']
['What is speed?', 'Remember that speed equals distance divided by time: v = d/t.']
['What is distance divided by time?', 'If the observers experience a difference in elapsed time, they must also observe a difference in distance traversed.']
['Why does this have to be true?', 'This is because the ratio d/t must be the same for both observers.']

['What is the meaning of length contraction?', 'The shortening of distance experienced by an observer moving with respect to the points whose distance apart is measured is called length contraction.']
['What is proper length?', 'Proper length, L0, is the distance between two points measured in the reference frame where the observer and the points are at rest.']
['How is length contraction related to proper length?', 'The observer in motion with respect to the points measures L. These two lengths are related by the equation']
['What is a possible example of length contraction?', 'To see how length contraction is seen by a moving observer, go to this simulation.']
['Does the simulation show time dilation?', 'Here you can also see that simultaneity, time dilation, and length contraction are interrelated phenomena.']
['What is momentum?', 'In classical physics, momentum is a simple product of mass and velocity.']
['Why is that?', 'When special relativity is taken into account, objects that have mass have a speed limit.']
['What is momentum?', 'Momentum is one of the most important concepts in physics.']
['What is a notable example of momentum?', 'The broadest form of Newton’s second law is stated in terms of momentum.']
['What is the definition of conserved momentum?', 'Momentum is conserved in classical mechanics whenever the net external force on a system is zero.']
['Why is it important?', 'This makes momentum conservation a fundamental tool for analyzing collisions.']
['What is momentum used for?', 'We will see that momentum has the same importance in modern physics.']

['What is another example of momentum?', 'Relativistic momentum is conserved, and much of what we know about subatomic structure comes from the analysis of collisions of accelerator-produced relativistic particles.']

['Which of the postulates of special relativity states that the laws of physics are the', 'One of the postulates of special relativity states that the laws of physics are the same in all inertial frames.']
['Is momentum equal to the square of speed?', 'The answer is yes, provided that the momentum is defined as follows.']

['Why do we use this definition?', 'We use the mass of the object as measured at rest because we cannot determine its mass while it is moving.']

['What are some other significant aspects of this content?', 'Note that we use $$\\(\\mathbf{u}\\)$$ for velocity here to distinguish it from relative velocity $$\\(\\mathbf{v}\\)$$ between observers.']
['What else is important to know?', 'Only one observer is being considered here.']

['How does this apply to everyday life?', 'With $$\\(\\mathbf{p}\\)$$ defined in this way, $$\\(\\mathbf{p}_{\\text{tot}}\\)$$ is conserved whenever the net external force is zero, just as in classical physics.']
['What else is important about this article?', 'Again we see that the relativistic quantity becomes virtually the same as the classical at low velocities.']

['What is this mean?', 'That is, relativistic momentum $$\\(\\gamma m\\mathbf{u}\\)$$ becomes the classical $$\\(m\\mathbf{u}\\)$$ at low velocities, because $$\\(\\gamma\\)$$ is very nearly equal to 1 at low velocities.']
['What is the relation between classical momentum and relativistic momentum?', 'Relativistic momentum has the same intuitive feel as classical momentum.']
['What else is significant about relativistic momentum?', 'It is greatest for large masses moving at high velocities.']

['What is another important detail that you should be aware of?', 'Because of the factor $$\\(\\gamma,\\)$$ however, relativistic momentum behaves differently from classical momentum by approaching infinity as $$\\(\\mathbf{u}\\)$$ approaches $$\\(c\\text{.}\\)$$  (See Figure 10.7.)']
['Why is this important?', 'This is another indication that an object with mass cannot reach the speed of light.']
['Why not?', 'If it did, its momentum would become infinite, which is an unreasonable value.']
['What is the definition of momentum?', 'Relativistic momentum is defined in such a way that the conservation of momentum will hold in all inertial frames.']
['What happens in zero external force?', 'Whenever the net external force on a system is zero, relativistic momentum is conserved, just as is the case for classical momentum.']
['What is a significant fact in the article?', 'This has been verified in numerous experiments.']
['What is it about?', 'Let us summarize the calculation of relativistic effects on objects moving at speeds near the speed of light.']

['How do we define u and v?', 'We use u as the velocity of a particle or an object in one frame of reference, and v for the velocity of one frame of reference with respect to another.']
['What is the first thing you would like to know about Relativistic Energy?', 'The original source of all the energy we use is the conversion of mass into energy.']

['What is the conversion of mass into energy called?', 'Most of this energy is generated by nuclear reactions in the sun and radiated to Earth in the form of electromagnetic radiation, where it is then transformed into all the forms with which we are familiar.']
['Where else does energy originate?', 'The remaining energy from nuclear reactions is produced in nuclear power plants and in Earth’s interior.']
['What happens after energy is converted into mass?', 'In each of these cases, the source of the energy is the conversion of a small amount of mass into a large amount of energy.']
['What are some examples of energy?', 'These sources are shown in Figure 10.8.']
['What is the first postulate?', 'The first postulate of relativity states that the laws of physics are the same in all inertial frames.']
['What did Einstein find in the second postulate?', 'Einstein showed that the law of conservation of energy is valid relativistically, if we define energy to include a relativistic factor.']
['What else did he find in the second postulate?', 'The result of his analysis is that a particle or object of mass m moving at velocity u has relativistic energy given by']
['What is $[E = gamma mc2?', 'This is the expression for the total energy of an object of mass m at any speed u and includes both kinetic and potential energy.']
['How is it equal to 1?', 'Look back at the equation for $$\\(\\gamma\\)$$ and you will see that it is equal to 1 when u is 0; that is, when an object is at rest.']
['What else can you tell me about E0?', 'Then the rest energy, E0, is simply']
['Is this an interesting statement?', 'This equation is very useful to nuclear physicists because it can be used to calculate the energy released by a nuclear reaction.']
['Does it tell you what a nuclear reaction is like?', 'This is done simply by subtracting the mass of the products of such a reaction from the mass of the reactants.']
['What is the difference in the equations?', 'The difference is the m in $$\\(E_{0} = mc^{2}\\text{.}\\)$$']
['Do we need to use it to find the value of m in the equation?', 'Here is a simple example:']
['What is an antimatter?', 'A positron is a type of antimatter that is just like an electron, except that it has a positive charge.']
['Why is this important?', 'When a positron and an electron collide, their masses are completely annihilated and converted to energy in the form of gamma rays.']
['What is mc2?', 'Because both particles have a rest mass of 9.11 × 10–31 kg, we multiply the mc2 term by 2.']
['What are gamma rays?', 'So the energy of the gamma rays is']
['e) How many kilograms is the distance between Earth and the Sun?', 'where we have the expression for the joule (J) in terms of its SI base units of kg, m, and s.']
['What is the main idea of this paragraph?', 'In general, the nuclei of stable isotopes have less mass then their constituent subatomic particles.']
['What else is significant about the subatomic particles?', 'The energy equivalent of this difference is called the binding energy of the nucleus.']
['What causes the binding energy?', 'This energy is released during the formation of the isotope from its constituent particles because the product is more stable than the reactants.']
['What else can you tell me about this article?', 'Expressed as mass, it is called the mass defect.']
['What is the mass defect?', 'For example, a helium nucleus is made of two neutrons and two protons and has a mass of 4.0003 atomic mass units (u).']
['What other information can you give me about the mass defect?', 'The sum of the masses of two protons and two neutrons is 4.0330 u.']
['Does the mass defect have any significance?', 'The mass defect then is 0.0327 u. Converted to kg, the mass defect is 5.0442 × 10–30 kg.']
['What other facts do you want to know about the mass defect?', 'Multiplying this mass times c2 gives a binding energy of 4.540 × 10–12 J.']
['How important is the mass defect for the human body?', 'This does not sound like much because it is only one atom.']
['What else should I know about the mass defect?', 'If you were to make one gram of helium out of neutrons and protons, it would release 683,000,000,000 J.']
['How much energy is released from a gram of helium?', 'By comparison, burning one gram of coal releases about 24 J.']
['What does the word temperature mean?', 'It’s one of those concepts so ingrained in our everyday lives that, although we know what it means intuitively, it can be hard to define.']
['What is the definition of temperature?', 'It is tempting to say that temperature measures heat, but this is not strictly true.']
['What is heat?', 'Heat is the transfer of energy due to a temperature difference.']
['How does temperature compare to heat?', 'Temperature is defined in terms of the instrument we use to tell us how hot or cold an object is, based on a mechanism and scale invented by people.']
['What instrument do we use to tell us how hot or cold an object is?', 'Temperature is literally defined as what we measure on a thermometer.']
['what is the confusion between heat and temperature?', 'Heat is often confused with temperature.']
['how do people use the confusion to mean something?', 'For example, we may say that the heat was unbearable, when we actually mean that the temperature was high.']
['why does this cause confusion?', 'This is because we are sensitive to the flow of energy by heat, rather than the temperature.']
['what is heat?', 'Since heat, like work, transfers energy, it has the SI unit of joule (J).']
['How does the temperature change?', 'Atoms and molecules are constantly in motion, bouncing off one another in random directions.']
['What does the kinetic energy do?', 'Recall that kinetic energy is the energy of motion, and that it increases in proportion to velocity squared.']

['How does this relate to temperature?', 'Without going into mathematical detail, we can say that thermal energy—the energy associated with heat—is the average kinetic energy of the particles (molecules or atoms) in a substance.']
['How is this related to temperature?', 'Faster moving molecules have greater kinetic energies, and so the substance has greater thermal energy, and thus a higher temperature.']
['What is the internal energy?', 'The total internal energy of a system is the sum of the kinetic and potential energies of its atoms and molecules.']
['What is the thermal energy?', 'Thermal energy is one of the subcategories of internal energy, as is chemical energy.']
['How do you determine temperature?', 'To measure temperature, some scale must be used as a standard of measurement.']
['What are three popular temperature scales?', 'The three most commonly used temperature scales are the Fahrenheit, Celsius, and Kelvin scales.']
['Are the Celsius and Fahrenheit scales different?', 'Both the Fahrenheit scale and Celsius scale are relative temperature scales, meaning that they are made around a reference point.']

['What reference point does the Celsius scale use?', 'For example, the Celsius scale uses the freezing point of water as its reference point; all measurements are either lower than the freezing point of water by a given number of degrees (and have a negative sign), or higher than the freezing point of water by a given number of degrees (and have a positive sign).']
['What temperature are we talking about?', 'The boiling point of water is 100 $$\\(\\text{°C}\\)$$  for the Celsius scale, and its unit is the degree Celsius  (°C(°C(°C ).']
['What are some key aspects of the article?', 'On the Fahrenheit scale, the freezing point of water is at 32 $$\\(\\text{°F}\\)$$, and the boiling point is at 212 $$\\(\\text{°F}\\)$$ .']
['What is the unit of temperature used in this scale?', 'The unit of temperature on this scale is the degree Fahrenheit  (°F(°F(°F ).']
['What is the Celsius scale?', 'Note that the difference in degrees between the freezing and boiling points is greater for the Fahrenheit scale than for the Celsius scale.']
['Does this have an impact on the meaning of temperature?', 'Therefore, a temperature difference of one degree Celsius is greater than a temperature difference of one degree Fahrenheit.']

['What else is interesting about this article?', 'Since 100 Celsius degrees span the same range as 180 Fahrenheit degrees, one degree on the Celsius scale is 1.8 times larger than one degree on the Fahrenheit scale (because  $$\\(\\frac{180}{100} = \\frac{9}{5} = 1.8\\)$$ ).']
['What is the use of this information?', 'This relationship can be used to convert between temperatures in Fahrenheit and Celsius (see Figure 11.2).']
['What is the Kelvin scale?', 'The Kelvin scale is the temperature scale that is commonly used in science because it is an absolute temperature scale.']
['What does the Kelvin scale mean?', 'This means that the theoretically lowest-possible temperature is assigned the value of zero.']
['What is zero degrees?', 'Zero degrees on the Kelvin scale is known as absolute zero; it is theoretically the point at which there is no molecular motion to produce thermal energy.']
['How does Kelvin use the scale?', 'On the original Kelvin scale first created by Lord Kelvin, all temperatures have positive values, making it useful for scientific work.']
['What is the unit on the scale?', 'The official temperature unit on this scale is the kelvin, which is abbreviated as K.']
['What are some of the important points on the scale?', 'The freezing point of water is 273.15 K, and the boiling point of water is 373.15 K.']
['What is a factor in temperature?', 'Although absolute zero is possible in theory, it cannot be reached in practice.']

['What is the lowest temperature ever created and measured?', 'The lowest temperature ever created and measured during a laboratory experiment was  $$\\(1.0 \\times 10^{- 10}\\)$$  K, at Helsinki University of Technology in Finland.']

['What else can you tell me about the lowest temperature?', 'In comparison, the coldest recorded temperature for a place on Earth’s surface was 183 K (–89 \t°C), at Vostok, Antarctica, and the coldest known place (outside the lab) in the universe is the Boomerang Nebula, with a temperature of 1 K. Luckily, most of us humans will never have to experience such extremes.']

["What's something interesting you found?", 'While the Fahrenheit scale is still the most commonly used scale in the United States, the majority of the world uses Celsius, and scientists prefer Kelvin.']
['What are the differences between these two?', 'It’s often necessary to convert between these scales.']
['What was the result of this study?', 'For instance, if the TV meteorologist gave the local weather report in kelvins, there would likely be some confused viewers!']
['What else did you find out about this?', 'Table 11.1 gives the equations for conversion between the three temperature scales.']

['What is a heat transfer?', 'If two objects at different temperatures are brought in contact with each other, energy is transferred from the hotter object (that is, the object with the greater temperature) to the colder (lower temperature) object, until both objects are at the same temperature.']

['What is the effect on both objects?', 'There is no net heat transfer once the temperatures are equal because the amount of heat transferred from one object to the other is the same as the amount of heat returned.']
['What else can you tell me about heat transfers?', 'One of the major effects of heat transfer is temperature change: Heating increases the temperature while cooling decreases it.']

['What else can you tell me about heat transfers?', 'Experiments show that the heat transferred to or from a substance depends on three factors—the change in the substance’s temperature, the mass of the substance, and certain physical properties related to the phase of the substance.']
['What is the formula for $$[Q = mcDel', 'where m is the mass of the substance and ΔT is the change in its temperature, in units of Celsius or Kelvin.']
['What is c', 'The symbol c stands for specific heat, and depends on the material and phase.']
['What is specific heat?', 'The specific heat is the amount of heat necessary to change the temperature of 1.00 kg of mass by 1.00 ºC.']

['Can you give me some more information about specific heat?', 'The specific heat c is a property of the substance; its SI unit is J/(kg $$\\(\\cdot\\)$$ K) or J/(kg $$\\(\\cdot\\)$$ $$\\(\\text{°C}\\)$$ ).']
['What else does the formula mean?', 'The temperature change ( $$\\(\\Delta T\\)$$ ) is the same in units of kelvins and degrees Celsius (but not degrees Fahrenheit).']
['Is there any other interesting information in the article?', 'Specific heat is closely related to the concept of heat capacity.']
['What is heat capacity?', 'Heat capacity is the amount of heat necessary to change the temperature of a substance by 1.00 $$\\(\\text{°C}\\)$$ .']
['What is the equation of heat capacity?', 'In equation form, heat capacity C is  $$\\(C = mc\\)$$, where m is mass and c is specific heat.']
['What else is significant about the equation?', 'Note that heat capacity is the same as specific heat, but without any dependence on mass.']

['Are there other significant differences between specific heat and heat capacity?', 'Consequently, two objects made up of the same material but with different masses will have different heat capacities.']
['How is this different from specific heat?', 'This is because the heat capacity is a property of an object, but specific heat is a property of any object made of the same material.']
['What else is the title of our study material about?', 'Values of specific heat must be looked up in tables, because there is no simple way to calculate them.']
['Is there a table?', 'Table 11.2 gives the values of specific heat for a few substances as a handy reference.']

['What is this table used for?', 'We see from this table that the specific heat of water is five times that of glass, which means that it takes five times as much heat to raise the temperature of 1 kg of water than to raise the temperature of 1 kg of glass by the same number of degrees.']
['What causes heat transfer?', 'Whenever there is a temperature difference, heat transfer occurs.']
['How is heat transfer used?', 'Heat transfer may happen rapidly, such as through a cooking pan, or slowly, such as through the walls of an insulated cooler.']
['What is conduction, convection, and radiation?', 'There are three different heat transfer methods: conduction, convection, and radiation.']
['How are all three methods interrelated?', 'At times, all three may happen simultaneously.']
['What other information do we need to know about this?', 'See Figure 11.3.']
['what is conduction?', 'Conduction is heat transfer through direct physical contact.']
['what is a common example?', 'Heat transferred between the electric burner of a stove and the bottom of a pan is transferred by conduction.']
['What else can you tell me about conduction?', 'Sometimes, we try to control the conduction of heat to make ourselves more comfortable.']

['what is the example?', 'Since the rate of heat transfer is different for different materials, we choose fabrics, such as a thick wool sweater, that slow down the transfer of heat away from our bodies in winter.']
['What was your first question?', 'As you walk barefoot across the living room carpet, your feet feel relatively comfortable…until you step onto the kitchen’s tile floor.']
['What does this tell you?', 'This is explained by different rates of heat transfer:']
['Why does the tile floor feel colder?', 'The tile material removes heat from your skin at a greater rate than the carpeting, which makes it feel colder.']
['What does conduction mean?', 'Some materials simply conduct thermal energy faster than others.']

['What kinds of materials are good conductors?', 'In general, metals (like copper, aluminum, gold, and silver) are good heat conductors, whereas materials like wood, plastic, and rubber are poor heat conductors.']
['What is the first figure in the section?', 'Figure 11.4 shows particles (either atoms or molecules) in two bodies at different temperatures.']
['What is the difference in temperature between the two bodies?', 'The (average) kinetic energy of a particle in the hot body is higher than in the colder body.']
['Why does it have more kinetic energy?', 'If two particles collide, energy transfers from the particle with greater kinetic energy to the particle with less kinetic energy.']
['Does heat transfer?', 'When two bodies are in contact, many particle collisions occur, resulting in a net flux of heat from the higher-temperature body to the lower-temperature body.']
['How is the heat flux calculated?', 'The heat flux depends on the temperature difference  $$\\(\\Delta T = T_{\\text{hot}} - T_{\\text{cold}}\\)$$ .']
['Do you have any other important information about the section?', 'Therefore, you will get a more severe burn from boiling water than from hot tap water.']
['what is convection?', 'Convection is heat transfer by the movement of a fluid.']
['where does this happen?', 'This type of heat transfer happens, for example, in a pot boiling on the stove, or in thunderstorms, where hot air rises up to the base of the clouds.']
['What did you learn about conduction?', 'As the temperature of fluids increase, they expand and become less dense.']
['What did you do for an example?', 'For example, Figure 11.4 could represent the wall of a balloon with different temperature gases inside the balloon than outside in the environment.']
['What happens to the balloon?', 'The hotter and thus faster moving gas particles inside the balloon strike the surface with more force than the cooler air outside, causing the balloon to expand.']
['Does it have any additional effects?', 'This decrease in density relative to its environment creates buoyancy (the tendency to rise).']
['What else did you learn about buoyancy?', 'Convection is driven by buoyancy—hot air rises because it is less dense than the surrounding air.']
['What are convection and radiation?', 'Sometimes, we control the temperature of our homes or ourselves by controlling air movement.']
['How do we control air movement?', 'Sealing leaks around doors with weather stripping keeps out the cold wind in winter.']
['What are some examples of air movement?', 'The house in Figure 11.5 and the pot of water on the stove in Figure 11.6 are both examples of convection and buoyancy by human design.']

['What are some natural examples of convection?', 'Ocean currents and large-scale atmospheric circulation transfer energy from one part of the globe to another, and are examples of natural convection.']
['What is Radiation?', 'Radiation is a form of heat transfer that occurs when electromagnetic radiation is emitted or absorbed.']

['What type of radiation is involved in this form of heat transfer?', 'Electromagnetic radiation includes radio waves, microwaves, infrared radiation, visible light, ultraviolet radiation, X-rays, and gamma rays, all of which have different wavelengths and amounts of energy (shorter wavelengths have higher frequency and more energy).']
['How is heat transferred?', 'You can feel the heat transfer from a fire and from the sun.']
['Is there another example of heat transfer?', 'Similarly, you can sometimes tell that the oven is hot without touching its door or looking inside—it may just warm you as you walk by.']

['Do other sources of heat transfer exist?', 'Another example is thermal radiation from the human body; people are constantly emitting infrared radiation, which is not visible to the human eye, but is felt as heat.']

['What is radiation?', 'Radiation is the only method of heat transfer where no medium is required, meaning that the heat doesn’t need to come into direct contact with or be transported by any matter.']
['Why is that?', 'The space between Earth and the sun is largely empty, without any possibility of heat transfer by convection or conduction.']
['What does the heat transfer?', 'Instead, heat is transferred by radiation, and Earth is warmed as it absorbs electromagnetic radiation emitted by the sun.']
['What does radiation include?', 'All objects absorb and emit electromagnetic radiation (see Figure 11.7).']
['What else did you learn about radiation?', 'The rate of heat transfer by radiation depends mainly on the color of the object.']
['What color object do you prefer for radiation?', 'Black is the most effective absorber and radiator, and white is the least effective.']
['What other things can you tell me about radiation?', 'People living in hot climates generally avoid wearing black clothing, for instance.']
['What else did you learn about radiation?', 'Similarly, black asphalt in a parking lot will be hotter than adjacent patches of grass on a summer day, because black absorbs better than green.']
['What is the opposite of black for radiation?', 'The reverse is also true—black radiates better than green.']
['What else are you learning about radiation?', 'On a clear summer night, the black asphalt will be colder than the green patch of grass, because black radiates energy faster than green.']
["What color object can't absorb radiation?", 'In contrast, white is a poor absorber and also a poor radiator.']
['What other information can you give me?', 'A white object reflects nearly all radiation, like a mirror.']
['What has the course taught you so far?', 'So far, we have learned that adding thermal energy by heat increases the temperature of a substance.']
['What else did you learn in the lesson?', 'But surprisingly, there are situations where adding energy does not change the temperature of a substance at all!']
['What happens to the substance when it does not change temperature?', 'Instead, the additional thermal energy acts to loosen bonds between molecules or atoms and causes a phase change.']

['What else do you think about this process?', 'Because this energy enters or leaves a system during a phase change without causing a temperature change in the system, it is known as latent heat (latent means hidden).']
['What are the three phases of matter?', 'The three phases of matter that you frequently encounter are solid, liquid and gas (see Figure 11.8).']

['What is the difference between solid and liquid?', 'Solid has the least energetic state; atoms in solids are in close contact, with forces between them that allow the particles to vibrate but not change position with neighboring particles.']
['What can you tell me about the particles?', '(These forces can be thought of as springs that can be stretched or compressed, but not easily broken.)']
['What is the state of gas?', 'Gas has a more energetic state than liquid, in which particles are broken free of their bonds.']
['How is that related to distances?', 'Particles in gases are separated by distances that are large compared with the size of the particles.']
["What's the most energetic state of all?", 'The most energetic state of all is plasma.']

['How is plasma different from liquid?', 'Although you may not have heard much about plasma, it is actually the most common state of matter in the universe—stars are made up of plasma, as is lightning.']
['What makes up the plasma state?', 'The plasma state is reached by heating a gas to the point where particles are pulled apart, separating the electrons from the rest of the particle.']
['What is an ionized gas?', 'This produces an ionized gas that is a combination of the negatively charged free electrons and positively charged ions, known as plasma.']
['what does the melting point refer to', 'Energy is required to melt a solid because the bonds between the particles in the solid must be broken.']

['what is the temperature of melted solid', 'Since the energy involved in a phase changes is used to break bonds, there is no increase in the kinetic energies of the particles, and therefore no rise in temperature.']
['what happens when you boil water', 'Similarly, energy is needed to vaporize a liquid to overcome the attractive forces between particles in the liquid.']
['what is the temperature of an empty container', 'There is no temperature change until a phase change is completed.']
['what is the temperature of soda?', 'The temperature of a cup of soda and ice that is initially at 0 $$\\(\\text{°C}\\)$$  stays at 0 $$\\(\\text{°C}\\)$$  until all of the ice has melted.']
['what happens when a liquid freezes', 'In the reverse of these processes—freezing and condensation—energy is released from the latent heat (see Figure 11.9).']
['What is the value of q?', 'where  $$\\(L_{f}\\)$$  is the latent heat of fusion, and  $$\\(L_{v}\\)$$  is the latent heat of vaporization.']
['What is the Latent heat of fusion?', 'The latent heat of fusion is the amount of heat needed to cause a phase change between solid and liquid.']
['What is the Latent heat of vaporization?', 'The latent heat of vaporization is the amount of heat needed to cause a phase change between liquid and gas.']

['What is the unit for J/kg?', '$$\\(L_{f}\\)$$  and  $$\\(L_{v}\\)$$  are coefficients that vary from substance to substance, depending on the strength of intermolecular forces, and both have standard units of J/kg.']
['What are some examples of heat transfer coefficient?', 'See Table 11.3 for values of  $$\\(L_{f}\\)$$  and  $$\\(L_{v}\\)$$  of different substances.']
['How did you get there?', 'Let’s consider the example of adding heat to ice to examine its transitions through all three phases—solid to liquid to gas.']
['What else is important?', 'A phase diagram indicating the temperature changes of water as energy is added is shown in Figure 11.10.']

['Why is this diagram important?', 'The ice starts out at −20 $$\\(\\text{°C}\\)$$, and its temperature rises linearly, absorbing heat at a constant rate until it reaches 0 $$\\(\\text{°}\\text{.}\\)$$']
['What else is interesting?', 'Once at this temperature, the ice gradually melts, absorbing 334 kJ/kg.']
['What happens while the ice melts?', 'The temperature remains constant at 0 $$\\(\\text{°C}\\)$$  during this phase change.']
['Does the ice then go back to solid?', 'Once all the ice has melted, the temperature of the liquid water rises, absorbing heat at a new constant rate.']
['Does the water boil?', 'At 100 $$\\(\\text{°C}\\)$$, the water begins to boil and the temperature again remains constant while the water absorbs 2256 kJ/kg during this phase change.']
['What happens after the water boils?', 'When all the liquid has become steam, the temperature rises again at a constant rate.']
['Why is vaporization important?', 'We have seen that vaporization requires heat transfer to a substance from its surroundings.']
['What is condensation?', 'Condensation is the reverse process, where heat in transferred away from a substance to its surroundings.']
['Does condensation increase temperature?', 'This release of latent heat increases the temperature of the surroundings.']
['Can we remove heat?', 'Energy must be removed from the condensing particles to make a vapor condense.']
['Is condensation always on cold surfaces?', 'This is why condensation occurs on cold surfaces: the heat transfers energy away from the warm vapor to the cold surface.']

['How does the energy get transferred?', 'The energy is exactly the same as that required to cause the phase change in the other direction, from liquid to vapor, and so it can be calculated from  $$\\(Q = mL_{v}\\)$$ .']
['Can you also calculate latent heat?', 'Latent heat is also released into the environment when a liquid freezes, and can be calculated from  $$\\(Q = mL_{f}\\)$$ .']

['What type of heat?', 'We learned in the previous chapter that when two objects (or systems) are in contact with one another, heat will transfer thermal energy from the object at higher temperature to the one at lower temperature until they both reach the same temperature.']
['What happens when they reach the same temperature?', 'The objects are then in thermal equilibrium, and no further temperature changes will occur if they are isolated from other systems.']
['Why is that?', 'The systems interact and change because their temperatures are different, and the changes stop once their temperatures are the same.']

['What is the basic meaning of thermal equilibrium?', 'Thermal equilibrium is established when two bodies are in thermal contact with each other—meaning heat transfer (i.e., the transfer of energy by heat) can occur between them.']
['What else can happen with thermal equilibrium?', 'If two systems cannot freely exchange energy, they will not reach thermal equilibrium.']

['What is an example of thermal equilibrium?', '(It is fortunate that empty space stands between Earth and the sun, because a state of thermal equilibrium with the sun would be too toasty for life on this planet!)']

['What is this theorem about?', 'If two systems, A and B, are in thermal equilibrium with each another, and B is in thermal equilibrium with a third system, C, then A is also in thermal equilibrium with C.']
['What is thermodynamics?', 'This statement may seem obvious, because all three have the same temperature, but it is basic to thermodynamics.']
['What is this theorem?', 'It is called the zeroth law of thermodynamics.']

['Which one is the oldest?', 'The explanation is that this law was discovered after the first and second laws of thermodynamics but is so fundamental that scientists decided it should logically come first.']
['What is the zeroth law?', 'As an example of the zeroth law in action, consider newborn babies in neonatal intensive-care units in hospitals.']
['What kinds of units?', 'Prematurely born or sick newborns are placed in special incubators.']
['What else is special about the incubators?', 'These babies have very little covering while in the incubators, so to an observer, they look as though they may not be warm enough.']
['Why is that?', 'However, inside the incubator, the temperature of the air, the cot, and the baby are all the same—that is, they are in thermal equilibrium.']
['What happens in a thermal equilibrium?', 'The ambient temperature is just high enough to keep the baby safe and comfortable.']
['What are they studying next?', 'Before covering the first law of thermodynamics, it is first important to understand the relationship between pressure, volume, and temperature.']
['What is pressure?', 'Pressure, P, is defined as']
['What is pressure used for?', 'Pressure is defined for all states of matter but is particularly important when discussing fluids (such as air).']

['What is pressure used for?', 'You have probably heard the word pressure being used in relation to blood (high or low blood pressure) and in relation to the weather (high- and low-pressure weather systems).']
['What is pressure used for?', 'These are only two of many examples of pressures in fluids.']
['What is the ideal gas law?', 'The relationship between the pressure, volume, and temperature for an ideal gas is given by the ideal gas law.']
['What is an ideal gas?', 'A gas is considered ideal at low pressure and fairly high temperature, and forces between its component particles can be ignored.']
['What does the ideal gas law state?', 'The ideal gas law states that']

['What is the relationship between P and V?', 'where P is the pressure of a gas, V is the volume it occupies, N is the number of particles (atoms or molecules) in the gas, and T is its absolute temperature.']
['What is the Boltzmann constant?', 'The constant k is called the Boltzmann constant and has the value  $$\\(k = 1.38 \\times 10^{-23}\\text{J/K}\\text{,}\\)$$']
['Can you tell me more about the ideal gas law?', 'For the purposes of this chapter, we will not go into calculations using the ideal gas law.']
['What is the best way to calculate the gas permeability?', 'Instead, it is important for us to notice from the equation that the following are true for a given mass of gas:']
['What is the inverse relationship between temperature and volume?', 'When volume is constant, pressure is directly proportional to temperature.']
['What is the inverse relationship between temperature and volume?', 'When temperature is constant, pressure is inversely proportional to volume.']
['What is the inverse relationship between volume and pressure?', 'When pressure is constant, volume is directly proportional to temperature.']
['What else is included in the information for this unit?', 'This last point describes thermal expansion—the change in size or volume of a given mass with temperature.']
['What is it an effect of?', 'An increase in temperature means that there’s an increase in the kinetic energy of the individual atoms.']

['What is an effect of temperature?', 'Gases are especially affected by thermal expansion, although liquids expand to a lesser extent with similar increases in temperature, and even solids have minor expansions at higher temperatures.']
['What else does the information include?', 'This is why railroad tracks and bridges have expansion joints that allow them to freely expand and contract with temperature changes.']
['What is the next question?', 'To get some idea of how pressure, temperature, and volume of a gas are related to one another, consider what happens when you pump air into a deflated tire.']

['What is the relationship between the temperature and pressure of air?', 'The tire’s volume first increases in direct proportion to the amount of air injected, without much increase in the tire pressure.']
['What else is important to know?', 'Once the tire has expanded to nearly its full size, the walls limit volume expansion.']
['What happens after that?', 'If you continue to pump air into tire (which now has a nearly constant volume), the pressure increases with increasing temperature (see Figure 12.4).']
['What is Pressure–Volume Work?', 'Pressure–volume work is the work that is done by the compression or expansion of a fluid.']
['What are the conditions that produce Pressure–Volume Work?', 'Whenever there is a change in volume and external pressure remains constant, pressure–volume work is taking place.']
['What does compression do to the fluid?', 'During a compression, a decrease in volume increases the internal pressure of a system as work is done on the system.']
['What does expansion do to the fluid?', 'During an expansion (Figure 12.5), an increase in volume decreases the internal pressure of a system as the system does work.']
['What does the formula for pressure volume work mean?', 'Recall that the formula for work is  $$\\(W = Fd.\\)$$']
['What are the pressure and volume formulas?', 'We can rearrange the definition of pressure,  $$\\(P = \\frac{F}{A},\\)$$  to get an expression for force in terms of pressure.']
['What is work?', 'Just as we say that work is force acting over a distance, for fluids, we can say that work is the pressure acting through the change in volume.']
['What does pressure mean?', 'For pressure–volume work, pressure is analogous to force, and volume is analogous to distance in the traditional definition of work.']
['What is it about?', 'Heat (Q) and work (W) are the two ways to add or remove energy from a system.']
['What are they?', 'The processes are very different.']
['What are they different for?', 'Heat is driven by temperature differences, while work involves a force exerted through a distance.']
['Does that matter?', 'Nevertheless, heat and work can produce identical results.']
['How can they do that?', 'For example, both can cause a temperature increase.']
['What else do you know about heat?', 'Heat transfers energy into a system, such as when the sun warms the air in a bicycle tire and increases the air’s temperature.']
['What else do you know about work?', 'Similarly, work can be done on the system, as when the bicyclist pumps air into the tire.']
['Does that mean the temperature of the tire would be higher?', 'Once the temperature increase has occurred, it is impossible to tell whether it was caused by heat or work.']
['What else is significant?', 'Heat and work are both energy in transit—neither is stored as such in a system.']
['How do they affect the system?', 'However, both can change the internal energy, U, of a system.']
['What is internal energy?', 'Internal energy is the sum of the kinetic and potential energies of a system’s atoms and molecules.']

['What else can you tell me about internal energy?', 'It can be divided into many subcategories, such as thermal and chemical energy, and depends only on the state of a system (that is, P, V, and T), not on how the energy enters or leaves the system.']
['What is the first law of thermodynamics?', 'In order to understand the relationship between heat, work, and internal energy, we use the first law of thermodynamics.']

['What does this law mean?', 'The first law of thermodynamics applies the conservation of energy principle to systems where heat and work are the methods of transferring energy into and out of the systems.']
['What else does it tell us?', 'It can also be used to describe how energy transferred by heat is converted and transferred again by work.']

['What does The First Law of Thermodynamics state?', 'The first law of thermodynamics states that the change in internal energy of a closed system equals the net heat transfer into the system minus the net work done by the system.']
['Is there an equation in The First Law of thermodynamics?', 'In equation form, the first law of thermodynamics is']
['What is this about?', 'Here,  $$\\(\\Delta U\\)$$ is the change in internal energy, U, of the system.']
['What is Q?', 'As shown in Figure 12.6, Q is the net heat transferred into the system—that is, Q is the sum of all heat transfers into and out of the system.']
['What is W?', 'W is the net work done by the system—that is, W is the sum of all work done on or by the system.']
['What is the convention?', 'By convention, if Q is positive, then there is a net heat transfer into the system; if W is positive, then there is net work done by the system.']
['What else did you learn about this article?', 'So positive Q adds energy to the system by heat, and positive W takes energy from the system by work.']
['Is this all?', 'Note that if heat transfers more energy into the system than that which is done by work, the difference is stored as internal energy.']
['What is Entropy?', 'Recall from the chapter introduction that it is not even theoretically possible for engines to be 100 percent efficient.']
['How is that possible?', 'This phenomenon is explained by the second law of thermodynamics, which relies on a concept known as entropy.']
['What does entropy mean?', 'Entropy is a measure of the disorder of a system.']
['What does it describe?', 'Entropy also describes how much energy is not available to do work.']
