['How does it work?', "The more disordered a system and higher the entropy, the less of a system's energy is available to do work."]
['What is one important fact that you learned in your reading?', 'Although all forms of energy can be used to do work, it is not possible to use the entire available energy for work.']

['What does this mean?', 'Consequently, not all energy transferred by heat can be converted into work, and some of it is lost in the form of waste heat—that is, heat that does not go toward doing work.']
['What else is important in the reading?', 'The unavailability of energy is important in thermodynamics; in fact, the field originated from efforts to convert heat to work, as is done by engines.']
['How does Q interact with temperature?', 'Q is positive for energy transferred into the system by heat and negative for energy transferred out of the system by heat.']
['What is entropy?', 'In SI, entropy is expressed in units of joules per kelvin (J/K).']

['Is there anything else interesting in this section?', 'If temperature changes during the process, then it is usually a good approximation (for small changes in temperature) to take T to be the average temperature in order to avoid trickier math (calculus).']

["Have you ever heard someone say something like, 'There is no way to know if", 'If so, you have been on the receiving end of a practical joke and, in the process, learned a valuable lesson about the nature of the universe as described by the second law of thermodynamics.']
['What are 52 pickup and why did they make this joke?', 'In the game of 52 pickup, the prankster tosses an entire deck of playing cards onto the floor, and you get to pick them up.']

['How do you know if it is true that the cards are still alive?', 'In the process of picking up the cards, you may have noticed that the amount of work required to restore the cards to an orderly state in the deck is much greater than the amount of work required to toss the cards and create the disorder.']

['What is the Second law of thermodynamics?', 'The second law of thermodynamics states that the total entropy of a system either increases or remains constant in any spontaneous process; it never decreases.']
['Why is that?', 'An important implication of this law is that heat transfers energy spontaneously from higher- to lower-temperature objects, but never spontaneously in the reverse direction.']
['Why is that?', 'This is because entropy increases for heat transfer of energy from hot to cold (Figure 12.9).']
['Is there any other important information?', 'Because the change in entropy is Q/T, there is a larger change in  $$\\(\\Delta S\\)$$  at lower temperatures (smaller T).']

['Is there anything else important?', 'The decrease in entropy of the hot (larger T) object is therefore less than the increase in entropy of the cold (smaller T) object, producing an overall increase in entropy for the system.']
['What is this theorem?', 'Another way of thinking about this is that it is impossible for any process to have, as its sole result, heat transferring energy from a cooler to a hotter object.']
['Why is it impossible?', 'Heat cannot transfer energy spontaneously from colder to hotter, because the entropy of the overall system would decrease.']

['How does this theory apply to water?', 'Suppose we mix equal masses of water that are originally at two different temperatures, say  $$\\(\\text{20}\\text{.0~°C}\\)$$  and  $$\\(\\text{40}\\text{.0~°C}\\)$$ .']
['What will happen when the two temperatures are combined?', 'The result will be water at an intermediate temperature of  $$\\(\\text{30}\\text{.0~°C}\\)$$ .']
['What else is significant about this process?', 'Three outcomes have resulted: entropy has increased, some energy has become unavailable to do work, and the system has become less orderly.']
['How is this relevant?', 'Let us think about each of these results.']

['What are the other questions you have to answer?', 'Mixing the two bodies of water has the same effect as the heat transfer of energy from the higher-temperature substance to the lower-temperature substance.']
['What is heat transfer?', 'The mixing decreases the entropy of the hotter water but increases the entropy of the colder water by a greater amount, producing an overall increase in entropy.']
['What are two aspects of the second law?', 'Second, once the two masses of water are mixed, there is no more temperature difference left to drive energy transfer by heat and therefore to do work.']
['What happens when the temperature difference is gone?', 'The energy is still in the water, but it is now unavailable to do work.']
['Why is it harder to combine things?', 'Third, the mixture is less orderly, or to use another term, less structured.']

['How is that beneficial?', 'Rather than having two masses at different temperatures and with different distributions of molecular speeds, we now have a single mass with a broad distribution of molecular speeds, the average of which yields an intermediate temperature.']

['What are three things the second law of thermodynamics talks about?', 'These three results—entropy, unavailability of energy, and disorder—not only are related but are, in fact, essentially equivalent.']

['What else is related to the three results?', 'Heat transfer of energy from hot to cold is related to the tendency in nature for systems to become disordered and for less energy to be available for use as work.']
['What does this law tell us?', 'A cold object in contact with a hot one never spontaneously transfers energy by heat to the hot object, getting colder while the hot object gets hotter.']
['Does the second law tell us anything else?', 'Nor does a hot, stationary automobile ever spontaneously cool off and start moving.']
['What are some examples of the second law?', 'Another example is the expansion of a puff of gas introduced into one corner of a vacuum chamber.']
['What happens to the gas when it is introduced into the corner?', 'The gas expands to fill the chamber, but it never regroups on its own in the corner.']
['How does the gas never regroup?', 'The random motion of the gas molecules could take them all back to the corner, but this is never observed to happen (Figure 12.10).']
['what did you have to say about heat?', "We've explained that heat never transfers energy spontaneously from a colder to a hotter object."]
["what's the problem with that?", 'The key word here is spontaneously.']
['what is your answer?', 'If we do work on a system, it is possible to transfer energy by heat from a colder to hotter object.']
["what's the next topic?", "We'll learn more about this in the next section, covering refrigerators as one of the applications of the laws of thermodynamics."]
['What is the law about?', 'Sometimes people misunderstand the second law of thermodynamics, thinking that based on this law, it is impossible for entropy to decrease at any particular location.']
['What do you mean?', 'But, it actually is possible for the entropy of one part of the universe to decrease, as long as the total change in entropy of the universe increases.']
['What is an equation?', 'In equation form, we can write this as']
['What else is the equation describing?', 'Energy transfer is necessary.']
['How is it applied in the real world?', 'If you pick up marbles that are scattered about the room and put them into a cup, your work has decreased the entropy of that system.']
['Can you explain another example?', 'If you gather iron ore from the ground and convert it into steel and build a bridge, your work has decreased the entropy of that system.']
['Are there other examples?', 'Energy coming from the sun can decrease the entropy of local systems on Earth—that is,  $$\\(\\Delta S_{\\text{syst}}\\)$$  is negative.']
['What happens?', 'But the overall entropy of the rest of the universe increases by a greater amount—that is,  $$\\(\\Delta S_{\\text{envir}}\\)$$  is positive and greater in magnitude.']
['What does this mean?', 'In the case of the iron ore, although you made the system of the bridge and steel more structured, you did so at the expense of the universe.']
['What else do you find interesting?', 'Altogether, the entropy of the universe is increased by the disorder created by digging up the ore and converting it to steel.']
['Do we have any other explanation?', 'Therefore,']

['What is the relationship among the two sides of a right-angled triangle according to the Py', 'Every time a plant stores some solar energy in the form of chemical potential energy, or an updraft of warm air lifts a soaring bird, Earth experiences local decreases in entropy as it uses part of the energy transfer from the sun into deep space to do work.']
['How does a decrease in entropy result?', 'There is a large total increase in entropy resulting from this massive energy transfer.']
['Why does the world still gain entropy?', 'A small part of this energy transfer by heat is stored in structured systems on Earth, resulting in much smaller, local decreases in entropy.']
['What is entropy?', 'Entropy is related not only to the unavailability of energy to do work; it is also a measure of disorder.']

['What else did you find interesting?', 'For example, in the case of a melting block of ice, a highly structured and orderly system of water molecules changes into a disorderly liquid, in which molecules have no fixed positions (Figure 12.11).']
['What are the results of this change in entropy?', "There is a large increase in entropy for this process, as we'll see in the following worked example."]
["What's a heat engine?", 'A heat engine does exactly this—it makes use of the properties of thermodynamics to transform heat into work.']
['What types of heat engines are there?', 'Gasoline and diesel engines, jet engines, and steam turbines that generate electricity are all examples of heat engines.']
['What are the other details of this material?', 'Figure 12.13 illustrates one of the ways in which heat transfers energy to do work.']
['What is the way in which heat transfers energy to do work?', 'Fuel combustion releases chemical energy that heat transfers throughout the gas in a cylinder.']
['What else is happening in the cylinder?', 'This increases the gas temperature, which in turn increases the pressure of the gas and, therefore, the force it exerts on a movable piston.']
['What happens with the force?', 'The gas does work on the outside world, as this force moves the piston through some distance.']
['What happens after the piston moves?', 'Thus, heat transfer of energy to the gas in the cylinder results in work being done.']
['What are the piston and rod in a reciprocating engine?', 'To repeat this process, the piston needs to be returned to its starting point.']

['What happens at the starting point?', 'Heat now transfers energy from the gas to the surroundings, so that the gas’s pressure decreases, and a force is exerted by the surroundings to push the piston back through some distance.']
['What does the cyclical process refer to?', 'A cyclical process brings a system, such as the gas in a cylinder, back to its original state at the end of every cycle.']
['Do all heat engines use cyclical processes?', 'All heat engines use cyclical processes.']
['What do they use heat for?', 'Heat engines do work by using part of the energy transferred by heat from some source.']

['How does it work?', 'As shown in Figure 12.14, heat transfers energy,  $$\\(Q_{\\text{h}}\\)$$, from the high-temperature object (or hot reservoir), whereas heat transfers unused energy,  $$\\(Q_{\\text{c}}\\)$$, into the low-temperature object (or cold reservoir), and the work done by the engine is W.']
['What does the reservoir mean?', 'In physics, a reservoir is defined as an infinitely large mass that can take in or put out an unlimited amount of heat, depending upon the needs of the system.']
['What is the temperature of the hot reservoir?', 'The temperature of the hot reservoir is  $$\\(T_{\\text{h}}\\text{,}\\)$$  and the temperature of the cold reservoir is  $$\\(T_{\\text{c}}\\)$$ .']
['What is a cyclical process?', 'As noted, a cyclical process brings the system back to its original condition at the end of every cycle.']
['What happens at the end of every cycle?', 'Such a system’s internal energy, U, is the same at the beginning and end of every cycle—that is,  $$\\(\\Delta U = 0\\)$$ .']

['How is the internal energy determined?', 'The first law of thermodynamics states that  $$\\(\\Delta U = Q - W\\text{,}\\)$$  where Q is the net heat transfer during the cycle, and W is the net work done by the system.']

['What is the net heat transfer?', 'The net heat transfer is the energy transferred in by heat from the hot reservoir minus the amount that is transferred out to the cold reservoir ( $$\\(Q = Q_{\\text{h}} - Q_{\\text{c}}\\)$$ ).']
['What does this mean?', 'Because there is no change in internal energy for a complete cycle ( $$\\(\\Delta U = 0\\)$$ ), we have']
['What was the cyclical process?', 'Because the hot reservoir is heated externally, which is an energy-intensive process, it is important that the work be done as efficiently as possible.']
['What else was interesting about this section?', 'In fact, we want W to equal  $$\\(Q_{\\text{h}}\\)$$, and for there to be no heat to the environment (that is,  $$\\(Q_{\\text{c}} = 0\\)$$ ).']
['Is this what you actually want?', 'Unfortunately, this is impossible.']
['Is there a reason why this is impossible?', 'According to the second law of thermodynamics, heat engines cannot have perfect conversion of heat into work.']
['Why is that?', 'Recall that entropy is a measure of the disorder of a system, which is also how much energy is unavailable to do work.']
['Are there any other important points in the article?', 'The second law of thermodynamics requires that the total entropy of a system either increases or remains constant in any process.']
['Is this the right explanation?', 'Therefore, there is a minimum amount of  $$\\(Q_{\\text{h}}\\)$$  that cannot be used for work.']
['Are there other important points in this section?', 'The amount of heat rejected to the cold reservoir,  $$\\(Q_{\\text{c}}\\text{,}\\)$$  depends upon the efficiency of the heat engine.']
['Is this correct?', 'The smaller the increase in entropy,  $$\\(\\Delta S\\)$$ , the smaller the value of  $$\\(Q_{\\text{c}}\\)$$, and the more heat energy is available to do work.']

["What is the cyclical process that we're studying about?", 'Heat pumps, air conditioners, and refrigerators utilize heat transfer of energy from low to high temperatures, which is the opposite of what heat engines do.']
['What are the two sides of the triangle?', 'Heat transfers energy  $$\\(Q_{\\text{c}}\\)$$  from a cold reservoir and delivers energy  $$\\(Q_{\\text{h}}\\)$$  into a hot one.']
['Why do we need to do that?', 'This requires work input, W, which produces a transfer of energy by heat.']
['How much heat is transferred in the process?', 'Therefore, the total heat transfer to the hot reservoir is']
['What is the purpose of a heat pump?', 'The purpose of a heat pump is to transfer energy by heat to a warm environment, such as a home in the winter.']

['What are the advantages of using a heat pump rather than burning fuel?', 'The great advantage of using a heat pump to keep your home warm rather than just burning fuel in a fireplace or furnace is that a heat pump supplies  $$\\(Q_{\\text{h}} = Q_{\\text{c}} +']
['What happens to the heat inside of a heat pump?', 'Heat  $$\\(Q_{\\text{c}}\\)$$  comes from the outside air, even at a temperature below freezing, to the indoor space.']
['How does it get heat outside?', 'You only pay for W, and you get an additional heat transfer of  $$\\(Q_{\\text{c}}\\)$$  from the outside at no cost.']
['What is another interesting fact?', 'In many cases, at least twice as much energy is transferred to the heated space as is used to run the heat pump.']
['What else do you think the article is about?', 'When you burn fuel to keep warm, you pay for all of it.']

['What is a disadvantage?', 'The disadvantage to a heat pump is that the work input (required by the second law of thermodynamics) is sometimes more expensive than simply burning fuel, especially if the work is provided by electrical energy.']
['What is Figure 12.15?', 'The basic components of a heat pump are shown in Figure 12.15.']
['What is the working fluid used for?', 'A working fluid, such as a refrigerant, is used.']
['What do the outdoor coils do?', 'In the outdoor coils (the evaporator), heat  $$\\(Q_{\\text{c}}\\)$$  enters the working fluid from the cold outdoor air, turning it into a gas.']

['What is the compressor?', 'The electrically driven compressor (work input W) raises the temperature and pressure of the gas and forces it into the condenser coils that are inside the heated space.']

['What happens to the gas inside the room?', 'Because the temperature of the gas is higher than the temperature inside the room, heat transfers energy to the room, and the gas condenses into a liquid.']
['What does the liquid do?', 'The liquid then flows back through an expansion (pressure-reducing) valve.']
['What happens after it returns?', 'The liquid, having been cooled through expansion, returns to the outdoor evaporator coils to resume the cycle.']

['what are air conditioners and refrigerators?', 'Air conditioners and refrigerators are designed to cool substances by transferring energy by heat  $$\\(Q_{\\text{c}}\\)$$  out of a cool environment to a warmer one, where heat  $$\\(Q_{\\text{h}}\\)$$  is given up.']
['what happens to heat in the fridge?', 'In the case of a refrigerator, heat is moved out of the inside of the fridge into the surrounding room.']
['where does heat go in an air conditioner?', 'For an air conditioner, heat is transferred outdoors from inside a home.']
['are heat pumps also used to cool rooms?', 'Heat pumps are also often used in a reverse setting to cool rooms in the summer.']
['What kind of work is required for heat transfer?', 'As with heat pumps, work input is required for heat transfer of energy from cold to hot.']

['How is air conditioning different?', 'The quality of air conditioners and refrigerators is judged by how much energy is removed by heat  $$\\(Q_{\\text{c}}\\)$$  from a cold environment, compared with how much work, W, is required.']
['What is considered waste heat?', 'So, what is considered the energy benefit in a heat pump, is considered waste heat in a refrigerator.']
['Why is the conversion of energy into work important?', 'In the conversion of energy into work, we are always faced with the problem of getting less out than we put in.']
['What is the problem?', 'The problem is that, in all processes, there is some heat  $$\\(Q_{\\text{c}}\\)$$  that transfers energy to the environment—and usually a very significant amount at that.']
['How does this impact things?', 'A way to quantify how efficiently a machine runs is through a quantity called thermal efficiency.']

['How is thermal efficiency defined?', 'We define thermal efficiency, Eff, to be the ratio of useful energy output to the energy input (or, in other words, the ratio of what we get to what we spend).']
['What is another way of saying this?', 'The efficiency of a heat engine is the output of net work, W, divided by heat-transferred energy,  $$\\(Q_{\\text{h}}\\)$$, into the engine; that is']
['What is a wave?', 'A wave is a disturbance that travels or propagates from the place where it was created.']
['What happens when waves are created?', 'Waves transfer energy from one place to another, but they do not necessarily transfer any mass.']
['What are some examples of waves?', 'Light, sound, and waves in the ocean are common examples of waves.']
['What do these examples have in common?', 'Sound and water waves are mechanical waves; meaning, they require a medium to travel through.']
['What are some properties of the medium?', 'The medium may be a solid, a liquid, or a gas, and the speed of the wave depends on the material properties of the medium through which it is traveling.']
['What is not a mechanical wave?', 'However, light is not a mechanical wave; it can travel through a vacuum such as the empty parts of outer space.']
['What are some examples of mechanical waves?', 'A familiar wave that you can easily imagine is the water wave.']

['What does the disturbance look like?', 'For water waves, the disturbance is in the surface of the water, an example of which is the disturbance created by a rock thrown into a pond or by a swimmer splashing the water surface repeatedly.']

['Does sound wave have a disturbance?', 'For sound waves, the disturbance is caused by a change in air pressure, an example of which is when the oscillating cone inside a speaker creates a disturbance.']

['Is there any disturbance associated with earthquakes?', 'For earthquakes, there are several types of disturbances, which include the disturbance of Earth’s surface itself and the pressure disturbances under the surface.']
['What are some more examples of mechanical waves?', 'Even radio waves are most easily understood using an analogy with water waves.']
['What does water waves help you study?', 'Because water waves are common and visible, visualizing water waves may help you in studying other types of waves, especially those that are not visible.']

['What is a typical example of pulse wave?', 'If you drop a pebble into the water, only a few waves may be generated before the disturbance dies down, whereas in a wave pool, the waves are continuous.']
['What does it mean?', 'A pulse wave is a sudden disturbance in which only one wave or a few waves are generated, such as in the example of the pebble.']
['What are other examples?', 'Thunder and explosions also create pulse waves.']
['What is periodic wave?', 'A periodic wave repeats the same oscillation for several cycles, such as in the case of the wave pool, and is associated with simple harmonic motion.']
['What is harmonic motion?', 'Each particle in the medium experiences simple harmonic motion in periodic waves by moving back and forth periodically through the same positions.']
['What is the first wave described by this text?', 'Consider the simplified water wave in Figure 13.2.']
['What is the wave like?', 'This wave is an up-and-down disturbance of the water surface, characterized by a sine wave pattern.']
['What else is noted about this wave?', 'The uppermost position is called the crest and the lowest is the trough.']
['What happens to a bird in the wave?', 'It causes a seagull to move up and down in simple harmonic motion as the wave crests and troughs pass under the bird.']
['What are longitudinal waves and transverse waves?', 'Mechanical waves are categorized by their type of motion and fall into any of two categories: transverse or longitudinal.']
['What do you learn from this information?', 'Note that both transverse and longitudinal waves can be periodic.']
['What do transverse and longitudinal waves have in common?', 'A transverse wave propagates so that the disturbance is perpendicular to the direction of propagation.']

['What are some examples of transverse waves?', 'An example of a transverse wave is shown in Figure 13.3, where a woman moves a toy spring up and down, generating waves that propagate away from herself in the horizontal direction while disturbing the toy spring in the vertical direction.']
['What is unique about longitudinal waves?', 'In contrast, in a longitudinal wave, the disturbance is parallel to the direction of propagation.']

['How do you visualize this?', 'Figure 13.4 shows an example of a longitudinal wave, where the woman now creates a disturbance in the horizontal direction—which is the same direction as the wave propagation—by stretching and then compressing the toy spring.']
['What are the three wave properties?', 'Waves may be transverse, longitudinal, or a combination of the two.']
['What do you think of transverse waves?', 'The waves on the strings of musical instruments are transverse (as shown in Figure 13.5), and so are electromagnetic waves, such as visible light.']
['What do you think of longitudinal waves?', 'Sound waves in air and water are longitudinal.']
['How do sound waves move?', 'Their disturbances are periodic variations in pressure that are transmitted in fluids.']
['What are longitudinal waves?', 'Sound in solids can be both longitudinal and transverse.']

['Do they have a role in water waves?', 'Essentially, water waves are also a combination of transverse and longitudinal components, although the simplified water wave illustrated in Figure 13.2 does not show the longitudinal motion of the bird.']
["What's the difference between longitudinal and transverse waves?", 'Earthquake waves under Earth’s surface have both longitudinal and transverse components as well.']
['what are their names?', 'The longitudinal waves in an earthquake are called pressure or P-waves, and the transverse waves are called shear or S-waves.']
['What are their characteristics?', 'These components have important individual characteristics; for example, they propagate at different speeds.']
['What are the surface waves?', 'Earthquakes also have surface waves that are similar to surface waves on water.']
['Why are they different?', 'For waves, these variables have the same basic meaning.']
['What is this used for?', 'However, it is helpful to word the definitions in a more specific way that applies directly to waves:']
['What are the characteristics of waves?', 'In addition to amplitude, frequency, and period, their wavelength and wave velocity also characterize waves.']
['What is the wavelength?', 'The wavelength $$\\(\\lambda\\)$$  is the distance between adjacent identical parts of a wave, parallel to the direction of propagation.']
['What is the wave velocity?', 'The wave velocity $$\\(v_{w}\\)$$  is the speed at which the disturbance moves.']
['What are some examples of waves?', 'Consider the periodic water wave in Figure 13.7.']
['What does wavelength refer to?', 'Its wavelength is the distance from crest to crest or from trough to trough.']
['What else is wavelength?', 'The wavelength can also be thought of as the distance a wave has traveled after one complete cycle—or one period.']
['What is period?', 'The time for one complete up-and-down motion is the simple water wave’s period T.']
['What is wave velocity?', 'In the figure, the wave itself moves to the right with a wave velocity vw.']
['What is amplitude?', 'Its amplitude X is the distance between the resting position and the maximum displacement—either the crest or the trough—of the wave.']

['What else is important?', 'It is important to note that this movement of the wave is actually the disturbance moving to the right, not the water itself; otherwise, the bird would move to the right.']
['What happens when the bird stays in place?', 'Instead, the seagull bobs up and down in place as waves pass underneath, traveling a total distance of 2X in one cycle.']
['What else is important?', 'However, as mentioned in the text feature on surfing, actual ocean waves are more complex than this simplified example.']
['How do we derive a function that represents the product of two functions of a variable', 'just as in the case of harmonic motion of an object.']
['What does the following tell us?', 'We can see from this relationship that a higher frequency means a shorter period.']
['What is frequency?', 'Recall that the unit for frequency is hertz (Hz), and that 1 Hz is one cycle—or one wave—per second.']
['What is propagation?', 'The speed of propagation vw is the distance the wave travels in a given time, which is one wavelength in a time of one period.']
['What is the equation?', 'In equation form, it is written as']
['What are the other important features of this article?', 'From this relationship, we see that in a medium where vw is constant, the higher the frequency, the smaller the wavelength.']
['What else is significant about the article?', 'See Figure 13.8.']
['What is the most important fact in this article?', 'These fundamental relationships hold true for all types of waves.']
['What is one example of this?', 'As an example, for water waves, vw is the speed of a surface wave; for sound, vw is the speed of sound; and for visible light, vw is the speed of light.']

['What else is important about the fundamental relationship between frequency and velocity?', 'The amplitude X is completely independent of the speed of propagation vw and depends only on the amount of energy in the wave.']
['What is something about the wave?', 'Most waves do not look very simple.']
['What is the wave?', 'They look more like the waves in Figure 13.10, rather than the simple water wave considered in the previous sections, which has a perfect sinusoidal shape.']
['What happens when two simple waves come together?', 'Waves superimpose by adding their disturbances; each disturbance corresponds to a force, and all the forces add.']

['What are they adding together?', 'If the disturbances are along the same line, then the resulting wave is a simple addition of the disturbances of the individual waves, that is, their amplitudes add.']
['What is pure constructive interference?', 'Pure constructive interference occurs when two identical waves arrive at the same point exactly in phase.']
['What is the point exactly in phase?', 'When waves are exactly in phase, the crests of the two waves are precisely aligned, as are the troughs.']
['What is pure destructive interference?', 'Refer to Figure 13.11.']

['What happens if there is pure constructive interference?', 'Because the disturbances add, the pure constructive interference of two waves with the same amplitude produces a wave that has twice the amplitude of the two individual waves, but has the same wavelength.']

['What was pure destructive interference?', 'Figure 13.12 shows two identical waves that arrive exactly out of phase—that is, precisely aligned crest to trough—producing pure destructive interference.']

['What is the amplitude of pure destructive interference?', 'Because the disturbances are in opposite directions for this superposition, the resulting amplitude is zero for pure destructive interference; that is, the waves completely cancel out each other.']

["What's unique about pure constructive interference?", 'While pure constructive interference and pure destructive interference can occur, they are not very common because they require precisely aligned identical waves.']
['What happens if you superpose two different waves?', 'The superposition of most waves that we see in nature produces a combination of constructive and destructive interferences.']
['What happens when there is no interference?', 'Waves that are not results of pure constructive or destructive interference can vary from place to place and time to time.']
['How do you apply this information to everyday life?', 'The sound from a stereo, for example, can be loud in one spot and soft in another.']
['How does that happen?', 'The varying loudness means that the sound waves add partially constructively and partially destructively at different locations.']
['What else can you tell me about that example?', 'A stereo has at least two speakers that create sound waves, and waves can reflect from walls.']
['What happens when the wave reflects from the wall?', 'All these waves superimpose.']

['What is the relationship between constructive interference and destructive interference?', 'An example of sounds that vary over time from constructive to destructive is found in the combined whine of jet engines heard by a stationary passenger.']
['What does the stationary passenger perceive?', 'The volume of the combined sound can fluctuate up and down as the sound from the two engines varies in time from constructive to destructive.']

['What does the first example look like?', 'The two previous examples considered waves that are similar—both stereo speakers generate sound waves with the same amplitude and wavelength, as do the jet engines.']
['What is the second example?', 'An example of the superposition of two dissimilar waves is shown in Figure 13.13.']
['What is special about it?', 'Here again, the disturbances add and subtract, but they produce an even more complicated-looking wave.']
['What else is unique?', 'The resultant wave from the combined disturbances of two dissimilar waves looks much different than the idealized sinusoidal shape of a periodic wave.']
['What are standing waves?', 'Sometimes waves do not seem to move and they appear to just stand in place, vibrating.']
['How are these waves formed?', 'Such waves are called standing waves and are formed by the superposition of two or more waves moving in opposite directions.']
['How does this affect their performance?', 'If the two waves have the same amplitude and wavelength, then they alternate between constructive and destructive interference.']
['Do these waves actually exist?', 'Standing waves created by the superposition of two identical waves moving in opposite directions are illustrated in Figure 13.14.']
['What are some examples?', 'As an example, standing waves can be seen on the surface of a glass of milk in a refrigerator.']
['What does that mean?', 'The vibrations from the refrigerator motor create waves on the milk that oscillate up and down but do not seem to move across the surface.']
['What are the other examples?', 'The two waves that produce standing waves may be due to the reflections from the side of the glass.']
['What kind of interferences can create standing waves?', 'Earthquakes can create standing waves and cause constructive and destructive interferences.']
['What are the different types of interferences?', 'As the earthquake waves travel along the surface of Earth and reflect off denser rocks, constructive interference occurs at certain points.']
['How does constructive interference help?', 'As a result, areas closer to the epicenter are not damaged while areas farther from the epicenter are damaged.']
['What happens to standing waves in the air?', 'Standing waves are also found on the strings of musical instruments and are due to reflections of waves from the ends of the string.']
['What are three examples of standing waves?', 'Figure 13.15 and Figure 13.16 show three standing waves that can be created on a string that is fixed at both ends.']
['What is reflected?', 'When the wave reaches the fixed end, it has nowhere else to go but back where it came from, causing the reflection.']
['What are the nodes?', 'The nodes are the points where the string does not move; more generally, the nodes are the points where the wave disturbance is zero in a standing wave.']
['Why do they stop moving?', 'The fixed ends of strings must be nodes, too, because the string cannot move there.']
['What is the antinode?', 'The antinode is the location of maximum amplitude in standing waves.']
['What is the frequency?', 'The standing waves on a string have a frequency that is related to the propagation speed  $$\\(v_{w}\\)$$  of the disturbance on the string.']
['How is the wavelength related to frequency?', 'The wavelength  $$\\(\\lambda\\)$$  is determined by the distance between the points where the string is fixed in place.']

['What happens when a wave hits something?', 'As we saw in the case of standing waves on the strings of a musical instrument, reflection is the change in direction of a wave when it bounces off a barrier, such as a fixed end.']
['What happens after a wave hits the fixed end?', 'When the wave hits the fixed end, it changes direction, returning to its source.']
['What happens to the wave after it refracts?', 'As it is reflected, the wave experiences an inversion, which means that it flips vertically.']
['What else happens to a wave in the water?', 'If a wave hits the fixed end with a crest, it will return as a trough, and vice versa (Henderson 2015).']
['What is the illustration showing that this occurs?', 'Refer to Figure 13.17.']

['What do you know about reflection and refraction of waves?', 'Rather than encountering a fixed end or barrier, waves sometimes pass from one medium into another, for instance, from air into water.']
['What does the medium have to do with how the wave travels?', 'Different types of media have different properties, such as density or depth, that affect how a wave travels through them.']
['What does refraction have to do with how the wave travels?', 'At the boundary between media, waves experience refraction—they change their path of propagation.']
['How does the wave speed change when it changes its path of propagation?', 'As the wave bends, it also changes its speed and wavelength upon entering the new medium.']
['Why does refraction change the wave speed?', 'Refer to Figure 13.18.']
['What is refraction of waves?', 'For example, water waves traveling from the deep end to the shallow end of a swimming pool experience refraction.']

['What happens to the waves when they reach shallower water?', 'They bend in a path closer to perpendicular to the surface of the water, propagate slower, and decrease in wavelength as they enter shallower water.']
['What is sound?', 'Sound is a wave.']
['What is it defined as?', 'More specifically, sound is defined to be a disturbance of matter that is transmitted from its source outward.']
['What is disturbance?', 'A disturbance is anything that is moved from its state of equilibrium.']
['How do you characterize sound?', 'Some sound waves can be characterized as periodic waves, which means that the atoms that make up the matter experience simple harmonic motion.']
['What can a vibrating string do?', 'A vibrating string produces a sound wave as illustrated in Figure 14.2, Figure 14.3, and Figure 14.4.']
['What does the vibrations have to do with air?', 'As the string oscillates back and forth, part of the string’s energy goes into compressing and expanding the surrounding air.']
['What happens after this?', 'This creates slightly higher and lower pressures.']
['What is the difference between compression and rarefaction?', 'The higher pressure... regions are compressions, and the low pressure regions are rarefactions.']
['What happens after the string has stopped vibrating?', 'The pressure disturbance moves through the air as longitudinal waves with the same frequency as the string.']
['What else does this do?', 'Some of the energy is lost in the form of thermal energy transferred to the air.']

['What can you tell me about the transverse waves?', 'You may recall from the chapter on waves that areas of compression and rarefaction in longitudinal waves (such as sound) are analogous to crests and troughs in transverse waves.']
['What are properties of sound waves?', 'The amplitude of a sound wave decreases with distance from its source, because the energy of the wave is spread over a larger and larger area.']
['Why is the energy spread out?', 'But some of the energy is also absorbed by objects, such as the eardrum in Figure 14.5, and some of the energy is converted to thermal energy in the air.']
['What other properties are included?', 'Figure 14.4 shows a graph of gauge pressure versus distance from the vibrating string.']

['What is the significance of this graph?', 'From this figure, you can see that the compression of a longitudinal wave is analogous to the peak of a transverse wave, and the rarefaction of a longitudinal wave is analogous to the trough of a transverse wave.']
['Why is this analogous?', 'Just as a transverse wave alternates between peaks and troughs, a longitudinal wave alternates between compression and rarefaction.']
['What is the speed of sound?', 'The speed of sound varies greatly depending upon the medium it is traveling through.']
['What is the relationship between stiffness and density?', 'The speed of sound in a medium is determined by a combination of the medium’s rigidity (or compressibility in gases) and its density.']
['What else do you know about stiffness?', 'The more rigid (or less compressible) the medium, the faster the speed of sound.']
['What else do you know about density?', 'The greater the density of a medium, the slower the speed of sound.']
['How is the speed of sound in air affected?', 'The speed of sound in air is low, because air is compressible.']
['What else is of interest in the article?', 'Because liquids and solids are relatively rigid and very difficult to compress, the speed of sound in such media is generally greater than in gases.']
['What is the table called?', 'Table 14.1 shows the speed of sound in various media.']

['What else can you tell me about the density?', 'Since temperature affects density, the speed of sound varies with the temperature of the medium through which it’s traveling to some extent, especially for gases.']
['what is the relationship between these three?', 'Sound, like all waves, travels at certain speeds through different media and has the properties of frequency and wavelength.']

['how fast does sound travel?', 'Sound travels much slower than light—you can observe this while watching a fireworks display (see Figure 14.6), since the flash of an explosion is seen before its sound is heard.']
['What is the relation between v and f?', 'where v is the speed of sound (in units of m/s), f is its frequency (in units of hertz), and  $$\\(\\lambda\\)$$  is its wavelength (in units of meters).']
['What is wavelength?', 'Recall that wavelength is defined as the distance between adjacent identical parts of a wave.']
['What is the definition of wavelength?', 'The wavelength of a sound, therefore, is the distance between adjacent identical parts of a sound wave.']

['What are the parts of a sound wave?', 'Just as the distance between adjacent crests in a transverse wave is one wavelength, the distance between adjacent compressions in a sound wave is also one wavelength, as shown in Figure 14.7.']
['What is the frequency of a sound wave?', 'The frequency of a sound wave is the same as that of the source.']
['What are some examples of this?', 'For example, a tuning fork vibrating at a given frequency would produce sound waves that oscillate at that same frequency.']
['What is frequency?', 'The frequency of a sound is the number of waves that pass a point per unit time.']
['What else can you tell me about this study material?', 'One of the more important properties of sound is that its speed is nearly independent of frequency.']

['What is the frequency?', 'If this were not the case, and high-frequency sounds traveled faster, for example, then the farther you were from a band in a football stadium, the more the sound from the low-pitch instruments would lag behind the high-pitch ones.']
['What is so important about the frequency?', 'But the music from all instruments arrives in cadence independent of distance, and so all frequencies must travel at nearly the same speed.']
['What is the relationship between v and temperature and humidity?', 'Recall that  $$\\(v = f\\lambda\\)$$, and in a given medium under fixed temperature and humidity, v is constant.']
['What is the relationship between f and $$(lambda', 'Therefore, the relationship between f and  $$\\(\\lambda\\)$$  is inverse:']
['What is the relationship between wavelength and frequency?', 'The higher the frequency, the shorter the wavelength of a sound wave.']
['What is sound?', 'The speed of sound can change when sound travels from one medium to another.']

['What happens to the frequency as a result of sound travel?', 'However, the frequency usually remains the same because it is like a driven oscillation and maintains the frequency of the original source.']
['What other change happens as a result of traveling sound?', 'If v changes and f remains the same, then the wavelength  $$\\(\\lambda\\)$$  must change.']
['How does sound travel?', 'Since  $$\\(v = f\\lambda\\)$$, the higher the speed of a sound, the greater its wavelength for a given frequency.']
['How many decibels are there in a decibel level?', 'In a quiet forest, you can sometimes hear a single leaf fall to the ground.']
['What are all the decibel levels?', 'But in a traffic jam filled with honking cars, you may have to shout just so the person next to you can hear Figure 14.9.']
['How is the loudness of sound related to energy?', 'The loudness of a sound is related to how energetically its source is vibrating.']

['What is another example of how loud a sound wave is?', 'In cartoons showing a screaming person, the cartoonist often shows an open mouth with a vibrating uvula (the hanging tissue at the back of the mouth) to represent a loud sound coming from the throat.']
['What kind of cartoon?', 'Figure 14.10 shows such a cartoon depiction of a bird loudly expressing its opinion.']
['What is the most important fact of this chapter?', 'A useful quantity for describing the loudness of sounds is called sound intensity.']
['How does it work?', 'In general, the intensity of a wave is the power per unit area carried by the wave.']
['What is power?', 'Power is the rate at which energy is transferred by the wave.']
['What is intensity in equation form?', 'In equation form, intensity I is']
['What is I = fracPA?', 'where P is the power through an area A. The SI unit for I is W/m2.']
['What is intensity?', 'The intensity of a sound depends upon its pressure amplitude.']
['What is the relationship between pressure amplitude and intensity?', 'The relationship between the intensity of a sound wave and its pressure amplitude (or pressure variation Δp) is']
['What are the other two quantities?', 'where ρ is the density of the material in which the sound wave travels, in units of kg/m3, and v is the speed of sound in the medium, in units of m/s.']
['What are the other units of pressure amplitude?', 'Pressure amplitude has units of pascals (Pa) or N/m2.']
['What is the relationship of the pressure amplitude and density?', 'Note that Δp is half the difference between the maximum and minimum pressure in the sound wave.']
['What else are you studying?', 'We can see from the equation that the intensity of a sound is proportional to its amplitude squared.']
['What is the pressure variation?', 'The pressure variation is proportional to the amplitude of the oscillation, and so I varies as (Δp)2.']

['What else did you study?', 'This relationship is consistent with the fact that the sound wave is produced by some vibration; the greater its pressure amplitude, the more the air is compressed during the vibration.']
['What else did you study?', 'Because the power of a sound wave is the rate at which energy is transferred, the energy of a sound wave is also proportional to its amplitude squared.']
['What does the decibel scale mean?', 'You may have noticed that when people talk about the loudness of a sound, they describe it in units of decibels rather than watts per meter squared.']
['Why is this?', 'While sound intensity (in W/m2) is the SI unit, the sound intensity level in decibels (dB) is more relevant for how humans perceive sounds.']
['How does the decibel scale work?', 'The way our ears perceive sound can be more accurately described by the logarithm of the intensity of a sound rather than the intensity of a sound directly.']
['What is the SI unit?', 'The sound intensity level β is defined to be']
['What is the equation?', 'where I is sound intensity in watts per meter squared, and I0 = 10–12 W/m2 is a reference intensity.']
['What is the reference point?', 'I0 is chosen as the reference point because it is the lowest intensity of sound a person with normal hearing can perceive.']
['How is the decibel level determined?', 'The decibel level of a sound having an intensity of 10–12 W/m2 is β = 0 dB, because log10 1 = 0.']
['What is the threshold of human hearing?', 'That is, the threshold of human hearing is 0 decibels.']
['What does dB mean?', 'Each factor of 10 in intensity corresponds to 10 dB.']
['What is this used for?', 'For example, a 90 dB sound compared with a 60 dB sound is 30 dB greater, or three factors of 10 (that is, 103 times) as intense.']
['What else is known about dB?', 'Another example is that if one sound is 107 as intense as another, it is 70 dB higher.']
['What can you tell me about the relationship between  and unit-less?', 'Since β is defined in terms of a ratio, it is unit-less.']
['Is there anything else interesting you learned about this?', 'The unit called decibel (dB) is used to indicate that this ratio is multiplied by 10.']

['What else are you curious about?', 'The sound intensity level is not the same as sound intensity—it tells you the level of the sound relative to a reference intensity rather than the actual intensity.']
['How does a voice make sound?', 'People create sounds by pushing air up through their lungs and through elastic folds in the throat called vocal cords.']
['How do the vocal cords make sound?', 'These folds open and close rhythmically, creating a pressure buildup.']
['How does the vocal cords create the sound?', 'As air travels up and past the vocal cords, it causes them to vibrate.']
['How do the vibrations travel?', 'This vibration escapes the mouth along with puffs of air as sound.']
['How do people change their voice?', 'A voice changes in pitch when the muscles of the larynx relax or tighten, changing the tension on the vocal chords.']
['How do people increase their voice?', 'A voice becomes louder when air flow from the lungs increases, making the amplitude of the sound pressure wave greater.']
['What is hearing?', 'Hearing is the perception of sound.']
['How does it perceive sound?', 'It can give us plenty of information—such as pitch, loudness, and direction.']
['What is a typical range for the frequency of sound?', 'Humans can normally hear frequencies ranging from approximately 20 to 20,000 Hz.']
['What else is important to know about hearing?', 'Other animals have hearing ranges different from that of humans.']
["What other animal's hearing ranges are different?", 'Dogs can hear sounds as high as 45,000 Hz, whereas bats and dolphins can hear up to 110,000 Hz sounds.']
['Is there anything else interesting about hearing?', 'You may have noticed that dogs respond to the sound of a dog whistle which produces sound out of the range of human hearing.']
['What is the first question you were asked?', 'Sounds below 20']
['Hz are called infrasound, whereas those above 20', 'Hz are called infrasound, whereas those above 20,000 Hz are ultrasound.']
['What else is important to know about pitch?', 'The perception of frequency is called pitch, and the perception of intensity is called loudness.']
["What's the main idea of Hearing and Voice?", 'The way we hear involves some interesting physics.']
['What is sound wave that hits our ear?', 'The sound wave that hits our ear is a pressure wave.']
['What is the function of ears?', 'The ear converts sound waves into electrical nerve impulses, similar to a microphone.']

['What are some important details?', 'Figure 14.11 shows the anatomy of the ear with its division into three parts: the outer ear or ear canal; the middle ear, which runs from the eardrum to the cochlea; and the inner ear, which is the cochlea itself.']
['What is the pinna?', 'The body part normally referred to as the ear is technically called the pinna.']
['What is the function of the outer ear?', 'The outer ear, or ear canal, carries sound to the eardrum protected inside of the ear.']
['What is the function of the middle ear?', 'The middle ear converts sound into mechanical vibrations and applies these vibrations to the cochlea.']

['What is the function of the lever system?', 'The lever system of the middle ear takes the force exerted on the eardrum by sound pressure variations, amplifies it and transmits it to the inner ear via the oval window.']
['What is the function of the muscle?', 'Two muscles in the middle ear protect the inner ear from very intense sounds.']
['How does it protect?', 'They react to intense sound in a few milliseconds and reduce the force transmitted to the cochlea.']
['What else is important?', 'This protective reaction can also be triggered by your own voice, so that humming during a fireworks display, for example, can reduce noise damage.']
['What do you think the next thing is?', 'Figure 14.12 shows the middle and inner ear in greater detail.']
['How does the inner ear work?', 'As the middle ear bones vibrate, they vibrate the cochlea, which contains fluid.']
['What happens next?', 'This creates pressure waves in the fluid that cause the tectorial membrane to vibrate.']
['What does this vibrating tectorial membrane do?', 'The motion of the tectorial membrane stimulates tiny cilia on specialized cells called hair cells.']
['What happens after this?', 'These hair cells, and their attached neurons, transform the motion of the tectorial membrane into electrical signals that are sent to the brain.']
['What is a frequency of sound?', 'The tectorial membrane vibrates at different positions based on the frequency of the incoming sound.']
['What do these different positions mean?', 'This allows us to detect the pitch of sound.']

['Is there anything else that is important to know?', 'Additional processing in the brain also allows us to determine which direction the sound is coming from (based on comparison of the sound’s arrival time and intensity between our two ears).']
['What books did you read?', 'Nave, R. Vocal sound production—HyperPhysics.']
['What does Hyper Physics refer to?', 'Retrieved from http://hyperphysics.phy-astr.gsu.edu/hbase/music/voice.html']
['What is the Doppler effect?', 'The Doppler effect is a change in the observed pitch of a sound, due to relative motion between the source and the observer.']

['When do you hear the Doppler effect?', 'An example of the Doppler effect due to the motion of a source occurs when you are standing still, and the sound of a siren coming from an ambulance shifts from high-pitch to low-pitch as it passes by.']
['How does the Doppler effect change sound?', 'The closer the ambulance is to you, the more sudden the shift.']
['Why is the shifting so sudden?', 'The faster the ambulance moves, the greater the shift.']
['What other types of sounds does the Doppler effect affect?', 'We also hear this shift in frequency for passing race cars, airplanes, and trains.']

['What other examples are given?', 'An example of the Doppler effect with a stationary source and moving observer is if you ride a train past a stationary warning bell, you will hear the bell’s frequency shift from high to low as you pass by.']
["What's the relationship between these three scenarios?", 'Let’s compare three different scenarios:']

['How would they differ?', 'Sound waves emitted by a stationary source (Figure 14.14), sound waves emitted by a moving source (Figure 14.15), and sound waves emitted by a stationary source but heard by moving observers (Figure 14.16).']
['What is the relationship between these scenarios?', 'In each case, the sound spreads out from the point where it was emitted.']
['What is the basic idea of this document?', 'If the source and observers are stationary, then observers on either side see the same wavelength and frequency as emitted by the source.']

['What is the doppler effect?', 'But if the source is moving and continues to emit sound as it travels, then the air compressions (crests) become closer together in the direction in which it’s traveling and farther apart in the direction it’s traveling away from.']

['What else does the doppler effect have to do with sound waves?', 'Therefore, the wavelength is shorter in the direction the source is moving (on the right in Figure 14.15), and longer in the opposite direction (on the left in Figure 14.15).']
['What happens when a sound wave is converted to a waveform?', 'Finally, if the observers move, as in Figure 14.16, the frequency at which they receive the compressions changes.']

['What happens with the frequency?', 'The observer moving toward the source receives them at a higher frequency (and therefore shorter wavelength), and the person moving away from the source receives them at a lower frequency (and therefore longer wavelength).']
['Is the Doppler effect related to wavelength and frequency?', 'We know that wavelength and frequency are related by  $$\\(v = f\\lambda\\text{,}\\)$$  where v is the fixed speed of sound.']
['What does fixed speed mean?', 'The sound moves in a medium and has the same speed v in that medium whether the source is moving or not.']
['What does f multiply by?', 'Therefore, f multiplied by  $$\\(\\lambda\\)$$  is a constant.']
['What else is important about wavelength and frequency?', 'Because the observer on the right in Figure 14.15 receives a shorter wavelength, the frequency she perceives must be higher.']
['What else is important about wavelength and frequency?', 'Similarly, the observer on the left receives a longer wavelength and therefore perceives a lower frequency.']
['What was the relationship between those three values?', 'The same thing happens in Figure 14.16.']

["How does this affect a sound wave's frequency?", 'A higher frequency is perceived by the observer moving toward the source, and a lower frequency is perceived by an observer moving away from the source.']
['What is the main difference between a moving observer and a stationary one?', 'In general, then, relative motion of source and observer toward one another increases the perceived frequency.']
['What happens if the relative motion is apart?', 'Relative motion apart decreases the perceived frequency.']
['What else is significant about this?', 'The greater the relative speed is, the greater the effect.']
['What is the Pythagorean Theorem?', 'where fs is the frequency of sound from a source, vs is the speed of the source along a line joining the source and observer, and vw is the speed of sound.']
['What other terms are used to define the sound pressure in this problem?', 'The minus sign is used for motion toward the observer and the plus sign for motion away from the observer.']
['What did you study?', 'Note that the greater the speed of the source, the greater the Doppler effect.']
['Is there a way to calculate the velocity of sound?', 'Similarly, for a stationary source and moving observer, the frequency perceived by the observer fobs is given by']
['What is the relation between vobs and fs?', 'where vobs is the speed of the observer along a line joining the source and observer.']
['What is the significance of a plus sign?', 'Here the plus sign is for motion toward the source, and the minus sign is for motion away from the source.']
['What were the problems you saw?', 'Suppose a jet airplane is coming nearly straight at you, emitting a sound of frequency fs.']
['How does the plane affect the frequency?', 'The greater the plane’s speed, vs, the greater the Doppler shift and the greater the value of fobs.']

['What does the Doppler shift do to the frequency?', 'Now, as vs approaches the speed of sound, vw, fobs approaches infinity, because the denominator in  $$\\(f_{obs} = f_{s}\\left( \\frac{v_{w}}{v_{w} - v_{s}} \\right)\\)$$  approaches zero.']
['What is this result?', 'This result means that at the speed of sound, in front of the source, each wave is superimposed on the previous one because the source moves forward at the speed of sound.']
['What happens to the waveform?', 'The observer gets them all at the same instant, and so the frequency is theoretically infinite.']

['What else is significant about the result?', 'If the source exceeds the speed of sound, no sound is received by the observer until the source has passed, so that the sounds from the source when it was approaching are stacked up with those from it when receding, creating a sonic boom.']
['What is a sonic boom?', 'A sonic boom is a constructive interference of sound created by an object moving faster than sound.']
['What causes sonic booms?', 'An aircraft creates two sonic booms, one from its nose and one from its tail (see Figure 14.17).']
['What can the aircraft do with those sonic booms?', 'During television coverage of space shuttle landings, two distinct booms could often be heard.']
['Why were the two distinct booms heard?', 'These were separated by exactly the time it would take the shuttle to pass by a point.']
['What can you observe about the sonic booms?', 'Observers on the ground often do not observe the aircraft creating the sonic boom, because it has passed by before the shock wave reaches them.']
['Does the aircraft have a negative impact on people?', 'If the aircraft flies close by at low altitude, pressures in the sonic boom can be destructive enough to break windows.']
['What can the government do about it?', 'Because of this, supersonic flights are banned over populated areas of the United States.']
['How do you know what note to play?', 'Sit in front of a piano sometime and sing a loud brief note at it while pushing down on the sustain pedal.']

['What happens?', 'It will sing the same note back at you—the strings that have the same frequencies as your voice, are resonating in response to the forces from the sound waves that you sent to them.']
['What does this mean?', 'This is a good example of the fact that objects—in this case, piano strings—can be forced to oscillate but oscillate best at their natural frequency.']

['What is resonance?', 'A driving force (such as your voice in the example) puts energy into a system at a certain frequency, which is not necessarily the same as the natural frequency of the system.']
['What happens after resonance?', 'Over time the energy dissipates, and the amplitude gradually reduces to zero- this is called damping.']
['What is the natural frequency?', 'The natural frequency is the frequency at which a system would oscillate if there were no driving and no damping force.']

['What happens when the driving force is equal to the natural frequency?', 'The phenomenon of driving a system with a frequency equal to its natural frequency is called resonance, and a system being driven at its natural frequency is said to resonate.']

['What were the examples in the section on resonance and beats?', 'Most of us have played with toys where an object bobs up and down on an elastic band, something like the paddle ball suspended from a finger in Figure 14.18.']
['What happens to the ball with more damping?', 'At first you hold your finger steady, and the ball bounces up and down with a small amount of damping.']
['What is the final outcome of this example?', 'If you move your finger up and down slowly, the ball will follow along without bouncing much on its own.']
['What happens when you move your finger faster?', 'As you increase the frequency at which you move your finger up and down, the ball will respond by oscillating with increasing amplitude.']

['What happens when you drive the ball at its natural frequency?', 'When you drive the ball at its natural frequency, the ball’s oscillations increase in amplitude with each oscillation for as long as you drive it.']

['What happens when you drive it faster?', 'As the driving frequency gets progressively higher than the resonant or natural frequency, the amplitude of the oscillations becomes smaller, until the oscillations nearly disappear and your finger simply moves up and down with little effect on the ball.']
['What are some examples?', 'Another example is that when you tune a radio, you adjust its resonant frequency so that it oscillates only at the desired station’s broadcast (driving) frequency.']
['Is there another example?', 'Also, a child on a swing is driven (pushed) by a parent at the swing’s natural frequency to reach the maximum amplitude (height).']
['Why is resonance important?', 'In all of these cases, the efficiency of energy transfer from the driving force into the oscillator is best at resonance.']
['What is the most important fact in the article?', 'All sound resonances are due to constructive and destructive interference.']
['What else is a consequence of constructive interference?', 'Only the resonant frequencies interfere constructively to form standing waves, while others interfere destructively and are absent.']
['What else can resonance lead to?', 'From the toot made by blowing over a bottle to the recognizability of a great singer’s voice, resonance and standing waves play a vital role in sound.']
['What is interference?', 'Interference happens to all types of waves, including sound waves.']
['What happens as a result?', 'In fact, one way to support that something is a wave is to observe interference effects.']
['What can interference be used for?', 'Figure 14.19 shows a set of headphones that employs a clever use of sound interference to cancel noise.']

['What else is known about interference?', 'To get destructive interference, a fast electronic analysis is performed, and a second sound is introduced with its maxima and minima exactly reversed from the incoming noise.']
['What are beats?', 'In addition to resonance, superposition of waves can also create beats.']
['What are different aspects of beats?', 'Beats are produced by the superposition of two waves with slightly different frequencies but the same amplitude.']
['What happens after that?', 'The waves alternate in time between constructive interference and destructive interference, giving the resultant wave an amplitude that varies over time.']
['What is an example of this?', '(See the resultant wave in Figure 14.20).']
['What is a resonance?', 'This wave fluctuates in amplitude, or beats, with a frequency called the beat frequency.']
['What is the equation for beat frequency?', 'The equation for beat frequency is']
['How would this wave propagate?', 'where f1 and f2 are the frequencies of the two original waves.']

['What is the relationship between frequency and sound wave?', 'If the two frequencies of sound waves are similar, then what we hear is an average frequency that gets louder and softer at the beat frequency.']
['What does the figure illustrate?', 'Suppose we hold a tuning fork near the end of a tube that is closed at the other end, as shown in Figure 14.21, Figure 14.22, and Figure 14.23.']
['What happens in the tube?', 'If the tuning fork has just the right frequency, the air column in the tube resonates loudly, but at most frequencies it vibrates very little.']
['What does this mean?', 'This means that the air column has only certain natural frequencies.']
['What else does the figure show?', 'The figures show how a resonance at the lowest of these natural frequencies is formed.']
['What is it?', 'A disturbance travels down the tube at the speed of sound and bounces off the closed end.']

['What happens after it bounces off the closed end?', 'If the tube is just the right length, the reflected sound arrives back at the tuning fork exactly half a cycle later, and it interferes constructively with the continuing sound produced by the tuning fork.']
['What happens after it interferes?', 'The incoming and reflected sounds form a standing wave in the tube as shown.']
['What is an antinode?', 'The standing wave formed in the tube has its maximum air displacement (an antinode) at the open end, and no displacement (a node) at the closed end.']
['What happens at the antinode?', 'Recall from the last chapter on waves that motion is unconstrained at the antinode, and halted at the node.']
['How is the displacement measured?', 'The distance from a node to an antinode is one-fourth of a wavelength, and this equals the length of the tube; therefore,  $$\\(\\lambda = \\ 4L\\)$$ .']
['How can resonance be produced?', 'This same resonance can be produced by a vibration introduced at or near the closed end of the tube, as shown in Figure 14.24.']

['What other types of wavelengths can resonance in a tube see Figure 14.25).', 'Since maximum air displacements are possible at the open end and none at the closed end, there are other, shorter wavelengths that can resonate in the tube see Figure 14.25).']

['How are wavelengths related to frequency?', 'Here the standing wave has three-fourths of its wavelength in the tube, or  $$\\(L = \\ \\left( {3/4} \\right)\\lambda\\prime\\)$$, so that  $$\\(\\lambda\\prime\\  = \\ 4L/3\\)$$ .']
['What are the various sounds?', 'There is a whole series of shorter-wavelength and higher-frequency sounds that resonate in the tube.']
['What is the terminology?', 'We use specific terms for the resonances in any system.']
['What are these terms?', 'The lowest resonant frequency is called the fundamental, while all higher resonant frequencies are called overtones.']
['What else do you know about this terminology?', 'All resonant frequencies are multiples of the fundamental, and are called harmonics.']
['How many harmonics are there?', 'The fundamental is the first harmonic, the first overtone is the second harmonic, and so on.']
['What are the four harmonics?', 'Figure 14.26 shows the fundamental and the first three overtones (the first four harmonics) in a tube closed at one end.']
['What does the fundamental frequency and harmonics have to do with chromatic aberration?', 'The fundamental and overtones can be present at the same time in a variety of combinations.']

['How does the overtones help to produce certain sounds?', 'For example, the note middle C on a trumpet sounds very different from middle C on a clarinet, even though both instruments are basically modified versions of a tube closed at one end.']

['What is the difference between fundamental frequency and harmonics?', 'The fundamental frequency is the same (and usually the most intense), but the overtones and their mix of intensities are different.']
['What is the mix of intensities?', 'This mix is what gives musical instruments (and human voices) their distinctive characteristics, whether they have air columns, strings, or drumheads.']

['What else is important to know?', 'In fact, much of our speech is determined by shaping the cavity formed by the throat and mouth and positioning the tongue to adjust the fundamental and combination of overtones.']
['Why is that important?', 'where f1 is the fundamental, f3 is the first overtone, and so on.']
['What is the effect of wavelength on the resonant frequencies?', 'Note that the resonant frequencies depend on the speed of sound v and on the length of the tube L.']
['What is an open-pipe resonator?', 'Another type of tube is one that is open at both ends (known as an open-pipe resonator).']
['What types of open-pipe resonators are there?', 'Examples are some organ pipes, flutes, and oboes.']
['What is special about the open-pipe resonator?', 'The air columns in tubes open at both ends have maximum air displacements at both ends.']
['What is one example of this?', '(See Figure 14.27).']
['What happens when the air gets pressurized?', 'Standing waves form as shown.']
['What is the function f_n?', 'where f1 is the fundamental, f2 is the first overtone, f3 is the second overtone, and so on.']
['What else can you tell me about the above?', 'Note that a tube open at both ends has a fundamental frequency twice what it would have if closed at one end.']
['What else do you know about the open at both ends tube?', 'It also has a different spectrum of overtones than a tube closed at one end.']

['How does this affect sound?', 'So if you had two tubes with the same fundamental frequency but one was open at both ends and the other was closed at one end, they would sound different when played because they have different overtones.']
['What is one example?', 'Middle C, for example, would sound richer played on an open tube since it has more overtones.']

['What else can you tell me about the relationship?', 'An open-pipe resonator has more overtones than a closed-pipe resonator because it has even multiples of the fundamental as well as odd, whereas a closed tube has only odd multiples.']
['What is light?', 'We generally take light for granted, but it is a truly amazing and mysterious form of energy.']
['What makes light so special?', 'Think about it: Light travels to Earth across millions of kilometers of empty space.']

['What is special about the Earth?', 'When it reaches us, it interacts with matter in various ways to generate almost all the energy needed to support life, provide heat, and cause weather patterns.']
['What is light a form of?', 'Light is a form of electromagnetic radiation (EMR).']
['What other forms of EMR are there?', 'The term light usually refers to visible light, but this is not the only form of EMR.']
['How does this differ from the other forms?', 'As we will see, visible light occupies a narrow band in a broad range of types of electromagnetic radiation.']
['What is the electron called?', 'Electromagnetic radiation is generated by a moving electric charge, that is, by an electric current.']

['What is the energy released in this current?', 'As you will see when you study electricity, an electric current generates both an electric field, E, and a magnetic field, B. These fields are perpendicular to each other.']
['When is this current occurring?', 'When the moving charge oscillates, as in an alternating current, an EM wave is propagated.']
['How is this wave propagated?', 'Figure 15.2 shows how an electromagnetic wave moves away from the source—indicated by the ~ symbol.']
['Wave speed—The rate at which the wave moves through the medium', 'Wavelength—The distance between two wave crests or two wave troughs, expressed in various metric measures of distance Frequency—']
['The frequency at which a wave travels.', 'The number of wave crests that pass a point per second, expressed in hertz (Hz or s–1) Amplitude:']
["The magnitude of the wave's energy.", 'The height of the crest above the null point']
['During an experiment, in which you were asked to measure the distance between two objects and determine', 'As mentioned, electromagnetic radiation takes several forms.']
['What are the basic characteristics of each form?', 'These forms are characterized by a range of frequencies.']

['Can you describe the relationship between frequency and wavelength?', 'Because frequency is inversely proportional to wavelength, any form of EMR can also be represented by its range of wavelengths.']
['What is a picture of wavelength and frequency?', 'Figure 15.3 shows the frequency and wavelength ranges of various types of EMR.']
['', 'Take a few minutes to study the positions of the various types of radiation on the EM spectrum, above.']
['Describe how visible light radiation is placed on the EM spectrum.', 'Sometimes all radiation with frequencies lower than those of visible light are referred to as infrared (IR) radiation.']
['How does the spectrum overlap with radio waves?', 'This includes radio waves, which overlap with the frequencies used for media broadcasts of TV and radio signals.']
['What about microwaves?', 'The microwave radiation that you see on the diagram is the same radiation that is used in a microwave oven.']
['Are there any other important features about the EM spectrum that are important?', 'What we feel as radiant heat is also a form of low-frequency EMR.']
['', 'All the high-frequency radiation to the right of visible light is sometimes referred to as ultraviolet (UV) radiation.']
['What is this called?', 'This includes X-rays and gamma (γ) rays.']

['How is this different from light?', 'The narrow band that is visible light extends from lower-frequency red light to higher-frequency violet light, thus the terms are infrared (below red) and ultraviolet (beyond violet).']
['what are some of the characteristics?', 'All the EM waves mentioned above are basically the same form of radiation.']
['are they all the same?', 'They can all travel across empty space, and they all travel at the speed of light in a vacuum.']
['what is their differentiator?', 'The basic difference between types of radiation is their differing frequencies.']
['how does that differ?', 'Each frequency has an associated wavelength.']
['how does this relate to wavelength?', 'As frequency increases across the spectrum, wavelength decreases.']
['does that change the energy?', 'Energy also increases with frequency.']
['what is the frequency used for?', 'Because of this, higher frequencies penetrate matter more readily.']
['how do frequencies differ?', 'Some of the properties and uses of the various EM spectrum bands are listed in Table 15.1.']
['What is visible light?', 'The narrow band of visible light is a combination of the colors of the rainbow.']
['What other things are important about visible light?', 'Figure 15.5 shows the section of the EM spectrum that includes visible light.']

['What other aspects about visible light are important?', 'The frequencies corresponding to these wavelengths are  $$\\(4.0\\  \\times \\ 10^{14}\\text{~s}^{-1}\\)$$  at the red end to  $$\\(7.9\\  \\times \\ 10^{14}\\text{~s}^{-1}\\)$$  at the violet end.']
['How is this relevant to the spectrum of electromagnetic radiation?', 'This is a very narrow range, considering that the EM spectrum spans about 20 orders of magnitude.']
['What else did you know about the color wheel?', 'As a child, you probably learned the color wheel, shown on the left in Figure 15.6.']
['What can you do with the color wheel?', 'It helps if you know what color results when you mix different colors of paint together.']
['What are the primary colors?', 'Mixing two of the primary pigment colors—magenta, yellow, or cyan—together results in a secondary color.']
['What are some of the colors that can be mixed?', 'For example, mixing cyan and yellow makes green.']
['How do you know how the colors are mixed?', 'This is called subtractive color mixing.']
['What is a different kind of color mixing?', 'Mixing different colors of light together is quite different.']
['How do you know that?', 'The diagram on the right shows additive color mixing.']
['What is that diagram showing?', 'In this case, the primary colors are red, green, and blue, and the secondary colors are cyan, magenta, and yellow.']

['What else can you tell me about the colors?', 'Mixing pigments and mixing light are different because materials absorb light by a different set of rules than does the perception of light by the eye.']
['What is the most important thing you learned about color mixing?', 'Notice that, when all colors are subtracted, the result is no color, or black.']
['Is that the same for adding colors?', 'When all colors are added, the result is white light.']
['Does the light turn out all white?', 'We see the reverse of this when white sunlight is separated into the visible spectrum by a prism or by raindrops when a rainbow appears in the sky.']
['What is the spectrum of electromagnetic radiation?', 'Humans have found uses for every part of the electromagnetic spectrum.']
['What are the uses of each range?', 'We will take a look at the uses of each range of frequencies, beginning with visible light.']
['How is visible light used?', 'Most of our uses of visible light are obvious; without it our interaction with our surroundings would be much different.']

['What other uses does light have?', 'We might forget that nearly all of our food depends on the photosynthesis process in plants, and that the energy for this process comes from the visible part of the spectrum.']
['How do plants use light?', 'Without photosynthesis, we would also have almost no oxygen in the atmosphere.']
['What are some applications of infrared?', 'The low-frequency, infrared region of the spectrum has many applications in media broadcasting.']
['What are some other applications of infrared?', 'Television, radio, cell phone, and remote-control devices all broadcast and/or receive signals with these wavelengths.']
['Are radio signals also considered radiation?', 'AM and FM radio signals are both low-frequency radiation.']
