['What is the difference between infrared and radio signals?', 'They are in different regions of the spectrum, but that is not their basic difference.']
['What does AM stand for?', 'AM and FM are abbreviations for amplitude modulation and frequency modulation.']
['Why are they different?', 'Information in AM signals has the form of changes in amplitude of the radio waves; information in FM signals has the form of changes in wave frequency.']
['What is one of the other applications?', 'Another application of long-wavelength radiation is found in microwave ovens.']
['What are microwave ovens?', 'These appliances cook or warm food by irradiating it with EM radiation in the microwave frequency range.']
['What type of microwaves are used in cooking?', 'Most kitchen microwaves use a frequency of  $$\\(2.45\\  \\times \\ 10^{9}\\)$$ Hz.']
['Why do microwaves cook food?', 'These waves have the right amount of energy to cause polar molecules, such as water, to rotate faster.']
['What is polar?', 'Polar molecules are those that have a partial charge separation.']
['What happens when they rotate faster?', 'The rotational energy of these molecules is given up to surrounding matter as heat.']
['What is the Radarange?', 'The first microwave ovens were called Radaranges because they were based on radar technology  developed during World War II.']

['What does radio have to do with electromagnetic radiation?', 'Radar uses radiation with wavelengths similar to those of microwaves to detect the location and speed of distant objects, such as airplanes, weather formations, and motor vehicles.']
['How does radar obtain information?', 'Radar information is obtained by receiving and analyzing the echoes of microwaves reflected by an object.']
['How can speed of the object be determined?', 'The speed of the object can be measured using the Doppler shift of the returning waves.']
['What is the Doppler shift?', 'This is the same effect you learned about when you studied sound waves.']

['What else is similar about sound waves and electromagnetic radiation?', 'Like sound waves, EM waves are shifted to higher frequencies by an object moving toward an observer, and to lower frequencies by an object moving away from the observer.']
['What does this effect do to galaxies?', 'Astronomers use this same Doppler effect to measure the speed at which distant galaxies are moving away from us.']

['What happens when the Doppler effect reaches the visible spectrum?', 'In this case, the shift in frequency is called the red shift, because visible frequencies are shifted toward the lower-frequency, red end of the spectrum.']
['What type of radiation?', 'Exposure to any radiation with frequencies greater than those of visible light carries some health hazards.']
['What are the hazards?', 'All types of radiation in this range are known to cause cell damage.']
['What else is significant?', 'The danger is related to the high energy and penetrating ability of these EM waves.']
['How is the damage sustained?', 'The likelihood of being harmed by any of this radiation depends largely on the amount of exposure.']
['How does one try to minimize exposure?', 'Most people try to reduce exposure to UV radiation from sunlight by using sunscreen and protective clothing.']
['What other types of radiation are dangerous?', 'Physicians still use X-rays to diagnose medical problems, but the intensity of the radiation used is extremely low.']
['What type of images are produced?', 'Figure 15.8 shows an X-ray image of a patient’s chest cavity.']
['What are some examples of medical imaging techniques?', 'One medical-imaging technique that involves no danger of exposure is magnetic resonance imaging (MRI).']
['Why is this technique used?', 'MRI is an important imaging and research tool in medicine, producing highly detailed two- and three-dimensional images.']
['What are radio waves?', 'Radio waves are broadcast, absorbed, and reemitted in a resonance process that is sensitive to the density of nuclei, usually hydrogen nuclei—protons.']
['What kind of radiation is it?', 'In a vacuum, all electromagnetic radiation travels at the same incredible speed of 3.00 × 108 m/s, which is equal to 671 million miles per hour.']
['What else is interesting in this section?', 'This is one of the fundamental physical constants.']
['What is that constant called?', 'It is referred to as the speed of light and is given the symbol c.']
['How did it travel?', 'The space between celestial bodies is a near vacuum, so the light we see from the Sun, stars, and other planets has traveled here at the speed of light.']
['What did it do?', 'Keep in mind that all EM radiation travels at this speed.']
['How does it do that?', 'All the different wavelengths of radiation that leave the Sun make the trip to Earth in the same amount of time.']
['How long does it take to make that trip?', 'That trip takes 8.3 minutes.']

['How long does it take to travel elsewhere?', 'Light from the nearest star, besides the Sun, takes 4.2 years to reach Earth, and light from the nearest galaxy—a dwarf galaxy that orbits the Milky Way—travels 25,000 years on its way to Earth.']
['What happens?', 'You can see why we call very long distances astronomical.']
['What is the physical medium?', 'When light travels through a physical medium, its speed is always less than the speed of light.']
['What is an example of the physical medium?', 'For example, light travels in water at three-fourths the value of c.']
['What other examples are there?', 'In air, light has a speed that is just slightly slower than in empty space: 99.97 percent of c. Diamond slows light down to just 41 percent of c.']
['What else is important about physical media?', 'When light changes speeds at a boundary between media, it also changes direction.']
['What changes direction?', 'The greater the difference in speeds, the more the path of light bends.']
['What else did you learn?', 'In other chapters, we look at this bending, called refraction, in greater detail.']
['Why did they introduce refraction?', 'We introduce refraction here to help explain a phenomenon called thin-film interference.']
['What is light scattering?', 'This occurs when light is both refracted by and reflected from a very thin film.']
['What is a light scattering diagram?', 'The diagram shows the path of light through such a thin film.']
['What are the symbols?', 'The symbols n1, n2, and n3 indicate that light travels at different speeds in each of the three materials.']
['What are interference and diffraction?', 'Learn more about this topic in the chapter on diffraction and interference.']
['What can I learn from this study material?', 'Figure 15.9 shows the result of thin film interference on the surface of soap bubbles.']
['What is the explanation of thin film interference?', 'Because ray 2 travels a greater distance, the two rays become out of phase.']
['What does that mean?', 'That is, the crests of the two emerging waves are no longer moving together.']
['Why is this problematic?', 'This causes interference, which reinforces the intensity of the wavelengths of light that create the bands of color.']
['Why are the color bands separated?', 'The color bands are separated because each color has a different wavelength.']

['What else can you tell me about thin film interference?', 'Also, the thickness of the film is not uniform, and different thicknesses cause colors of different wavelengths to interfere in different places.']
['How thick is the film?', 'Note that the film must be very, very thin—somewhere in the vicinity of the wavelengths of visible light.']
['What are the most common types of electromagnetic waves?', 'You have probably experienced how polarized sunglasses reduce glare from the surface of water or snow.']
['What causes this effect?', 'The effect is caused by the wave nature of light.']

['What are the other characteristics of electromagnetic waves?', 'Looking back at Figure 15.2, we see that the electric field moves in only one direction perpendicular to the direction of propagation.']
['What about the magnetic field?', 'Light from most sources vibrates in all directions perpendicular to propagation.']
['What can you tell me about the polarized field?', 'Light with an electric field that vibrates in only one direction is called polarized.']
['How is it visualized?', 'A diagram of polarized light would look like Figure 15.2.']
['What is a polarizing filter?', 'Polarized glasses are an example of a polarizing filter.']
['What is polarized glasses?', 'These glasses absorb most of the horizontal light waves and transmit the vertical waves.']
['Why do they absorb the horizontal waves?', 'This cuts down glare, which is caused by horizontal waves.']
['How do they work?', 'Figure 15.10 shows how waves traveling along a rope can be used as a model of how a polarizing filter works.']
['What is a vertically polarized wave?', 'The oscillations in one rope are in a vertical plane and are said to be vertically polarized.']
['What is horizontally polarized?', 'Those in the other rope are in a horizontal plane and are horizontally polarized.']
['What happens with a horizontally polarized wave?', 'If a vertical slit is placed on the first rope, the waves pass through.']
['What happens with a vertical slit?', 'However, a vertical slit blocks the horizontally polarized waves.']
['What are the Rope Models?', 'For EM waves, the direction of the electric field oscillation is analogous to the disturbances on the ropes.']
['Which types of electromagnetic wave behavior can light have?', 'Light can also be polarized by reflection.']
['What happens to polarized light?', 'Most of the light reflected from water, glass, or any highly reflective surface is polarized horizontally.']
['What can you learn from this information?', 'Figure 15.11 shows the effect of a polarizing lens on light reflected from the surface of water.']
['What is the relationship among these angles?', 'We can use the speed of light, c, to carry out several simple but interesting calculations.']
['What is a simple calculation?', 'If we know the distance to a celestial object, we can calculate how long it takes its light to reach us.']
['What does this calculation tell you?', 'Of course, we can also make the reverse calculation if we know the time it takes for the light to travel to us.']
['What happens when you know the time it takes?', 'For an object at a very great distance from Earth, it takes many years for its light to reach us.']
['What does this tell us?', 'This means that we are looking at the object as it existed in the distant past.']
['What can this tell us about the object?', 'The object may, in fact, no longer exist.']
['What is a light year?', 'Very large distances in the universe are measured in light years.']

['How do you calculate a light year?', 'One light year is the distance that light travels in one year, which is  $$\\(9.46\\  \\times \\ 10^{12}\\)$$ kilometers or $$\\(5.88\\  \\times \\ 10^{12}\\)$$ miles (…and 1012 is a trillion!).']
['What other information is helpful about the article?', 'The rate at which light is radiated from a source is called luminous flux, P, and it is measured in lumens (lm).']
['What else is important about this article?', 'Energy-saving light bulbs, which provide more luminous flux for a given use of electricity, are now available.']
['What types of light bulbs are available?', 'One of these bulbs is called a compact fluorescent lamp; another is an LED (light-emitting diode) bulb.']

['Why should we use energy-saving light bulbs?', 'If you wanted to replace an old incandescent bulb with an energy saving bulb, you would want the new bulb to have the same brightness as the old one.']
['How can you tell which bulb has the same brightness?', 'To compare bulbs accurately, you would need to compare the lumens each one puts out.']
['What other information about wattage is important?', 'Comparing wattage—that is, the electric power used—would be misleading.']
['How else can we know how many lumens a bulb produces?', 'Both wattage and lumens are stated on the packaging.']
['What is luminous flux?', 'The luminous flux of a bulb might be 2,000 lm.']
['What does it account for?', 'That accounts for all the light radiated in all directions.']
['Does it still help?', 'However, what we really need to know is how much light falls on an object, such as a book, at a specific distance.']
['How are lumens and lux related?', 'The number of lumens per square meter is called illuminance, and is given in units of lux (lx).']
['How is luminous flux determined?', 'Picture a light bulb in the middle of a sphere with a 1-m radius.']
['How large is the sphere?', 'The total surface of the sphere equals 4πr2 m2.']
['What does that tell us about illuminance?', 'The illuminance is now only one-fourth as great, because the r2 term in the denominator is 4 instead of 1.']
['What else does that tell us about illuminance?', 'Figure 15.12 shows how illuminance decreases with the inverse square of the distance.']
['What else did you find interesting about this material?', 'There are three ways, as shown in Figure 16.2, in which light can travel from a source to another location.']
['What are the three ways?', 'It can come directly from the source through empty space, such as from the Sun to Earth.']
['What else is important?', 'Light can travel to an object through various media, such as air and glass.']
['How does it travel through these things?', 'Light can also arrive at an object after being reflected, such as by a mirror.']
['What happens to light in all these cases?', 'In all these cases, light is modeled as traveling in a straight line, called a ray.']

['What does light do when it meets certain things?', 'Light may change direction when it encounters the surface of a different material (such as a mirror) or when it passes from one material to another (such as when passing from air into glass).']
['What happens to the light after it changes direction?', 'It then continues in a straight line—that is, as a ray.']
['Where does the word ray come from?', 'The word ray comes from mathematics.']
['What does it mean?', 'Here it means a straight line that originates from some point.']
['What other interesting information did you find?', 'It is acceptable to visualize light rays as laser rays (or even science fiction depictions of ray guns).']

['What was the first thing you learned about light?', 'Because light moves in straight lines, that is, as rays, and changes directions when it interacts with matter, it can be described through geometry and trigonometry.']
['What is the name of this part of optics?', 'This part of optics, described by straight lines and angles, is therefore called geometric optics.']

['What other things did you find interesting?', 'There are two laws that govern how light changes direction when it interacts with matter: the law of reflection, for situations in which light bounces off matter; and the law of refraction, for situations in which light passes through matter.']
['What was the next major point?', 'In this section, we consider the geometric optics of reflection.']
['What does mirror reflect?', 'Whenever we look into a mirror or squint at sunlight glinting from a lake, we are seeing a reflection.']
['What is the law of reflection?', 'The law of reflection states:']
['What else does it state?', 'The angle of reflection,  $$\\(\\theta_{\\text{r}}\\)$$, equals the angle of incidence,  $$\\(\\theta_{\\text{i}}\\)$$.']
['What is the law of reflection?', 'This law governs the behavior of all waves when they interact with a smooth surface, and therefore describe the behavior of light waves as well.']
['What else do you find interesting in this article?', 'The reflection of light is simplified when light is treated as a ray.']

['How is this done?', 'This concept is illustrated in Figure 16.3, which also shows how the angles are measured relative to the line perpendicular to the surface at the point where the light ray strikes it.']
['What is that line called?', 'This perpendicular line is also called the normal line, or just the normal.']
['What else can you tell me?', 'Light reflected in this way is referred to as specular (from the Latin word for mirror: speculum).']
['What are characteristics of mirrors?', 'We expect to see reflections from smooth surfaces, but Figure 16.4, illustrates how a rough surface reflects light.']

['What happens when you have rough surfaces?', 'Because the light is reflected from different parts of the surface at different angles, the rays go in many different directions, so the reflected light is diffused.']
['What can diffused light be used for?', 'Diffused light allows you to read a printed page from almost any angle because some of the rays go in different directions.']
['What other objects can be seen from many angles?', 'Many objects, such as people, clothing, leaves, and walls, have rough surfaces and can be seen from many angles.']
['What are the characteristics of mirrors?', 'A mirror, on the other hand, has a smooth surface and reflects light at specific angles.']
['What kind of object are you looking at in your mirror?', 'When we see ourselves in a mirror, it appears that our image is actually behind the mirror.']
['What else can you tell me about the mirror?', 'We see the light coming from a direction determined by the law of reflection.']
['What are the angles in between?', 'The angles are such that our image is exactly the same distance behind the mirror, di, as the distance we stand away from the mirror, do.']

['What else can you tell me about mirrors?', 'Although these mirror images make objects appear to be where they cannot be (such as behind a solid wall), the images are not figments of our imagination.']
['What else is significant about the mirrors?', 'Mirror images can be photographed and videotaped by instruments and look just as they do to our eyes, which are themselves optical instruments.']
['What is an image in a mirror?', 'An image in a mirror is said to be a virtual image, as opposed to a real image.']
['What is the difference between a real and virtual image?', 'A virtual image is formed when light rays appear to diverge from a point without actually doing so.']
['What does this figure help illustrate?', 'Figure 16.5 helps illustrate how a flat mirror forms an image.']
['What does the figure show?', 'Two rays are shown emerging from the same point, striking the mirror, and reflecting into the observer’s eye.']
['What happens after this?', 'The rays can diverge slightly, and both still enter the eye.']
['What else do we know about a flat mirror?', 'If the rays are extrapolated backward, they seem to originate from a common point behind the mirror, allowing us to locate the image.']
['What else do we know about a flat mirror?', 'The paths of the reflected rays into the eye are the same as if they had come directly from that point behind the mirror.']

['What else can we say about a flat mirror?', 'Using the law of reflection—the angle of reflection equals the angle of incidence—we can see that the image and object are the same distance from the mirror.']
['What are the two different images?', 'This is a virtual image, as defined earlier.']
['What characteristics are there?', 'Some mirrors are curved instead of flat.']
['What happens if there is a curve in the mirror?', 'A mirror that curves inward is called a concave mirror, whereas one that curves outward is called a convex mirror.']
['What can you find on the internet?', 'Pick up a well-polished metal spoon and you can see an example of each type of curvature.']
['What do you think of that?', 'The side of the spoon that holds the food is a concave mirror; the back of the spoon is a convex mirror.']
['Is there any other explanation of this?', 'Observe your image on both sides of the spoon.']
['What are ray diagrams?', 'Ray diagrams can be used to find the point where reflected rays converge or appear to converge, or the point from which rays appear to diverge.']
['Where do ray diagrams start?', 'This is called the focal point, F.']

['What is F?', 'The distance from F to the mirror along the central axis (the line perpendicular to the center of the mirror’s surface) is called the focal length, f. Figure 16.9 shows the focal points of concave and convex mirrors.']
['What type of mirrors are these?', 'Images formed by a concave mirror vary, depending on which side of the focal point the object is placed.']

['What else can the mirror be used for?', 'For any object placed on the far side of the focal point with respect to the mirror, the rays converge in front of the mirror to form a real image, which can be projected onto a surface, such as a screen or sheet of paper']
['What else did you learn?', 'However, for an object located inside the focal point with respect to the concave mirror, the image is virtual.']
['What is an image that appears behind the mirror?', 'For a convex mirror the image is always virtual—that is, it appears to be behind the mirror.']
['What else did you learn?', 'The ray diagrams in Figure 16.10 show how to determine the nature of the image formed by concave and convex mirrors.']
['What kind of mirrors are used in the world?', 'You should be able to notice everyday applications of curved mirrors.']
['What examples are there?', 'One common example is the use of security mirrors in stores, as shown in Figure 16.11.']
['Which part of the telescope is used to reflect light?', 'Some telescopes also use curved mirrors and no lenses (except in the eyepieces) both to magnify images and to change the path of light.']
['Which telescope shows the best image?', 'Figure 16.12 shows a Schmidt-Cassegrain telescope.']
['What is the Schmidt-Cassegrain telescope used for?', 'This design uses a spherical primary concave mirror and a convex secondary mirror.']
['How does the image appear on the focal plane?', 'The image is projected onto the focal plane by light passing through the perforated primary mirror.']

['What is the effective focal length of the telescope?', 'The effective focal length of such a telescope is the focal length of the primary mirror multiplied by the magnification of the secondary mirror.']
['Why does the effective focal length matter?', 'The result is a telescope with a focal length much greater than the length of the telescope itself.']
['What is Parabolic mirror', 'A parabolic concave mirror has the very useful property that all light from a distant source, on reflection by the mirror surface, is directed to the focal point.']
['What are the other properties', 'Likewise, a light source placed at the focal point directs all the light it emits in parallel lines away from the mirror.']
['What is Parabolic Mirror used for', 'This case is illustrated by the ray diagram in Figure 16.13.']
['How is it used', 'The light source in a car headlight, for example, is located at the focal point of a parabolic mirror.']

['What else does Table 16.1 contain?', 'Parabolic mirrors are also used to collect sunlight and direct it to a focal point, where it is transformed into heat, which in turn can be used to generate electricity.']
['What is another application of parabolic mirrors?', 'This application is shown in Figure 16.14.']

['What are the equations?', 'Curved mirrors and the images they create involve a fairly small number of variables: the mirror’s radius of curvature, R; the focal length, f; the distances of the object and image from the mirror, do and di, respectively; and the heights of the object and image, ho and hi, respectively.']
['What signs do the variables have?', 'The signs of these values indicate whether the image is inverted, erect (upright), real, or virtual.']
['What are the equations?', 'We now look at the equations that relate these variables and apply them to everyday problems.']
['What are the implications of this equation?', 'This equation can be rearranged several ways.']
['What are some examples of this?', 'For example, it may be written to solve for focal length.']
['What is magnification?', 'Magnification, m, is the ratio of the size of the image, hi, to the size of the object, ho.']
['What is the value of m?', 'The value of m can be calculated in two ways.']
['What is the Pythagorean theorem?', 'This relationship can be written to solve for any of the variables involved.']
['What is an example of a variable involved in this relationship?', 'For example, the height of the image is given by']
['How did we get to this equation?', 'We saved the simplest equation for last.']
['What is the simplest equation for the radius of curvature?', 'The radius of curvature of a curved mirror, R, is simply twice the focal length.']

['What information can we get from the algebraic sign?', 'A negative di indicates a virtual image; a positive value indicates a real image A negative hi indicates an inverted image; a positive value indicates an erect image']
['What other information can we get from the algebraic sign?', 'For concave mirrors, f is positive; for convex mirrors, f is negative']
['What is the law of refraction?', 'You may have noticed some odd optical phenomena when looking into a fish tank.']
['What are these odd optical phenomena?', 'For example, you may see the same fish appear to be in two different places (Figure 16.16).']

['How do you know that it is in two different places?', 'This is because light coming to you from the fish changes direction when it leaves the tank and, in this case, light rays traveling along two different paths both reach our eyes.']

['How is this refraction of light different?', 'The changing of a light ray’s direction (loosely called bending) when it passes a boundary between materials of different composition, or between layers in single material where there are changes in temperature and density, is called refraction.']
['What else does the law of refraction do?', 'Refraction is responsible for a tremendous range of optical phenomena, from the action of lenses to voice transmission through optical fibers.']
['Why does light bend when it moves in a particular direction?', 'It is because light changes speed when going from one material to another.']
['What is light waves?', 'This behavior is typical of all waves and is especially easy to apply to light because light waves have very small wavelengths, and so they can be treated as rays.']
['What else should we know?', 'Before we study the law of refraction, it is useful to discuss the speed of light and how it varies between different media.']
['What happened to the speed of light in 1879?', 'The speed of light is now known to great precision.']

['What is the value of this?', 'In fact, the speed of light in a vacuum, c, is so important, and is so precisely known, that it is accepted as one of the basic physical quantities, and has the fixed value']
['What does this mean?', 'where the approximate value of 3.00  $$\\(\\times\\)$$  108 m/s is used whenever three-digit precision is sufficient.']
['What else does this tell me?', 'The speed of light through matter is less than it is in a vacuum, because light interacts with atoms in a material.']
['How does this work?', 'The speed of light depends strongly on the type of material, given that its interaction with different atoms, crystal lattices, and other substructures varies.']
['What else can we learn from this information?', 'We define the index of refraction, n, of a material to be']
['What is $$[n = fraccv,]?', 'where v is the observed speed of light in the material.']

['What is an indices of refraction?', 'Because the speed of light is always less than c in matter and equals c only in a vacuum, the index of refraction (plural: indices of refraction) is always greater than or equal to one.']
['What did you do next?', 'Figure 16.17 provides an analogy for and a description of how a ray of light changes direction when it passes from one medium to another.']
['How did the figure come about?', 'As in the previous section, the angles are measured relative to a perpendicular to the surface at the point where the light ray crosses it.']
['What other things are relevant in the analogy?', 'The change in direction of the light ray depends on how the speed of light changes.']
['What is the relation between speed and direction?', 'The change in the speed of light is related to the indices of refraction of the media involved.']
['What is the relation between indices of refraction and direction?', 'In the situations shown in Figure 16.17, medium 2 has a greater index of refraction than medium 1.']
['What does this mean?', 'This difference in index of refraction means that the speed of light is less in medium 2 than in medium 1.']
['What is the analogy?', 'Note that, in Figure 16.17(a), the path of the ray moves closer to the perpendicular when the ray slows down.']
['Is that correct?', 'Conversely, in Figure 16.17(b), the path of the ray moves away from the perpendicular when the ray speeds up.']
['Is that correct?', 'The path is exactly reversible.']
['What else is important about this section?', 'In both cases, you can imagine what happens by thinking about pushing a lawn mower from a footpath onto grass, and vice versa.']
['Why is that?', 'Going from the footpath to grass, the right front wheel is slowed and pulled to the side as shown.']
['Why is that?', 'This is the same change in direction for light when it goes from a fast medium to a slow one.']
['Is that correct?', 'When going from the grass to the footpath, the left front wheel moves faster than the others, and the mower changes direction as shown.']
['Is that correct?', 'This, too, is the same change in direction as light going from slow to fast.']
['What is the relationship between incident angle and speed?', 'The amount that a light ray changes direction depends both on the incident angle and the amount that the speed changes.']

['What is the effect of speed change on light?', 'For a ray at a given incident angle, a large change in speed causes a large change in direction, and thus a large change in the angle of refraction.']

['How can you find out the exact mathematical relationship between incident angle and speed change?', 'The exact mathematical relationship is the law of refraction, or Snell’s law, which is stated in equation form as']

['How is this used in science?', 'Here, n1 and n2 are the indices of refraction for media 1 and 2, respectively, and θ1 and θ2 are the angles between the rays and the perpendicular in the respective media 1 and 2, as shown in Figure 16.17.']
['How are they different?', 'The incoming ray is called the incident ray and the outgoing ray is called the refracted ray.']
['What are the associated angles?', 'The associated angles are called the angle of incidence and the angle of refraction.']
['Are there any other aspects about this that you want to know?', 'Later, we apply Snell’s law to some practical situations.']
['What is dispersion?', 'Dispersion is defined as the spreading of white light into the wavelengths of which it is composed.']
['Why does it spread?', 'This happens because the index of refraction varies slightly with wavelength.']
['What else can dispersion do?', 'Figure 16.18 shows how a prism disperses white light into the colors of the rainbow.']
['What is the relationship between refraction and reflection?', 'Rainbows are produced by a combination of refraction and reflection.']
['How does light pass through water?', 'Light enters a drop of water and is reflected from the back of the drop, as shown in Figure 16.19.']
['What is the relationship between refraction and reflection?', 'The light is refracted both as it enters and as it leaves the drop.']
['What happens during refraction?', 'Because the index of refraction of water varies with wavelength, the light is dispersed and a rainbow is observed.']
['Why does a mirror reflect less than 90 percent of light?', 'A good-quality mirror reflects more than 90 percent of the light that falls on it; the mirror absorbs the rest.']
['Why does the mirror absorb light?', 'But, it would be useful to have a mirror that reflects all the light that falls on it.']
['Can we have total reflection?', 'Interestingly, we can produce total reflection using an aspect of refraction.']
['What does refraction involve?', 'Consider what happens when a ray of light strikes the surface between two materials, such as is shown in Figure 16.20(a).']
['What happens when the light strikes the surface between two materials?', 'Part of the light crosses the boundary and is refracted; the rest is reflected.']
['What is an example of refraction?', 'If, as shown in the figure, the index of refraction for the second medium is less than the first, the ray bends away from the perpendicular.']

['How does this differ from what happens when light enters a window?', 'Because n1 > n2, the angle of refraction is greater than the angle of incidence—that is,  $$\\(\\theta_{\\text{2}}\\)$$ > $$\\(\\theta_{\\text{1}}\\)$$ .']
['What is a difference between light entering the window and light leaving the window?', 'Now, imagine what happens as the incident angle is increased.']
["The incident angle increases because it is greater than the ray's normal.", 'This causes  $$\\(\\theta_{\\text{2}}\\)$$  to increase as well.']
['How does this effect the light?', 'The largest the angle of refraction,  $$\\(\\theta_{\\text{2}}\\)$$, can be is 90°, as shown in Figure 16.20(b).']

['What is the critical angle?', 'The critical angle,  $$\\(\\theta_{\\text{c}}\\)$$, for a combination of two materials is defined to be the incident angle,  $$\\(\\theta_{\\text{1}}\\)$$, which produces an angle of refraction of 90°.']
['What else does the article say?', 'That is,  $$\\(\\theta_{\\text{c}}\\)$$  is the incident angle for which  $$\\(\\theta_{\\text{2}}\\)$$ = 90°.']

['What else is significant about this article?', 'If the incident angle,  $$\\(\\theta_{\\text{1}}\\)$$, is greater than the critical angle, as shown in Figure 16.20(c), then all the light is reflected back into medium 1, a condition called total internal reflection.']
['What is the relationship between angles and indices of refraction?', 'Recall that Snell’s law states the relationship between angles and indices of refraction.']

["What's the first question I want to ask you?", 'When the incident angle equals the critical angle ( $$\\(\\theta_{\\text{1}}\\)$$= $$\\(\\theta_{\\text{c}}\\)$$), the angle of refraction is 90° ( $$\\(\\theta_{\\text{2}}\\)$$= 90°).']
['What happens next?', 'Noting that sin 90° = 1, Snell’s law in this case becomes']

['What is total internal reflection?', 'Total internal reflection occurs for any incident angle greater than the critical angle,  $$\\(\\theta_{\\text{c}}\\)$$, and it can only occur when the second medium has an index of refraction less than the first.']

['What happens if the incident angle is smaller than this?', 'Note that the previous equation is written for a light ray that travels in medium 1 and reflects from medium 2, as shown in Figure 16.20.']
['What are some of the important applications?', 'There are several important applications of total internal reflection.']
['What can it explain about diamonds?', 'Total internal reflection, coupled with a large index of refraction, explains why diamonds sparkle more than other materials.']

['What other interesting facts about this material?', 'The critical angle for a diamond-to-air surface is only 24.4°; so, when light enters a diamond, it has trouble getting back out (Figure 16.21).']
['How does the light do this?', 'Although light freely enters the diamond at different angles, it can exit only if it makes an angle less than 24.4° with the normal to a given surface.']
['How are diamonds used?', 'Facets on diamonds are specifically intended to make this unlikely, so that the light can exit only in certain places.']

['What else does this have to do with sparkle?', 'Diamonds with very few impurities are very clear, so the light makes many internal reflections and is concentrated at the few places it can exit—hence the sparkle.']
['What is it about?', 'A light ray that strikes an object that consists of two mutually perpendicular reflecting surfaces is reflected back exactly parallel to the direction from which it came.']
['Why is this true?', 'This parallel reflection is true whenever the reflecting surfaces are perpendicular, and it is independent of the angle of incidence.']
['What is an example of this?', 'Such an object is called a corner reflector because the light bounces from its inside corner.']

['What kind of objects are there?', 'Many inexpensive reflector buttons on bicycles, cars, and warning signs have corner reflectors designed to return light in the direction from which it originates.']
['What else do you know about the material?', 'Corner reflectors are perfectly efficient when the conditions for total internal reflection are satisfied.']
['What else can you tell me about this material?', 'With common materials, it is easy to obtain a critical angle that is less than 45°.']
['What else did you find interesting?', 'One use of these perfect mirrors is in binoculars, as shown in Figure 16.22.']
['What else do you know about this material?', 'Another application is for periscopes used in submarines.']
['What is the most important information I should know for this assignment?', 'Fiber optics are one common application of total internal reflection.']
['What is fiber optics?', 'In communications, fiber optics are used to transmit telephone, internet, and cable TV signals, and they use the transmission of light down fibers of plastic or glass.']

['What happens when light enters the fiber?', 'Because the fibers are thin, light entering one is likely to strike the inside surface at an angle greater than the critical angle and, thus, be totally reflected (Figure 16.23).']

['What is the design of the fiber optics?', 'The index of refraction outside the fiber must be smaller than inside, a condition that is satisfied easily by coating the outside of the fiber with a material that has an appropriate refractive index.']
['Does the coating have to be on both sides of the fiber?', 'In fact, most fibers have a varying refractive index to allow more light to be guided along the fiber through total internal reflection.']
['What is reflected along the fiber?', 'Rays are reflected around corners as shown in the figure, making the fibers into tiny light pipes.']
['What are lenses used for?', 'Lenses are found in a huge array of optical instruments, ranging from a simple magnifying glass to the eye to a camera’s zoom lens.']
['what can be told about the law of refraction?', 'In this section, we use the law of refraction to explore the properties of lenses and how they form images.']
['What is one important fact you need to know about this topic?', 'Some of what we learned in the earlier discussion of curved mirrors also applies to the study of lenses.']

['What is the difference between the mirror and lens characteristics?', 'Concave, convex, focal point F, and focal length f have the same meanings as before, except each measurement is made from the center of the lens instead of the surface of the mirror.']

['What was the explanation for that?', 'The convex lens shown in Figure 16.25 has been shaped so that all light rays that enter it parallel to its central axis cross one another at a single point on the opposite side of the lens.']
['How does that help with the measurement?', 'The central axis, or axis, is defined to be a line normal to the lens at its center.']
['What happens when a lens of this type is used?', 'Such a lens is called a converging lens because of the converging effect it has on light rays.']

['What else is a fact we need to know?', 'An expanded view of the path of one ray through the lens is shown in Figure 16.25 to illustrate how the ray changes direction both as it enters and as it leaves the lens.']

['What happens when you look through it?', 'Because the index of refraction of the lens is greater than that of air, the ray moves toward the perpendicular as it enters and away from the perpendicular as it leaves.']
['Is that correct?', '(This is in accordance with the law of refraction.)']
['How is that reflected?', 'As a result of the shape of the lens, light is thus bent toward the axis at both surfaces.']
['What are the other characteristics of lenses?', 'Note that rays from a light source placed at the focal point of a converging lens emerge parallel from the other side of the lens.']
['What does a converging lens do?', 'You may have heard of the trick of using a converging lens to focus rays of sunlight to a point.']
['Why did they do this?', 'Such a concentration of light energy can produce enough heat to ignite paper.']

['What other information did we learn?', 'Figure 16.26 shows a concave lens and the effect it has on rays of light that enter it parallel to its axis (the path taken by ray 2 in the figure is the axis of the lens).']
['Why is the lens a diverging lens?', 'The concave lens is a diverging lens because it causes the light rays to bend away (diverge) from its axis.']

['What is the focal point of the diverging lens?', 'In this case, the lens has been shaped so all light rays entering it parallel to its axis appear to originate from the same point, F, defined to be the focal point of a diverging lens.']
['What is the focal length of a lens?', 'The distance from the center of the lens to the focal point is again called the focal length, or “ƒ,” of the lens.']
['How can you find the focal length of a lens?', 'Note that the focal length of a diverging lens is defined to be negative.']

['What else happened in this section?', 'An expanded view of the path of one ray through the lens is shown in Figure 16.26 to illustrate how the shape of the lens, together with the law of refraction, causes the ray to follow its particular path and diverge.']
['What is one of the characteristics of a lens?', 'The power, P, of a lens is very easy to calculate.']
['How does it work?', 'It is simply the reciprocal of the focal length, expressed in meters']
['How is the unit of power determined?', 'The units of power are diopters, D, which are expressed in reciprocal meters.']
['What other information did you find interesting in this article?', 'If the focal length is negative, as it is for the diverging lens in Figure 16.26, then the power is also negative.']
['What is an example of image formation?', 'In some circumstances, a lens forms an image at an obvious location, such as when a movie projector casts an image onto a screen.']
['How does a movie projector work?', 'In other cases, the image location is less obvious.']
['What is image formation?', 'We use ray tracing for thin lenses to illustrate how they form images, and we develop equations to describe the image-formation quantitatively.']
['What are the rules for ray tracing?', 'These are the rules for ray tracing:']
['What happens to a ray passing through the center of a converging lens?', 'Consider an object some distance away from a converging lens, as shown in Figure 16.27.']
['How can you determine the location of an image?', 'To find the location and size of the image formed, we trace the paths of select light rays originating from one point on the object.']
['What is the originating point?', 'In this example, the originating point is the top of a woman’s head.']
['How many rays do you need to trace?', 'Figure 16.27 shows three rays from the top of the object that can be traced using the ray-tracing rules just listed.']
['What will happen after tracing these rays?', 'Rays leave this point traveling in many directions, but we concentrate on only a few, which have paths that are easy to trace.']
['What do we determine from these rays?', 'The first ray is one that enters the lens parallel to its axis and passes through the focal point on the other side (rule 1).']
['What is the other ray?', 'The second ray passes through the center of the lens without changing direction (rule 3).']
['What happens to the third ray?', 'The third ray passes through the nearer focal point on its way into the lens and leaves the lens parallel to its axis (rule 4).']
['What is the final result?', 'The image of the top of the person’s head is located at this point.']
['How many points do you need to trace?', 'Rays from another point on the object, such as the belt buckle, also cross at another common point, forming a complete image, as shown.']
['What happened after tracing these rays?', 'Although three rays are traced in Figure 16.27, only two are necessary to locate the image.']
['What is the best way to trace these rays?', 'It is best to trace rays for which there are simple ray-tracing rules.']
['What is the application of ray tracing?', 'Before applying ray tracing to other situations, let us consider the example shown in Figure 16.27 in more detail.']
['What is this about?', 'The image formed in Figure 16.27 is a real image—meaning, it can be projected.']
['What is projection?', 'That is, light rays from one point on the object actually cross at the location of the image and can be projected onto a screen, a piece of film, or the retina of an eye.']
['What is the object distance, do?', 'In Figure 16.27, the object distance, do, is greater than f.']
['What is the next step in this topic?', 'Now we consider a ray diagram for a convex lens where do< f, and another diagram for a concave lens.']
['What does case 1 mean?', 'The examples in Figure 16.27 and Figure 16.28 represent the three possible cases—case 1, case 2, and case 3—summarized in Table 16.3.']
['What does the table mean?', 'In the table, m is magnification; the other symbols have the same meaning as they did for curved mirrors.']
['What are the equations?', 'Image formation by lenses can also be calculated from simple equations.']
['What are the equations?', 'We learn how these calculations are carried out near the end of this section.']
['What is a lens?', 'Some common applications of lenses with which we are all familiar are magnifying glasses, eyeglasses, cameras, microscopes, and telescopes.']
['Do we need to look at other applications of lenses?', 'We take a look at the latter two examples, which are the most complex.']
['What is an example of a telescope without lens?', 'We have already seen the design of a telescope that uses only mirrors in Figure 16.12.']
['What is an example of a telescope with two lenses?', 'Figure 16.29 shows the design of a telescope that uses two lenses.']
['What is an example of a telescope with three lenses?', 'Part (a) of the figure shows the design of the telescope used by Galileo.']
['Why is this more advantageous?', 'It produces an upright image, which is more convenient for many applications.']
['What is the telescope with four lenses?', 'Part (b) shows an arrangement of lenses used in many astronomical telescopes.']
['What is the advantage of this?', 'This design produces an inverted image, which is less of a problem when viewing celestial objects.']
["What are the four figures we're working with?", 'Figure 16.30 shows the path of light through a typical microscope.']
['What is a microscope?', 'Microscopes were first developed during the early 1600s by eyeglass makers in the Netherlands and Denmark.']
['What is a compound microscope?', 'The simplest compound microscope is constructed from two convex lenses, as shown schematically in Figure 16.30.']
['What is the first lens?', 'The first lens is called the objective lens; it has typical magnification values from 5 $$\\(\\times\\)$$  to 100 $$\\(\\times\\)$$ .']
['What are objectives?', 'In standard microscopes, the objectives are mounted such that when you switch between them, the sample remains in focus.']
['What is parfocal?', 'Objectives arranged in this way are described as parfocal.']
['What is the second lens?', 'The second lens, the eyepiece, also referred to as the ocular, has several lenses that slide inside a cylindrical barrel.']
['How does the eyepiece help focus?', 'The focusing ability is provided by the movement of both the objective lens and the eyepiece.']
['Why do you use the two lenses?', 'The purpose of a microscope is to magnify small objects, and both lenses contribute to the final magnification.']

['Why are the two lenses different?', 'In addition, the final enlarged image is produced in a location far enough from the observer to be viewed easily because the eye cannot focus on objects or images that are too close.']
['What is an example of this physics in practice?', 'Real lenses behave somewhat differently from how they are modeled using rays diagrams or the thin-lens equations.']
['What happens to real lenses in practice?', 'Real lenses produce aberrations.']
['What is aberrations?', 'An aberration is a distortion in an image.']
['Why are there different aberrations?', 'There are a variety of aberrations that result from lens size, material, thickness, and the position of the object.']
['What kind of aberrations are there?', 'One common type of aberration is chromatic aberration, which is related to color.']

['How is color related to aberrations?', 'Because the index of refraction of lenses depends on color, or wavelength, images are produced at different places and with different magnifications for different colors.']
['What is the difference between mirrors and lenses?', 'The law of reflection is independent of wavelength, so mirrors do not have this problem.']
['Why do they not have this problem?', 'This result is another advantage for the use of mirrors in optical systems such as telescopes.']
['What is the most important thing you learned in this lesson?', 'Figure 16.31(a) shows chromatic aberration for a single convex lens, and its partial correction with a two-lens system.']

['What happens to violet light in a lens?', 'The index of refraction of the lens increases with decreasing wavelength, so violet rays are refracted more than red rays, and are thus focused closer to the lens.']
['What is the problem?', 'The diverging lens corrects this in part, although it is usually not possible to do so completely.']
['What are some things to be aware of in regards to the converging lens?', 'Lenses made of different materials and with different dispersions may be used.']

['What are some examples of the lenses?', 'For example, an achromatic doublet consisting of a converging lens made of crown glass in contact with a diverging lens made of flint glass can reduce chromatic aberration dramatically (Figure 16.31(b)).']
['What does the eye do?', 'The eye is perhaps the most interesting of all optical instruments.']
['What is most interesting about the eye?', 'It is remarkable in how it forms images and in the richness of detail and color they eye can detect.']
['What else can it do?', 'However, our eyes commonly need some correction to reach what is called normal vision, but should be called ideal vision instead.']
['Why is this?', 'Image formation by our eyes and common vision correction are easy to analyze using geometric optics.']
['What is the anatomy of the eye?', 'Figure 16.32 shows the basic anatomy of the eye.']
['Is there anything interesting?', 'The cornea and lens form a system that, to a good approximation, acts as a single thin lens.']
['How does the eye create an image?', 'For clear vision, a real image must be projected onto the light-sensitive retina, which lies at a fixed distance from the lens.']
['What else does it do?', 'The lens of the eye adjusts its power to produce an image on the retina for objects at different distances.']
['How does the eye adjust for distances?', 'The center of the image falls on the fovea, which has the greatest density of light receptors and the greatest acuity (sharpness) in the visual field.']
['What is the blind spot?', 'There are no receptors at the place where the optic nerve meets the eye, which is called the blind spot.']
['Why is that?', 'An image falling on this spot cannot be seen.']

['What else did you find interesting?', 'The variable opening (or pupil) of the eye along with chemical adaptation allows the eye to detect light intensities from the lowest observable to 1010 times greater (without damage).']
['How did they do that?', 'Ten orders of magnitude is an incredible range of detection.']
['What other things do the eyes do?', 'Our eyes perform a vast number of functions, such as sense direction, movement, sophisticated colors, and distance.']
['Do the eyes process information?', 'Processing of visual nerve impulses begins with interconnections in the retina and continues in the brain.']
['How does the eye communicate with the brain?', 'The optic nerve conveys signals received by the eye to the brain.']
['What kind of indices do lenses have?', 'Refractive indices are crucial to image formation using lenses.']
['What does a table show?', 'Table 16.4 shows refractive indices relevant to the eye.']
['What is the bending of rays called?', 'The biggest change in the refractive index—and the one that causes the greatest bending of rays—occurs at the cornea rather than the lens.']
['What is the ray diagram?', 'The ray diagram in Figure 16.33 shows image formation by the cornea and lens of the eye.']
['What are the refractive indices?', 'The rays bend according to the refractive indices provided in Table 16.4.']
['Why do rays bend?', 'The cornea provides about two-thirds of the magnification of the eye because the speed of light changes considerably while traveling from air into the cornea.']
['Where does the remaining magnification come from?', 'The lens provides the remaining magnification needed to produce an image on the retina.']

['What are the layers of lens?', 'The cornea and lens can be treated as a single thin lens, although the light rays pass through several layers of material (such as the cornea, aqueous humor, several layers in the lens, and vitreous humor), changing direction at each interface.']
['How is image formed?', 'The image formed is much like the one produced by a single convex lens.']
['What was case 1?', 'This result is a case 1 image.']
['What is the image upside down?', 'Images formed in the eye are inverted, but the brain inverts them once more to make them seem upright.']
['What is the basic principle of physics?', 'As noted, the image must fall precisely on the retina to produce clear vision—that is, the image distance, di, must equal the lens-to-retina distance.']
['What does di equal to?', 'Because the lens-to-retina distance does not change, di must be the same for objects at all distances.']
['What are the other basic principles?', 'The eye manages to vary the distance by varying the power (and focal length) of the lens to accommodate for objects at various distances.']
['How do they regulate the lens power?', 'In Figure 16.33, you can see the small ciliary muscles above and below the lens that change the shape of the lens and, thus, the focal length.']
['What type of vision correction is there?', 'The need for some type of vision correction is very common.']
['How do you know this?', 'Common vision defects are easy to understand, and some are simple to correct.']
['What are common vision defects?', 'Figure 16.34 illustrates two common vision defects.']
['What is nearsightedness?', 'Nearsightedness, or myopia, is the inability to see distant objects clearly while close objects are in focus.']
['What causes this?', 'The nearsighted eye overconverges the nearly parallel rays from a distant object, and the rays cross in front of the retina.']
['What does this do to the image?', 'More divergent rays from a close object are converged on the retina, producing a clear image.']
['What is farsightedness?', 'Farsightedness, or hyperopia, is the inability to see close objects clearly whereas distant objects may be in focus.']
['What causes this?', 'A farsighted eye does not converge rays from a close object sufficiently to make the rays meet on the retina.']
['What does this do to the image?', 'Less divergent rays from a distant object can be converged for a clear image.']

['What can you tell me about nearsightedness?', 'Because the nearsighted eye overconverges light rays, the correction for nearsightedness involves placing a diverging spectacle lens in front of the eye.']
['What does the diverging lens do?', 'This lens reduces the power of an eye that has too short a focal length (Figure 16.35(a)).']
['What can you tell me about farsightedness?', 'Because the farsighted eye underconverges light rays, the correction for farsightedness is to place a converging spectacle lens in front of the eye.']
['What does the converging lens do?', 'This lens increases the power of an eye that has too long a focal length (Figure 16.35(b)).']
['What else did I tell you about the material?', 'As promised, there are no new equations to memorize.']
['What else did you promise?', 'We can use equations already presented for solving problems involving curved mirrors.']
['How do these mirrors and lenses differ?', 'Careful analysis allows you to apply these equations to lenses.']
['Is there a way for us to get more equations or better explanations?', 'Here are the equations you need']

['What is the relationship between diffraction and interference?', 'We know that visible light is the type of electromagnetic wave to which our eyes responds.']
['What does light obey?', 'As we have seen previously, light obeys the equation']

['What else did you learn?', 'where  $$\\(c = 3.00\\  \\times \\ 10^{8}\\)$$  m/s is the speed of light in vacuum, f is the frequency of the electromagnetic wave in Hz (or s–1), and  $$\\(\\lambda\\)$$  is its wavelength in m.']
['What is the range of wavelengths?', 'The range of visible wavelengths is approximately 380 to 750 nm.']
['What does the light do?', 'As is true for all waves, light travels in straight lines and acts like a ray when it interacts with objects several times as large as its wavelength.']
['Does the light follow any patterns?', 'However, when it interacts with smaller objects, it displays its wave characteristics prominently.']
['How is interference different from a light beam?', 'Interference is the identifying behavior of a wave.']
['What are the figure 17.2?', 'In Figure 17.2, both the ray and wave characteristics of light can be seen.']
['What are the ray characteristics?', 'The laser beam emitted by the observatory represents ray behavior, as it travels in a straight line.']
['What are the wave characteristics?', 'Passing a pure, one-wavelength beam through vertical slits with a width close to the wavelength of the beam reveals the wave character of light.']

['Are there other things in this figure?', 'Here we see the beam spreading out horizontally into a pattern of bright and dark regions that are caused by systematic constructive and destructive interference.']
['What is interference?', 'As it is characteristic of wave behavior, interference is observed for water waves, sound waves, and light waves.']
['what is the principle of interference?', 'That interference is a characteristic of energy propagation by waves is demonstrated more convincingly by water waves.']
['what is an example of water waves?', 'Figure 17.3 shows water waves passing through gaps between some rocks.']
['what is interference?', 'You can easily see that the gaps are similar in width to the wavelength of the waves and that this causes an interference pattern as the waves pass beyond the gaps.']
['what is interference pattern?', 'A cross-section across the waves in the foreground would show the crests and troughs characteristic of an interference pattern.']
['What kind of wave properties does light have?', 'Light has wave characteristics in various media as well as in a vacuum.']
['What do the wave properties do?', 'When light goes from a vacuum to some medium, such as water, its speed and wavelength change, but its frequency, f, remains the same.']
['How do the wave properties change?', 'The speed of light in a medium is  $$\\(v = c/n\\)$$, where n is its index of refraction.']
['What else can you tell me about the wave properties?', 'If you divide both sides of the equation  $$\\(c = f\\lambda\\)$$  by n, you get  $$\\(c/n = v = f\\lambda/n\\)$$ .']
['What is the wavelength in a medium?', 'Therefore,  $$\\(v = f\\lambda_{n}\\)$$, where  $$\\(\\lambda_{n}\\)$$  is the wavelength in a medium, and']
['What did you find interesting?', 'where  $$\\(\\lambda\\)$$  is the wavelength in vacuum and n is the medium’s index of refraction.']
['What does this mean?', 'It follows that the wavelength of light is smaller in any medium than it is in vacuum.']

['What happens to the wavelengths when they are smaller?', 'In water, for example, which has n = 1.333, the range of visible wavelengths is (380 nm)/1.333 to (760 nm)/1.333, or  $$\\(\\lambda_{n} =\\)$$ 285–570 nm.']
['What are other interesting things about this paragraph?', 'Although wavelengths change while traveling from one medium to another, colors do not, since colors are associated with frequency.']
['What is the main point of this document?', 'The Dutch scientist Christiaan Huygens (1629–1695) developed a useful technique for determining in detail how and where waves propagate.']

['How did Huygens determine in detail how and where waves propagate?', 'He used wavefronts, which are the points on a wave’s surface that share the same, constant phase (such as all the points that make up the crest of a water wave).']
['How do wavefronts propagate?', 'Huygens’s principle states, “Every point on a wavefront is a source of wavelets that spread out in the forward direction at the same speed as the wave itself.']
['What happens when wavelets spread?', 'The new wavefront is a line tangent to all of the wavelets.”']
['What does the figure 17.4 show?', 'Figure 17.4 shows how Huygens’s principle is applied.']
['What is a wavefront?', 'A wavefront is the long edge that moves; for example, the crest or the trough.']
['What happens at each point on the wavefront?', 'Each point on the wavefront emits a semicircular wave that moves at the propagation speed v.']
['What does the vector tell us about how the wavefront will be developed?', 'These are drawn later at a time, t, so that they have moved a distance  $$\\(s = vt\\)$$ .']
['What else is important to know about the wavefront?', 'The new wavefront is a line tangent to the wavelets and is where the wave is located at time t.']
['Do other types of waves work the same way?', 'Huygens’s principle works for all types of waves, including water waves, sound waves, and light waves.']
['How is the principle useful for light waves?', 'It will be useful not only in describing how light waves propagate, but also in how they interfere.']

['What was the problem we studied?', 'For light, you expect to see a sharp shadow of the doorway on the floor of the room, and you expect no light to bend around corners into other parts of the room.']

['What is another example of how the human senses can affect perception?', 'When sound passes through a door, you hear it everywhere in the room and, thus, you understand that sound spreads out when passing through such an opening.']
["What are some examples of light's non-standard behavior?", 'The answer is that the wavelengths that make up the light are very short, so that the light acts like a ray.']
['Are there any other examples of light being distorted?', 'Sound has wavelengths on the order of the size of the door, and so it bends around corners.']

['What are some of the topics in this section?', 'If light passes through smaller openings, often called slits, you can use Huygens’s principle to show that light bends as sound does (see Figure 17.5).']
['What else is in the section?', 'The bending of a wave around the edges of an opening or an obstacle is called diffraction.']
['What is diffraction?', 'Diffraction is a wave characteristic that occurs for all types of waves.']
['What is evidence?', 'If diffraction is observed for a phenomenon, it is evidence that the phenomenon is produced by waves.']
['What is an example?', 'Thus, the horizontal diffraction of the laser beam after it passes through slits in Figure 17.2 is evidence that light has the properties of a wave.']
['What are the two arguments that he used to support his position?', 'The fact that Huygens’s principle worked was not considered enough evidence to prove that light is a wave.']
['Why was he considered unpopular?', 'People were also reluctant to accept light’s wave nature because it contradicted the ideas of Isaac Newton, who was still held in high esteem.']

['Did he receive any recognition for this theory?', 'The acceptance of the wave character of light came after 1801, when the English physicist and physician Thomas Young (1773–1829) did his now-classic double-slit experiment (see Figure 17.7).']
['What other important things should you know about waves?', 'When light passes through narrow slits, it is diffracted into semicircular waves, as shown in Figure 17.8 (a).']
['What else are waves made of?', 'Pure constructive interference occurs where the waves line up crest to crest or trough to trough.']
['What happens when there is destructive interference?', 'Pure destructive interference occurs where they line up crest to trough.']
['What can you observe when light is being diffracted?', 'The light must fall on a screen and be scattered into our eyes for the pattern to be visible.']
['What is the analogous pattern for water waves?', 'An analogous pattern for water waves is shown in Figure 17.8 (b).']
['What else can you observe while looking through the slits?', 'Note that regions of constructive and destructive interference move out from the slits at well-defined angles to the original beam.']
['Are there any other things of note?', 'Those angles depend on wavelength and the distance between the slits, as you will see below.']

['What is this article about?', 'The fact that the wavelength of light of one color, or monochromatic light, can be calculated from its two-slit diffraction pattern in Young’s experiments supports the conclusion that light has wave properties.']
['What is an example of a calculation involved in this article?', 'To understand the basis of such calculations, consider how two waves travel from the slits to the screen.']
['What else is relevant to this?', 'Each slit is a different distance from a given point on the screen.']
['What does this mean?', 'Thus different numbers of wavelengths fit into each path.']

['What happens when these waves arrive at different times?', 'Waves start out from the slits in phase (crest to crest), but they will end up out of phase (crest to trough) at the screen if the paths differ in length by half a wavelength, interfering destructively.']
['What else happens?', 'If the paths differ by a whole wavelength, then the waves arrive in phase (crest to crest) at the screen, interfering constructively.']

['How else can interference be modeled?', 'More generally, if the paths taken by the two waves differ by any half-integral number of wavelengths  $$\\((\\frac{1}{2}\\lambda,\\ \\frac{3}{2}\\lambda,\\ \\frac{5}{2}\\lambda,\\text{~etc}\\text{.)}\\)$$, then destructive interference occurs.']

['How else can interference be modeled?', 'Similarly, if the paths taken by the two waves differ by any integral number of wavelengths  $$\\((\\lambda,\\ 2\\lambda,\\ 3\\lambda,\\text{~etc}\\text{.)}\\)$$, then constructive interference occurs.']
['What are some other interesting facts about this study material?', 'Figure 17.9 shows how to determine the path-length difference for waves traveling from two slits to a common point on a screen.']

['What else is mentioned about this measurement?', 'If the screen is a large distance away compared with the distance between the slits, then the angle  $$\\(\\theta\\)$$  between the path and a line from the slits perpendicular to the screen (see the figure) is nearly the same for each path.']

['Is there anything else interesting about the measurement?', 'That approximation and simple trigonometry show the length difference,  $$\\(\\Delta L\\)$$, to be  $$\\(d\\sin\\theta\\)$$, where d is the distance between the slits,']
['What is the number m?', 'The number m is the order of the interference.']
['What order does it have?', 'For example, m = 4 is fourth-order interference.']
['What does this show?', 'Light passing through a single slit forms a diffraction pattern somewhat different from that formed by double slits.']
['What is different about a single slit?', 'Figure 17.11 shows a single-slit diffraction pattern.']
['What does it show?', 'Note that the central maximum is larger than those on either side, and that the intensity decreases rapidly on either side.']
['What else is mentioned in the material?', 'The analysis of single-slit diffraction is illustrated in Figure 17.12.']
['What else is there to read?', 'Assuming the screen is very far away compared with the size of the slit, rays heading toward a common destination are nearly parallel.']
['What else is in this material?', 'That approximation allows a series of trigonometric operations that result in the equations for the minima produced by destructive interference.']
['What do you learn from this information?', 'When rays travel straight ahead, they remain in phase and a central maximum is obtained.']

['What else did you learn?', 'However, when rays travel at an angle  $$\\(\\theta\\)$$  relative to the original direction of the beam, each ray travels a different distance to the screen, and they can arrive in or out of phase.']

['What else happened during this process?', 'Thus, a ray from the center travels a distance  $$\\(\\lambda/2\\)$$  farther than the ray from the top edge of the slit, they arrive out of phase, and they interfere destructively.']

['Did anything else interesting happen during this test?', 'Similarly, for every ray between the top and the center of the slit, there is a ray between the center and the bottom of the slit that travels a distance  $$\\(\\lambda/2\\)$$  farther to the common point on the screen, and so interferes destructively.']
['What did you learn next?', 'Symmetrically, there will be another minimum at the same angle below the direct ray.']

['What is the equation used to determine constructive interference?', 'To calculate the positions of constructive interference for a double slit, the path-length difference must be an integral multiple, m, of the wavelength.']
['What is the number associated with this equation?', '$$\\(\\lambda\\)$$']

['What is the function?', 'where d is the distance between the slits and  $$\\(\\theta\\)$$  is the angle between a line from the slits to the maximum and a line perpendicular to the barrier in which the slits are located.']
['What is the next section of this paper?', 'To calculate the positions of destructive interference for a double slit, the path-length difference must be a half-integral multiple of the wavelength:']
['When was Einstein first aware of photons and excited atoms?', 'In 1917, Albert Einstein was thinking about photons and excited atoms.']
['What were his thoughts?', 'He considered an atom excited by a certain amount of energy and what would happen if that atom were hit by a photon with the same amount of energy.']
['Did he find anything interesting about this concept?', 'He suggested that the atom would emit a photon with that amount of energy, and it would be accompanied by the original photon.']
['What other findings did he make?', 'Those photons could go on to hit other excited atoms, and soon you would have a stream of in-phase photons.']
['What is a stream of in-phase photons?', 'Such a light stream is said to be coherent.']
['What did the scientific community do with his idea?', 'Some four decades later, Einstein’s idea found application in a process called, light amplification by stimulated emission of radiation.']
['What was the alphabet?', 'Take the first letters of all the words (except by and “of”) and write them in order.']
['What was the last word?', 'You get the word laser (see Figure 17.2 (a)), which is the name of the device that produces such a beam of light.']
['What other interesting aspects about this content have you noticed?', 'Laser beams are directional, very intense, and narrow (only about 0.5 mm in diameter).']
['What are the applications of laser beams?', 'These properties lead to a number of applications in industry and medicine.']
['How are they used?', 'The following are just a few examples:']
['What chapter was this in?', 'This chapter began with a picture of a compact disc (see Figure 17.1).']
['What was the picture of?', 'Those audio and data-storage devices began replacing cassette tapes during the 1990s.']
['How do they work?', 'CDs are read by interpreting variations in reflections of a laser beam from the surface.']
['Does anything else need lasers?', 'Some barcode scanners use a laser beam.']
['Does it have any other uses?', 'Lasers are used in industry to cut steel and other metals.']
['Does it have any other uses?', 'Lasers are bounced off reflectors that astronauts left on the Moon.']
['Why?', 'The time it takes for the light to make the round trip can be used to make precise calculations of the Earth-Moon distance.']
['What else can you tell me about lasers?', 'Laser beams are used to produce holograms.']
['What is a hologram?', 'The name hologram means entire picture (from the Greek holo-, as in holistic), because the image is three-dimensional.']
['Why is it three dimensional?', 'A viewer can move around the image and see it from different perspectives.']
['Why is this different than traditional photography?', 'Holograms take advantage of the wave properties of light, as opposed to traditional photography which is based on geometric optics.']
['What else do you know about holograms?', 'A holographic image is produced by constructive and destructive interference of a split laser beam.']
['What else can you tell me about lasers?', 'One of the advantages of using a laser as a surgical tool is that it is accompanied by very little bleeding.']
['Does it have any other uses?', 'Laser eye surgery has improved the vision of many people, without the need for corrective lenses.']
['What does that mean?', 'A laser beam is used to change the shape of the lens of the eye, thus changing its focal length.']
['What are some important applications of light?', 'An interesting thing happens if you pass light through a large number of evenly-spaced parallel slits.']
['What is that called?', 'Such an arrangement of slits is called a diffraction grating.']
['What happens to light?', 'An interference pattern is created that is very similar to the one formed by double-slit diffraction (see Figure 17.8 and Figure 17.9).']
['How was this grating made?', 'A diffraction grating can be manufactured by scratching glass with a sharp tool to form a number of precisely positioned parallel lines, which act like slits.']

['What are other applications of this?', 'Diffraction gratings work both for transmission of light, as in Figure 17.13, and for reflection of light, as on the butterfly wings or the Australian opal shown in Figure 17.14, or the CD pictured in the opening illustration of this chapter.']
['How are they used?', 'In addition to their use as novelty items, diffraction gratings are commonly used for spectroscopic dispersion and analysis of light.']
['How do you analyze the light?', 'What makes them particularly useful is the fact that they form a sharper pattern than do double slits.']
['What is the sharper pattern?', 'That is, their bright regions are narrower and brighter, while their dark regions are darker.']
['What else can you tell me about this?', 'Figure 17.15 shows idealized graphs demonstrating the sharper pattern.']
['What are some examples of these?', 'Natural diffraction gratings occur in the feathers of certain birds.']

['What do these gratings do?', 'Tiny, fingerlike structures in regular patterns act as reflection gratings, producing constructive interference that gives the feathers colors not solely due to their pigmentation.']
['What is iridescence?', 'The effect is called iridescence.']

['What are diffraction gratings?', 'Diffraction gratings are key components of monochromators—devices that separate the various wavelengths of incoming light and allow a beam with only a specific wavelength to pass through.']
['What are monochromators used for?', 'Monochromators are used, for example, in optical imaging of particular wavelengths from biological or medical samples.']

['How do they help analyze a sample?', 'A diffraction grating can be chosen to specifically analyze a wavelength of light emitted by molecules in diseased cells in a biopsy sample, or to help excite strategic molecules in the sample with a selected frequency of light.']
['What other uses are there for monochromators?', 'Another important use is in optical fiber technologies where fibers are designed to provide optimum performance at specific wavelengths.']
['What wavelengths are used in optical fiber technologies?', 'A range of diffraction gratings is available for selecting specific wavelengths for such use.']
['What is one of the applications of wavelengths?', 'Diffraction gratings are used in spectroscopes to separate a light source into its component wavelengths.']
['What is another application of wavelengths?', 'When a material is heated to incandescence, it gives off wavelengths of light characteristic of the chemical makeup of the material.']
['How can the chemical makeup of a material be determined?', 'A pure substance will produce a spectrum that is unique, thus allowing identification of the substance.']
['What else is another application of wavelengths?', 'Spectroscopes are also used to measure wavelengths both shorter and longer than visible light.']
['What else is noteworthy about wavelengths?', 'Such instruments have become especially useful to astronomers and chemists.']
['What is a diagram?', 'Figure 17.18 shows a diagram of a spectroscope.']
['What is light?', 'Light diffracts as it moves through space, bending around obstacles and interfering constructively and destructively.']
['What does this mean?', 'While diffraction allows light to be used as a spectroscopic tool, it also limits the detail we can obtain in images.']
['what is an example of a wave-based application?', 'Figure 17.19 (a) shows the effect of passing light through a small circular aperture.']
['what was the effect?', 'Instead of a bright spot with sharp edges, a spot with a fuzzy edge surrounded by circles of light is obtained.']
['why did they use a circular aperture?', 'This pattern is caused by diffraction similar to that produced by a single slit.']
['what were the results of their experiment?', 'Light from different parts of the circular aperture interferes constructively and destructively.']
['What are the effects of that interference?', 'The effect is most noticeable when the aperture is small, but the effect is there for large apertures, too.']
['What is figure 17.19?', 'Figure 17.19 (b) shows the diffraction pattern produced by two point light sources that are close to one another.']
['What does it show?', 'The pattern is similar to that for a single point source, and it is just barely possible to tell that there are two light sources rather than one.']
['Why would it be hard to tell?', 'If they are closer together, as in Figure 17.19 (c), you cannot distinguish them, thus limiting the detail, or resolution, you can obtain.']
['What does this limit do?', 'That limit is an inescapable consequence of the wave nature of light.']
['What was the main idea of this material?', 'There are many situations in which diffraction limits the resolution.']
