['Why does it limit the resolution?', 'The acuity of vision is limited because light passes through the pupil, the circular aperture of the eye.']

['What are some examples of the limitation of resolution?', 'Be aware that the diffraction-like spreading of light is due to the limited diameter of a light beam, not the interaction with an aperture.']

['What is an example of this?', 'Thus light passing through a lens with a diameter of D shows the diffraction effect and spreads, blurring the image, just as light passing through an aperture of diameter D does.']
['What else can diffraction limit?', 'Diffraction limits the resolution of any system having a lens or mirror.']
['What else does it limit?', 'Telescopes are also limited by diffraction, because of the finite diameter, D, of their primary mirror.']
['What does the chapter cover?', 'Early in the chapter, it was mentioned that when light passes from one medium to another, its speed and wavelength change, but its frequency remains constant.']
['What is the equation for diffraction?', 'The equation']

['What are we studying?', 'shows how to the wavelength in a given medium,  $$\\(\\lambda_{n}\\)$$, is related to the wavelength in a vacuum,  $$\\(\\lambda\\)$$, and the refractive index, n, of the medium.']
['What else did we learn?', 'The equation is useful for calculating the change in wavelength of a monochromatic laser beam in various media.']
['What else did you find interesting?', 'The analysis of a diffraction grating is very similar to that for a double slit.']
['What is a double slit?', 'As you know from the discussion of double slits in Young’s double-slit experiment, light is diffracted by, and spreads out after passing through, each slit.']
['What else do you want to know?', 'Rays travel at an angle  $$\\(\\theta\\)$$  relative to the incident direction.']
['What else can you tell me about rays?', 'Each ray travels a different distance to a common point on a screen far away.']
['What does the screen display?', 'The rays start in phase, and they can be in or out of phase when they reach a screen, depending on the difference in the path lengths traveled.']
['Why is that?', 'Each ray travels a distance that differs by  $$\\(d\\sin\\theta\\)$$  from that of its neighbor, where d is the distance between slits.']

['What happens when they arrive in phase?', 'If  $$\\(d\\sin\\theta\\)$$  equals an integral number of wavelengths, the rays all arrive in phase, and constructive interference (a maximum) is obtained.']
['Is it possible for interference to occur?', 'Thus, the condition necessary to obtain constructive interference for a diffraction grating is']
['What else can you tell me about this material?', 'where d is the distance between slits in the grating,  $$\\(\\lambda\\)$$  is the wavelength of the light, and m is the order of the maximum.']
['How is this relevant to the question?', 'Note that this is exactly the same equation as for two slits separated by d.']
['How is this different?', 'However, the slits are usually closer in diffraction gratings than in double slits, producing fewer maxima at larger angles.']

['What is the definition of diffraction?', 'To answer that question, consider the diffraction pattern for a circular aperture, which, similar to the diffraction pattern of light passing through a slit, has a central maximum that is wider and brighter than the maxima surrounding it (see Figure 17.19 (a)).']

['What is the diameter of a circular aperture?', 'It can be shown that, for a circular aperture of diameter D, the first minimum in the diffraction pattern occurs at  $$\\(\\theta = 1.22\\lambda/D\\)$$, provided that the aperture is large compared with the wavelength of light, which is the case for most optical instruments.']
['Who developed the diffraction limit?', 'The accepted criterion for determining the diffraction limit to resolution based on diffraction was developed by Lord Rayleigh in the 19th century.']

['What does the diffraction limit determine?', 'The Rayleigh criterion for the diffraction limit to resolution states that two images are just resolvable when the center of the diffraction pattern of one is directly over the first minimum of the diffraction pattern of the other.']
['What is the definition of maximum brightness?', 'See Figure 17.20 (b).']
['What are the angles?', 'The first minimum is at an angle of  $$\\(\\theta = 1.22\\lambda/D\\)$$, so that two point objects are just resolvable if they are separated by the angle']

['What does the ta represent?', 'where  $$\\(\\lambda\\)$$  is the wavelength of the light (or other electromagnetic radiation) and D is the diameter of the aperture, lens, mirror, etc., with which the two objects are observed.']
['what is radians?', 'In the expression above,  $$\\(\\theta\\)$$  has units of radians.']
["What kind of charge does the phrase 'electric charge' mean?", 'You may know someone who has an electric personality, which usually means that other people are attracted to this person.']
['What does it mean to be attracted to someone?', 'This saying is based on electric charge, which is a property of matter that causes objects to attract or repel each other.']
['What are the positive and negative charges?', 'Electric charge comes in two varieties, which we call positive and negative.']
['What are the differences between them?', 'Like charges repel each other, and unlike charges attract each other.']
['Do they repel each other?', 'Thus, two positive charges repel each other, as do two negative charges.']
['How do they attract each other?', 'A positive charge and a negative charge attract each other.']

['what does it mean?', 'When various materials are rubbed together in controlled ways, certain combinations of materials always result in a net charge of one type on one material and a net charge of the opposite type on the other material.']
['what type of charge does it have?', 'By convention, we call one type of charge positive and the other type negative.']
['what are some examples?', 'For example, when glass is rubbed with silk, the glass becomes positively charged and the silk negatively charged.']
['what happens when it is rubbed?', 'Because the glass and silk have opposite charges, they attract one another like clothes that have rubbed together in a dryer.']
['can they repel one another?', 'Two glass rods rubbed with silk in this manner will repel one another, because each rod has positive charge on it.']
['do they repel each other?', 'Similarly, two silk cloths rubbed in this manner will repel each other, because both cloths have negative charge.']
['what does this tell us?', 'Figure 18.2 shows how these simple materials can be used to explore the nature of the force between charges.']
['Why did scientists investigate the two types of charges?', 'It took scientists a long time to discover what lay behind these two types of charges.']

['When did the word electric originate?', 'The word electric itself comes from the Greek word elektron for amber, because the ancient Greeks noticed that amber, when rubbed by fur, attracts dry straw.']

['What did William Gilbert propose?', 'Almost 2,000 years later, the English physicist William Gilbert proposed a model that explained the effect of electric charge as being due to a mysterious electrical fluid that would pass from one object to another.']

['What happened to his model?', 'This model was debated for several hundred years, but it was finally put to rest in 1897 by the work of the English physicist J. J. Thomson and French physicist Jean Perrin.']
['What did Thomson do?', 'Along with many others, Thomson and Perrin were studying the mysterious cathode rays that were known at the time to consist of particles smaller than the smallest atom.']
['What did Perrin show?', 'Perrin showed that cathode rays actually carried negative electrical charge.']

['Why did Thomson believe his work?', 'Later, Thomson’s work led him to declare, “I can see no escape from the conclusion that [cathode rays] are charges of negative electricity carried by particles of matter.”']

['What does the article focus on?', 'It took several years of further experiments to confirm Thomson’s interpretation of the experiments, but science had in fact discovered the particle that carries the fundamental unit of negative electrical charge.']
['What is that particle called?', 'We now know this particle as the electron.']

['Did they tell us anything else about this topic?', 'Atoms, however, were known to be electrically neutral, which means that they carry the same amount of positive and negative charge, so their net charge is zero.']
['Was this helpful?', 'Because electrons are negative, some other part of the atom must contain positive charge.']

['What was their next article?', 'Thomson put forth what is called the plum pudding model, in which he described atoms as being made of thousands of electrons swimming around in a nebulous mass of positive charge, as shown by the left-side image of Figure 18.3.']

['How did the students like this theory?', 'His student, Ernest Rutherford, originally believed that this model was correct and used it (along with other models) to try to understand the results of his experiments bombarding gold foils with alpha particles (i.e., helium atoms stripped of their electrons).']
['Did the experiment work as expected?', 'The results, however, did not confirm Thomson’s model but rather destroyed it!']

['What did they discover?', 'Rutherford found that most of the space occupied by the gold atoms was actually empty and that almost all of the matter of each atom was concentrated into a tiny, extremely dense nucleus, as shown by the right-side image of Figure 18.3.']
['What else was they learning about?', 'The atomic nucleus was later found to contain particles called protons, each of which carries a unit of positive electric charge.']
['How many protons did they find?', '1']
['Who carries the electric charge?', 'Protons and electrons are thus the fundamental particles that carry electric charge.']
['What is the charge?', 'Each proton carries one unit of positive charge, and each electron carries one unit of negative charge.']
['What is the opposite of the charge?', 'To the best precision that modern technology can provide, the charge carried by a proton is exactly the opposite of that carried by an electron.']

['What is the SI unit for electric charge?', 'The SI unit for electric charge is the coulomb (abbreviated as “C”), which is named after the French physicist Charles Augustin de Coulomb, who studied the force between charged objects.']

['Is there a specific formula for the SI unit of electric charge?', 'The proton carries  $$\\(+ 1.602\\  \\times \\ 10^{-19}\\text{C.}\\)$$  and the electron carries  $$\\(-1.602\\  \\times \\ 10^{-19}\\text{C,}\\)$$ .']
['What are the other details of the formula?', 'The number n of protons required to make +1.00 C is']
['What is the formula for electric charge?', 'The same number of electrons is required to make −1.00 C of electric charge.']
['What is the unit of charge?', 'The fundamental unit of charge is often represented as e.']
['How is the charge represented?', 'Thus, the charge on a proton is e, and the charge on an electron is −e.']
['What is the equation of charge?', 'Mathematically,  $$\\(e = + 1.602\\  \\times \\ 10^{-19}\\text{C}\\text{.}\\)$$']

['What happens to the total charge of a system?', 'Because the fundamental positive and negative units of charge are carried on protons and electrons, we would expect that the total charge cannot change in any system that we define.']
['What is the relationship between charge and its conservation?', 'In other words, although we might be able to move charge around, we cannot create or destroy it.']
['Is this true?', 'This should be true provided that we do not create or destroy protons or electrons in our system.']

['Do they make it impossible to conserve charge?', 'In the twentieth century, however, scientists learned how to create and destroy electrons and protons, but they found that charge is still conserved.']
['Why is this so?', 'Many experiments and solid theoretical arguments have elevated this idea to the status of a law.']
['Is there a law about this?', 'The law of conservation of charge says that electrical charge cannot be created or destroyed.']
['Was this law ever used?', 'The law of conservation of charge is very useful.']
['What is it?', 'It tells us that the net charge in a system is the same before and after any interaction within the system.']
['Is there anything else important?', 'Of course, we must ensure that no external charge enters the system during the interaction and that no internal charge leaves the system.']
['What is the mathematical expression for it?', 'Mathematically, conservation of charge can be expressed as']
['What is conductors and insulators?', 'Materials can be classified depending on whether they allow charge to move.']
['What is the most important information you can provide?', 'If charge can easily move through a material, such as metals, then these materials are called conductors.']
['What does this mean?', 'This means that charge can be conducted (i.e., move) through the material rather easily.']
["What can't charge move through?", 'If charge cannot move through a material, such as rubber, then this material is called an insulator.']
['What are most materials?', 'Most materials are insulators.']
['What makes most materials insulators?', 'Their atoms and molecules hold on more tightly to their electrons, so it is difficult for electrons to move between atoms.']
['Why is it difficult?', 'However, it is not impossible.']
['What is possibe?', 'With enough energy, it is possible to force electrons to move through an insulator.']
['Why is this dangerous?', 'However, the insulator is often physically destroyed in the process.']
['How are metals different from other materials?', 'In metals, the outer electrons are loosely bound to their atoms, so not much energy is required to make electrons move through metal.']
['What are some examples of metals?', 'Such metals as copper, silver, and aluminum are good conductors.']
['What are some examples of insulators?', 'Insulating materials include plastics, glass, ceramics, and wood.']
['What does this mean?', 'The conductivity of some materials is intermediate between conductors and insulators.']
['What are semiconductors?', 'These are called semiconductors.']
['How do they conduct?', 'They can be made conductive under the right conditions, which can involve temperature, the purity of the material, and the force applied to push electrons through them.']
['What can you do with them?', 'Because we can control whether semiconductors are conductors or insulators, these materials are used extensively in computer chips.']
['What is the most commonly used semiconductor?', 'The most commonly used semiconductor is silicon.']
['What is in the next section?', 'Figure 18.8 shows various materials arranged according to their ability to conduct electrons.']
['What happens if charges are like?', 'Because like charges repel each other, they will push against each other until they are as far apart as they can get.']
['Does a conductor allow the charge to move?', 'Because the charge can move in a conductor, it moves to the outer surfaces of the object.']
['What happens to the charge on the sphere?', 'Figure 18.9(a) shows schematically how an excess negative charge spreads itself evenly over the outer surface of a metal sphere.']
['How do the electrons move?', 'The electrons still repel each other, but they are not able to move, because the material is an insulator.']
['What happens to the excess charge?', 'Thus, the excess charge stays put and does not distribute itself over the object.']
['How does this happen?', 'Figure 18.9(b) shows this situation.']
['When is it considered neutral?', 'Most objects we deal with are electrically neutral, which means that they have the same amount of positive and negative charge.']
['What is a neutral object considered?', 'However, transferring negative charge from one object to another is fairly easy to do.']
['What happens when this happens?', 'When negative charge is transferred from one object to another, an excess of positive charge is left behind.']
['What is the positive charge?', 'The positive charge is carried by the proton, which is stuck firmly in the nucleus of atoms, and the atoms are stuck in place in solid materials.']
['Why are electrons easier to transfer?', 'Electrons, which carry the negative charge, are much easier to remove from their atoms or molecules and can therefore be transferred more easily.']
['What is it?', 'Electric charge can be transferred in several manners.']
['What is the contact method?', 'One of the simplest ways to transfer charge is charging by contact, in which the surfaces of two objects made of different materials are placed in close contact.']
['What happens when they are separated?', 'If one of the materials holds electrons more tightly than the other, then it takes some electrons with it when the materials are separated.']
['What can happen if the materials are rubbed together?', 'Rubbing two surfaces together increases the transfer of electrons, because it creates a closer contact between the materials.']
['What else does the rubbing do?', 'It also serves to present fresh material with a full supply of electrons to the other material.']
['How does this apply to the human body?', 'Thus, when you walk across a carpet on a dry day, your shoes rub against the carpet, and some electrons are removed from the carpet by your shoes.']
['What happens to the shoes when this occurs?', 'The result is that you have an excess of negative charge on your shoes.']
['How does the excess of charge transfer?', 'When you then touch a doorknob, some of your excess of electrons transfer to the neutral doorknob, creating a small spark.']
['What do you find interesting in this section?', 'Touching the doorknob with your hand demonstrates a second way to transfer electric charge, which is charging by conduction.']
['How does it work?', 'This transfer happens because like charges repel, and so the excess electrons that you picked up from the carpet want to be as far away from each other as possible.']
['How do they get there?', 'Some of them move to the doorknob, where they will distribute themselves over the outer surface of the metal.']
['What other types of transfer are discussed?', 'Another example of charging by conduction is shown in the top row of Figure 18.10.']

['What is the top row of figure 18.10?', 'A metal sphere with 100 excess electrons touches a metal sphere with 50 excess electrons, so 25 electrons from the first sphere transfer to the second sphere.']
['What does this do?', 'Each sphere finishes with 75 excess electrons.']
['What other questions do we have?', 'The same reasoning applies to the transfer of positive charge.']

['What are the differences between positive and negative charge?', 'However, because positive charge essentially cannot move in solids, it is transferred by moving negative charge in the opposite direction.']
['How do you explain that?', 'For example, consider the bottom row of Figure 18.10.']
['Why is that the case?', 'The first metal sphere has 100 excess protons and touches a metal sphere with 50 excess protons, so the second sphere transfers 25 electrons to the first sphere.']
['What happens as a result of that?', 'These 25 extra electrons will electrically cancel 25 protons so that the first metal sphere is left with 75 excess protons.']
["What's the final result of that?", 'This is shown in the bottom row of Figure 18.10.']
['What else does this illustrate?', 'The second metal sphere lost 25 electrons so it has 25 more excess protons, for a total of 75 excess protons.']
['Is this an actual example?', 'The end result is the same if we consider that the first ball transferred a net positive charge equal to that of 25 protons to the first ball.']

['What is the main idea of Transfer and Separation of Charge?', 'In this discussion, you may wonder how the excess electrons originally got from your shoes to your hand to create the spark when you touched the doorknob.']
['What happens next in the discussion?', 'The answer is that no electrons actually traveled from your shoes to your hands.']

['What happened after the electrons traveled to your hands?', 'Instead, because like charges repel each other, the excess electrons on your shoe simply pushed away some of the electrons in your feet.']
['What else does the discussion cover?', 'The electrons thus dislodged from your feet moved up into your leg and in turn pushed away some electrons in your leg.']
['What happens after this?', 'This process continued through your whole body until a distribution of excess electrons covered the extremities of your body.']

['What is the end result of this discussion?', 'Thus your head, your hands, the tip of your nose, and so forth all received their doses of excess electrons that had been pushed out of their normal positions.']
['What is the most interesting aspect of this section?', 'All this was the result of electrons being pushed out of your feet by the excess electrons on your shoes.']
['what is this type of charge separation called?', 'This type of charge separation is called polarization.']

['can this revert?', 'As soon as the excess electrons leave your shoes (by rubbing off onto the floor or being carried away in humid air), the distribution of electrons in your body returns to normal.']
['what is this reverting?', 'Every part of your body is again electrically neutral (i.e., zero excess charge).']
['What is the polarization?', 'The phenomenon of polarization is seen in Figure 18.1.']
['Why is the child polarized?', 'The child has accumulated excess positive charge by sliding on the slide.']
['What is it a result of?', 'This excess charge repels itself and so becomes distributed over the extremities of the child’s body, notably in his hair.']
['Why does it end up there?', 'As a result, the hair stands on end, because the excess negative charge on each strand repels the excess positive charge on neighboring strands.']
['What is polarization?', 'Polarization can be used to charge objects.']
['What is a good example of polarization?', 'Consider the two metallic spheres shown in Figure 18.11.']
['What is the relation between the two metal spheres?', 'The spheres are electrically neutral, so they carry the same amounts of positive and negative charge.']

['What do you find interesting about this discussion?', 'In the top picture (Figure 18.11(a)), the two spheres are touching, and the positive and negative charge is evenly distributed over the two spheres.']

['What is a way to separate the positive and negative charge?', 'We then approach a glass rod that carries an excess positive charge, which can be done by rubbing the glass rod with silk, as shown in Figure 18.11(b).']

['How does the negative charge leave the sphere?', 'Because opposite charges attract each other, the negative charge is attracted to the glass rod, leaving an excess positive charge on the opposite side of the right sphere.']

['What other objects can you use to create an unbalanced charge?', 'This is an example of charging by induction, whereby a charge is created by approaching a charged object with a second object to create an unbalanced charge in the second object.']
['What happens to the excess charge?', 'If we then separate the two spheres, as shown in Figure 18.11(c), the excess charge is stuck on each sphere.']
['What happens to the two spheres?', 'The left sphere now has an excess negative charge, and the right sphere has an excess positive charge.']
['How does the opposite charge move?', 'Finally, in the bottom picture, the rod is removed, and the opposite charges attract each other, so they move as close together as they can get.']

['What happened in the 17th century?', 'More than 100 years before Thomson and Rutherford discovered the fundamental particles that carry positive and negative electric charges, the French scientist Charles-Augustin de Coulomb mathematically described the force between charged objects.']
['What did de Coulomb do?', 'Doing so required careful measurements of forces between charged spheres, for which he built an ingenious device called a torsion balance.']
['What is a waveguide?', 'This device, shown in Figure 18.15, contains an insulating rod that is hanging by a thread inside a glass-walled enclosure.']
['What is inside the enclosure?', 'At one end of the rod is the metallic sphere A.']

['Who else was in the enclosure?', 'When no charge is on this sphere, it touches sphere B. Coulomb would touch the spheres with a third metallic ball (shown at the bottom of the diagram) that was charged.']
['What happened after this?', 'An unknown amount of charge would distribute evenly between spheres A and B, which would then repel each other, because like charges repel.']
['What would the rod do then?', 'This force would cause sphere A to rotate away from sphere B, thus twisting the wire until the torsion in the wire balanced the electrical force.']
['What did Coulomb do after this?', 'Coulomb then turned the knob at the top, which allowed him to rotate the thread, thus bringing sphere A closer to sphere B.']
['What happened next?', 'He found that bringing sphere A twice as close to sphere B required increasing the torsion by a factor of four.']
['What was this test used for?', 'Bringing the sphere three times closer required a ninefold increase in the torsion.']
['How did he use this data?', 'From this type of measurement, he deduced that the electrical force between the spheres was inversely proportional to the distance squared between the spheres.']
['How did he describe this force?', 'In other words,']
['How is the charge distributed between the spheres?', 'An electrical charge distributes itself equally between two conducting spheres of the same size.']
['What did Coulomb find out?', 'Knowing this allowed Coulomb to divide an unknown charge in half.']
['How does he do this?', 'Repeating this process would produce a sphere with one quarter of the initial charge, and so on.']
['How did he test this?', 'Using this technique, he measured the force between spheres A and B when they were charged with different amounts of charge.']
['How was this done?', 'These measurements led him to deduce that the force was proportional to the charge on each sphere, or']
['What are the terms used in the equation?', 'This equation is known as Coulomb’s law, and it describes the electrostatic force between charged objects.']
['What is k?', 'The constant of proportionality k is called Coulomb’s constant.']
['What is the value of k?', 'In SI units, the constant k has the value  $$\\(k = 8.99\\  \\times \\ 10^{9}\\text{N} \\cdot \\text{m}^{\\text{2}}\\text{/C}^{\\text{2.}}\\)$$']
['What is the direction of force?', 'The direction of the force is along the line joining the centers of the two objects.']
["How does Coulomb's law work?", 'If the two charges are of opposite signs, Coulomb’s law gives a negative result.']
['How does this help us understand the force between particles?', 'This means that the force between the particles is attractive.']
['How does this help us understand the force between molecules?', 'If the two charges have the same signs, Coulomb’s law gives a positive result.']
['What does this mean?', 'This means that the force between the particles is repulsive.']
['What are the opposite signs of negative?', 'For example, if both  $$\\(q_{1}\\)$$  and  $$\\(q_{2}\\)$$  are negative or if both are positive, the force between them is repulsive.']
['What does this mean for the force between molecules?', 'This is shown in Figure 18.16(a).']

['What are the opposite signs of positive?', 'If  $$\\(q_{1}\\)$$  is a negative charge and  $$\\(q_{2}\\)$$  is a positive charge (or vice versa), then the charges are different, so the force between them is attractive.']
['What does this mean for the force between molecules?', 'This is shown in Figure 18.16(b).']
['What are some additional things you learned?', 'Note that Coulomb’s law applies only to charged objects that are not moving with respect to each other.']
['What is this law about?', 'The law says that the force is proportional to the amount of charge on each object and inversely proportional to the square of the distance between the objects.']
['What else did you learn?', 'If we double the charge  $$\\(q_{1}\\)$$, for instance, then the force is doubled.']
['How does the force change as distance increases?', 'If we double the distance between the objects, then the force between them decreases by a factor of  $$\\(2^{2} = 4\\)$$ .']

['How does this law apply to anything else?', 'Although Coulomb’s law is true in general, it is easiest to apply to spherical objects or to objects that are much smaller than the distance between the objects (in which case, the objects can be approximated as spheres).']
['What is an inverse-square law?', 'Coulomb’s law is an example of an inverse-square law, which means the force depends on the square of the denominator.']
['What other inverse-square laws are there?', 'Another inverse-square law is Newton’s law of universal gravitation, which is  $$\\(F = {{Gm_{1}m_{2}}/r^{2}}\\)$$ .']

['What difference between these two laws?', 'Although these laws are similar, they differ in two important respects: (i) The gravitational constant G is much, much smaller than k ( $$\\(G = 6.67\\  \\times \\ 10^{- 11}\\text{m}^{3}\\text{/kg} \\cdot \\text{s}^{2}\\)$$ ); and (ii) only one type of mass exists, whereas two types of electric charge exist.']

['What are the two different properties of mass?', 'These two differences explain why gravity is so much weaker than the electrostatic force and why gravity is only attractive, whereas the electrostatic force can be attractive or repulsive.']
['What is the most important part of this study material for you?', 'Finally, note that Coulomb measured the distance between the spheres from the centers of each sphere.']
['How did he determine the radius of one sphere?', 'He did not explain this assumption in his original papers, but it turns out to be valid.']
['What is this assumption about?', 'From outside a uniform spherical distribution of charge, it can be treated as if all the charge were located at the center of the sphere.']

['What else can you tell me about the Force Field?', 'You may have heard of a force field in science fiction movies, where such fields apply forces at particular positions in space to keep a villain trapped or to protect a spaceship from enemy fire.']
['What are other applications of force fields?', 'The concept of a field is very useful in physics, although it differs somewhat from what you see in movies.']
['What is a field?', 'A field is a way of conceptualizing and mapping the force that surrounds any object and acts on another object at a distance without apparent physical connection.']

['What is a field of energy?', 'For example, the gravitational field surrounding Earth and all other masses represents the gravitational force that would be experienced if another mass were placed at a given point within the field.']
['What is an electric field?', 'Michael Faraday, an English physicist of the nineteenth century, proposed the concept of an electric field.']

['What is an electric field used for?', 'If you know the electric field, then you can easily calculate the force (magnitude and direction) applied to any electric charge that you place in the field.']
['What is an electric field?', 'An electric field is generated by electric charge and tells us the force per unit charge at all locations in space around a charge distribution.']

['What does it tell us about the charge distribution?', 'The charge distribution could be a single point charge; a distribution of charge over, say, a flat plate; or a more complex distribution of charge.']
['What is an electric field?', 'The electric field extends into space around the charge distribution.']
['What is an electric field?', 'Now consider placing a test charge in the field.']
['What is a test charge?', 'A test charge is a positive electric charge whose charge is so small that it does not significantly disturb the charges that create the electric field.']
['What is the test charge?', 'The electric field exerts a force on the test charge in a given direction.']
['What is the force?', 'The force exerted is proportional to the charge of the test charge.']
['What is the force proportional to?', 'For example, if we double the charge of the test charge, the force exerted on it doubles.']
['What does it tell you?', 'Mathematically, saying that electric field is the force per unit charge is written as']
['What is the relationship between E and F?', 'where we are considering only electric forces.']

['How is the force on the positive test charge related to the electric field?', 'Note that the electric field is a vector field that points in the same direction as the force on the positive test charge.']
['What are the units of the electric field?', 'The units of electric field are N/C.']
['What does the F represent?', 'where the absolute value is used, because we only consider the magnitude of the force.']
['What is the magnitude of the field?', 'The magnitude of the electric field is then']
['What does this equation represent?', 'This equation gives the magnitude of the electric field created by a point charge Q.']
['What is the distance from a point charge?', 'The distance r in the denominator is the distance from the point charge, Q, or from the center of a spherical charge, to the point of interest.']
['What is the reactivity?', 'If the test charge is removed from the electric field, the electric field still exists.']
['How can you create a three-dimensional map of the electric field?', 'To create a three-dimensional map of the electric field, imagine placing the test charge in various locations in the field.']

['How do you calculate the field?', 'At each location, measure the force on the charge, and use the vector equation  $$\\(\\overset{\\rightarrow}{E} = {\\overset{\\rightarrow}{F}/q_{\\text{test}}}\\)$$  to calculate the electric field.']
['What happens to the vector?', 'Draw an arrow at each point where you place the test charge to represent the strength and the direction of the electric field.']
['What are the length of the arrows?', 'The length of the arrows should be proportional to the strength of the electric field.']
['What happens if you join the arrows?', 'If you join together these arrows, you obtain lines.']
['What is the figure?', 'Figure 18.17 shows an image of the three-dimensional electric field created by a positive charge.']
['What is this chapter about?', 'Just drawing the electric field lines in a plane that slices through the charge gives the two-dimensional electric-field maps shown in Figure 18.18.']
['Are there two directions for the electric field?', 'On the left is the electric field created by a positive charge, and on the right is the electric field created by a negative charge.']
['What is the problem?', 'Notice that the electric field lines point away from the positive charge and toward the negative charge.']
['What does this mean?', 'Thus, a positive test charge placed in the electric field of the positive charge will be repelled.']
['Why is that?', 'This is consistent with Coulomb’s law, which says that like charges repel each other.']
['What is the next thing you will need to do?', 'If we place the positive charge in the electric field of the negative charge, the positive charge is attracted to the negative charge.']
['What is this all about?', 'The opposite is true for negative test charges.']
['What happens after that?', 'Thus, the direction of the electric field lines is consistent with what we find by using Coulomb’s law.']
['What does this equation tell us?', 'The equation  $$\\(E = {{k|Q|}/r^{2}}\\)$$  says that the electric field gets stronger as we approach the charge that generates it.']
['What does this mean?', 'For example, at 2 cm from the charge Q (r = 2 cm), the electric field is four times stronger than at 4 cm from the charge (r = 4 cm).']
['What else did you see?', 'Looking at Figure 18.17 and Figure 18.18 again, we see that the electric field lines become denser as we approach the charge that generates it.']
['What does this mean?', 'In fact, the density of the electric field lines is proportional to the strength of the electric field!']
['What are some of the interesting things you learned from studying it?', 'Electric-field maps can be made for several charges or for more complicated charge distributions.']
['What else did you learn?', 'The electric field due to multiple charges may be found by adding together the electric field from each individual charge.']
['What else is important about this information?', 'Because this sum can only be a single number, we know that only a single electric-field line can go through any given point.']
['How do you explain this?', 'In other words, electric-field lines cannot cross each other.']
['What is the most important information in the figure?', 'Figure 18.19(a) shows a two-dimensional map of the electric field generated by a charge of +q and a nearby charge of −q.']
['How is this important?', 'The three-dimensional version of this map is obtained by rotating this map about the axis that goes through both charges.']
['What is another important information?', 'A positive test charge placed in this field would experience a force in the direction of the field lines at its location.']
['Why is that?', 'It would thus be repelled from the positive charge and attracted to the negative charge.']
['What else is significant about the figure?', 'Figure 18.19(b) shows the electric field generated by two charges of −q.']
['How is this different from the other two figures?', 'Note how the field lines tend to repel each other and do not overlap.']
['What else is interesting about the figure?', 'A positive test charge placed in this field would be attracted to both charges.']

['What else is significant about the figure?', 'If you are far from these two charges, where far means much farther than the distance between the charges, the electric field looks like the electric field from a single charge of −2q.']

['What is the basic structure of energy in space?', 'As you learned in studying gravity, a mass in a gravitational field has potential energy, which means it has the potential to accelerate and thereby increase its kinetic energy.']
['Why do objects with kinetic energy accelerate?', 'This kinetic energy can be used to do work.']
['What is an example of using kinetic energy to do work?', 'For example, imagine you want to use a stone to pound a nail into a piece of wood.']

['What happens to the potential energy?', 'You first lift the stone high above the nail, which increases the potential energy of the stone-Earth system—because Earth is so large, it does not move, so we usually shorten this by saying simply that the potential energy of the stone increases.']
['How does gravity interact with potential energy?', 'When you drop the stone, gravity converts the potential energy into kinetic energy.']
['What happens when the kinetic energy is used to do work?', 'When the stone hits the nail, it does work by pounding the nail into the wood.']
['What is gravitational potential energy?', 'The gravitational potential energy is the work that a mass can potentially do by virtue of its position in a gravitational field.']

['What can you tell me about potential energy?', 'Potential energy is a very useful concept, because it can be used with conservation of energy to calculate the motion of masses in a gravitational field.']
['What are some key terms in it?', 'Electric potential energy works much the same way, but it is based on the electric field instead of the gravitational field.']
['What is an electric field?', 'By virtue of its position in an electric field, a charge has an electric potential energy.']

['How does it convert to kinetic energy?', 'If the charge is free to move, the force due to the electric field causes it to accelerate, so its potential energy is converted to kinetic energy, just like a mass that falls in a gravitational field.']
['Can this energy be used?', 'This kinetic energy can be used to do work.']
['What is the energy that a charge can do?', 'The electric potential energy is the work that a charge can do by virtue of its position in an electric field.']
['What are some key terms in Section Key Terms?', 'The analogy between gravitational potential energy and electric potential energy is depicted in Figure 18.21.']
['Why is it depicted in figure 18.21?', "On the left, the ball-Earth system gains gravitational potential energy when the ball is higher in Earth's gravitational field."]
['How do those two systems compare?', 'On the right, the two-charge system gains electric potential energy when the positive charge is farther from the negative charge.']
['What are the key terms?', 'Let’s use the symbol  $$\\(U_{G}\\)$$  to denote gravitational potential energy.']
['How does this change?', 'When a mass falls in a gravitational field, its gravitational potential energy decreases.']

['What does conservation of energy tell us?', 'Conservation of energy tells us that the work done by the gravitational field to make the mass accelerate must equal the loss of potential energy of the mass.']
['What is work done by gravitational field?', 'If we use the symbol  $$\\(W_{\\text{done}\\text{by}\\text{gravity}}\\)$$  to denote this work, then']

['What is the formula for this problem?', 'where F is the force due to gravity, and  $$\\(y_{\\text{i}}\\)$$  and  $$\\(y_{\\text{f}}\\)$$  are the initial and final positions of the ball, respectively.']
['What is the negative sign for?', 'The negative sign is because gravity points down, which we consider to be the negative direction.']
['What does F = mg mean?', 'For the constant gravitational field near Earth’s surface,  $$\\(F = mg\\)$$ .']
['What does the formula for energy mean?', 'The change in gravitational potential energy of the mass is']

['What do you mean by F  left(F - y_text', 'Note that  $$\\(y_{\\text{f}} - y_{\\text{i}}\\)$$  is just the negative of the height h from which the mass falls, so we usually just write  $$\\(\\Delta U_{\\text{']
['What does F mean', 'G}} = - mgh\\)$$ .']
['What is the final question?', 'We now apply the same reasoning to a charge in an electric field to find the electric potential energy.']

['What are the results of this application?', 'The change  $$\\(\\Delta U_{\\text{E}}\\)$$  in electric potential energy is the work done by the electric field to move a charge q from an initial position  $$\\(x_{\\text{i}}\\)$$  to a final position  $$\\(x_{\\text{f}}\\)$$  ( $$\\(- \\Delta U_{\\text{E}} = W_{\\text{done}\\text{by}\\text{E-field}}\\)$$ ).']

['What is the work done by the field?', 'The definition of work does not change, except that now the work is done by the electric field:  $$\\(W_{\\text{done}\\text{by}\\text{E-field}} = F(x_{\\text{f}} - x_{\\text{i}})\\)$$ .']
['What else can you tell me about the field?', 'For a charge that falls through a constant electric field E, the force applied to the charge by the electric field is  $$\\(F = qE\\)$$ .']
['What is the change in potential energy of the charge?', 'The change in electric potential energy of the charge is thus']
["What's this analogy compared to?", 'Figure 18.22 shows how this analogy would work if we were close to Earth’s surface, where gravity is constant.']
["What's in the top image?", 'The top image shows a charge accelerating due to a constant electric field.']
['What else can you tell me?', 'Likewise, the round mass in the bottom image accelerates due to a constant gravitation field.']
['What happens after it accelerates?', 'In both cases, the potential energy of the particle decreases, and its kinetic energy increases.']

['What is important to know about this equation?', 'If the electric field is not constant, then the equation  $$\\(\\Delta U_{\\text{E}} = - qE\\left( {x_{\\text{f}} - x_{\\text{i}}} \\right)\\)$$  is not valid, and deriving the electric potential energy becomes more involved.']

['What is an example of how this equation can be involved?', 'For example, consider the electric potential energy of an assembly of two point charges  $$\\(q_{1}\\)$$  and  $$\\(q_{2}\\)$$  of the same sign that are initially very far apart.']
['What are the initial positions of the two charges?', 'We start by placing charge  $$\\(q_{1}\\)$$  at the origin of our coordinate system.']
['How does this charge move?', 'This takes no electrical energy, because there is no electric field at the origin (because charge  $$\\(q_{2}\\)$$  is very far away).']
['What happens next?', 'We then bring charge  $$\\(q_{2}\\)$$  in from very far away to a distance r from the center of charge  $$\\(q_{1}\\)$$ .']
['What is the energy?', 'This requires some effort, because the electric field of charge  $$\\(q_{1}\\)$$  applies a repulsive force on charge  $$\\(q_{2}\\)$$ .']
['What happens next?', 'The energy it takes to assemble these two charges can be recuperated if we let them fly apart again.']
['How can this be done?', 'Thus, the charges have potential energy when they are a distance r apart.']
['What does potential energy look like?', 'It turns out that the electric potential energy of a pair of point charges  $$\\(q_{1}\\)$$  and  $$\\(q_{2}\\)$$  a distance r apart is']

['What is the main idea of this section?', 'To recap, if charges  $$\\(q_{1}\\)$$  and  $$\\(q_{2}\\)$$  are free to move, they can accumulate kinetic energy by flying apart, and this kinetic energy can be used to do work.']
['What else are you learning about in this section?', 'The maximum amount of work the two charges can do (if they fly infinitely far from each other) is given by the equation above.']
['What is this question asking you about?', 'Notice that if the two charges have opposite signs, then the potential energy is negative.']
['What does the negative potential energy mean?', 'This means that the charges have more potential to do work when they are far apart than when they are at a distance r apart.']
['Why is that?', 'This makes sense: Opposite charges attract, so the charges can gain more kinetic energy if they attract each other from far away than if they start at only a short distance apart.']
['What else is a fact about this situation?', 'Thus, they have more potential to do work when they are far apart.']
['Are there any other interesting things about this situation?', 'Figure 18.23 summarizes how the electric potential energy depends on charge and separation.']

['What is it about?', 'Recall that to find the force applied by a fixed charge Q on any arbitrary test charge q, it was convenient to define the electric field, which is the force per unit charge applied by Q on any test charge that we place in its electric field.']
['What else is it about?', 'The same Strategy is used here with electric potential energy:']
['What else did we study?', 'We now define the electric potential V, which is the electric potential energy per unit charge.']
['What is the voltage called?', 'Normally, the electric potential is simply called the potential or voltage.']
['Is it measured in units?', 'The units for the potential are J/C, which are given the name volt (V) after the Italian physicist Alessandro Volta (1745–1827).']
['How is it measured?', 'From the equation  $$\\(U_{\\text{E}} = {{kq_{1}q_{2}}/r}\\)$$, the electric potential a distance r from a point charge  $$\\(q_{1}\\)$$  is']
['What is this equation?', 'This equation gives the energy required per unit charge to bring a charge  $$\\(q_{2}\\)$$  from infinity to a distance r from a point charge  $$\\(q_{1}\\text{.}\\)$$']
['How is this represented?', 'Mathematically, this is written as']
['What is the correct V?', '$$\\[V = \\left.']
['What else are the relevant details?', '\\frac{U_{E}}{q_{2}} \\right|_{R = r} - \\left. \\frac{U_{E}}{q_{2}} \\right|_{R = \\infty}\\text{.}\\]$$']
['What is the relationship among the three sides of a right-angled triangle according to the Py', 'Note that this equation actually represents a difference in electric potential.']

['What is the potential difference?', 'However, because the second term is zero, it is normally not written, and we speak of the electric potential instead of the electric potential difference, or we just say the potential difference, or voltage).']

['What is the potential difference of the two points?', 'Below, when we consider the electric potential energy per unit charge between two points not infinitely far apart, we speak of electric potential difference explicitly.']

['What are the other variables that could influence potential difference?', 'Just remember that electric potential and electric potential difference are really the same thing; the former is used just when the electric potential energy is zero in either the initial or final charge configuration.']
['What is the text about?', 'Now consider the electric potential near a group of charges q1, q2, and q3, as drawn in Figure 18.24.']
['How is it derived?', 'The electric potential is derived by considering the electric field.']

['Why does the electric potential add together?', 'Electric fields follow the principle of superposition and can be simply added together, so the electric potential from different charges also add together.']
['What does this tell us?', 'Thus, the electric potential of a point near a group of charges is']
['What is the function that the field vector ta,tt and tr are', 'Now let’s consider the electric potential in a uniform electric field.']

['How is the potential determined?', 'From the equation  $$\\(\\Delta U_{\\text{E}} = - qE\\left( {x_{\\text{f}} - x_{\\text{i}}} \\right)\\)$$, we see that the potential difference in going from  $$\\(x_{\\text{i}}\\)$$  to  $$\\(x_{\\text{f}}\\)$$  in a uniform electric field E is']
['What are some other examples?', 'Notice that a positive charge in a region with high potential will experience a force pushing it toward regions of lower potential.']
['What is potential?', 'In this sense, potential is like pressure for fluids.']
['How so?', 'Imagine a pipe containing fluid, with the fluid at one end of the pipe under high pressure and the fluid at the other end of the pipe under low pressure.']
['What happens next?', 'If nothing prevents the fluid from flowing, it will flow from the high-pressure end to the low-pressure end.']
['What happens next?', 'Likewise, a positive charge that is free to move will move from a region with high potential to a region with lower potential.']
['What are the current values of these two capacitors?', 'Consider again the X-ray tube discussed in the previous sample problem.']
['What is an example of what is happening in the current?', 'A single positive charge produces an electric field that points away from it, as in Figure 18.17.']
['What is the field like?', 'This field is not uniform, because the space between the lines increases as you move away from the charge.']
['What happens when you combine two charges?', 'However, if we combine a positive and a negative charge, we obtain the electric field shown in Figure 18.19(a).']
['Are the lines equally spaced?', 'Notice that, between the charges, the electric field lines are more equally spaced.']
['What is the current through the capacitor?', 'Now the region between the lines of charge contains a fairly uniform electric field.']

["I'm just waiting for you to explain your understanding of the polarization.", 'We can extend this idea even further and into two dimensions by placing two metallic plates face to face and charging one with positive charge and the other with an equal magnitude of negative charge.']
['How can we do this?', 'This can be done by connecting one plate to the positive terminal of a battery and the other plate to the negative terminal, as shown in Figure 18.28.']
['What can we infer from this?', 'The electric field between these charged plates will be extremely uniform.']
['What is the difference between plates and plates?', 'Let’s think about the work required to charge these plates.']
['What are some advantages of using a capacitor?', 'Before the plates are connected to the battery, they are neutral—that is, they have zero net charge.']

['How does the capacitor charge?', 'Placing the first positive charge on the left plate and the first negative charge on the right plate requires very little work, because the plates are neutral, so no opposing charges are present.']
['When does the capacitor charge?', 'Now consider placing a second positive charge on the left plate and a second negative charge on the right plate.']
['What are some factors in charge transfer?', 'Because the first two charges repel the new arrivals, a force must be applied to the two new charges over a distance to put them on the plates.']
['What else is important about work?', 'This is the definition of work, which means that, compared with the first pair, more work is required to put the second pair of charges on the plates.']
['What other facts about work are important?', 'To place the third positive and negative charges on the plates requires yet more work, and so on.']
['What else should we know about work?', 'The battery!']
["What is the battery's job in this scenario?", 'Its chemical potential energy is converted into the work required to separate the positive and negative charges.']
['What is the difference between a battery and capacitor?', 'Although the battery does work, this work remains within the battery-plate system.']

['What is the relation between energy and conservation of energy?', 'Therefore, conservation of energy tells us that, if the potential energy of the battery decreases to separate charges, the energy of another part of the system must increase by the same amount.']
['What happens when the energy is stored in the battery?', 'In fact, the energy from the battery is stored in the electric field between the plates.']
['How is this related to a raise hammer?', 'This idea is analogous to considering that the potential energy of a raised hammer is stored in Earth’s gravitational field.']
['What happens if the gravitational field disappears?', 'If the gravitational field were to disappear, the hammer would have no potential energy.']
['What happens if the electric field disappears?', 'Likewise, if no electric field existed between the plates, no energy would be stored between them.']
['What else will I need to know?', 'If we now disconnect the plates from the battery, they will hold the energy.']
['How will they hold the energy?', 'We could connect the plates to a lightbulb, for example, and the lightbulb would light up until this energy was used up.']
['What are the plates for?', 'These plates thus have the capacity to store energy.']
['What can happen as a result?', 'For this reason, an arrangement such as this is called a capacitor.']
['What is a capacitor?', 'A capacitor is an arrangement of objects that, by virtue of their geometry, can store energy an electric field.']
['Are there any diagrams in the document that help you learn?', 'Various real capacitors are shown in Figure 18.29.']
['What is the common design?', 'They are usually made from conducting plates or sheets that are separated by an insulating material.']
['What other designs are there?', 'They can be flat or rolled up or have other geometries.']

['What is the relationship between C and Q and V?', 'where Q is the magnitude of the charge on each capacitor plate, and V is the potential difference in going from the negative plate to the positive plate.']
['How can you figure this out?', 'This means that both Q and V are always positive, so the capacitance is always positive.']

['What else can you tell me?', 'We can see from the equation for capacitance that the units of capacitance are C/V, which are called farads (F) after the nineteenth-century English physicist Michael Faraday.']

['What can you tell me about this content?', 'The equation  $$\\(C = {Q/V}\\)$$  makes sense: A parallel-plate capacitor (like the one shown in Figure 18.28) the size of a football field could hold a lot of charge without requiring too much work per unit charge to push the charge into the capacitor.']
['How is this calculated?', 'Thus, Q would be large, and V would be small, so the capacitance C would be very large.']

['What about smaller capacitors?', 'Squeezing the same charge into a capacitor the size of a fingernail would require much more work, so V would be very large, and the capacitance would be much smaller.']
['What is one important fact about this material?', 'Although the equation  $$\\(C = {Q/V}\\)$$  makes it seem that capacitance depends on voltage, in fact it does not.']

['What is the fact that capacitance depends on voltage?', 'For a given capacitor, the ratio of the charge stored in the capacitor to the voltage difference between the plates of the capacitor always remains the same.']
['Where does the capacitance come from?', 'Capacitance is determined by the geometry of the capacitor and the materials that it is made from.']
['What is the geometry of the capacitor?', 'For a parallel-plate capacitor with nothing between its plates, the capacitance is given by']
['Which two sides of a right triangle would resemble each other according to the Pytha', 'where A is the area of the plates of the capacitor and d is their separation.']
['How does the capacitor act?', 'We use  $$\\(C_{0}\\)$$  instead of C, because the capacitor has nothing between its plates (in the next section, we’ll see what happens when this is not the case).']
['What is the constant of free space called?', 'The constant  $$\\(\\varepsilon_{0}\\text{,}\\)$$  read epsilon zero is called the permittivity of free space, and its value is']
['What else can you tell me about this content?', 'Coming back to the energy stored in a capacitor, we can ask exactly how much energy a capacitor stores.']

['Is there any other interesting information?', 'If a capacitor is charged by putting a voltage V across it for example, by connecting it to a battery with voltage V—the electrical potential energy stored in the capacitor is']

['Why does it say this?', 'Before working through some sample problems, let’s look at what happens if we put an insulating material between the plates of a capacitor that has been charged and then disconnected from the charging battery, as illustrated in Figure 18.30.']

['What happens after we remove the insulating material?', 'Because the material is insulating, the charge cannot move through it from one plate to the other, so the charge Q on the capacitor does not change.']

['What happened after we put the insulating material in?', 'An electric field exists between the plates of a charged capacitor, so the insulating material becomes polarized, as shown in the lower part of the figure.']
["What's this referred to as?", 'An electrically insulating material that becomes polarized in an electric field is called a dielectric.']
['What are dielectrics?', 'Figure 18.30 shows that the negative charge in the molecules in the material shifts to the left, toward the positive charge of the capacitor.']
['How does this happen?', 'This shift is due to the electric field, which applies a force to the left on the electrons in the molecules of the dielectric.']
['What happens to the right sides of the molecules?', 'The right sides of the molecules are now missing a bit of negative charge, so their net charge is positive.']
['What are dielectrics?', 'All electrically insulating materials are dielectrics, but some are better dielectrics than others.']
['What are they better at?', 'A good dielectric is one whose molecules allow their electrons to shift strongly in an electric field.']

['What does the electric field do?', 'In other words, an electric field pulls their electrons a fair bit away from their atom, but they do not escape completely from their atom (which is why they are insulators).']
['What does figure 18.31 show?', 'Figure 18.31 shows a macroscopic view of a dielectric in a charged capacitor.']

['How does the view of a dielectric effect the electric field?', 'Notice that the electric-field lines in the capacitor with the dielectric are spaced farther apart than the electric-field lines in the capacitor with no dielectric.']

['How does this affect the field?', 'This means that the electric field in the dielectric is weaker, so it stores less electrical potential energy than the electric field in the capacitor with no dielectric.']
['What is special about dielectrics?', 'In fact, the molecules in the dielectric act like tiny springs, and the energy in the electric field goes into stretching these springs.']

['What else does the energy do?', 'With the electric field thus weakened, the voltage difference between the two sides of the capacitor is smaller, so it becomes easier to put more charge on the capacitor.']
['Why is that important?', 'Placing a dielectric in a capacitor before charging it therefore allows more charge and potential energy to be stored in the capacitor.']
['How does a parallel plate help?', 'A parallel plate with a dielectric has a capacitance of']
['What is the relationship among the three sides of a right-angled triangle according to the Py', 'where  $$\\(\\kappa\\)$$  (kappa) is a dimensionless constant called the dielectric constant.']

['What does the dielectric constant have to do with capacitors?', 'Because  $$\\(\\kappa\\)$$  is greater than 1 for dielectrics, the capacitance increases when a dielectric is placed between the capacitor plates.']
['What is the dielectric constant of a material?', 'The dielectric constant of several materials is shown in Table 18.1.']

['What do they mean by alternating current?', 'Just as water flows from high to low elevation, electrons that are free to move will travel from a place with low potential to a place with high potential.']
['What is the difference between battery and electrical current?', 'A battery has two terminals that are at different potentials.']
['How does the current flow?', 'If the terminals are connected by a conducting wire, an electric current (charges) will flow, as shown in Figure 19.2.']

['What is the current like when it flows?', 'Electrons will then move from the low-potential terminal of the battery (the negative end) through the wire and enter the high-potential terminal of the battery (the positive end).']
['What is current?', 'Electric current is the rate at which electric charge moves.']

['Does it matter how fast it moves?', 'A large current, such as that used to start a truck engine, moves a large amount very quickly, whereas a small current, such as that used to operate a hand-held calculator, moves a small amount of charge more slowly.']
['What is current I defined as?', 'In equation form, electric current I is defined as']
['What does this mean?', 'where  $$\\(\\Delta Q\\)$$  is the amount of charge that flows past a given area and  $$\\(\\Delta t\\)$$  is the time it takes for the charge to move past the area.']
['What is the SI unit?', 'The SI unit for electric current is the ampere (A), which is named in honor of the French physicist André-Marie Ampère (1775–1836).']
['What does an ampere mean?', 'One ampere is one coulomb per second, or']
['What is the most important thing you learned?', 'Electric current moving through a wire is in many ways similar to water current moving through a pipe.']
['What else is interesting?', 'To define the flow of water through a pipe, we can count the water molecules that flow past a given section of the pipe.']
['Do we use that same approach for electric current?', 'As shown in Figure 19.3, electric current is very similar.']
['How do we count those charges?', 'We count the number of electrical charges that flow past a section of a conductor; in this case, a wire.']

['What was the problem you were studying?', 'Assume each particle q in Figure 19.3 carries a charge  $$\\(q = 1\\;\\text{nC}\\)$$, in which case the total charge shown would be  $$\\(\\Delta Q = 5q = 5\\;\\text{nC}\\)$$ .']
['What are the charges moving past the area?', 'If these charges move past the area A in a time  $$\\(\\Delta t = 1\\;\\text{ns}\\)$$, then the current would be']
['How does it work in an ionic compound?', 'Note that we assigned a positive charge to the charges in Figure 19.3.']
['What are the negative charges?', 'Normally, negative charges—electrons—are the mobile charge in wires, as indicated in Figure 19.2.']
['What are the positive charges?', 'Positive charges are normally stuck in place in solids and cannot move freely.']

['What is the conventional current?', 'However, because a positive current moving to the right is the same as a negative current of equal magnitude moving to the left, as shown in Figure 19.4, we define conventional current to flow in the direction that a positive charge would flow if it could move.']
['What is the current composed of?', 'Thus, unless otherwise specified, an electric current is assumed to be composed of positive charges.']
['What is C?', 'Also note that one Coulomb is a significant amount of electric charge, so 5 A is a very large current.']
['How much current will you see in everyday life?', 'Most often you will see current on the order of milliamperes (mA).']
['What is the direction of conventional current?', 'The direction of conventional current is the direction that positive charge would flow.']
['What are the other types of current?', 'Depending on the situation, positive charges, negative charges, or both may move.']
['What is important about electrons?', 'In metal wires, as we have seen, current is carried by electrons, so the negative charges move.']
['What is important about ions?', 'In ionic solutions, such as salt water, both positively charged and negatively charged ions move.']
['What else does current do?', 'This is also true in nerve cells.']
['Are there any other types of current?', 'Pure positive currents are relatively rare but do occur.']
['Who is Franklin?', 'History credits American politician and scientist Benjamin Franklin with describing current as the direction that positive charges flow through a wire.']
['What was his theory?', 'He named the type of charge associated with electrons negative long before they were known to carry current in so many situations.']
['What type of obstacles do electrons encounter as they move?', 'As electrons move through a metal wire, they encounter obstacles such as other electrons, atoms, impurities, etc.']
['What happens to the electrons as they encounter obstacles?', 'The electrons scatter from these obstacles, as depicted in Figure 19.5.']
['What happens with each interaction?', 'Normally, the electrons lose energy with each interaction.']
['How many collisions happen each time?', '1']
['What is the energy loss caused by?', 'To keep the electrons moving thus requires a force, which is supplied by an electric field.']
['How does the electric field work?', 'The electric field in a wire points from the end of the wire at the higher potential to the end of the wire at the lower potential.']
['How do the electrons move?', 'Electrons, carrying a negative charge, move on average (or drift) in the direction opposite the electric field, as shown in Figure 19.5.']
['How does this help me understand the subject?', 'So far, we have discussed current that moves constantly in a single direction.']
['What does this mean?', 'This is called direct current, because the electric charge flows in only one direction.']
['What is this referred to as?', 'Direct current is often called DC current.']

['What are the most important concepts presented in this document?', 'Many sources of electrical power, such as the hydroelectric dam shown at the beginning of this chapter, produce alternating current, in which the current direction alternates back and forth.']
['What is AC current?', 'Alternating current is often called AC current.']
['What time intervals does AC current follow?', 'Alternating current moves back and forth at regular time intervals, as shown in Figure 19.6.']
['What happens if there is no source of AC current?', 'The alternating current that comes from a normal wall socket does not suddenly switch directions.']
['What causes it to switch?', 'Rather, it increases smoothly up to a maximum current and then smoothly decreases back to zero.']
['What happens after the current drops to zero?', 'It then grows again, but in the opposite direction until it has reached the same maximum value.']
['What happens after that maximum value?', 'After that, it decreases smoothly back to zero, and the cycle starts over again.']
['What type of devices use AC?', 'Devices that use AC include vacuum cleaners, fans, power tools, hair dryers, and countless others.']
['How do these devices obtain power?', 'These devices obtain the power they require when you plug them into a wall socket.']
['What happens when you plug the devices into the socket?', 'The wall socket is connected to the power grid that provides an alternating potential (AC potential).']
['What does AC potential do to the devices?', 'When your device is plugged in, the AC potential pushes charges back and forth in the circuit of the device, creating an alternating current.']
['What type of power does the computer use?', 'Many devices, however, use DC, such as computers, cell phones, flashlights, and cars.']
['What is the DC potential?', 'One source of DC is a battery, which provides a constant potential (DC potential) between its terminals.']
['What can the battery do?', 'With your device connected to a battery, the DC potential pushes charge in one direction through the circuit of your device, creating a DC current.']
['What else do you learn about DC potential?', 'Another way to produce DC current is by using a transformer, which converts AC potential to DC potential.']
['What do you use the transformer for?', 'Small transformers that you can plug into a wall socket are used to charge up your laptop, cell phone, or other electronic device.']
['What is a transformer?', 'People generally call this a charger or a battery, but it is a transformer that transforms AC voltage into DC voltage.']

['What else did you learn about the power source?', 'The next time someone asks to borrow your laptop charger, tell them that you don’t have a laptop charger, but that they may borrow your converter.']
['what was he talking about?', 'As mentioned previously, electrical current in a wire is in many ways similar to water flowing through a pipe.']
['why is the water similar to a wire?', 'The water current that can flow through a pipe is affected by obstacles in the pipe, such as clogs and narrow sections in the pipe.']
['how would these obstacles affect the water current?', 'These obstacles slow down the flow of current through the pipe.']

['what else was significant?', 'Similarly, electrical current in a wire can be slowed down by many factors, including impurities in the metal of the wire or collisions between the charges in the material.']
['what is resistance?', 'These factors create a resistance to the electrical current.']
['what does resistance mean?', 'Resistance is a description of how much a wire or other electrical component opposes the flow of charge through it.']

["who invented Ohm's law?", 'In the 19th century, the German physicist Georg Simon Ohm (1787–1854) found experimentally that current through a conductor is proportional to the voltage drop across a current-carrying conductor.']
['What is the relationship between voltage and resistance?', 'This relationship is called Ohm’s law.']
['How does it relate to the current?', 'It can be viewed as a cause-and-effect relationship, with voltage being the cause and the current being the effect.']
['Does it have a specific name?', 'Ohm’s law is an empirical law like that for friction, which means that it is an experimentally observed phenomenon.']
['What are the units?', 'The units of resistance are volts per ampere, or V/A.']
['What is the symbol for V/A?', 'We call a V/A an ohm, which is represented by the uppercase Greek letter omega ( $$\\(\\text{Ω}\\)$$ ).']
["What does  have to do with Ohm's law?", 'Thus,']
["What is Ohm's law?", 'Ohm’s law holds for most materials and at common temperatures.']
['What happens when the temperature is too low?', 'At very low temperatures, resistance may drop to zero (superconductivity).']
['What happens when the temperature is too high?', 'At very high temperatures, the thermal motion of atoms in the material inhibits the flow of electrons, increasing the resistance.']
['Are all substances considered to be Ohmic?', 'The many substances for which Ohm’s law holds are called ohmic.']
['What type of conductors are Ohmic?', 'Ohmic materials include good conductors like copper, aluminum, and silver, and some poor conductors under certain circumstances.']
["What else is significant about Ohm's law?", 'The resistance of ohmic materials remains essentially the same for a wide range of voltage and current.']
["What's your first question?", 'Now that we understand the concept of electric current, let’s see what we can do with it.']
['What do you mean?', 'As you are no doubt aware, the modern lifestyle relies heavily on electrical devices.']
['What do electrical devices contain?', 'These devices contain ingenious electric circuits, which are complete, closed pathways through which electric current flows.']
['What is an electric circuit?', 'Returning to our water analogy, an electric circuit is to electric charge like a network of pipes is to water:']
['What does it do?', 'The electric circuit guides electric charge from one point to the next, running the charge through various devices along the way to extract work or information.']
['What type of circuits are used in power systems?', 'Electric circuits are made from many materials and cover a huge range of sizes, as shown in Figure 19.8.']

['Are there any specific types of circuits mentioned in the passage?', 'Computers and cell phones contain electric circuits whose features can be as small as roughly a billionth of a meter (a nanometer, or  $$\\(10^{-9}\\text{m}\\)$$ ).']
['Why are the features so small?', 'The pathways that guide the current in these devices are made by ultraprecise chemical treatments of silicon or other semiconductors.']
['Are there other types of circuits mentioned in the passage?', 'Large power systems, on the other hand, contain electric circuits whose features are on the scale of meters.']
['Why are the features so large?', 'These systems carry such large electric currents that their physical dimensions must be relatively large.']
['What kind of pathways do these circuits consist of?', 'The pathways that form electric circuits are made from a conducting material, normally a metal in macroscopic circuits.']

['What kinds of objects can be connected through these pathways?', 'For example, copper wires inside your school building form the electrical circuits that power lighting, projectors, screens, speakers, etc.']
['What kind of representations do we use to represent these circuits?', 'To represent an electric circuit, we draw circuit diagrams.']
['What lines and symbols do we use?', 'We use lines and symbols to represent the elements in the circuit.']
['What is the most important part of this section for you?', 'A simple electric circuit diagram is shown on the left side of Figure 19.9.']
['What is the right side of this figure?', 'On the right side is an analogous water circuit, which we discuss below.']

['What are some of the symbols we will use?', 'There are many different symbols that scientists and engineers use in circuit diagrams, but we will focus on four main symbols: the wire, the battery or voltage source, resistors, and the ground.']
['What does the black lines mean?', 'The thin black lines in the electric circuit diagram represent the pathway that the electric charge must follow.']
['What does the black lines mean?', 'These pathways are assumed to be perfect conductors, so electric charge can move along these pathways without losing any energy.']
['What does perfect conductor mean?', 'In reality, the wires in circuits are not perfect, but they come close enough for our purposes.']
['What is the main topic of this section?', 'The zigzag element labeled R is a resistor, which is a circuit element that provides a known resistance.']
['What does the R stand for?', 'Macroscopic resistors are often color coded to indicate their resistance, as shown in Figure 19.10.']

['What is Figure 19.9?', 'The red element in Figure 19.9 is a battery, with its positive and negative terminals indicated; the longer line represents the positive terminal of the battery, and the shorter line represents the negative terminal.']
['How do you identify the battery?', 'Note that the battery icon is not always colored red; this is done in Figure 19.9 just to make it easy to identify.']

['What does the element labeled ground on the lower left of the circuit indicate?', 'Finally, the element labeled ground on the lower left of the circuit indicates that the circuit is connected to Earth, which is a large, essentially neutral object containing an infinite amount of charge.']
['What is ground connected to?', 'Among other things, the ground determines the potential of the negative terminal of the battery.']
['What is the potential of ground?', 'Normally, the potential of the ground is defined to be zero:  $$\\(V_{\\text{ground}} \\equiv 0\\)$$ .']
['How does zero affect the lower wire?', 'This means that the entire lower wire in Figure 19.10 is at a voltage of zero volts.']
['What are the currents in?', 'The electric current in Figure 19.9 is indicted by the blue line labeled I.']
['What is the arrow on?', 'The arrow indicates the direction in which positive charge would flow in this circuit.']

['What direction does the negative charge flow?', 'Recall that, in metals, electrons are mobile charge carriers, so negative charges actually flow in the opposite direction around this circuit (i.e., counterclockwise).']
['What is the difference?', 'However, we draw the current to show the direction in which positive charge would move.']
['What can you tell me about Figure 19.9?', 'On the right side of Figure 19.9 is an analogous water circuit.']
['Why is this analogous?', 'Water at a higher pressure leaves the top of the pump, which is like charges leaving the positive terminal of the battery.']
['How does the water flow?', 'The water travels through the pipe, like the charges traveling through the wire.']
['Does the water get warmer?', 'Next, the water goes through a sand filter, which heats up as the water squeezes through.']
['What happens after the filter?', 'This step is like the charges going through the resistor.']
['What happens during the pass?', 'When charges flow through a resistor, they do work to heat up the resistor.']
['What happens after the resistor?', 'After flowing through the sand filter, the water has converted its potential energy into heat, so it is at a lower pressure.']
['What is the voltage?', 'Likewise, the charges exiting the resistor have converted their potential energy into heat, so they are at a lower voltage.']
['What else is significant?', 'Recall that voltage is just potential energy per charge.']
['Is there more?', 'Thus, water pressure is analogous to electric potential energy (i.e., voltage).']
