['What else does this tell me?', 'Coming back to the water circuit again, we see that the water returns to the bottom of the pump, which is like the charge returning to the negative terminal of the battery.']
['Is there more?', 'The water pump uses a source of energy to pump the water back up to a high pressure again, giving it the pressure required to go through the circuit once more.']
['Why does it use energy?', 'The water pump is like the battery, which uses chemical energy to increase the voltage of the charge up to the level of the positive terminal.']
['What is the voltage rating of the battery?', 'The potential energy per charge at the positive terminal of the battery is the voltage rating of the battery.']
['Why is this voltage important?', 'This voltage is like water pressure in the upper pipe.']
['What causes this pressure?', 'Just like a higher pressure forces water to move toward a lower pressure, a higher voltage forces electric charge to flow toward a lower voltage.']
['What is a pump?', 'The pump takes water at low pressure and does work on it, ejecting water at a higher pressure.']
['What happens to the water?', 'Likewise, a battery takes charge at a low voltage, does work on it, and ejects charge at a higher voltage.']
['What is the current in the water circuit of Figure 19.9?', 'Note that the current in the water circuit of Figure 19.9 is the same throughout the circuit.']

['Is it always the same current?', 'In other words, if we measured the number of water molecules passing a cross-section of the pipe per unit time at any point in the circuit, we would get the same answer no matter where in the circuit we measured.']
['Does that mean that the water always flows at the same speed?', 'The same is true of the electrical circuit in the same figure.']
['What else is true about the electric circuit?', 'The electric current is the same at all points in this circuit, including inside the battery and in the resistor.']
['Are there any other interesting things that are true about the current in the electric circuit?', 'The electric current neither speeds up in the wires nor slows down in the resistor.']

['What else is true about current in the electric circuit?', 'Thus, the current is the same at all points in the circuit shown in Figure 19.9.']

['What happens to the voltage?', 'In the water circuit, the water pressure at the pump outlet stays the same until the water goes through the sand filter, assuming no energy loss in the pipe.']

['What is the most important concept from this text?', 'If the switch is closed for a long time in the electric circuit or if the valve is open for a long time in the water circuit, the current will eventually stop flowing because the capacitor or the membrane will have become completely charged.']
['What happens when it is completely charged?', 'Each circuit is now in the steady state, which means that its characteristics do not change over time.']
['what are some characteristics?', 'In this case, the steady state is characterized by zero current, and this does not change as long as the switch or valve remains in the same position.']

['What does this document cover?', 'Although the circuit in Figure 19.12 may seem a bit pointless because all that happens when the switch is closed is that the capacitor charges up, it does show the capacitor’s ability to store charge.']

['How can this be beneficial?', 'This property of capacitors is used in circuits in many ways.']

['How can this be useful?', 'In addition, capacitors can serve as filters.']
['What are filters?', 'To understand this, let’s go back to the water analogy.']
['Where does water come from?', 'Suppose you have a water hose and are watering your garden.']
['What happens when your friend kinks the hose?', 'Your friend thinks he’s funny, and kinks the hose.']
['What happens to you?', 'While the hose is kinked, you experience no water flow.']
['Why does he kink the hose?', 'When he lets go, the water starts flowing again.']
['What happens next?', 'If he does this really fast, you experience water-no water-water-no water, and that’s really no way to water your garden.']
['What does this mean for you?', 'Now imagine that the hose is filling up a big bucket, and you are watering from the bottom of the bucket.']

['What do you learn from this?', 'Your friend kinking the water hose is filtered by the big bucket’s supply of water, so it does not impact your ability to water the garden.']
['What else do you know about this analogy?', 'We can think of the interruptions in the current (be it water or electrical current) as noise.']
['What does the capacitor do?', 'Capacitors act in an analogous way as the water bucket to help filter out the noise.']
['What else do you know about capacitors?', 'Capacitors have so many uses that it is very rare to find an electronic circuit that does not include some capacitors.']
['What happened next?', 'Now that we have a basic idea of how electrical circuits work, let’s see what happens in circuits with more than one circuit element.']

['What is power?', 'Power is associated by many people with electricity.']

['What does power do for us?', 'We also use electric power to start our cars, to run our computers, or to light our homes.']
['What is power?', 'Power is the rate at which energy of any type is transferred; electric power is the rate at which electric energy is transferred in a circuit.']
['Is there any other information I should know about power?', 'In this section, we’ll learn not only what this means, but also what factors determine electric power.']

['When was the study material created?', 'People have been aware of magnets and magnetism for thousands of years.']
['What happened early on?', 'The earliest records date back to ancient times, particularly in the region of Asia Minor called Magnesia—the name of this region is the source of words like magnet.']
['Where was Magnesia?', 'Magnetic rocks found in Magnesia, which is now part of western Turkey, stimulated interest during ancient times.']

['Did magnets create problems?', 'When humans first discovered magnetic rocks, they likely found that certain parts of these rocks attracted bits of iron or other magnetic rocks more strongly than other parts.']
['How are they identified?', 'These areas are called the poles of a magnet.']
['What are poles?', 'A magnetic pole is the part of a magnet that exerts the strongest force on other magnets or magnetic material, such as iron.']
['Are there other examples?', 'For example, the poles of the bar magnet shown in Figure 20.2 are where the paper clips are concentrated.']

['What is the most important thing you learned from the article?', 'If a bar magnet is suspended so that it rotates freely, one pole of the magnet will always turn toward the north, with the opposite pole facing south.']
['What did they discover by testing the magnets?', 'This discovery led to the compass, which is simply a small, elongated magnet mounted so that it can rotate freely.']
['What were some examples of compass designs?', 'An example of a compass is shown Figure 20.3.']
['What are the two poles?', 'The pole of the magnet that orients northward is called the north pole, and the opposite pole of the magnet is called the south pole.']

['What is the most important information about magnets?', 'The discovery that one particular pole of a magnet orients northward, whereas the other pole orients southward allowed people to identify the north and south poles of any magnet.']
["What is magnets' greatest influence on everyday life?", 'It was then noticed that the north poles of two different magnets repel each other, and likewise for the south poles.']
['Are there any exceptions to this rule?', 'Conversely, the north pole of one magnet attracts the south pole of other magnets.']
['What is the analogy?', 'This situation is analogous to that of electric charge, where like charges repel and unlike charges attract.']
['How is this analogous to magnets?', 'In magnets, we simply replace charge with pole: Like poles repel and unlike poles attract.']
['Why is this so important?', 'This is summarized in Figure 20.4, which shows how the force between magnets depends on their relative orientation.']
["What's an important fact in this section of the study material?", 'Consider again the fact that the pole of a magnet that orients northward is called the north pole of the magnet.']
['What does the opposite pole do?', 'If unlike poles attract, then the magnetic pole of Earth that is close to the geographic North Pole must be a magnetic south pole!']
['How does this apply to magnets?', 'Likewise, the magnetic pole of Earth that is close to the geographic South Pole must be a magnetic north pole.']

["What's the figure called that describes this situation?", 'This situation is depicted in Figure 20.5, in which Earth is represented as containing a giant internal bar magnet with its magnetic south pole at the geographic North Pole and vice versa.']

['What are some important things to know?', 'If we were to somehow suspend a giant bar magnet in space near Earth, then the north pole of the space magnet would be attracted to the south pole of Earth’s internal magnet.']
['What are some examples of this?', 'This is in essence what happens with a compass needle:']
['What does this do?', 'Its magnetic north pole is attracted to the magnet south pole of Earth’s internal magnet.']
['Was this material a textbook or online?', 'The answer is no:']
["What's the significance of the poles?", 'Each half of the bar magnet has a north pole and a south pole.']
['What else do you know about the poles?', 'You can even continue cutting each piece of the bar magnet in half, and you will always obtain a new, smaller magnet with two opposite poles.']

['What is your favorite part of the article?', 'As shown in Figure 20.6, you can continue this process down to the atomic scale, and you will find that even the smallest particles that behave as magnets have two opposite poles.']

['Does anything else interesting happen in the article?', 'In fact, no experiment has ever found any object with a single magnetic pole, from the smallest subatomic particle such as electrons to the largest objects in the universe such as stars.']
['What is the most important thing that you learned?', 'Because magnets always have two poles, they are referred to as magnetic dipoles—di means two.']
['What else did you learn?', 'Below, we will see that magnetic dipoles have properties that are analogous to electric dipoles.']
['What materials are magnetic?', 'Only certain materials, such as iron, cobalt, nickel, and gadolinium, exhibit strong magnetic effects.']
['What is ferromagnetic?', 'Such materials are called ferromagnetic, after the Latin word ferrum for iron.']
['What is weak magnetization?', 'Other materials exhibit weak magnetic effects, which are detectable only with sensitive instruments.']

['What else is important to know about magnets?', 'Not only do ferromagnetic materials respond strongly to magnets—the way iron is attracted to magnets—but they can also be magnetized themselves—that is, they can be induced to be magnetic or made into permanent magnets (Figure 20.7).']
['What is a permanent magnet?', 'A permanent magnet is simply a material that retains its magnetic behavior for a long time, even when exposed to demagnetizing influences.']

['What is magnetization?', 'When a magnet is brought near a previously unmagnetized ferromagnetic material, it causes local magnetization of the material with unlike poles closest, as in the right side of Figure 20.7.']
['How does this effect the magnet?', 'This causes an attractive force, which is why unmagnetized iron is attracted to a magnet.']
['what happens on a microscopic scale?', 'What happens on a microscopic scale is illustrated in Figure 7(a).']
['what does a domain do?', 'Regions within the material called domains act like small bar magnets.']
['what happens in the domains?', 'Within domains, the magnetic poles of individual atoms are aligned.']
['What does the atom do?', 'Each atom acts like a tiny bar magnet.']
['what are the domains?', 'Domains are small and randomly oriented in an unmagnetized ferromagnetic object.']
['what else is interesting about this section?', 'In response to an external magnetic field, the domains may grow to millimeter size, aligning themselves, as shown in Figure 7(b).']
['is this permanent?', 'This induced magnetization can be made permanent if the material is heated and then cooled, or simply tapped in the presence of other magnets.']
['What is magnetization?', 'Conversely, a permanent magnet can be demagnetized by hard blows or by heating it in the absence of another magnet.']
['What is thermal?', 'Increased thermal motion at higher temperature can disrupt and randomize the orientation and size of the domains.']
['Why is temperature important?', 'There is a well-defined temperature for ferromagnetic materials, which is called the Curie temperature, above which they cannot be magnetized.']
['Is it cold or hot?', 'The Curie temperature for iron is 1,043 K (770 $$\\(\\text{°C}\\)$$ ), which is well above room temperature.']
['Does it matter what metal is used?', 'There are several elements and alloys that have Curie temperatures much lower than room temperature and are ferromagnetic only below those temperatures.']
['What is magnetic fields?', 'We have thus seen that forces can be applied between magnets and between magnets and ferromagnetic materials without any contact between the objects.']
['What is reminiscent of electric forces?', 'This is reminiscent of electric forces, which also act over distances.']

['What is the concept of electric fields?', 'Electric forces are described using the concept of the electric field, which is a force field around electric charges that describes the force on any other charge placed in the field.']
['What is the concept of magnetic fields?', 'Likewise, a magnet creates a magnetic field around it that describes the force exerted on other magnets placed in the field.']

['What does magnetic field lines represent?', 'As with electric fields, the pictorial representation of magnetic field lines is very useful for visualizing the strength and direction of the magnetic field.']

['What is the definition of magnetic field lines?', 'As shown in Figure 20.9, the direction of magnetic field lines is defined to be the direction in which the north pole of a compass needle points.']

['What is the direction of a compass needle when placed near a magnet?', 'If you place a compass near the north pole of a magnet, the north pole of the compass needle will be repelled and point away from the magnet.']
['Can you tell me what happens when the north pole of a magnet is repelled?', 'Thus, the magnetic field lines point away from the north pole of a magnet and toward its south pole.']
['What is one way magnetic fields can be mapped out?', 'Magnetic field lines can be mapped out using a small compass.']

['How is the compass used to map out magnetic fields?', 'The compass is moved from point to point around a magnet, and at each point, a short line is drawn in the direction of the needle, as shown in Figure 20.10.']
['How are the lines joined?', 'Joining the lines together then reveals the path of the magnetic field line.']
['What else can be used to map out magnetic fields?', 'Another way to visualize magnetic field lines is to sprinkle iron filings around a magnet.']
['Why do we need to sprinkle the filings around?', 'The filings will orient themselves along the magnetic field lines, forming a pattern such as that shown on the right in Figure 20.10.']

['What is the relationship between magnetic fields and electric field lines?', 'When two magnets are brought close together, the magnetic field lines are perturbed, just as happens for electric field lines when two electric charges are brought together.']

['When two magnets are brought close together, what happens?', 'Bringing two north poles together—or two south poles—will cause a repulsion, and the magnetic field lines will bend away from each other.']
['What is the result of this?', 'This is shown in Figure 20.11, which shows the magnetic field lines created by the two closely separated north poles of a bar magnet.']
['What happens if the poles touch?', 'When opposite poles of two magnets are brought together, the magnetic field lines join together and become denser between the poles.']
['How does this compare to the separation?', 'This situation is shown in Figure 20.11.']
['what kind of fields are magnetic?', 'Like the electric field, the magnetic field is stronger where the lines are denser.']
['what is the density?', 'Thus, between the two north poles in Figure 20.11, the magnetic field is very weak because the density of the magnetic field is almost zero.']
['what happens in that area?', 'A compass placed at that point would essentially spin freely if we ignore Earth’s magnetic field.']

['how does that change the field?', 'Conversely, the magnetic field lines between the north and south poles in Figure 20.11 are very dense, indicating that the magnetic field is very strong in this region.']
['what happens in that region?', 'A compass placed here would quickly align with the magnetic field and point toward the south pole on the right.']
['What is a magnetic field?', 'Note that magnets are not the only things that make magnetic fields.']
['Did any currents cause magnetic fields?', 'Early in the nineteenth century, people discovered that electrical currents cause magnetic effects.']
['Who discovered this?', 'The first significant observation was by the Danish scientist Hans Christian Oersted (1777–1851), who found that a compass needle was deflected by a current-carrying wire.']
['Did they make a discovery about that?', 'This was the first significant evidence that the movement of electric charges had any connection with magnets.']
['What is an electromagnet?', 'An electromagnet is a device that uses electric current to make a magnetic field.']
['What is an electromagnet?', 'These temporarily induced magnets are called electromagnets.']

['What do people use electromagnets for?', 'Electromagnets are employed for everything from a wrecking yard crane that lifts scrapped cars to controlling the beam of a 90-km-circumference particle accelerator to the magnets in medical-imaging machines (see Figure 20.12).']
['What is a magnetic field?', 'The magnetic field created by an electric current in a long straight wire is shown in Figure 20.13.']
['What happens when the current flows through a wire?', 'The magnetic field lines form concentric circles around the wire.']
['What can you tell me about magnetic fields?', 'The direction of the magnetic field can be determined using the right-hand rule.']
['What is the right-hand rule?', 'This rule shows up in several places in the study of electricity and magnetism.']

['What does the right-hand rule say?', 'Applied to a straight current-carrying wire, the right-hand rule says that, with your right thumb pointed in the direction of the current, the magnetic field will be in the direction in which your right fingers curl, as shown in Figure 20.13.']
['Does the right-hand rule say anything else?', 'If the wire is very long compared to the distance r from the wire, the strength B of the magnetic field is given by']
['What is the function B_[straighttextwire of this magnetic field?', '$$\\[B_{\\text{straight}\\text{wire}} = \\frac{\\mu_{0}']
['What is the function I?', 'I}{2\\pi r}\\]$$']
['Which is the formula to find a magnetic field according to this paper?', 'where I is the current in the wire in amperes.']
['What is the SI unit for magnetic field?', 'The SI unit for magnetic field is the tesla (T).']
['How does the field propagate in free space?', 'The symbol  $$\\(\\mu_{0}\\)$$ —read “mu-zero”—is a constant called the “permeability of free space” and is given by']
['What happened next?', 'Now imagine winding a wire around a cylinder with the cylinder then removed.']
['What happens then?', 'The result is a wire coil, as shown in Figure 20.14.']
['What does it do?', 'This is called a solenoid.']
['What is it?', 'To find the direction of the magnetic field produced by a solenoid, apply the right-hand rule to several points on the coil.']
['Do that?', 'You should be able to convince yourself that, inside the coil, the magnetic field points from left to right.']
['How is that accomplished?', 'In fact, another application of the right-hand rule is to curl your right-hand fingers around the coil in the direction in which the current flows.']
['Does it move?', 'Your right thumb then points in the direction of the magnetic field inside the coil: left to right in this case.']
['What are the individual loops of wire inside a solenoid?', 'Each loop of wire contributes to the magnetic field inside the solenoid.']
['What happens when the magnetic field lines are drawn from a loop of wire outside?', 'Because the magnetic field lines must form closed loops, the field lines close the loop outside the solenoid.']
['What is the result?', 'The magnetic field lines are much denser inside the solenoid than outside the solenoid.']
['What is the result of this?', 'The resulting magnetic field looks very much like that of a bar magnet, as shown in Figure 20.15.']
['What is the most important aspect of this?', 'The magnetic field strength deep inside a solenoid is']

['Why does magnetic force exist?', 'If a moving electric charge, that is electric current, produces a magnetic field that can exert a force on another magnet, then the reverse should be true by Newton’s third law.']

['Why does a magnet exert force on another magnet?', 'In other words, a charge moving through the magnetic field produced by another object should experience a force—and this is exactly what we find.']

['What are some other examples?', 'As a concrete example, consider Figure 20.16, which shows a charge q moving with velocity  $$\\(\\overset{\\rightarrow}{v}\\)$$  through a magnetic field  $$\\(\\overset{\\rightarrow}{']
['B', 'B}\\)$$  between the poles of a permanent magnet.']
['How large is the force of this charge?', 'The magnitude F of the force experienced by this charge is']

['How do you know which direction the force is facing?', 'The direction of the force may be found by using another version of the right-hand rule: First, we join the tails of the velocity vector and a magnetic field vector, as shown in step 1 of Figure 20.16.']

['How does the right-hand rule calculate?', 'We then curl our right fingers from  $$\\(\\overset{\\rightarrow}{v}\\)$$  to  $$\\(\\overset{\\rightarrow}{B}\\)$$, as indicated in step (2) of Figure 20.16.']
['What happens when you use the right-hand rule?', 'The direction in which the right thumb points is the direction of the force.']
['What is the direction of the force on the page?', 'For the charge in Figure 20.16, we find that the force is directed into the page.']

['What is the factor $$(sintheta)$$', 'Note that the factor  $$\\(\\sin\\theta\\)$$  in the equation  $$\\(F = qvB\\sin\\theta\\)$$ means that zero force is applied on a charge that moves parallel to a magnetic field because  $$\\(\\theta = 0\\)$$  and  $$\\(\\sin 0 = 0\\)$$ .']

['What is the maximum force the charge can experience', 'The maximum force a charge can experience is when it moves perpendicular to the magnetic field, because  $$\\(\\theta = 90{^\\circ}\\)$$ and  $$\\(\\sin 90{^\\circ} = 1\\;\\text{.}\\)$$']
['What is the difference between a magnetic field and a current?', 'Instead of a single charge moving through a magnetic field, consider now a steady current I moving through a straight wire.']
['What does the electric current involve?', 'An electric current involves charges that move.']
['What is the speed of the charges?', 'If the charges q move a distance  $$\\(\\ell\\)$$  in a time t, then their speed is  $$\\(v = {\\ell/t\\text{.}}\\)$$']
['What is the effect of a magnetic field?', 'Inserting this into the equation  $$\\(F = qvB\\sin\\theta\\)$$  gives']
['I am trying to do a question for the class that will help me get an idea of', 'The factor q/t in this equation is nothing more than the current in the wire.']
['So, if we use q/t formula and subtract the square of B, then', 'Thus, using  $$\\(I = {q/t}\\)$$, we obtain']
['What is this equation for?', 'This equation gives the force on a straight current-carrying wire of length  $$\\(\\ell\\)$$  in a magnetic field of strength B.']
['What else is in the equation?', 'The angle  $$\\(\\theta\\)$$  is the angle between the current vector and the magnetic field vector.']

['Did you find anything else interesting?', 'Note that  $$\\(\\ell\\)$$  is the length of wire that is in the magnetic field and for which  $$\\(\\theta \\neq 0\\;\\text{,}\\)$$  as shown in Figure 20.19.']
['What does the equation mean?', 'The direction of the force is determined in the same way as for a single charge.']
['What else is important?', 'Curl your right fingers from the vector for I to the vector for B, and your right thumb will point in the direction of the force on the wire.']
['What else should I know about the equation?', 'For the wire shown in Figure 20.19, the force is directed into the page.']
['What else should we do?', 'Throughout this section, you may have noticed the symmetries between magnetic effects and electric effects.']
["What's special about that?", 'These effects all fall under the umbrella of electromagnetism, which is the study of electric and magnetic phenomena.']
['How does it work?', 'We have seen that electric charges produce electric fields, and moving electric charges produce magnetic fields.']
['What else are they?', 'A magnetic dipole produces a magnetic field, and, as we will see in the next section, moving magnetic dipoles produce an electric field.']
['What else?', 'Thus, electricity and magnetism are two intimately related and symmetric phenomena.']

['What is the relationship among current, voltage, and field?', 'As we learned previously, a current-carrying wire in a magnetic field experiences a force—recall  $$\\(F = I\\ell B\\sin\\theta\\)$$ .']

['What is the most important aspect of this article?', 'Electric motors, which convert electrical energy into mechanical energy, are the most common application of magnetic force on current-carrying wires.']
['What does the motor consist of?', 'Motors consist of loops of wire in a magnetic field.']
['How do the loops move?', 'When current is passed through the loops, the magnetic field exerts a torque on the loops, which rotates a shaft.']
['What is the result of the rotation?', 'Electrical energy is converted to mechanical work in the process.']
['What is the drawing of an electric motor?', 'Figure 20.23 shows a schematic drawing of an electric motor.']

['What is the most important concept in this section?', 'Let us examine the force on each segment of the loop in Figure 20.23 to find the torques produced about the axis of the vertical shaft—this will lead to a useful equation for the torque on the loop.']
['What are some of the other concepts?', 'We take the magnetic field to be uniform over the rectangular loop, which has width w and height  $$\\(\\ell\\text{,}\\)$$  as shown in the figure.']
['How do we determine the force on each segment of the loop?', 'First, consider the force on the top segment of the loop.']
['How do we determine the direction of the force?', 'To determine the direction of the force, we use the right-hand rule.']
['What is the right-hand rule?', 'The current goes from left to right into the page, and the magnetic field goes from left to right in the plane of the page.']
['What does the right hand rule say?', 'Curl your right fingers from the current vector to the magnetic field vector and your right thumb points down.']
['What does this mean?', 'Thus, the force on the top segment is downward, which produces no torque on the shaft.']

['What happened next?', 'Repeating this analysis for the bottom segment—neglect the small gap where the lead wires go out—shows that the force on the bottom segment is upward, again producing no torque on the shaft.']
['Using a small box and a ruler, draw the vertical segment of the loop.', 'Consider now the left vertical segment of the loop.']

['Does the left vertical segment of the loop exert the same force as the right vertical segment?', 'Again using the right-hand rule, we find that the force exerted on this segment is perpendicular to the magnetic field, as shown in Figure 20.23.']
['What is the force?', 'This force produces a torque on the shaft.']

['What is the torque on the shaft?', 'Repeating this analysis on the right vertical segment of the loop shows that the force on this segment is in the direction opposite that of the force on the left segment, thereby producing an equal torque on the shaft.']
['How is the total torque on the shaft related to the left vertical segment of the loop?', 'The total torque on the shaft is thus twice the toque on one of the vertical segments of the loop.']
['What did you find interesting in the material?', 'To find the magnitude of the torque as the wire loop spins, consider Figure 20.24, which shows a view of the wire loop from above.']

['How did you find that torque?', 'Recall that torque is defined as  $$\\(\\tau = rF\\sin\\theta\\text{,}\\)$$  where F is the applied force, r is the distance from the pivot to where the force is applied, and θ is the angle between r and F.']
['What was the most important aspect of this?', 'Notice that, as the loop spins, the current in the vertical loop segments is always perpendicular to the magnetic field.']
['What else is significant in this article?', 'Thus, the equation  $$\\(F = I\\ell B\\sin\\theta\\)$$  gives the magnitude of the force on each vertical segment as  $$\\(F = I\\ell B\\text{.}\\)$$']
['How did you calculate the force?', 'The distance r from the shaft to where this force is applied is w/2, so the torque created by this force is']
['What was the relation between rotational and circular motions?', 'If we have a multiple loop with N turns, we get N times the torque of a single loop.']
['What is the calculation for this?', 'Using the fact that the area of the loop is  $$\\(A = w\\ell\\text{;}\\)$$  the expression for the torque becomes']
['What is the NIAB?', 'This is the torque on a current-carrying loop in a uniform magnetic field.']
['What else does it tell us?', 'This equation can be shown to be valid for a loop of any shape.']
['What did you learn?', 'From the equation  $$\\(\\tau = NIAB\\sin\\theta\\text{,}\\)$$  we see that the torque is zero when  $$\\(\\theta = 0\\text{.}\\)$$']
['What happened after that?', 'As the wire loop rotates, the torque increases to a maximum positive torque of  $$\\(w\\ell B\\)$$  when  $$\\(\\theta = 90{^\\circ}\\operatorname{}\\text{.}\\)$$']

['What happened next?', 'The torque then decreases back to zero as the wire loop rotates to  $$\\(\\theta = 180{^\\circ}\\operatorname{}\\text{.}\\)$$  From  $$\\(\\theta = 180{^\\circ}\\operatorname{}\\)$$  to  $$\\(\\theta = 360{^\\circ}\\operatorname{}\\text{,}\\)$$  the torque is negative.']
['What happened next?', 'Thus, the torque changes sign every half turn, so the wire loop will oscillate back and forth.']

['How is a solenoid used?', 'Consider now what happens if we run the motor in reverse; that is, we attach a handle to the shaft and mechanically force the coil to rotate within the magnetic field, as shown in Figure 20.26.']

['What is the force?', 'As per the equation  $$\\(F = qvB\\sin\\theta\\)$$ —where  $$\\(\\theta\\)$$  is the angle between the vectors  $$\\(\\overset{\\rightarrow}{v}\\)$$  and  $$\\(\\overset{\\rightarrow}{B}\\text{—charges}\\)$$  in the wires of the loop experience a magnetic force because they are moving in a magnetic field.']
['What does the right-hand rule tell us?', 'Again using the right-hand rule, where we curl our fingers from vector  $$\\(\\overset{\\rightarrow}{v}\\)$$  to vector  $$\\(\\overset{\\rightarrow}{']
['', 'B}\\)$$, we find that charges in the top and bottom segments feel a force perpendicular to the wire, which does not cause a current.']

["Why doesn't there a current?", 'However, charges in the vertical wires experience forces parallel to the wire, causing a current to flow through the wire and through an external circuit if one is connected.']
['What is an external circuit?', 'A device such as this that converts mechanical energy into electrical energy is called a generator.']
['Is there a way to find the total current flowing in the circuit?', 'Because current is induced only in the side wires, we can find the induced emf by only considering these wires.']

['How can we get the voltage in the coil?', 'As explained in Induced Current in a Wire, motional emf in a straight wire moving at velocity v through a magnetic field B is  $$\\(E = B\\ell v\\text{,}\\)$$  where the velocity is perpendicular to the magnetic field.']

['Are the current and voltage related in some way?', 'In the generator, the velocity makes an angle  $$\\(\\theta\\)$$  with B (see Figure 20.27), so the velocity component perpendicular to B is  $$\\(v\\sin\\theta\\text{.}\\)$$']

['Do we need to calculate the emf for each wire individually?', 'Thus, in this case, the emf induced on each vertical wire segment is  $$\\(E = B\\ell v\\sin\\theta\\text{,}\\)$$  and they are in the same direction.']
['Do we need to add the emfs for the other wires?', 'The total emf around the loop is then']
['What is the problem?', 'Although this expression is valid, it does not give the emf as a function of time.']
['What else does this mean?', 'To find how the emf evolves in time, we assume that the coil is rotated at a constant angular velocity  $$\\(\\omega\\text{.}\\)$$']
['What else do we need to know?', 'The angle  $$\\(\\theta\\)$$  is related to the angular velocity by  $$\\(\\theta = \\omega t\\text{,}\\)$$  so that']

['What is the relationship among the three sides of a right-angled triangle according to the Py', 'Recall that tangential velocity v is related to angular velocity  $$\\(\\omega\\)$$  by  $$\\(v = r\\omega\\text{.}\\)$$']
['Is there any other interesting information in this section?', 'Here,  $$\\(r = {w/2}\\)$$, so that  $$\\(v = \\left( {w\\operatorname{/2}} \\right)\\omega\\)$$  and']
['What is $$[E = NABomegasinome', 'is the emf induced in a generator coil of N turns and area A rotating at a constant angular velocity  $$\\(\\omega\\)$$  in a uniform magnetic field B.']
['What is the maximum (peak) emf?', 'Figure 20.28 shows a generator connected to a light bulb and a graph of the emf vs. time.']

['What was the result of the generator being connected to the light bulb?', 'Note that the emf oscillates from a positive maximum of  $$\\(E_{0}\\)$$  to a negative maximum of  $$\\({-E}_{0}\\text{.}\\)$$']

['What other information can you give me about the positive and negative maximum?', 'In between, the emf goes through zero, which means that zero current flows through the light bulb at these times.']
['Why does the light bulb flicker on and off?', 'Thus, the light bulb actually flickers on and off at a frequency of 2f, because there are two zero crossings per period.']
['What is the frequency of alternating current?', 'In the United States, the frequency of alternating current is 60 Hz, so the lights flicker on and off at a frequency of 120 Hz.']
['Why do you not notice the flicker?', 'This is faster than the refresh rate of the human eye, so you don’t notice the flicker of the lights.']
['What else do you know about light bulbs?', 'Also, other factors prevent various different types of light bulbs from switching on and off so fast, so the light output is smoothed out a bit.']
['In what way did the model help?', 'In real life, electric generators look a lot different than the figures in this section, but the principles are the same.']

['Where does the mechanical energy come from?', 'The source of mechanical energy that turns the coil can be falling water—hydropower—steam produced by the burning of fossil fuels, or the kinetic energy of wind.']
['How does the steam turbine work?', 'Figure 20.29 shows a cutaway view of a steam turbine; steam moves over the blades connected to the shaft, which rotates the coil within the generator.']
['What is an example of magnetic induction?', 'Another very useful and common device that exploits magnetic induction is called a transformer.']

['What does a transformer do?', 'Transformers do what their name implies—they transform voltages from one value to another; the term voltage is used rather than emf because transformers have internal resistance.']

['What are other examples of transformers?', 'For example, many cell phones, laptops, video games, power tools, and small appliances have a transformer built into their plug-in unit that changes 120 V or 240 V AC into whatever voltage the device uses.']
['What are some examples of transformers?', 'Figure 20.30 shows two different transformers.']
['What are they?', 'Notice the wire coils that are visible in each device.']
['What are they for?', 'The purpose of these coils is explained below.']

['what is the maximum (peak) emf?', 'Figure 20.31 shows a laminated-coil transformer, which is based on Faraday’s law of induction and is very similar in construction to the apparatus Faraday used to demonstrate that magnetic fields can generate electric currents.']
['What are the two wire coils called?', 'The two wire coils are called the primary and secondary coils.']
['Why do they need to be paired together?', 'In normal use, the input voltage is applied across the primary coil, and the secondary produces the transformed output voltage.']

['How is the iron core different from other metals?', 'Not only does the iron core trap the magnetic field created by the primary coil, but also its magnetization increases the field strength, which is analogous to how a dielectric increases the electric field strength in a capacitor.']
['What is the output voltage?', 'Since the input voltage is AC, a time-varying magnetic flux is sent through the secondary coil, inducing an AC output voltage.']

['What is the maximum (peak) emf?', 'For the transformer shown in Figure 20.31, the output voltage  $$\\(V_{\\text{S}}\\)$$  from the secondary coil depends almost entirely on the input voltage  $$\\(V_{\\text{P}}\\)$$  across the primary coil and the number of loops in the primary and secondary coils.']
["What else can you tell me about Faraday's law?", 'Faraday’s law of induction for the secondary coil gives its induced output voltage  $$\\(V_{\\text{S}}\\)$$  to be']
['What is the formula?', 'where  $$\\(N_{\\text{S}}\\)$$  is the number of loops in the secondary coil and  $$\\({\\text{Δ}\\text{Φ}}/{\\text{Δ}t}\\)$$  is the rate of change of magnetic flux.']

['What is the output voltage?', 'The output voltage equals the induced emf  $$\\(\\text{(}V_{\\text{S}} = E_{\\text{S}}\\text{),}\\)$$  provided coil resistance is small—a reasonable assumption for transformers.']

['What happens to the magnetic flux as it rotates?', 'The cross-sectional area of the coils is the same on each side, as is the magnetic field strength, and so  $$\\(\\text{Δ}\\text{Φ/Δ}t\\)$$  is the same on each side.']
['What happens to the input voltage?', 'The input primary voltage  $$\\(V_{\\text{P}}\\)$$  is also related to changing flux by']
['What is the transformer equation?', 'This is known as the transformer equation.']

['How does it work?', 'It simply states that the ratio of the secondary voltage to the primary voltage in a transformer equals the ratio of the number of loops in secondary coil to the number of loops in the primary coil.']

['What are transformers used for?', 'Transformers are widely used in the electric power industry to increase voltages—called step-up transformers—before long-distance transmission via high-voltage wires.']
['What are other uses?', 'They are also used to decrease voltages—called step-down transformers—to deliver power to homes and businesses.']
['How is power generated?', 'The overwhelming majority of electric power is generated by using magnetic induction, whereby a wire coil or copper disk is rotated in a magnetic field.']
['What is primary energy?', 'The primary energy required to rotate the coils or disk can be provided by a variety of means.']
['What is a secondary energy source?', 'Hydroelectric power plants use the kinetic energy of water to drive electric generators.']
['What are other secondary energy sources?', 'Coal or nuclear power plants create steam to drive steam turbines that turn the coils.']
['What are other primary energy sources?', 'Other sources of primary energy include wind, tides, or waves on water.']
['What is Transmission of Electrical Power?', 'Once power is generated, it must be transmitted to the consumer, which often means transmitting power over hundreds of kilometers.']
['How is power transmitted?', 'To do this, the voltage of the power plant is increased by a step-up transformer, that is stepped up, and the current decreases proportionally because']
['What is this theorem about?', 'The lower current  $$\\(I_{\\text{transmitted}}\\)$$  in the transmission wires reduces the Joule losses, which is heating of the wire due to a current flow.']
['What is this heating caused by?', 'This heating is caused by the small, but nonzero, resistance  $$\\(R_{\\text{wire}}\\)$$  of the transmission wires.']
['What is the significance of this?', 'The power lost to the environment through this heat is']
['I am interested in how the loss of power is proportional to the current squared in the', 'which is proportional to the current squared in the transmission wire.']

['What else will you be studying?', 'This is why the transmitted current  $$\\(I_{\\text{transmitted}}\\)$$  must be as small as possible and, consequently, the voltage must be large to transmit the power  $$\\(P_{\\text{transmitted}}\\text{⋅}\\)$$']
['What are some important facts about transmission voltage?', 'Voltages ranging from 120 to 700 kV are used for transmitting power over long distances.']
['What is the typical voltage?', 'The voltage is stepped up at the exit of the power station by a step-up transformer, as shown in Figure 20.32.']
['What was the question?', 'Once the power has arrived at a population or industrial center, the voltage is stepped down at a substation to between 5 and 30 kV.']
['What happens after the voltage is stepped down?', 'Finally, at individual homes or businesses, the power is stepped down again to 120, 240, or 480 V.']
['What is transformer?', 'Each step-up and step-down transformation is done with a transformer designed based on Faradays law of induction.']
["Who's law of induction?", 'We’ve come a long way since Queen Elizabeth asked Faraday what possible use could be made of electricity.']
['What is the current current?', 'In the preceding section, we learned that a current creates a magnetic field.']
['What does this mean?', 'If nature is symmetrical, then perhaps a magnetic field can create a current.']

['How did this happen?', 'In 1831, some 12 years after the discovery that an electric current generates a magnetic field, English scientist Michael Faraday (1791–1862) and American scientist Joseph Henry (1797–1878) independently demonstrated that magnetic fields can produce currents.']

['What else did you find out about this?', 'The basic process of generating currents with magnetic fields is called induction; this process is also called magnetic induction to distinguish it from charging by induction, which uses the electrostatic Coulomb force.']
['What else is noteworthy about Changing magnetic fields?', 'When Faraday discovered what is now called Faraday’s law of induction, Queen Victoria asked him what possible use was electricity.']
['What was his response?', '“Madam,” he replied, “What good is a baby?”']
['What else did you find interesting?', 'Today, currents induced by magnetic fields are essential to our technological society.']
['What kind of technology is involved?', 'The electric generator—found in everything from automobiles to bicycles to nuclear power plants—uses magnetism to generate electric current.']

['What other devices do this?', 'Other devices that use magnetism to induce currents include pickup coils in electric guitars, transformers of every size, certain microphones, airport security gates, and damping mechanisms on sensitive chemical balances.']

['What is one of the topics we are studying today?', 'One experiment Faraday did to demonstrate magnetic induction was to move a bar magnet through a wire coil and measure the resulting electric current through the wire.']
['How was this experiment performed?', 'A schematic of this experiment is shown in Figure 20.33.']
['What happened during this experiment?', 'He found that current is induced only when the magnet moves with respect to the coil.']
['What does that mean?', 'When the magnet is motionless with respect to the coil, no current is induced in the coil, as in Figure 20.33.']

['What happened next?', 'In addition, moving the magnet in the opposite direction (compare Figure 20.33 with Figure 20.33) or reversing the poles of the magnet (compare Figure 20.33 with Figure 20.33) results in a current in the opposite direction.']
['What is Induced Electromotive Force?', 'If a current is induced in the coil, Faraday reasoned that there must be what he called an electromotive force pushing the charges through the coil.']
['What does this mean?', 'This interpretation turned out to be incorrect; instead, the external source doing the work of moving the magnet adds energy to the charges in the coil.']
['What is energy added per unit charge?', 'The energy added per unit charge has units of volts, so the electromotive force is actually a potential.']
['Why did he call it an electromotive force?', 'Unfortunately, the name electromotive force stuck and with it the potential for confusing it with a real force.']

['What does the term electromotive force mean now?', 'For this reason, we avoid the term electromotive force and just use the abbreviation emf, which has the mathematical symbol  $$\\(\\varepsilon\\text{.}\\)$$']
['What is emf?', 'The emf may be defined as the rate at which energy is drawn from a source per unit current flowing through a circuit.']
['What is voltage?', 'Thus, emf is the energy per unit charge added by a source, which contrasts with voltage, which is the energy per unit charge released as the charges flow through a circuit.']

['How can we determine the induced emf?', 'To understand why an emf is generated in a coil due to a moving magnet, consider Figure 20.34, which shows a bar magnet moving downward with respect to a wire loop.']
['What was the left hand image of?', 'Initially, seven magnetic field lines are going through the loop (see left-hand image).']

['What was the right hand image of?', 'Because the magnet is moving away from the coil, only five magnetic field lines are going through the loop after a short time  $$\\(\\text{Δ}t\\)$$  (see right-hand image).']
['What is the result of this experiment?', 'Thus, when a change occurs in the number of magnetic field lines going through the area defined by the wire loop, an emf is induced in the wire loop.']
['How is this derived?', 'Experiments such as this show that the induced emf is proportional to the rate of change of the magnetic field.']
['What else did you mention?', 'Mathematically, we express this as']
['What is the purpose of this theory?', 'Note that magnetic field lines that lie in the plane of the wire loop do not actually pass through the loop, as shown by the left-most loop in Figure 20.35.']

['How does the figure explain this?', 'In this figure, the arrow coming out of the loop is a vector whose magnitude is the area of the loop and whose direction is perpendicular to the plane of the loop.']

['What is the other figure?', 'In Figure 20.35, as the loop is rotated from  $$\\(\\theta = 90{^\\circ}\\operatorname{}\\)$$ to  $$\\({\\theta = 0{^\\circ}\\operatorname{}}\\text{,}\\)$$  the contribution of the magnetic field lines to the emf increases.']

['What does this do?', 'Thus, what is important in generating an emf in the wire loop is the component of the magnetic field that is perpendicular to the plane of the loop, which is  $$\\({B\\cos\\theta}\\text{.}\\)$$']
['What is this analogous to?', 'This is analogous to a sail in the wind.']
['How?', 'Think of the conducting loop as the sail and the magnetic field as the wind.']

["Does this help you understand the'sail in the wind' analogy?", 'To maximize the force of the wind on the sail, the sail is oriented so that its surface vector points in the same direction as the winds, as in the right-most loop in Figure 20.35.']

['What about when the sail is orientated differently?', 'When the sail is aligned so that its surface vector is perpendicular to the wind, as in the left-most loop in Figure 20.35, then the wind exerts no force on the sail.']
['What kind of field lines?', 'Another way to reduce the number of magnetic field lines that go through the conducting loop in Figure 20.35 is not to move the magnet but to make the loop smaller.']
['What happens when you make the loop smaller?', 'Experiments show that changing the area of a conducting loop in a stable magnetic field induces an emf in the loop.']
['What does the emf do?', 'Thus, the emf produced in a conducting loop is proportional to the rate of change of the product of the perpendicular magnetic field and the loop area']
['What does this text contain?', 'where  $$\\(B\\cos\\theta\\)$$  is the perpendicular magnetic field and A is the area of the loop.']
['What is an example of the product?', 'The product  $$\\(BA\\cos\\theta\\)$$  is very important.']

['What is the function of the product?', 'It is proportional to the number of magnetic field lines that pass perpendicularly through a surface of area A. Going back to our sail analogy, it would be proportional to the force of the wind on the sail.']
['What is the total amount of energy in a magnetic field?', 'It is called the magnetic flux and is represented by  $$\\(\\text{Φ}\\)$$ .']
['What is the unit of magnetic flux?', 'The unit of magnetic flux is the weber (Wb), which is magnetic field per unit area, or T/m2.']
['What is the weber also?', 'The weber is also a volt second (Vs).']
['What is one important fact in the document?', 'Finally, for a coil made from N loops, the emf is N times stronger than for a single loop.']
['What is this strength?', 'Thus, the emf induced by a changing magnetic field in a coil of N loops is']

['Where does this proportionality begin?', 'The last question to answer before we can change the proportionality into an equation is “In what direction does the current flow?” The Russian scientist Heinrich Lenz (1804–1865) explained that the current flows in the direction that creates a magnetic field that tries to keep the flux constant in the loop.']
['What is this proportionality used for?', 'For example, consider again Figure 20.34.']
['What are the current loops?', 'The motion of the bar magnet causes the number of upward-pointing magnetic field lines that go through the loop to decrease.']
['Why does this happen?', 'Therefore, an emf is generated in the loop that drives a current in the direction that creates more upward-pointing magnetic field lines.']
['What direction does the current flow?', 'By using the right-hand rule, we see that this current must flow in the direction shown in the figure.']

['Why does it try to keep the flux constant in the loop?', 'To express the fact that the induced emf acts to counter the change in the magnetic flux through a wire loop, a minus sign is introduced into the proportionality  $$\\(\\varepsilon \\propto {{\\text{Δ}\\text{Φ}}/{\\text{Δ}t}}\\text{.}\\)$$, which gives Faraday’s law of induction.']
['What is Lenz’s law?', 'Lenz’s law is very important.']
['Is it illustrated?', 'To better understand it, consider Figure 20.36, which shows a magnet moving with respect to a wire coil and the direction of the resulting current in the coil.']
['What happens with the magnetic field lines?', 'In the top row, the north pole of the magnet approaches the coil, so the magnetic field lines from the magnet point toward the coil.']

['Does anything else happen with Lenz’s law?', 'Thus, the magnetic field  $$\\({\\overset{\\rightarrow}{B}}_{\\text{mag}} = B_{\\text{mag}}\\left( \\hat{x} \\right)\\)$$  pointing to the right increases in the coil.']

['Does it change in any other direction?', 'According to Lenz’s law, the emf produced in the coil will drive a current in the direction that creates a magnetic field  $$\\({\\overset{\\rightarrow}{B}}_{\\text{coil}} = B_{\\text{coil}}\\left( {- \\hat{x}} \\right)\\)$$  inside the coil pointing to the left.']
['Is there any other important fact regarding Lenz’s law?', 'This will counter the increase in magnetic flux pointing to the right.']

['What else is interesting?', 'To see which way the current must flow, point your right thumb in the desired direction of the magnetic field  $$\\({\\overset{\\rightarrow}{B}}_{\\text{coil,}}\\)$$  and the current will flow in the direction indicated by curling your right fingers.']
['Are the images helpful?', 'This is shown by the image of the right hand in the top row of Figure 20.36.']
['Does this have an impact on the current flow?', 'Thus, the current must flow in the direction shown in Figure 4(a).']
['What is the most significant thing I should know about this document?', 'In Figure 4(b), the direction in which the magnet moves is reversed.']
['What is the relation between field and direction?', 'In the coil, the right-pointing magnetic field  $$\\({\\overset{\\rightarrow}{B}}_{\\text{mag}}\\)$$  due to the moving magnet decreases.']

['What will happen if there is no direction?', 'Lenz’s law says that, to counter this decrease, the emf will drive a current that creates an additional right-pointing magnetic field  $$\\({\\overset{\\rightarrow}{B}}_{\\text{coil}}\\)$$  in the coil.']

['Can you give me some examples?', 'Again, point your right thumb in the desired direction of the magnetic field, and the current will flow in the direction indicate by curling your right fingers (Figure 4(b)).']
['What is the next question?', 'Finally, in Figure 4(c), the magnet is reversed so that the south pole is nearest the coil.']
['What happened then?', 'Now the magnetic field  $$\\({\\overset{\\rightarrow}{B}}_{\\text{mag}}\\)$$  points toward the magnet instead of toward the coil.']
['What is the other interesting thing about this part?', 'As the magnet approaches the coil, it causes the left-pointing magnetic field in the coil to increase.']
['What is Lenz’s law?', 'Lenz’s law tells us that the emf induced in the coil will drive a current in the direction that creates a magnetic field pointing to the right.']
['Why is the field pointing to the right?', 'This will counter the increasing magnetic flux pointing to the left due to the magnet.']
['What is a rule?', 'Using the right-hand rule again, as indicated in the figure, shows that the current must flow in the direction shown in Figure 4(c).']
['What is the first thing you tell me about Blackbodies?', 'Our first story of curious significance begins with a T-shirt.']
['How is the t-shirt important?', 'You are likely aware that wearing a tight black T-shirt outside on a hot day provides a significantly less comfortable experience than wearing a white shirt.']
['What else does the black shirt have to do with the story?', 'Black shirts, as well as all other black objects, will absorb and re-emit a significantly greater amount of radiation from the sun.']
['How does this relate to what?', 'This shirt is a good approximation of what is called a blackbody.']
['What are blackbodies?', 'A perfect blackbody is one that absorbs and re-emits all radiated energy that is incident upon it.']
['What else is a blackbody used for?', 'Imagine wearing a tight shirt that did this!']
['What did you study in your class?', 'This phenomenon is often modeled with quite a different scenario.']
['What did you study?', 'Imagine carving a small hole in an oven that can be heated to very high temperatures.']

['What happens if there is light around the hole?', 'As the temperature of this container gets hotter and hotter, the radiation out of this dark hole would increase as well, re-emitting all energy provided it by the increased temperature.']
['How does it look like it glows?', 'The hole may even begin to glow in different colors as the temperature is increased.']
['What colors will it glow in?', 'Like a burner on your stove, the hole would glow red, then orange, then blue, as the temperature is increased.']
['What happens after a certain point?', 'In time, the hole would continue to glow but the light would be invisible to our eyes.']
['What does this say?', 'This container is a good model of a perfect blackbody.']
['What does this title have to do with science?', 'It is the analysis of blackbodies that led to one of the most consequential discoveries of the twentieth century.']
['What is one example of how you will study Blackbodies?', 'Take a moment to carefully examine Figure 21.2.']
['What will happen to the figure?', 'The more time you spend interpreting this figure, the closer you will be to understanding quantum physics!']
['What is the name of a figure in that chapter?', 'Figure 21.2 is a plot of radiation intensity against radiated wavelength.']
['What does this graph show?', 'In other words, it shows how the intensity of radiated light changes when a blackbody is heated to a particular temperature.']
['How did you figure this out?', 'It may help to just follow the bottom-most red line labeled 3,000 K, red hot.']
['What does the graph show?', 'The graph shows that when a blackbody acquires a temperature of 3,000 K, it radiates energy across the electromagnetic spectrum.']
['What wavelength does it most intensely emit energy at?', 'However, the energy is most intensely emitted at a wavelength of approximately 1000 nm.']
['What is the wavelength of 1000 nm?', 'This is in the infrared portion of the electromagnetic spectrum.']
['What other information can you provide?', 'While a body at this temperature would appear red-hot to our eyes, it would truly appear ‘infrared-hot’ if we were able to see the entire spectrum.']
['When the temperature of the gas is constant, radiated energy stays constant.', 'As temperature increases, the total amount of energy radiated increases.']
['What can we do in Figure 21.2 to visualize this?', 'This is shown by examining the area underneath each line.']
['What is the difference between red lines and blue lines?', 'Regardless of temperature, all red lines on the graph undergo a consistent pattern.']
['What else is notable about this figure?', 'While electromagnetic radiation is emitted throughout the spectrum, the intensity of this radiation peaks at one particular wavelength.']
['What does the wavelength peak at?', 'As the temperature changes, the wavelength of greatest radiation intensity changes.']
['What temperature is the highest heat of radiation at?', 'At 4,000 K, the radiation is most intense in the yellow-green portion of the spectrum.']

['At what temperature would the blackbody be white hot?', 'At 6,000 K, the blackbody would radiate white hot, due to intense radiation throughout the visible portion of the electromagnetic spectrum.']
['What else is significant about Figure 21.2?', 'Remember that white light is the emission of all visible colors simultaneously.']
['What color light is emitted?', 'As the temperature increases, the frequency of light providing the greatest intensity increases as well.']
['Does this mean that frequency is decreasing?', 'Recall the equation  $$\\(v = f\\lambda.\\)$$']
['What happens to frequency?', 'Because the speed of light is constant, frequency and wavelength are inversely related.']
['What else can we infer from this?', 'This is verified by the leftward movement of the three red lines as temperature is increased.']
['', 'While in science it is important to categorize observations, theorizing as to why the observations exist is crucial to scientific advancement.']
['What are two theories that helped move scientific research forward?', 'It is questions like these that drove significant research at the turn of the twentieth century.']
['What was the question that Max Planck set in motion?', 'And within the context of these questions, Max Planck discovered something of tremendous importance.']

["What is the prevailing theory about Planck's revolution?", 'The prevailing theory at the time of Max Planck’s discovery was that intensity and frequency were related by the equation  $$\\(I = \\frac{2kT}{\\lambda^{2}}.\\)$$']

['What does this equation infer?', 'This equation, derived from classical physics and using wave phenomena, infers that as wavelength increases, the intensity of energy provided will decrease with an inverse-squared relationship.']
['What happens if the ratio of distance to wavelength is constant?', 'This relationship is graphed in Figure 21.3 and shows a troubling trend.']
['Why was this a troubling trend?', 'For starters, it should be apparent that the graph from this equation does not match the blackbody graphs found experimentally.']
['What else did this graph reveal?', 'Additionally, it shows that for an object of any temperature, there should be an infinite amount of energy quickly emitted in the shortest wavelengths.']
['What should be done?', 'When theory and experimental results clash, it is important to re-evaluate both models.']
['What happened after this was found?', 'The disconnect between theory and reality was termed the ultraviolet catastrophe.']

["What is the Planck's Revolution?", 'Due to concerns over the ultraviolet catastrophe, Max Planck began to question whether another factor impacted the relationship between intensity and wavelength.']
['What was this factor?', 'This factor, he posited, should affect the probability that short wavelength light would be emitted.']

['What was the result of this?', 'Should this factor reduce the probability of short wavelength light, it would cause the radiance curve to not progress infinitely as in the classical theory, but would instead cause the curve to precipitate back downward as is shown in the 5,000 K, 4,000 K, and 3,000 K temperature lines of the graph in Figure 21.3.']

['What else is significant about the Factor?', 'Planck noted that this factor, whatever it may be, must also be dependent on temperature, as the intensity decreases at lower and lower wavelengths as the temperature increases.']

['How did this change the view of physics?', 'The determination of this probability factor was a groundbreaking discovery in physics, yielding insight not just into light but also into energy and matter itself.']
['What was the consequence of this discovery?', 'It would be the basis for Planck’s 1918 Nobel Prize in Physics and would result in the transition of physics from classical to modern understanding.']
['What did Planck have to do with the discovery?', 'In an attempt to determine the cause of the probability factor, Max Planck constructed a new theory.']

['What is the theory called?', 'This theory, which created the branch of physics called quantum mechanics, speculated that the energy radiated by the blackbody could exist only in specific numerical, or quantum, states.']

['How was this theory calculated?', 'This theory is described by the equation  $$\\(E = nhf,\\)$$  where n is any nonnegative integer (0, 1, 2, 3, …) and h is Planck’s constant, given by  $$\\(h = 6.626\\  \\times \\ 10^{-34}\\text']
['Is there a formula for the probabilities of these things?', '{J} \\cdot \\text{s},\\)$$  and f is frequency.']
["What is Planck's equation?", 'Through this equation, Planck’s probability factor can be more clearly understood.']
['What are the three ways light quantized?', 'Each frequency of light provides a specific quantized amount of energy.']

['How is the spectrum structured?', 'Low frequency light, associated with longer wavelengths would provide a smaller amount of energy, while high frequency light, associated with shorter wavelengths, would provide a larger amount of energy.']
['How is this a relationship?', 'For specified temperatures with specific total energies, it makes sense that more low frequency light would be radiated than high frequency light.']
['Is this explained more in the articles?', 'To a degree, the relationship is like pouring coins through a funnel.']
['What is the analogy?', 'More of the smaller pennies would be able to pass through the funnel than the larger quarters.']
['Why does this matter?', 'In other words, because the value of the coin is somewhat related to the size of the coin, the probability of a quarter passing through the funnel is reduced!']
['I think that it is best to first read the first paragraph, and then, as you study', 'Furthermore, an increase in temperature would signify the presence of higher energy.']
['What is the ultimate conclusion?', 'As a result, the greater amount of total blackbody energy would allow for more of the high frequency, short wavelength, energies to be radiated.']
['How does this affect the blackbody curve?', 'This permits the peak of the blackbody curve to drift leftward as the temperature increases, as it does from the 3,000 K to 4,000 K to 5,000 K values.']
['What is the next question?', 'Furthering our coin analogy, consider a wider funnel.']
['What would the wider funnel do?', 'This funnel would permit more quarters to pass through and allow for a reduction in concern about the probability factor.']
['What is the first step in our study material?', 'In summary, it is the interplay between the predicted classical model and the quantum probability that creates the curve depicted in Figure 21.3.']
['What is the highest frequency?', 'Just as quarters have a higher currency denomination than pennies, higher frequencies come with larger amounts of energy.']

['Does anything else tie this to currency denomination?', 'However, just as the probability of a quarter passing through a fixed diameter funnel is reduced, so is the probability of a high frequency light existing in a fixed temperature object.']
['How does this help?', 'As is often the case in physics, it is the balancing of multiple incredible ideas that finally allows for better understanding.']
['What is Quantization?', 'It may be helpful at this point to further consider the idea of quantum states.']

['What are quantum states?', 'Atoms, molecules, and fundamental electron and proton charges are all examples of physical entities that are quantized—that is, they appear only in certain discrete values and do not have every conceivable value.']
['What is a revolutionary concept?', 'On the macroscopic scale, this is not a revolutionary concept.']
['What are some other examples of quantum states?', 'A standing wave on a string allows only particular harmonics described by integers.']

['Can you explain how quantum states are used in practical applications?', 'Going up and down a hill using discrete stair steps causes your potential energy to take on discrete values as you move from step to step.']
['What other examples do you have?', 'Furthermore, we cannot have a fraction of an atom, or part of an electron’s charge, or 14.33 cents.']
["Why can't we do this?", 'Rather, everything is built of integral multiples of these substructures.']
['What did it mean?', 'That said, to discover quantum states within a phenomenon that science had always considered continuous would certainly be surprising.']

['Who discovered it?', 'When Max Planck was able to use quantization to correctly describe the experimentally known shape of the blackbody spectrum, it was the first indication that energy was quantized on a small scale as well.']

['How was it discovered?', 'This discovery earned Planck the Nobel Prize in Physics in 1918 and was such a revolutionary departure from classical physics that Planck himself was reluctant to accept his own idea.']

['Why were they reluctant?', 'The general acceptance of Planck’s energy quantization was greatly enhanced by Einstein’s explanation of the photoelectric effect (discussed in the next section), which took energy quantization a step further.']
['What does the photoelectric effect do?', 'When light strikes certain materials, it can eject electrons from them.']
['What does this mean?', 'This is called the photoelectric effect, meaning that light (photo) produces electricity.']
['What other applications are there?', 'One common use of the photoelectric effect is in light meters, such as those that adjust the automatic iris in various types of cameras.']
['What other uses are there?', 'Another use is in solar cells, as you probably have in your calculator or have seen on a rooftop or a roadside sign.']
['What do they do?', 'These make use of the photoelectric effect to convert light into electricity for running different devices.']

['What are the Revolutionary Properties of the Photoelectric Effect?', 'When Max Planck theorized that energy was quantized in a blackbody radiator, it is unlikely that he would have recognized just how revolutionary his idea was.']

['Why did he say that?', 'Using tools similar to the light meter in Figure 21.5, it would take a scientist of Albert Einstein’s stature to fully discover the implications of Max Planck’s radical concept.']

['What is the Revolutionary Properties of the photoelectric effect?', 'Through careful observations of the photoelectric effect, Albert Einstein realized that there were several characteristics that could be explained only if EM radiation is itself quantized.']
['What was his explanation?', 'While these characteristics will be explained a bit later in this section, you can already begin to appreciate why Einstein’s idea is very important.']
['What is it that quantized means?', 'It means that the apparently continuous stream of energy in an EM wave is actually not a continuous stream at all.']
['Why is it not?', 'In fact, the EM wave itself is actually composed of tiny quantum packets of energy called photons.']
['What is E = hf?', 'where E is the energy of a photon of frequency f and h is Planck’s constant.']

["What is Planck's constant?", 'A beam from a flashlight, which to this point had been considered a wave, instead could now be viewed as a series of photons, each providing a specific amount of energy see Figure 21.6.']
['What is the light beam made of?', 'Furthermore, the amount of energy within each individual photon is based upon its individual frequency, as dictated by  $$\\(E = hf.\\)$$']

['How does the frequency determine the energy of photons?', 'As a result, the total amount of energy provided by the beam could now be viewed as the sum of all frequency-dependent photon energies added together.']

['Which of the following is not a type of variable?', 'Just as with Planck’s blackbody radiation, Einstein’s concept of the photon could take hold in the scientific community only if it could succeed where classical physics failed.']
['What was the photoelectric effect?', 'The photoelectric effect would be a key to demonstrating Einstein’s brilliance.']
['What type of property do we need to consider?', 'Consider the following five properties of the photoelectric effect.']

['What are these properties?', 'All of these properties are consistent with the idea that individual photons of EM radiation are absorbed by individual electrons in a material, with the electron gaining the photon’s energy.']
['What else do these properties have in common?', 'Some of these properties are inconsistent with the idea that EM radiation is a simple wave.']

['Are there other properties that are important for the photoelectric effect?', 'For simplicity, let us consider what happens with monochromatic EM radiation in which all photons have the same energy hf.']
['What are the questions?', 'If we vary the frequency of the EM radiation falling on a clean metal surface, we find the following:']

['What else can you tell me about the effect of frequency?', 'For a given material, there is a threshold frequency f0 for the EM radiation below which no electrons are ejected, regardless of intensity.']
['What does the photon model do?', 'Using the photon model, the explanation for this is clear.']
['What else is mentioned?', 'Individual photons interact with individual electrons.']
['What else is mentioned?', 'Thus if the energy of an individual photon is too low to break an electron away, no electrons will be ejected.']
['What else is mentioned?', 'However, if EM radiation were a simple wave, sufficient energy could be obtained simply by increasing the intensity.']
['What other information is mentioned?', 'Once EM radiation falls on a material, electrons are ejected without delay.']
['What happens after this?', 'As soon as an individual photon of sufficiently high frequency is absorbed by an individual electron, the electron is ejected.']
['What else is mentioned?', 'If the EM radiation were a simple wave, several minutes would be required for sufficient energy to be deposited at the metal surface in order to eject an electron.']
['What else is mentioned?', 'The number of electrons ejected per unit time is proportional to the intensity of the EM radiation and to no other characteristic.']
['What is the photon model?', 'High-intensity EM radiation consists of large numbers of photons per unit area, with all photons having the same characteristic energy, hf.']
['What is mentioned?', 'The increased number of photons per unit area results in an increased number of electrons per unit area ejected.']
['What else is mentioned?', 'If we vary the intensity of the EM radiation and measure the energy of ejected electrons, we find the following:']
['What is mentioned next?', 'The maximum kinetic energy of ejected electrons is independent of the intensity of the EM radiation.']
['What else is mentioned?', 'Instead, as noted in point 3 above, increased intensity results in more electrons of the same energy being ejected.']
['What is mentioned next?', 'If EM radiation were a simple wave, a higher intensity could transfer more energy, and higher-energy electrons would be ejected.']
['What is mentioned next?', 'The kinetic energy KE of an ejected electron equals the photon energy minus the binding energy BE of the electron in the specific material.']
['What is mentioned next?', 'An individual photon can give all of its energy to an electron.']
['What else is mentioned?', 'The photon’s energy is partly used to break the electron away from the material.']
['What else is mentioned?', 'The remainder goes into the ejected electron’s kinetic energy.']
['What is mentioned next?', 'In equation form, this is given by']

['What is this equation about?', 'where  $$\\(KE_{e}\\)$$  is the maximum kinetic energy of the ejected electron,  $$\\(hf\\)$$  is the photon’s energy, and BE is the binding energy of the electron to the particular material.']
['What does it tell us?', 'This equation explains the properties of the photoelectric effect quantitatively and demonstrates that BE is the minimum amount of energy necessary to eject an electron.']
['What else is significant about this equation?', 'If the energy supplied is less than BE, the electron cannot be ejected.']
['What else did you learn about this equation?', 'The binding energy can also be written as  $$\\(BE = hf_{0},\\)$$  where  $$\\(f_{0}\\)$$  is the threshold frequency for the particular material.']
['What else was significant about this equation?', 'Figure 21.8 shows a graph of maximum  $$\\(KE_{e}\\)$$  versus the frequency of incident EM radiation falling on a particular material.']

['What kind of applications does the photoelectric effect have?', 'While Einstein’s understanding of the photoelectric effect was a transformative discovery in the early 1900s, its presence is ubiquitous today.']

['What are some examples of how the photoelectric effect is applied?', 'If you have watched streetlights turn on automatically in response to the setting sun, stopped elevator doors from closing simply by putting your hands between them, or turned on a water faucet by sliding your hands near it, you are familiar with the electric eye, a name given to a group of devices that use the photoelectric effect for detection.']
['What can we learn about photoconductive cells?', 'All these devices rely on photoconductive cells.']
['What are photoconductive cells?', 'These cells are activated when light is absorbed by a semi-conductive material, knocking off a free electron.']
['Why does it knock off a free electron?', 'When this happens, an electron void is left behind, which attracts a nearby electron.']
['What happens with the electron?', 'The movement of this electron, and the resultant chain of electron movements, produces a current.']
['What else does this current do?', 'If electron ejection continues, further holes are created, thereby increasing the electrical conductivity of the cell.']
['What happens as the current increases?', 'This current can turn switches on and off and activate various familiar mechanisms.']
['What is one of the most significant applications of this effect?', 'One such mechanism takes place where you may not expect it.']
['What is it?', 'Next time you are at the movie theater, pay close attention to the sound coming out of the speakers.']
['Why do they emit sound?', 'This sound is actually created using the photoelectric effect!']
['What is on the audiotape?', 'The audiotape in the projector booth is a transparent piece of film of varying width.']
['How is the film used?', 'This film is fed between a photocell and a bright light produced by an exciter lamp.']
['What happens when this light hits the photocell?', 'As the transparent portion of the film varies in width, the amount of light that strikes the photocell varies as well.']
['What else does this do?', 'As a result, the current in the photoconductive circuit changes with the width of the filmstrip.']
['Does this create sound?', 'This changing current is converted to a changing frequency, which creates the soundtrack commonly heard in the theater.']
['Is there any other content in this chapter?', 'Although strange to consider, the answer to both questions is yes.']

['Why is this important?', 'Despite the odd nature of photons, scientists prior to Einstein had long suspected that the fundamental particle of electromagnetic radiation shared properties with our more macroscopic particles.']
['What were those properties?', 'This is no clearer than when considering the photoelectric effect, where photons knock electrons out of a substance.']
['What happened with the photoelectric effect?', 'While it is strange to think of a massless particle exhibiting momentum, it is now a well-established fact within the scientific community.']
['What is the figure?', 'Figure 21.10 shows macroscopic evidence of photon momentum.']
['What does figure 21.10 refer to?', 'Figure 21.10 shows a comet with two prominent tails.']
['What is the composition of the comet tails?', 'Comet tails are composed of gases and dust evaporated from the body of the comet and ionized gas.']
['What is interesting about the comet tails?', 'What most people do not know about the tails is that they always point away from the Sun rather than trailing behind the comet.']
['What can you tell me about the diagram?', 'This can be seen in the diagram.']
