['What are some of the things that are important about photon momentum?', 'The evidence indicates that the dust particles of the comet are forced away from the Sun when photons strike them.']

['How does photons force the particles away?', 'Evidently, photons carry momentum in the direction of their motion away from the Sun, and some of this momentum is transferred to dust particles in collisions.']
['What happens when protons collide?', 'The blue tail is caused by the solar wind, a stream of plasma consisting primarily of protons and electrons evaporating from the corona of the Sun.']
['What is momentum?', 'Momentum is conserved in quantum mechanics, just as it is in relativity and classical physics.']

['What is the Compton Effect?', 'Some of the earliest direct experimental evidence of this came from the scattering of X-ray photons by electrons in substances, a phenomenon discovered by American physicist Arthur H. Compton (1892–1962).']

['When did he discover the Compton Effect?', 'Around 1923, Compton observed that X-rays reflecting from materials had decreased energy and correctly interpreted this as being due to the scattering of the X-ray photons by electrons.']
['What is the photon?', 'This phenomenon could be handled as a collision between two particles—a photon and an electron at rest in the material.']
['What else does the article cover?', 'After careful observation, it was found that both energy and momentum were conserved in the collision.']
['What else did the article cover?', 'See Figure 21.11.']
['Who won the Nobel Prize?', 'For the discovery of this conserved scattering, now known as the Compton effect, Arthur Compton was awarded the Nobel Prize in 1929.']
['was determined by Louis de Broglie.', 'was determined by Louis de Broglie.']
['The de Broglie relation has the following terms: h', 'In this equation, called the de Broglie relation, h represents Planck’s constant and λ is the photon wavelength.']
['What are some of the characteristics of photon momentum?', 'We can see that photon momentum is small, since  $$\\(\\mathbf{p} = h/\\lambda.\\)$$  and h is very small.']
['Why does this matter?', 'It is for this reason that we do not ordinarily observe photon momentum.']
['What is a common observation?', 'Our mirrors do not recoil when light reflects from them, except perhaps in cartoons.']

['What is photon momentum?', 'Compton saw the effects of photon momentum because he was observing X-rays, which have a small wavelength and a relatively large momentum, interacting with the lightest of particles, the electron.']
['What do we know about electromagnetic radiation?', 'We have long known that EM radiation is like a wave, capable of interference and diffraction.']
['What else do we know about light?', 'We now see that light can also be modeled as particles—massless photons of discrete energy and momentum.']
['How does the particle wave duality differ?', 'We call this twofold nature the particle-wave duality, meaning that EM radiation has properties of both particles and waves.']
['How is this contradictory?', 'This may seem contradictory, since we ordinarily deal with large objects that never act like both waves and particles.']
['What are some examples of particles and waves?', 'An ocean wave, for example, looks nothing like a grain of sand.']
['How does the duality relate to light?', 'However, this so-called duality is simply a term for properties of the photon analogous to phenomena we can observe directly, on a macroscopic scale.']
['What else can you tell me about this?', 'See Figure 21.14.']

['Is there anything else we need to know?', 'If this term seems strange, it is because we do not ordinarily observe details on the quantum level directly, and our observations yield either particle-like or wave-like properties, but never both simultaneously.']

['What is the particle-wave duality?', 'Since we have a particle-wave duality for photons, and since we have seen connections between photons and matter in that both have momentum, it is reasonable to ask whether there is a particle-wave duality for matter as well.']
['Is there such a particle-wave duality for matter as well?', 'The answer, strangely, is yes.']
['What does this mean?', 'The consequences of this are tremendous, as particle-wave duality has been a constant source of scientific wonder during the twentieth and twenty-first centuries.']
['What are the atoms?', 'While often taken for granted, our knowledge of the existence and structure of atoms is the result of centuries of contemplation and experimentation.']

['How were they discovered?', 'The earliest known speculation on the atom dates back to the fifth century B.C., when Greek philosophers Leucippus and Democritus contemplated whether a substance could be divided without limit into ever smaller pieces.']

['Whose ideas were more refined?', 'Since then, scientists such as John Dalton (1766–1844), Amadeo Avogadro (1776–1856), and Dmitri Mendeleev (1834–1907) helped to discover the properties of that fundamental structure of matter.']

['Who was another scientist that helped?', 'While much could be written about any number of important scientific philosophers, this section will focus on the role played by Ernest Rutherford (1871–1937).']

['What did Rutherford discover?', 'Though his understanding of our most elemental matter is rooted in the success of countless prior investigations, his surprising discovery about the interior of the atom is most fundamental in explaining so many well-known phenomena.']
['What was the plum pudding model?', 'In the early 1900’s, the plum pudding model was the accepted model of the atom.']

['What did the model say?', 'Proposed in 1904 by J. J. Thomson, the model suggested that the atom was a spherical ball of positive charge, with negatively charged electrons scattered evenly throughout.']
['What was the pudding like?', 'In that model, the positive charges made up the pudding, while the electrons acted as isolated plums.']

['Why was it popular?', 'During its short life, the model could be used to explain why most particles were neutral, although with an unbalanced number of plums, electrically charged atoms could exist.']

['When was this experiment conducted?', 'When Ernest Rutherford began his gold foil experiment in 1909, it is unlikely that anyone would have expected that the plum pudding model would be challenged.']

['What was his experiment?', 'However, using a radioactive source, a thin sheet of gold foil, and a phosphorescent screen, Rutherford would uncover something so great that he would later call it “the most incredible event that has ever happened to me in my life”[James, L. K. (1993).']
['Did he win any awards?', 'Nobel Laureates in Chemistry, 1901–1992.']
['Where was it published?', 'Washington, DC: American Chemical Society.]']
["What was Rutherford's experiment?", 'The experiment that Rutherford designed is shown in Figure 22.2.']

['What was the experiment about?', 'As you can see in, a radioactive source was placed in a lead container with a hole in one side to produce a beam of positively charged helium particles, called alpha particles.']
['What was the beam of alpha particles made up of?', 'Then, a thin gold foil sheet was placed in the beam.']
['What did the gold foil do?', 'When the high-energy alpha particles passed through the gold foil, they were scattered.']
['How did the scattering occur?', 'The scattering was observed from the bright spots they produced when they struck the phosphor screen.']
['What was the plum pudding model?', 'The expectation of the plum pudding model was that the high-energy alpha particles would be scattered only slightly by the presence of the gold sheet.']

['What were the bowling pin analogy?', 'Because the energy of the alpha particles was much higher than those typically associated with atoms, the alpha particles should have passed through the thin foil much like a supersonic bowling ball would crash through a few dozen rows of bowling pins.']
['What was the deflection?', 'Any deflection was expected to be minor, and due primarily to the electrostatic Coulomb force between the alpha particles and the foil’s interior electric charges.']
['What did Rutherford say he discovered in the experiment?', 'However, the true result was nothing of the sort.']

['What were the results?', 'While the majority of alpha particles passed through the foil unobstructed, Rutherford and his collaborators Hans Geiger and Ernest Marsden found that alpha particles occasionally were scattered to large angles, and some even came back in the direction from which they came!']
['What was the result?', 'The result, called Rutherford scattering, implied that the gold nuclei were actually very small when compared with the size of the gold atom.']

['How did Rutherford determine that?', 'As shown in Figure 22.3, the dense nucleus is surrounded by mostly empty space of the atom, an idea verified by the fact that only 1 in 8,000 particles was scattered backward.']
["What is Rutherford's Experiment?", 'Although the results of the experiment were published by his colleagues in 1909, it took Rutherford two years to convince himself of their meaning.']
['How did Rutherford react?', 'Rutherford later wrote: “It was almost as incredible as if you fired a 15-inch shell at a piece of tissue paper and it came back and hit you.']
['Why did Rutherford believe this?', 'On consideration, I realized that this scattering backwards ... [meant] ... the greatest part of the mass of the atom was concentrated in a tiny nucleus.”']

["When was Rutherford's analysis published?", 'In 1911, Rutherford published his analysis together with a proposed model of the atom, which was in part based on Geiger’s work from the previous year.']
['What was the model of the atom?', 'As a result of the paper, the size of the nucleus was determined to be about  $$\\(10^{-15}\\)$$  m, or 100,000 times smaller than the atom.']
["How did Rutherford's model impact physics?", 'That implies a huge density, on the order of  $$\\(10^{15}\\)$$  g/cm3, much greater than any macroscopic matter.']

['What happened with the Rutherford experiment?', 'Based on the size and mass of the nucleus revealed by his experiment, as well as the mass of electrons, Rutherford proposed the planetary model of the atom.']
['What is the planetary model of the atom?', 'The planetary model of the atom pictures low-mass electrons orbiting a large-mass nucleus.']
['What other things did Rutherford suggest?', 'The sizes of the electron orbits are large compared with the size of the nucleus, and most of the atom is a vacuum.']
["What did Rutherford's model look like?", 'The model is analogous to how low-mass planets in our solar system orbit the large-mass Sun.']
['What else can you tell me about this experiment?', 'In the atom, the attractive Coulomb force is analogous to gravitation in the planetary system (see Figure 22.4).']
["What is the significance of Max Planck's discovery?", 'In 1900, Max Planck recognized that all energy radiated from a source is emitted by atoms in quantum states.']
['What is the answer to question two?', 'The answer was first found by investigating the spectrum of light or emission spectrum produced when a gas is highly energized.']
['What is the first question?', 'Figure 22.5 shows how to isolate the emission spectrum of one such gas.']
['What is the figure 22.5 about?', 'The gas is placed in the discharge tube at the left, where it is energized to the point at which it begins to radiate energy or emit light.']
['What does this do?', 'The radiated light is channeled by a thin slit and then passed through a diffraction grating, which will separate the light into its constituent wavelengths.']
['What happens next?', 'The separated light will then strike the photographic film on the right.']
['What is the line spectrum shown in part (b) of Figure 22.5?', 'The line spectrum shown in part (b) of Figure 22.5 is the output shown on the film for excited iron.']
['What else can you tell me about this spectrum?', 'Note that this spectrum is not continuous but discrete.']
['What does discrete mean?', 'In other words, only particular wavelengths are emitted by the iron source.']
['What is Absorption and Emission Spectra?', 'The spectrum of light created by excited iron shows a variety of discrete wavelengths emitted within the visible spectrum.']
['How is the spectrum formed?', 'Each element, when excited to the appropriate degree, will create a discrete emission spectrum as in part (b) of Figure 22.5.']
['What wavelengths are produced?', 'However, the wavelengths emitted will vary from element to element.']
['What are the effects of the wavelengths?', 'The emission spectrum for iron was chosen for Figure 22.5 solely because a substantial portion of its emission spectrum is within the visible spectrum.']
['What is the next figure that you can see?', 'Figure 22.6 shows the emission spectrum for hydrogen.']
['What is significant about this?', 'Note that, while discrete, a large portion of hydrogen emission takes place in the ultraviolet and infrared regions.']
['What is a spectrum?', 'Just as an emission spectrum shows all discrete wavelengths emitted by a gas, an absorption spectrum will show all light that is absorbed by a gas.']
['What does the absorption spectrum look like?', 'Black lines exist where the wavelengths are absorbed, with the remainder of the spectrum lit by light is free to pass through.']
['What is an example of the absorption spectrum?', 'Figure 22.7 shows the absorption spectrum of the Sun.']
['What are the black lines?', 'The black lines are called Fraunhofer lines, and they correspond to the wavelengths absorbed by gases in the Sun’s exterior.']
['What do you want to learn?', 'To tie the unique signatures of emission spectra to the composition of the atom itself would require clever thinking.']
['Who was Bohr?', 'Niels Bohr (1885–1962), a Danish physicist, did just that, by making immediate use of Rutherford’s planetary model of the atom.']
['Did he help Rutherford with anything?', 'Bohr, shown in Figure 22.8, became convinced of its validity and spent part of 1912 at Rutherford’s laboratory.']
['What happened in 1912?', 'In 1913, after returning to Copenhagen, he began publishing his theory of the simplest atom, hydrogen, based on Rutherford’s planetary model.']
['What was the proof?', 'Bohr was able to derive the formula for the hydrogen spectrum using basic physics, the planetary model of the atom, and some very important new conjectures.']
['What were the new conjectures?', 'His first conjecture was that only certain orbits are allowed:']
['Why is this important?', 'In other words, in an atom, the orbits of electrons are quantized.']
['How is an orbit quantized?', 'Each quantized orbit has a different distinct energy, and electrons can move to a higher orbit by absorbing energy or drop to a lower orbit by emitting energy.']

['What happens after an electron moves?', 'Because of the quantized orbits, the amount of energy emitted or absorbed must also be quantized, producing the discrete spectra seen in Figure 22.5 and Figure 22.7.']
['How can you explain how quantum orbits affect energy absorption and emission?', 'In equation form, the amount of energy absorbed or emitted can be found as']
['What is E equal to?', 'where  $$\\(E_{i}\\)$$  refers to the energy of the initial quantized orbit, and  $$\\(E_{f}\\)$$  refers to the energy of the final orbits.']
['How is the wavelength determined?', 'Furthermore, the wavelength emitted can be found using the equation']
['What is energy?', 'It makes sense that energy is involved in changing orbits.']
['What kinds of energy are involved?', 'For example, a burst of energy is required for a satellite to climb to a higher orbit.']
['What is not expected?', 'What is not expected is that atomic orbits should be quantized.']
['What are the implications?', 'Quantization is not observed for satellites or planets, which can have any orbit, given the proper energy (see Figure 22.9).']
['Is there anything else that you find interesting?', 'Figure 22.10 shows an energy-level diagram, a convenient way to display energy states.']
['What is the diagram for?', 'Each of the horizontal lines corresponds to the energy of an electron in a different orbital.']
['What are the energy levels?', 'Energy is plotted vertically with the lowest or ground state at the bottom and with excited states above.']
['What else did you find interesting?', 'The vertical arrow downwards shows energy being emitted out of the atom due to an electron dropping from one excited state to another.']
['What would that correspond to?', 'That would correspond to a line shown on the atom’s emission spectrum.']

['What is this referred to as?', 'The Lyman series shown in Figure 22.6 results from electrons dropping to the ground state, while the Balmer and Paschen series result to electrons dropping to the n = 2 and n = 3 states, respectively.']

['What does E_n mean?', 'The negative value in the equation is based upon a baseline energy of zero when the electron is infinitely far from the atom.']
['Why is the negative value there?', 'As a result, the negative value shows that energy is necessary to free the electron from its orbital state.']
['What happens when the electron is freed from its orbital state?', 'The minimum energy to free the electron is also referred to as its binding energy.']
['What is the equation for?', 'The equation is only valid for atoms with single electrons in their orbital shells (like hydrogen).']

['What is the atomic number?', 'The atomic number is the number of protons in the nucleus—it is different for each element.']

['How was this equation derived?', 'The above equation is derived from some basic physics principles, namely conservation of energy, conservation of angular momentum, Coulomb’s law, and centripetal force.']
['Why were they derivated?', 'There are three derivations that result in the orbital energy equations, and they are shown below.']
['What did the derivations tell?', 'While you can use the energy equations without understanding the derivations, they will help to remind you of just how valuable those fundamental concepts are.']
['What else was significant about this Derivation?', 'One primary difference between the planetary model of the solar system and the planetary model of the atom is the cause of the circular motion.']

['What was the cause of the circular motion?', 'While gravitation causes the motion of orbiting planets around an interior star, the Coulomb force is responsible for the circular shape of the electron’s orbit.']

['Did the Derivation 1 have anything else significant?', 'The magnitude of the centripetal force is  $$\\(\\frac{m_{e}v^{2}}{r_{n}}\\)$$, while the magnitude of the Coulomb force is  $$\\(\\frac{k\\left( {Zq_{e}} \\right)\\left( q_{e} \\right)}{r_{e}{}^{2}}\\)$$ .']
['What else did you find important about this Derivation?', 'The assumption here is that the nucleus is more massive than the stationary electron, and the electron orbits about it.']
['What else did you find interesting about this Derivation?', 'That is consistent with the planetary model of the atom.']

['What is the orbital energy of the electron?', 'Bohr was clever enough to find a way to calculate the electron orbital energies in hydrogen.']

['Was there any other step in his work?', 'Assuming circular orbits, Bohr proposed that the angular momentum L of an electron in its orbit is also quantized, that is, it has only specific, discrete values.']

['Who is Bohr?', 'At the time, Bohr himself did not know why angular momentum should be quantized, but by using that assumption, he was able to calculate the energies in the hydrogen spectrum, something no one else had done at the time.']
['What is the familiar KE?', 'Kinetic energy is the familiar  $$\\(KE = \\frac{1}{2}mv^{2}\\)$$, assuming the electron is not moving at a relativistic speed.']
['What is the unfamiliar PE?', 'Potential energy for the electron is electrical, or  $$\\(PE = q_{e}V\\)$$, where V is the potential due to the nucleus, which looks like a point charge.']

['How does it compare?', 'Since the electron’s charge is negative, we see that  $$\\(PE = \\frac{- kZq_{e}{}^{2}}{r_{n}}\\text{.}\\)$$ Substituting the expressions for KE and PE,']

["What is the limitation of Bohr's theory?", 'There are limits to Bohr’s theory.']
['What is the limitation?', 'It does not account for the interaction of bound electrons, so it cannot be fully applied to multielectron atoms, even one as simple as the two-electron helium atom.']
['How does the model relate to atoms?', 'Bohr’s model is what we call semiclassical.']
['What is semiclassical?', 'The orbits are quantized (nonclassical) but are assumed to be simple circular paths (classical).']
['Is this the only time that the orbits are quantized?', 'As quantum mechanics was developed, it became clear that there are no well-defined orbits; rather, there are clouds of probability.']

['Is there anything else that stands out about this section of the document?', 'Additionally, Bohr’s theory did not explain that some spectral lines are doublets or split into two when examined closely.']
['Did Bohr think it was a failure?', 'While we shall examine a few of those aspects of quantum mechanics in more detail, it should be kept in mind that Bohr did not fail.']
['Did Bohr ever fail?', 'Rather, he made very important steps along the path to greater knowledge and laid the foundation for all of atomic physics that has since evolved.']
['What is this about?', 'Following']
["Bohr's initial work on the hydrogen atom, a decade was to pass", 'Bohr’s initial work on the hydrogen atom, a decade was to pass before Louis de Broglie proposed that matter has wave properties.']
['What did he propose?', 'The wave-like properties of matter were subsequently confirmed by observations of electron interference when scattered from crystals.']
['What was the interference?', 'Electrons can exist only in locations where they interfere constructively.']
['What are the wavelengths?', 'When an electron is bound to an atom, its wavelength must fit into a small space, something like a standing wave on a string (see Figure 22.12).']
['What are the orbits?', 'Orbits in which an electron can constructively interfere with itself are allowed.']
['Are there other orbits?', 'All orbits in which constructive interference cannot occur are not able to exist.']
['What else can only occur?', 'Thus, only certain orbits are allowed.']
['Why?', 'The wave nature of an electron, according to de Broglie, is why the orbits are quantized!']

['What are some things you learned?', 'For a circular orbit, constructive interference occurs when the electron’s wavelength fits neatly into the circumference, so that wave crests always align with crests and wave troughs align with troughs, as shown in Figure 22.12(b).']
['What are some other aspects of the article?', 'More precisely, when an integral multiple of the electron’s wavelength equals the circumference of the orbit, constructive interference is obtained.']
['What else is notable about the article?', 'In equation form, the condition for constructive interference and an allowed electron orbit is']
["What do you mean by '2pi r_n'?", 'where  $$\\(\\lambda_{n}\\)$$  is the electron’s wavelength and rn is the radius of that circular orbit.']
['What does Figure 22.13 show?', 'Figure 22.13 shows the third and fourth orbitals of a hydrogen atom.']
['What is an important aspect of measurement?', 'The answer is fundamentally important—measurement affects the system being observed.']

['What are some examples of this?', 'It is impossible to measure a physical quantity exactly, and greater precision in measuring one quantity produces less precision in measuring a related quantity.']

['Who is he?', 'It was Werner Heisenberg who first stated that limit to knowledge in 1929 as a result of his work on quantum mechanics and the wave characteristics of all particles (see Figure 22.14).']
['What can you do with a scattering object?', 'For example, you can measure the position of a moving electron by scattering light or other electrons from it.']
['What happens if you use light to measure the position of the electron?', 'However, by doing so, you are giving the electron energy, and therefore imparting momentum to it.']
['What happens with the momentum?', 'As a result, the momentum of the electron is affected and cannot be determined precisely.']
['How can you determine the momentum?', 'This change in momentum could be anywhere from close to zero up to the relative momentum of the electron ( $$\\(p \\approx h/\\lambda\\)$$ ).']
['Is there anything else to know about the Heisenberg uncertainty principle?', 'Note that, in this case, the particle is an electron, but the principle applies to any particle.']

['What is the uncertainty about?', 'Viewing the electron through the model of wave-particle duality, Heisenberg recognized that, because a wave is not located at one fixed point in space, there is an uncertainty associated with any electron’s position.']
['What is the uncertainty associated with?', 'That uncertainty in position,  $$\\(\\text{Δ}x\\)$$ , is approximately equal to the wavelength of the particle.']
['What is the wavelength?', 'That is,  $$\\(\\text{Δ}x \\approx \\lambda\\)$$ .']
['What is the trade-off between position and momentum?', 'There is an interesting trade-off between position and momentum.']
['Why is that important?', 'The uncertainty in an electron’s position can be reduced by using a shorter-wavelength electron, since  $$\\(\\text{Δ}x \\approx \\lambda\\)$$ .']
['What happens when it is shorter?', 'But shortening the wavelength increases the uncertainty in momentum, since  $$\\(\\text{Δ}p \\approx h/\\lambda\\)$$ .']
['What happens when it is longer?', 'Conversely, the uncertainty in momentum can be reduced by using a longer-wavelength electron, but that increases the uncertainty in position.']
['How do you get the information?', 'Mathematically, you can express the trade-off by multiplying the uncertainties.']
['Why can you do that?', 'The wavelength cancels, leaving']
['What is the problem that you are studying?', 'Therefore, if one uncertainty is reduced, the other must increase so that their product is  $$\\(\\approx h\\)$$  .']

['What was the most important information in this paragraph?', 'With the use of advanced mathematics, Heisenberg showed that the best that can be done in a simultaneous measurement of position and momentum is']

['What did you find most interesting about The Quantum Model of the Atom?', 'Because of the wave characteristic of matter, the idea of well-defined orbits gives way to a model in which there is a cloud of probability, consistent with Heisenberg’s uncertainty principle.']
['What is a specific example given to show that the uncertainty principle works?', 'Figure 22.15 shows how the principle applies to the ground state of hydrogen.']

['What were some other interesting things about the article?', 'If you try to follow the electron in some well-defined orbit using a probe that has a wavelength small enough to measure position accurately, you will instead knock the electron out of its orbit.']
['Are there any other interesting things in this section?', 'Each measurement of the electron’s position will find it to be in a definite location somewhere near the nucleus.']
['How does the model work?', 'Repeated measurements reveal a cloud of probability like that in the figure, with each speck the location determined by a single measurement.']
['What is unique about the orbits?', 'There is not a well-defined, circular-orbit type of distribution.']
['What else is unique?', 'Nature again proves to be different on a small scale than on a macroscopic scale.']
['What is the quest to find the substructures of matter?', 'There is an ongoing quest to find the substructures of matter.']
['What are the substructures?', 'At one time, it was thought that atoms would be the ultimate substructure.']
['What else has been known about substructures?', 'However, just when the first direct evidence of atoms was obtained, it became clear that they have a substructure and a tiny nucleus.']
['What is the nucleus?', 'The nucleus itself has spectacular characteristics.']
['What characteristics?', 'For example, certain nuclei are unstable, and their decay emits radiations with energies millions of times greater than atomic energies.']
['What else is known about the nucleus?', 'Some of the mysteries of nature, such as why the core of Earth remains molten and how the Sun produces its energy, are explained by nuclear phenomena.']
['Did they discover anything else about the nucleus?', 'The exploration of radioactivity and the nucleus has revealed new fundamental particles, forces, and conservation laws.']
['What is the exploration of radioactivity and the nucleus?', 'That exploration has evolved into a search for further underlying structures, such as quarks.']
['What else is in this section?', 'In this section, we will explore the fundamentals of the nucleus and nuclear radioactivity.']
['What is a proton?', 'At this point, you are likely familiar with the neutron and proton, the two fundamental particles that make up the nucleus of an atom.']
['What is a neutron?', 'Those two particles, collectively called nucleons, make up the small interior portion of the atom.']
['How is the difference between neutron and proton?', 'Both particles have nearly the same mass, although the neutron is about two parts in 1,000 more massive.']
['What is the mass of a proton?', 'The mass of a proton is equivalent to 1,836 electrons, while the mass of a neutron is equivalent to that of 1,839 electrons.']
['What is the difference in their weights?', 'That said, each of the particles is significantly more massive than the electron.']
['What else is the document about?', 'When describing the mass of objects on the scale of nucleons and atoms, it is most reasonable to measure their mass in terms of atoms.']
['What are some examples of atoms?', 'The atomic mass unit (u) was originally defined so that a neutral carbon atom would have a mass of exactly 12 u.']

['What else is interesting?', 'Given that protons and neutrons are approximately the same mass, that there are six protons and six neutrons in a carbon atom, and that the mass of an electron is minuscule in comparison, measuring this way allows for both protons and neutrons to have masses close to 1 u.']
['Are there any other examples?', 'Table 22.1 shows the mass of protons, neutrons, and electrons on the new scale.']
['What else is important about the nucleus?', 'Another other useful mass unit on the atomic scale is the  $$\\(\\text{M}\\text{e}\\text{V}/c^{2}\\)$$ .']
['How are the atomic and mass units related?', 'While rarely used in most contexts, it is convenient when one uses the equation  $$\\(E = mc^{2}\\)$$, as will be addressed later in this text.']
['What is this article about?', 'To more completely characterize nuclei, let us also consider two other important quantities: the atomic number and the mass number.']
['What does that atomic number represent?', 'The atomic number, Z, represents the number of protons within a nucleus.']
['What does the mass number determine?', 'That value determines the elemental quality of each atom.']
['What is the difference in atoms between carbon and oxygen?', 'Every carbon atom, for instance, has a Z value of 6, whereas every oxygen atom has a Z value of 8.']
['Are there any other differences between the atoms?', 'For clarification, only oxygen atoms may have a Z value of 8.']
['What happens if the Z value is not 8?', 'If the Z value is not 8, the atom cannot be oxygen.']
['What is the mass number?', 'The mass number, A, represents the total number of protons and neutrons, or nucleons, within an atom.']
['What are the protons and neutrons in an atom?', 'For an ordinary carbon atom the mass number would be 12, as there are typically six neutrons accompanying the six protons within the atom.']
['How does it measure mass?', 'In the case of carbon, the mass would be exactly 12 u.']
['What is the mass number for oxygen?', 'For oxygen, with a mass number of 16, the atomic mass is 15.994915 u.']
['How do you know the difference?', 'Of course, the difference is minor and can be ignored for most scenarios.']
['How do you know the difference?', 'Again, because the mass of an electron is so small compared to the nucleons, the mass number and the atomic mass can be essentially equivalent.']
['Are there any other interesting facts about the atomic number?', 'Figure 22.16 shows an example of Lithium-7, which has an atomic number of 3 and a mass number of 7.']
['What is the mass number?', 'The intent of the mass number is to differentiate between various isotopes of an atom.']
['What does an isotope consist of?', 'The term isotope refers to the variation of atoms based upon the number of neutrons within their nucleus.']

['What is the typical number of neutrons per atom?', 'While it is most common for there to be six neutrons accompanying the six protons within a carbon atom, it is possible to find carbon atoms with seven neutrons or eight neutrons.']
['What are the different types of carbon atoms?', 'Those carbon atoms are respectively referred to as carbon-13 and carbon-14 atoms, with their mass numbers being their primary distinction.']

['What is the importance of isotopes?', 'The isotope distinction is an important one to make, as the number of neutrons within an atom can affect a number of its properties, not the least of which is nuclear stability.']
['what is the nuclide?', 'To more easily identify various atoms, their atomic number and mass number are typically written in a form of representation called the nuclide.']
['what is the form of that representation?', 'The nuclide form appears as follows: $$\\({}_{A}^{Z}X{}_{N}\\)$$, where X is the atomic symbol and N represents the number of neutrons.']
['What do nuclides mean?', 'Let us look at a few examples of nuclides expressed in the  $$\\({}_{A}^{Z}X{}_{N}\\)$$  notation.']
['What other particles are there in the nucleus?', 'The nucleus of the simplest atom, hydrogen, is a single proton, or  $$\\({}_{}^{}{}\\)$$ (the zero for no neutrons is often omitted).']
['Is there anything else I should know about the atom of hydrogen?', 'To check the symbol, refer to the periodic table—you see that the atomic number Z of hydrogen is 1.']
['Is there anything else I should know?', 'Since you are given that there are no neutrons, the mass number A is also 1.']

['Does it have a difference in mass or composition?', 'There is a scarce form of hydrogen found in nature called deuterium; its nucleus has one proton and one neutron and, hence, twice the mass of common hydrogen.']
['What is the symbol for deuterium?', 'The symbol for deuterium is, thus,  $$\\({}_{1}^{2}\\text{H}{}_{2}\\)$$ .']

['Are there any other nuclides that we should be aware of?', 'An even rarer—and radioactive—form of hydrogen is called tritium, since it has a single proton and two neutrons, and it is written  $$\\({}_{1}^{3}\\text{H}{}_{2}\\)$$ .']
['What are other features of this nucleus?', 'The three varieties of hydrogen have nearly identical chemistries, but the nuclei differ greatly in mass, stability, and other characteristics.']
['What is this called?', 'Again, the different nuclei are referred to as isotopes of the same element.']
['What was the purpose of the atoms in this material?', 'There is some redundancy in the symbols A, X, Z, and N.']
['Why is there some redundancy?', 'If the element X is known, then Z can be found in a periodic table.']
['How is Z related to A?', 'If both A and X are known, then N can also be determined by first finding Z; then, N  = A  – Z.']
['What is the difference between nuclides and atoms?', 'Thus the simpler notation for nuclides is']
['What is X?', 'which is sufficient and is most commonly used.']
['What is so commonly used?', 'For example, in this simpler notation, the three isotopes of hydrogen are  $$\\({}^{1}\\text{H}\\)$$, $$\\({}^{2}\\text{H}\\)$$, and  $$\\({}^{3}\\text{H}\\)$$ .']
['What other isotopes?', 'For $$\\({}^{238}\\text{U}\\)$$, should we need to know, wecan determine that Z = 92 for uranium from the periodic table, and thus, N = 238 − 92 = 146.']
['When was this discovered?', 'In 1896, the French physicist Antoine Henri Becquerel (1852–1908) noticed something strange.']
['Why was he concerned?', 'When a uranium-rich mineral called pitchblende was placed on a completely opaque envelope containing a photographic plate, it darkened spots on the photographic plate..']
['What did he do next?', 'Becquerel reasoned that the pitchblende must emit invisible rays capable of penetrating the opaque material.']

['Did he find out more about this?', 'Stranger still was that no light was shining on the pitchblende, which means that the pitchblende was emitting the invisible rays continuously without having any energy input!']

['What did scientists discover?', 'There is an apparent violation of the law of conservation of energy, one that scientists can now explain using Einstein’s famous equation  $$\\(E = mc^{2}\\text{.}\\)$$']
['What were other discoveries?', 'It was soon evident that Becquerel’s rays originate in the nuclei of the atoms and have other unique characteristics.']
['What is the chemical reaction of uranium?', 'To this point, most reactions you have studied have been chemical reactions, which are reactions involving the electrons surrounding the atoms.']
['What do these rays originate from?', 'However, two types of experimental evidence implied that Becquerel’s rays did not originate with electrons, but instead within the nucleus of an atom.']
['what is this material about?', 'First, the radiation is found to be only associated with certain elements, such as uranium.']
['where does the uranium radiation come from?', 'Whether uranium was in the form of an element or compound was irrelevant to its radiation.']
['what else did you find interesting about uranium?', 'In addition, the presence of radiation does not vary with temperature, pressure, or ionization state of the uranium atom.']
['what is temperature, pressure, and ionization state?', 'Since all of those factors affect electrons in an atom, the radiation cannot come from electron transitions, as atomic spectra do.']
['What was the biggest evidence the radiation cannot be atomic?', 'The huge energy emitted during each event is the second piece of evidence that the radiation cannot be atomic.']

['How big is the energy per event?', 'Nuclear radiation has energies on the order of 106 eV per event, which is much greater than typical atomic energies that are a few eV, such as those observed in spectra and chemical reactions, and more than ten times as high as the most energetic X-rays.']
['What is the relationship among the three sides of a right-angled triangle?', 'To answer those questions, it is necessary to look into the structure of the nucleus.']
['What is the structure of the nucleus?', 'Though it is perhaps surprising, you will find that many of the same principles that we observe on a macroscopic level still apply to the nucleus.']
['What is an important fact from the study material?', 'A variety of experiments indicate that a nucleus behaves something like a tightly packed ball of nucleons, as illustrated in Figure 22.17.']
['What are some other important things to know about the nucleus?', 'Those nucleons have large kinetic energies and, thus, move rapidly in very close contact.']
['What else can be learned from the information?', 'Nucleons can be separated by a large force, such as in a collision with another nucleus, but strongly resist being pushed closer together.']
['What else is significant?', 'The most compelling evidence that nucleons are closely packed in a nucleus is that the radius of a nucleus, r, is found to be approximately']
['What does the formula mean?', 'Note that  $$\\(r^{3} \\propto A\\)$$ .']

['What is this relationship?', 'Since many nuclei are spherical, and the volume of a sphere is  $$\\(V = \\left( \\frac{4}{3} \\right)\\pi r^{3}\\)$$, we see that  $$\\(V \\propto A\\)$$ —that is, the volume of a nucleus is proportional to the number of nucleons in it.']
['What are the nucleons called?', 'That is what you expect if you pack nucleons so close that there is no empty space between them.']
['Why did they choose this number?', 'After all, the nucleus is very small and its protons, being positive, should exert tremendous repulsive forces on one another.']
['What are those forces?', 'Considering that, it seems that the nucleus would be forced apart, not together!']
['What are the other constants?', 'The answer is that a previously unknown force holds the nucleus together and makes it into a tightly packed ball of nucleons.']
['What is the force called?', 'This force is known as the strong nuclear force.']
['Can we predict the strength of the force?', 'The strong force has such a short range that it quickly fall to zero over a distance of only 10–15 meters.']
['How is the force like glue?', 'However, like glue, it is very strong when the nucleons get close to one another.']
["What is important about the nucleus' shape?", 'The balancing of the electromagnetic force with the nuclear forces is what allows the nucleus to maintain its spherical shape.']

['How does the balance affect nuclear structure?', 'If, for any reason, the electromagnetic force should overcome the nuclear force, components of the nucleus would be projected outward, creating the very radiation that Becquerel discovered!']
['What happens to the nucleus when it breaks apart?', 'Understanding why the nucleus would break apart can be partially explained using Table 22.2.']
['What is the balance?', 'The balance between the strong nuclear force and the electromagnetic force is a tenuous one.']

['What is the strength of these forces?', 'Recall that the attractive strong nuclear force exists between any two nucleons and acts over a very short range while the weaker repulsive electromagnetic force only acts between protons, although over a larger range.']

['What happens to the nucleus when it is out of balance?', 'Considering the interactions, an imperfect balance between neutrons and protons can result in a nuclear reaction, with the result of regaining equilibrium.']
['Who discovered the uranium-rich pitchblende?', 'The radiation discovered by Becquerel was due to the large number of protons present in his uranium-rich pitchblende.']
['What else did Becquerel discover?', 'In short, the large number of protons caused the electromagnetic force to be greater than the strong nuclear force.']
['What happened in the unstable nucleus?', 'To regain stability, the nucleus needed to undergo a nuclear reaction called alpha (α) decay.']
['What is radioactivity?', 'Radioactivity refers to the act of emitting particles or energy from the nucleus.']
['What does it cause?', 'When the uranium nucleus emits energetic nucleons in Becquerel’s experiment, the radioactive process causes the nucleus to alter in structure.']
['What alteration is it in?', 'The alteration is called radioactive decay.']
['What does radioactivity mean?', 'Any substance that undergoes radioactive decay is said to be radioactive.']
['What else did you find interesting?', 'That those terms share a root with the term radiation should not be too surprising, as they all relate to the transmission of energy.']
['What is Alpha Decay?', 'Alpha decay refers to the type of decay that takes place when too many protons exist in the nucleus.']
['What is it?', 'It is the most common type of decay and causes the nucleus to regain equilibrium between its two competing internal forces.']
['What is the resemblance?', 'During alpha decay, the nucleus ejects two protons and two neutrons, allowing the strong nuclear force to regain balance with the repulsive electromagnetic force.']
['What happens?', 'The nuclear equation for an alpha decay process can be shown as follows.']
['What will happen to the original nuclide?', 'By ejecting an alpha particle, the original nuclide decreases in atomic number.']
['What is that?', 'That means that Becquerel’s uranium nucleus, upon decaying, is actually transformed into thorium, two atomic numbers lower on the periodic table!']
['What is transmutation?', 'The process of changing elemental composition is called transmutation.']
['How is that related to the second thing to note?', 'Note that the two protons and two neutrons ejected from the nucleus combine to form a helium nucleus.']
['What happens to the helium?', 'Shortly after decay, the ejected helium ion typically acquires two electrons to become a stable helium atom.']
['What is the final thing to note?', 'Finally, it is important to see that, despite the elemental change, physical conservation still takes place.']
['What is physical conservation?', 'The mass number of the new element and the alpha particle together equal the mass number of the original element.']
['What is the mass number?', 'Also, the net charge of all particles involved remains the same before and after the transmutation.']
['What is beta decay?', 'Like alpha decay, beta ( βββ ) decay also takes place when there is an imbalance between neutrons and protons within the nucleus.']
['What is different about beta decay?', 'For beta decay, however, a neutron is transformed into a proton and electron or vice versa.']

['What else is significant about beta decay?', 'The transformation allows for the total mass number of the atom to remain the same, although the atomic number will increase by one (or decrease by one).']
['How does the change in neutrons affect the atom?', 'Once again, the transformation of the neutron allows for a rebalancing of the strong nuclear and electromagnetic forces.']
['What is the nuclear equation for beta decay?', 'The nuclear equation for a beta decay process is shown below.']
['What is the symbol $$(v)$$?', 'The symbol  $$\\(v\\)$$  in the equation above stands for a high-energy particle called the neutrino.']
['What happens when a nucleus emits a positron?', 'A nucleus may also emit a positron, and in that case Z decreases and N increases.']
['What is the nuclear fusion process?', 'It is beyond the scope of this section and will be discussed in further detail in the chapter on particles.']
['What is the most interesting information from this article?', 'It is worth noting, however, that the mass number and charge in all beta-decay reactions are conserved.']
['What is it about?', 'Gamma decay is a unique form of radiation that does not involve balancing forces within the nucleus.']
['What are the special aspects of gamma decay?', 'Gamma decay occurs when a nucleus drops from an excited state to the ground state.']
['How does the change in energy affect it?', 'Recall that such a change in energy state will release energy from the nucleus in the form of a photon.']
['What else is special about it?', 'The energy associated with the photon emitted is so great that its wavelength is shorter than that of an X-ray.']
['What is the nuclear equation?', 'Its nuclear equation is as follows.']
['Why would they differ?', 'The charges of the three radiated particles differ.']
['What is the charge of an alpha particle?', 'Alpha particles, with two protons, carry a net charge of +2.']
['What is the charge of an beta particle?', 'Beta particles, with one electron, carry a net charge of –1.']
['What is the charge of a gamma particle?', 'Meanwhile, gamma rays are solely photons, or light, and carry no charge.']
['How is the charge related?', 'The difference in charge plays an important role in how the three radiations affect surrounding substances.']
['What is the first major finding you learned?', 'Alpha particles, being highly charged, will quickly interact with ions in the air and electrons within metals.']
['How does that affect their effect?', 'As a result, they have a short range and short penetrating distance in most materials.']
['What happens next?', 'Beta particles, being slightly less charged, have a larger range and larger penetrating distance.']
['What else was uncovered?', 'Gamma rays, on the other hand, have little electric interaction with particles and travel much farther.']
['What else did you learn in this section?', 'Two diagrams below show the importance of difference in penetration.']
['What are the diagrams?', 'Table 22.3 shows the distance of radiation penetration, and Figure 22.21 shows the influence various factors have on radiation penetration distance.']
['What is the rate of radioactive decay?', 'Unstable nuclei decay.']
['Why do unstable nuclides decay?', 'However, some nuclides decay faster than others.']
['Who discovered this?', 'For example, radium and polonium, discovered by Marie and Pierre Curie, decay faster than uranium.']
['Why do they decay faster than uranium?', 'That means they have shorter lifetimes, producing a greater rate of decay.']
['What is half-life?', 'Here we will explore half-life and activity, the quantitative terms for lifetime and rate of decay.']
["What's the next step?", 'The answer can be found by examining Figure 22.24, which shows how the number of radioactive nuclei in a sample decreases with time.']
['What else is significant about this section?', 'The time in which half of the original number of nuclei decay is defined as the half-life,  $$\\(t_{\\frac{1}{2}}\\)$$ .']
['What else can you tell me about half-life?', 'After one half-life passes, half of the remaining nuclei will decay in the next half-life.']
['Does that mean a specific amount of nuclei will decay?', 'Then, half of that amount in turn decays in the following half-life.']
['What else can you tell me about half-life?', 'Therefore, the number of radioactive nuclei decreases from N to N / 2 in one half-life, to N / 4 in the next, to N / 8 in the next, and so on.']
['What else can you tell me about half-life?', 'Nuclear decay is an example of a purely statistical process.']

['What is the relationship among the three sides of a right-angled triangle according to the Py', 'where e = 2.71828... is the base of the natural logarithm, and  $$\\(\\lambda\\)$$  is the decay constant for the nuclide.']

['What is the relation between the nuclides and e-t?', 'The shorter the half-life, the larger is the value of  $$\\(\\lambda\\)$$, and the faster the exponential  $$\\(e^{- \\lambda t}\\)$$  decreases with time.']
['How can I find the decay constant?', 'The decay constant can be found with the equation']
['What does activity mean?', 'Generally, it means the number of decays per unit time is very high.']
['What is the definition?', 'We define activity R to be the rate of decay expressed in decays per unit time.']
['What is an example?', 'In equation form, this is']
['What is the SI unit for activity?', 'The SI unit for activity is one decay per second and it is given the name becquerel (Bq) in honor of the discoverer of radioactivity.']
['What is the half-life of a nucleus?', 'That is,']
['What is the R?', 'Activity R is often expressed in other units, such as decays per minute or decays per year.']
['What other units of activity are there?', 'One of the most common units for activity is the curie (Ci), defined to be the activity of 1 g of 226Ra, in honor of Marie Curie’s work with radium.']
['What is the curie?', 'The definition of the curie is']
['What is radioactive dating?', 'Radioactive dating or radiometric dating is a clever use of naturally occurring radioactivity.']
['What are some of the most common uses of this?', 'Its most familiar application is carbon-14 dating.']
['What is carbon 14?', 'Carbon-14 is an isotope of carbon that is produced when solar neutrinos strike  $$\\({}^{14}\\text{N}\\)$$  particles within the atmosphere.']
['Why is carbon 14 so important?', 'Radioactive carbon has the same chemistry as stable carbon, and so it mixes into the biosphere, where it is consumed and becomes part of every living organism.']

['How is carbon-14 found?', 'Carbon-14 has an abundance of 1.3 parts per trillion of normal carbon, so if you know the number of carbon nuclei in an object (perhaps determined by mass and Avogadro’s number), you can multiply that number by  $$\\(1.3\\  \\times \\ 10^{- 12}\\)$$  to find the number of  $$\\({}^{14}\\text{C}\\)$$  nuclei within the object.']
['Does it decay?', 'Over time, carbon-14 will naturally decay back to  $$\\({}^{14}\\text{N}\\)$$  with a half-life of 5,730 years (note that this is an example of beta decay).']
['What are some examples of this?', 'When an organism dies, carbon exchange with the environment ceases, and  $$\\({}^{14}\\text{']
['N', 'C}\\)$$  is not replenished.']

['What does the measurement tell?', 'By comparing the abundance of  $$\\({}^{14}\\text{C}\\)$$  in an artifact, such as mummy wrappings, with the normal abundance in living tissue, it is possible to determine the artifact’s age (or time since death).']

['What is the accuracy?', 'Carbon-14 dating can be used for biological tissues as old as 50 or 60 thousand years, but is most accurate for younger samples, since the abundance of  $$\\({}^{14}\\text{C}\\)$$  nuclei in them is greater.']
['How does the method work?', 'One of the most famous cases of carbon-14 dating involves the Shroud of Turin, a long piece of fabric purported to be the burial shroud of Jesus (see Figure 22.25).']
['What other important information is there?', 'This relic was first displayed in Turin in 1354 and was denounced as a fraud at that time by a French bishop.']
['What else is significant about this relic?', 'Its remarkable negative imprint of an apparently crucified body resembles the then-accepted image of Jesus.']
['What is most interesting about this relic?', 'As a result, the relic has been remained controversial throughout the centuries.']

['What is interesting about this study?', 'Carbon-14 dating was not performed on the shroud until 1988, when the process had been refined to the point where only a small amount of material needed to be destroyed.']

['What is most important in this study?', 'Samples were tested at three independent laboratories, each being given four pieces of cloth, with only one unidentified piece from the shroud, to avoid prejudice.']

["Did the results support the relic's claim?", 'All three laboratories found samples of the shroud contain 92 percent of the  $$\\({}^{14}\\text{C}\\)$$  found in living tissues, allowing the shroud to be dated (see How Old is the Shroud of Turin?).']
['what was the previous section?', 'The previous section dealt with naturally occurring nuclear decay.']
['what happened during natural nuclear decay?', 'Without human intervention, some nuclei will change composition in order to achieve a stable equilibrium.']
['what else does this section cover?', 'This section delves into a less-natural process.']
['are there any more questions I should ask?', 'The answer to this question is yes.']
['what is a less natural process?', 'Through two distinct methods, humankind has discovered multiple ways of manipulating the atom to release its internal energy.']
['what is nuclear fission?', 'In simplest terms, nuclear fission is the splitting of an atomic bond.']

['What happens to an atomic bond when it splits?', 'Given that it requires great energy separate two nucleons, it may come as a surprise to learn that splitting a nucleus can release vast potential energy.']
['What happens to that energy?', 'And although it is true that huge amounts of energy can be released, considerable effort is needed to do so in practice.']
['Why is nuclear fission so important?', 'An unstable atom will naturally decay, but it may take millions of years to do so.']
['What happens when these unstable atoms are bombarded with neutrons?', 'As a result, a physical catalyst is necessary to produce useful energy through nuclear fission.']
['What is the catalyst?', 'The catalyst typically occurs in the form of a free neutron, projected directly at the nucleus of a high-mass atom.']
['What does this content have in common?', 'As shown in Figure 22.26, a neutron strike can cause the nucleus to elongate, much like a drop of liquid water.']
['What is this called?', 'This is why the model is known as the liquid drop model.']
['How does this impact the force?', 'As the nucleus elongates, nucleons are no longer so tightly packed, and the repulsive electromagnetic force can overcome the short-range strong nuclear force.']
['What does this lead to?', 'The imbalance of forces can result in the two ends of the drop flying apart, with some of the nuclear binding energy released to the surroundings.']
['What is one important part of the article that you learned?', 'As you can imagine, the consequences of the nuclei splitting are substantial.']
['What are the other consequences?', 'When a nucleus is split, it is not only energy that is released, but a small number of neutrons as well.']

['What does that lead to?', 'Those neutrons have the potential to cause further fission in other nuclei, especially if they are directed back toward the other nuclei by a dense shield or neutron reflector (see part (d) of Figure 22.26).']
['What happens when a nucleus splits into two equal parts?', 'However, not every neutron produced by fission induces further fission.']
['What happens in the neutrons?', 'Some neutrons escape the fissionable material, while others interact with a nucleus without making it split.']
['What can we do to enhance the neutrons?', 'We can enhance the number of fissions produced by neutrons by having a large amount of fissionable material as well as a neutron reflector.']
["What's the critical mass?", 'The minimum amount necessary for self-sustained fission of a given nuclide is called its critical mass.']
["What's the difference between nuclides?", 'Some nuclides, such as 239Pu, produce more neutrons per fission than others, such as 235U.']
["What's another difference between nuclides?", 'Additionally, some nuclides are easier to make fission than others.']
['What are the nuclides?', 'In particular, 235U and 239Pu are easier to fission than the much more abundant 238U.']
['What are the factors in the critical mass?', 'Both factors affect critical mass, which is smallest for 239Pu.']
['What is the chain reaction?', 'The self-sustained fission of nuclei is commonly referred to as a chain reaction, as shown in Figure 22.27.']
['What happens when a chain reaction starts?', 'A chain reaction can have runaway results.']
['What are the results of chain reactions?', 'If each atomic split results in two nuclei producing a new fission, the number of nuclear reactions will increase exponentially.']
['What are the results of fission?', 'One fission will produce two atoms, the next round of fission will create four atoms, the third round eight atoms, and so on.']
['What else happens during fission?', 'Of course, each time fission occurs, more energy will be emitted, further increasing the power of the atomic reaction.']
['Can there be a nuclear chain reaction?', 'And that is just if two neutrons create fission reactions each round.']
['What do the scientists think of this?', 'Perhaps you can now see why so many people consider atomic energy to be an exciting energy source!']
['What kind of fission is this?', 'To make a self-sustained nuclear fission reactor with 235U, it is necessary to slow down the neutrons.']
['What does this involve?', 'Water is very effective at this, since neutrons collide with protons in water molecules and lose energy.']
['What is this referred to as?', 'Figure 22.28 shows a schematic of a reactor design called the pressurized water reactor.']
['What are control rods?', 'Control rods containing nuclides that very strongly absorb neutrons are used to adjust neutron flux.']
['What else did you learn?', 'To produce large amounts of power, reactors contain hundreds to thousands of critical masses, and the chain reaction easily becomes self-sustaining.']
['What is the control rods used for?', 'Neutron flux must be carefully regulated to avoid an out-of-control exponential increase in the rate of fission.']
['What are control rods?', 'Control rods help prevent overheating, perhaps even a meltdown or explosive disassembly.']

['What is water used for?', 'The water that is used to slow down neutrons, necessary to get them to induce fission in 235U, and achieve criticality, provides a negative feedback for temperature increase.']
['What else can it do?', 'In case the reactor overheats and boils the water to steam or is breached, the absence of water kills the chain reaction.']
['Why does it not completely stop the chain reaction?', 'Considerable heat, however, can still be generated by the reactor’s radioactive fission products.']
['What else are there to protect the reactor?', 'Other safety features, thus, need to be incorporated in the event of a loss of coolant accident, including auxiliary cooling water and pumps.']
['The average fission reaction produces 200 MeV of energy.', 'The average fission reaction produces 200 MeV of energy.']
['What are the other two facts?', 'If you were to measure the mass of the products of a nuclear reaction, you would find that their mass was slightly less than the mass of the original nucleus.']
['What are the radians and distance between those radians?', 'Those are important questions, and they can both be answered with one of the most famous equations in scientific history.']
["How does Einstein's theory relate to energy?", 'Recall that, according to Einstein’s theory, energy and mass are essentially the same thing.']

['What is fission?', 'In the case of fission, the mass of the products is less than that of the reactants because the missing mass appears in the form of the energy released in the reaction, with a constant value of c2 Joules of energy converted for each kilogram of material.']

['What is the value of c2?', 'The value of c2 is substantial—from Einstein’s equation, the amount of energy in just 1 gram of mass would be enough to support the average U.S. citizen for more than 270 years!']
['How is the mass-energy transformation?', 'The example below will show you how a mass-energy transformation of this type takes place.']
['What is Nuclear Fusion?', 'Nuclear fusion is defined as the combining, or fusing, of two nuclei and, the combining of nuclei also results in an emission of energy.']
['What is Counterintuitive about nuclear fusion?', 'For many, the concept is counterintuitive.']
["What's the difference between fission and fusion?", 'The difference between fission and fusion, which results from the size of the nuclei involved, will be addressed next.']

['What is the relationship among the three sides of a right-angled triangle according to the Py', 'Remember that the structure of a nucleus is based on the interplay of the compressive nuclear strong force and the repulsive electromagnetic force.']
['What else is important?', 'For nuclei that are less massive than iron, the nuclear force is actually stronger than that of the Coulomb force.']
['What is the result?', 'As a result, when a low-mass nucleus absorbs nucleons, the added neutrons and protons bind the nucleus more tightly.']
['What happens next?', 'The increased nuclear strong force does work on the nucleus, and energy is released.']

['What is one of the key topics of nuclear fusion?', 'Once the size of the created nucleus exceeds that of iron, the short-ranging nuclear force does not have the ability to bind a nucleus more tightly, and the emission of energy ceases.']
['What is another important fact about nuclear fusion?', 'In fact, for fusion to occur for elements of greater mass than iron, energy must be added to the system!']
['What are the two figures?', 'Figure 22.29 shows an energy-mass curve commonly used to describe nuclear reactions.']
['What is the figure?', 'Notice the location of iron (Fe) on the graph.']
['What else does the graph represent?', 'All low-mass nuclei to the left of iron release energy through fusion, while all high-mass particles to the right of iron produce energy through fission.']
['What is the major obstruction to fusion?', 'The major obstruction to fusion is the Coulomb repulsion force between nuclei.']

['What are the two ways to overcome the repulsion force between nuclei?', 'Since the attractive nuclear force that can fuse nuclei together is short ranged, the repulsion of like positive charges must be overcome in order to get nuclei close enough to induce fusion.']
['What happens with distance between the nuclei?', 'Figure 22.30 shows an approximate graph of the potential energy between two nuclei as a function of the distance between their centers.']
['What does the graph look like?', 'The graph resembles a hill with a well in its center.']
['What else is notable about the graph?', 'A ball rolled to the left must have enough kinetic energy to get over the hump before it falls into the deeper well with a net gain in energy.']
['What is so interesting about this?', 'So it is with fusion.']

['What can you tell me about repulsion?', 'If the nuclei are given enough kinetic energy to overcome the electric potential energy due to repulsion, then they can combine, release energy, and fall into a deep well.']
['How is that accomplished?', 'One way to accomplish that end is to heat fusion fuel to high temperatures so that the kinetic energy of thermal motion is sufficient to get the nuclei together.']
['What is Nuclear Fusion?', 'You might think that, in our Sun, nuclei are constantly coming into contact and fusing.']
['This is partially true.', 'However, this is only partially true.']
['What makes it only partially true?', 'Only at the Sun’s core are the particles close enough and the temperature high enough for fusion to occur!']

['How does nuclear fusion work?', 'In the series of reactions below, the Sun produces energy by fusing protons, or hydrogen nuclei ( $$\\({}^{1}\\text{H}\\)$$, by far the Sun’s most abundant nuclide) into helium nuclei  $$\\({}^{4}\\text{H}\\text{e}\\)$$ .']
['What is the proton-proton cycle?', 'The principal sequence of fusion reactions forms what is called the proton-proton cycle']
['How are these two related?', 'where  $$\\(e^{+}\\)$$  stands for a positron and  $$\\(v_{e}\\)$$  is an electron neutrino.']
['Does it provide any more information?', 'The energy in parentheses is released by the reaction.']
['Is there anything else?', 'Note that the first two reactions must occur twice for the third to be possible, so the cycle consumes six protons ( $$\\({}^{1}\\text{H}\\)$$ ) but gives back two.']
['How do the reactions relate to the others?', 'Furthermore, the two positrons produced will find two electrons and annihilate to form four more  $$\\(\\gamma\\)$$  rays, for a total of six.']
['What are the e and h?', 'where the 26.7 MeV includes the annihilation energy of the positrons and electrons and is distributed among all the reaction products.']
['What are the reactions of electrons and positrons?', 'The solar interior is dense, and the reactions occur deep in the Sun where temperatures are highest.']
['What happens in the deep sun?', 'It takes about 32,000 years for the energy to diffuse to the surface and radiate away.']
['Does the sun radiate?', 'However, the neutrinos can carry their energy out of the Sun in less than two seconds, because they interact so weakly with other matter.']
['What does negative feedback mean?', 'Negative feedback in the Sun acts as a thermostat to regulate the overall energy output.']
['What do they regulate?', 'For instance, if the interior of the Sun becomes hotter than normal, the reaction rate increases, producing energy that expands the interior.']
['Why does the expansion increase?', 'The expansion cools it and lowers the reaction rate.']
['Why does it cool down?', 'Conversely, if the interior becomes too cool, it contracts, increasing the temperature and therefore the reaction rate (see Figure 22.31).']
['How does the sun get depleted of energy?', 'Stars like the Sun are stable for billions of years, until a significant fraction of their hydrogen has been depleted.']
['what are some important points about fission?', 'The world was in political turmoil when fission was discovered in 1938.']
['what was the significance of this?', 'Compounding the troubles, the possibility of a self-sustained chain reaction was immediately recognized by leading scientists the world over.']
['what were the conceits?', 'The enormous energy known to be in nuclei, but considered inaccessible, now seemed to be available on a large scale.']

['What other important information is included in the material?', 'Within months after the announcement of the discovery of fission, Adolf Hitler banned the export of uranium from newly occupied Czechoslovakia.']
['Why did he ban the export?', 'It seemed that the possible military value of uranium had been recognized in Nazi Germany, and that a serious effort to build a nuclear bomb had begun.']
['Who were the scientists that developed nuclear weapons?', 'Alarmed scientists, many of whom fled Nazi Germany, decided to take action.']
['What was the famous person?', 'None was more famous or revered than Einstein.']
['What was the name of the famous person?', 'It was felt that his help was needed to get the American government to make a serious effort at constructing nuclear weapons as a matter of survival.']
['Who wrote the letter?', 'Leo Szilard, a Hungarian physicist who had emigrated to America, took a draft of a letter to Einstein, who, although a pacifist, signed the final version.']
['What was the letter for?', 'The letter was for President Franklin Roosevelt, warning of the German potential to build extremely powerful bombs of a new type.']
['When was the letter sent?', 'It was sent in August of 1939, just before the German invasion of Poland that marked the start of World War II.']
['What happened in 1941?', 'It was not until December 6, 1941, the day before the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor, that the United States made a massive commitment to building a nuclear bomb.']
['Who was building the bomb?', 'The top secret Manhattan Project was a crash program aimed at beating the Germans.']

['How long was the program?', 'It was carried out in remote locations, such as Los Alamos, New Mexico, whenever possible, and eventually came to cost billions of dollars and employ the efforts of more than 100,000 people.']
['Who were some of the scientists?', 'J. Robert Oppenheimer (1904–1967), a talented physicist, was chosen to head the project.']
['What did they accomplish?', 'The first major step was made by Enrico Fermi and his group in December 1942, when they completed the first self-sustaining nuclear reactor.']
['What happened next?', 'This first atomic pile, built in a squash court at the University of Chicago, proved that a fission chain reaction was possible.']
['What was the Manhattan Project?', 'Plutonium was recognized as easier to fission with neutrons and, hence, a superior fission material very early in the Manhattan Project.']
['What else was learned about the Manhattan Project?', 'Plutonium availability was uncertain, and so a uranium bomb was developed simultaneously.']
['What did the project teach us?', 'Figure 22.32 shows a gun-type bomb, which takes two subcritical uranium masses and shoots them together.']

['What else did you find interesting about the article?', 'To get an appreciable yield, the critical mass must be held together by the explosive charges inside the cannon barrel for a few microseconds.']
['How was the device made?', 'Since the buildup of the uranium chain reaction is relatively slow, the device to bring the critical mass together can be relatively simple.']
['Did they use a neutron source?', 'Owing to the fact that the rate of spontaneous fission is low, a neutron source is at the center the assembled critical mass.']
['What is an important thing that happened in this section?', 'Plutonium’s special properties necessitated a more sophisticated critical mass assembly, shown schematically in Figure 22.33.']

['What is a sophisticated critical mass assembly?', 'A spherical mass of plutonium is surrounded by shaped charges (high explosives that focus their blast) that implode the plutonium, crushing it into a smaller volume to form a critical mass.']

['What can be done with an implosion technique?', 'The implosion technique is faster and more effective, because it compresses three-dimensionally rather than one-dimensionally as in the gun-type bomb.']
['What else did you find interesting?', 'Again, a neutron source is included to initiate the chain reaction.']
['What was the first nuclear weapon built?', 'Owing to its complexity, the plutonium bomb needed to be tested before there could be any attempt to use it.']
['Where did these tests occur?', 'On July 16, 1945, the test named Trinity was conducted in the isolated Alamogordo Desert in New Mexico, about 200 miles south of Los Alamos (see Figure 22.34).']
['What was the result of these tests?', 'A new age had begun.']
['What was the yield of that bomb?', 'The yield of the Trinity device was about 10 kilotons (kT), the equivalent of 5,000 of the largest conventional bombs.']

['When did the atomic bomb first drop?', 'Although Germany surrendered on May 7, 1945, Japan had been steadfastly refusing to surrender for many months, resulting large numbers of civilian and military casualties.']
['What else did you find interesting?', 'Invasion plans by the Allies estimated a million casualties of their own and untold losses of Japanese lives.']
['Did they try to stop the bomb from dropping?', 'The bomb was viewed as a way to end the war.']
['Who had first commissioned the bomb?', 'The first bomb used was a gun-type uranium bomb dropped on Hiroshima on August 6 by the United States.']
['How did the bomb kill the people?', 'Its yield of about 15 kT destroyed the city and killed an estimated 80,000 people, with 100,000 more being seriously injured.']
['What was the second bomb used for?', 'The second bomb was an implosion-type plutonium bomb dropped on Nagasaki only three days later.']

['How did that bomb kill the people?', 'Its 20-kT yield killed at least 50,000 people, something less than Hiroshima because of the hilly terrain and the fact that it was a few kilometers off target.']
['What other information is important to know?', 'The Japanese were told that one bomb a week would be dropped until they surrendered unconditionally, which they did on August 14.']
['Did they use more than one bomb in the war?', 'In actuality, the United States had only enough plutonium for one more bomb, as yet unassembled.']

['What did scientists do to produce weapons?', 'Knowing that fusion produces several times more energy per kilogram of fuel than fission, some scientists pursued the idea of constructing a fusion bomb.']

['Did the US produce the first fusion bomb?', 'The first such bomb was detonated by the United States several years after the first fission bombs, on October 31, 1952, at Eniwetok Atoll in the Pacific Ocean.']
['Was it a success?', 'It had a yield of 10 megatons (MT), about 670 times that of the fission bomb that destroyed Hiroshima.']

['Did other countries do this?', 'The Soviet Union followed with a fusion device of its own in August 1953, and a weapons race, beyond the aim of this text to discuss, continued until the end of the Cold War.']
['What did you learn?', 'Figure 22.35 shows a simple diagram of how a thermonuclear bomb is constructed.']
['Why is that?', 'A fission bomb is exploded next to fusion fuel in the solid form of lithium deuteride.']

['What happens after the explosion?', 'Before the shock wave blows it apart,  $$\\(\\gamma\\)$$  rays heat and compress the fuel, and neutrons create tritium through the reaction  $$\\(n +^{6}\\text{L}\\text{i}\\rightarrow^{3}\\text{H} +^{4}\\text{H}\\text{e}\\)$$ .']
['What is the next section?', 'Additional fusion and fission fuels are enclosed in a dense shell of  $$\\({}^{238}\\text{U}\\)$$ .']

['What is the shell for?', 'At the same time that the uranium shell reflects the neutrons back into the fuel to enhance its fusion, the fast-moving neutrons cause the plentiful and inexpensive  $$\\({}^{238}\\text{U}\\)$$  to fission, part of what allows thermonuclear bombs to be so large.']
["What's a key aspect of this material?", 'Of course, not all applications of nuclear physics are as destructive as the weapons described above.']
['What other applications of physics are used?', 'Hundreds of nuclear fission power plants around the world attest to the fact that controlled fission is both practical and economical.']
['Why does it have this purpose?', 'Given growing concerns over global warming, nuclear power is often seen as a viable alternative to energy derived from fossil fuels.']
['What was the purpose of medical applications?', 'Applications of nuclear physics have become an integral part of modern life.']

['What types of medical applications have they become?', 'From the bone scan that detects one cancer to the radioiodine treatment that cures another, nuclear radiation has diagnostic and therapeutic effects on medicine.']
['What other types of medical imaging techniques do we learn about?', 'A host of medical imaging techniques employ nuclear radiation.']
['What are some of the advantages of using nuclear radiation?', 'First,  $$\\(\\gamma\\)$$  radiation can easily penetrate tissue; hence, it is a useful probe to monitor conditions inside the body.']

['What other benefits does it have?', 'Second, nuclear radiation depends on the nuclide and not on the chemical compound it is in, so that a radioactive nuclide can be put into a compound designed for specific purposes.']
['What type of compound is used to create it?', 'When that is done, the compound is said to be tagged.']
['What are some of the uses of tagged compounds?', 'A tagged compound used for medical purposes is called a radiopharmaceutical.']

['What else can radiopharmaceuticals be used for?', 'Radiation detectors external to the body can determine the location and concentration of a radiopharmaceutical to yield medically useful information.']
['What are some examples of using this?', 'For example, certain drugs are concentrated in inflamed regions of the body, and their locations can aid diagnosis and treatment as seen in Figure 22.37.']

['What other applications can you think of?', 'Another application utilizes a radiopharmaceutical that the body sends to bone cells, particularly those that are most active, to detect cancerous tumors or healing points.']
['What happens next?', 'Images can then be produced of such bone scans.']
['What other uses can you give me?', 'Clever use of radioisotopes determines the functioning of body organs, such as blood flow, heart muscle activity, and iodine uptake in the thyroid gland.']

['What is an example?', 'For instance, a radioactive form of iodine can be used to monitor the thyroid, a radioactive thallium salt can be used to follow the blood stream, and radioactive gallium can be used for cancer imaging.']
['What is one thing that you learned in this section?', 'Once a radioactive compound has been ingested, a device like that shown in Figure 22.38 is used to monitor nuclear activity.']
['What type of device is used?', 'The device, called an Anger camera or gamma camera uses a piece of lead with holes bored through it.']
['What is the second device used?', 'The gamma rays are redirected through the collimator to narrow their beam, and are then interpreted using a device called a scintillator.']
['What does this device do?', 'The computer analysis of detector signals produces an image.']
