['What are the drawbacks?', 'One of the disadvantages of this detection method is that there is no depth information (i.e., it provides a two-dimensional view of the tumor as opposed to a three-dimensional view), because radiation from any location under that detector produces a signal.']

['What is the most important aspect of Medical Imaging?', 'Single-photon-emission computer tomography (SPECT) used in conjunction with a CT scanner improves on the process carried out by the gamma camera.']

['How is the SPECT achieved?', 'Figure 22.39 shows a patient in a circular array of SPECT detectors that may be stationary or rotated, with detector output used by a computer to construct a detailed image.']
['What type of images are obtained?', 'The spatial resolution of this technique is poor, but the three-dimensional image created results in a marked improvement in contrast.']
['What kind of image is it?', 'Positron emission tomography (or PET) scans utilize images produced by  $$\\(\\beta^{+}\\)$$  emitters.']
['What is the role of the positron?', 'When the emitted positron β+ encounters an electron, mutual annihilation occurs, producing two γ rays.']

['What is the role of the two  rays?', 'Those  $$\\(\\gamma\\)$$  rays have identical 0.511 MeV energies (the energy comes from the destruction of an electron or positron mass) and they move directly away from each other, allowing detectors to determine their point of origin accurately (as shown in Figure 22.40).']

['What else does the PET scan consist of?', 'It requires detectors on opposite sides to simultaneously (i.e., at the same time) detect photons of 0.511 MeV energy and utilizes computer imaging techniques similar to those in SPECT and CT scans.']
['What is the role of PET?', 'PET is used extensively for diagnosing brain disorders.']
['What does it note?', 'It can note decreased metabolism in certain regions that accompany Alzheimer’s disease.']
['What else is it used to check?', 'PET can also locate regions in the brain that become active when a person carries out specific activities, such as speaking, closing his or her eyes, and so on.']
['How does ionizing radiation effect the human body?', 'We hear many seemingly contradictory things about the biological effects of ionizing radiation.']
['How are the effects contradictory?', 'It can cause cancer, burns, and hair loss, and yet it is used to treat and even cure cancer.']
['What are the contradictions?', 'Once again, there is an underlying simplicity in nature, even in complicated biological organisms.']

['What is the underlying simplicity?', 'All the effects of ionizing radiation on biological tissue can be understood by knowing that ionizing radiation affects molecules within cells, particularly DNA molecules.']
['What else did you find out about the study material?', 'Let us take a brief look at molecules within cells and how cells operate.']

['What else do you find out about cells?', 'Cells have long, double-helical DNA molecules containing chemical patterns called genetic codes that govern the function and processes undertaken by the cells.']
['What happens if the dna is damaged?', 'Damage to DNA consists of breaks in chemical bonds or other changes in the structural features of the DNA chain, leading to changes in the genetic code.']
['How much damage can happen?', 'In human cells, we can have as many as a million individual instances of damage to DNA per cell per day.']
['Why is that important?', 'The repair ability of DNA is vital for maintaining the integrity of the genetic code and for the normal functioning of the entire organism.']
['What happens with dna damaged?', 'A cell with a damaged ability to repair DNA, which could have been induced by ionizing radiation, can do one of the following:']
['What does senescence cause?', 'The cell can go into an irreversible state of dormancy, known as senescence.']
['How is cell death called?', 'The cell can commit suicide, known as programmed cell death.']
['What causes a tumor?', 'The cell can go into unregulated cell division, leading to tumors and cancers.']

['What does the body do to ionizing radiation?', 'Since ionizing radiation damages the DNA, ionizing radiation has its greatest effect on cells that rapidly reproduce, including most types of cancer.']
['Why does ionizing radiation have its greatest effect on cells that rapidly reproduce?', 'Thus, cancer cells are more sensitive to radiation than normal cells and can be killed by it easily.']
['How does ionizing radiation cause cancer?', 'Cancer is characterized by a malfunction of cell reproduction, and can also be caused by ionizing radiation.']
['How can ionizing radiation cure cancer?', 'There is no contradiction to say that ionizing radiation can be both a cure and a cause.']
['Why is radiotherapy so effective against cancer?', 'Radiotherapy is effective against cancer because cancer cells reproduce rapidly and, consequently, are more sensitive to radiation.']
['Why is it necessary to limit the dose to normal cells?', 'The central problem in radiotherapy is to make the dose for cancer cells as high as possible while limiting the dose for normal cells.']

['What other important information did you find in this section?', 'The ratio of abnormal cells killed to normal cells killed is called the therapeutic ratio, and all radiotherapy techniques are designed to enhance that ratio.']
['What other techniques are used to enhance that ratio?', 'Radiation can be concentrated in cancerous tissue by a number of techniques.']
['What type of techniques are used?', 'One of the most prevalent techniques for well-defined tumors is a geometric technique shown in Figure 22.41.']
['How does the technique work?', 'A narrow beam of radiation is passed through the patient from a variety of directions with a common crossing point in the tumor.']
['Why is this important?', 'The technique concentrates the dose in the tumor while spreading it out over a large volume of normal tissue.']
['What are the uses of radiotherapy?', 'Another use of radiation therapy is through radiopharmaceuticals.']
['Why are radiopharmaceuticals used?', 'Cleverly, radiopharmaceuticals are used in cancer therapy by tagging antibodies with radioisotopes.']
['Where do those antibodies come from?', 'Those antibodies are extracted from the patient, cultured, loaded with a radioisotope, and then returned to the patient.']
['What happens after returning those antibodies?', 'The antibodies are then concentrated almost entirely in the tissue they developed to fight, thus localizing the radiation in abnormal tissue.']
['What kind of iodine is used?', 'This method is used with radioactive iodine to fight thyroid cancer.']

['What are the side effects?', 'While the therapeutic ratio can be quite high for such short-range radiation, there can be a significant dose for organs that eliminate radiopharmaceuticals from the body, such as the liver, kidneys, and bladder.']
['How is it used?', 'As with most radiotherapy, the technique is limited by the tolerable amount of damage to the normal tissue.']
['What was Radiation Dosage?', 'To quantitatively discuss the biological effects of ionizing radiation, we need a radiation dose unit that is directly related to those effects.']
['What are the effects of radiation?', 'To do define such a unit, it is important to consider both the biological organism and the radiation itself.']
['What is the definition of Radiation dose?', 'Knowing that the amount of ionization is proportional to the amount of deposited energy, we define a radiation dose unit called the rad.']
['What is the Radiation Dosage unit?', 'It 1/100 of a joule of ionizing energy deposited per kilogram of tissue, which is']
['How much dose would an affected tissue receive if it was exposed to a certain amount of', 'and the unaffected tissue would have a zero rad dose.']
['How do you calculate radiation doses?', 'When calculating radiation doses, you divide the energy absorbed by the mass of affected tissue.']
['What else do you need to know about calculating radiation doses?', 'You must specify the affected region, such as the whole body or forearm in addition to giving the numerical dose in rads.']
['What is the significance of 1 rad?', 'Although the energy per kilogram in 1 rad is small, it can still have significant effects.']
['What is another significant factor?', 'Since only a few eV cause ionization, just 0.01 J of ionizing energy can create a huge number of ion pairs and have an effect at the cellular level.']

['What else did you learn about this unit?', 'The effects of ionizing radiation may be directly proportional to the dose in rads, but they also depend on the type of radiation and the type of tissue.']

['What does type of radiation refer to?', 'That is, for a given dose in rads, the effects depend on whether the radiation is  $$\\(\\alpha\\)$$,  $$\\(\\beta\\)$$,  $$\\(\\gamma\\)$$, X-ray, or some other type of ionizing radiation.']

['Is there any additional information about this topic?', 'The relative biological effectiveness (RBE) relates to the amount of biological damage that can occur from a given type of radiation and is given in Table 22.4 for several types of ionizing radiation.']
['What dose units are used?', 'A final dose unit more closely related to the effect of radiation on biological tissue is called the roentgen equivalent man, or rem.']
['How is the rem defined?', 'A combination of all factors mentioned previously, the roentgen equivalent man is defined to be the dose in rads multiplied by the relative biological effectiveness.']
['What does a large-scale effect have?', 'The large-scale effects of radiation on humans can be divided into two categories: immediate effects and long-term effects.']
['How is an immediate effect characterized?', 'Table 22.5 gives the immediate effects of whole-body exposures received in less than one day.']
['Why is a long-term effect important?', 'If the radiation exposure is spread out over more time, greater doses are needed to cause the effects listed.']
['How does the dose impact a person?', 'Any dose less than 10 rem is called a low dose, a dose 10 to 100 rem is called a moderate dose, and anything greater than 100 rem is called a high dose.']
['What are the four basic forces?', 'Despite the apparent complexity within the universe, there remain just four basic forces.']
['What are the four basic forces?', 'These forces are responsible for all interactions known to science: from the very small to the very large to those that we experience in our day-to-day lives.']

['What do the four basic forces describe?', 'These forces describe the movement of galaxies, the chemical reactions in our laboratories, the structure within atomic nuclei, and the cause of radioactive decay.']
['What do they describe?', 'They describe the true cause behind familiar terms like friction and the normal force.']
['Are the four forces known as fundamental?', 'These four basic forces are known as fundamental because they alone are responsible for all observations of forces in nature.']
['What are the four fundamental forces?', 'The four fundamental forces are gravity, electromagnetism, weak nuclear force, and strong nuclear force.']
['What are the forces?', 'The gravitational force is most familiar to us because it describes so many of our common observations.']
['What is the gravitational force used for?', 'It explains why a dropped ball falls to the ground and why our planet orbits the Sun.']
['What else can it do?', 'It gives us the property of weight and determines much about the motion of objects in our daily lives.']

['How does this force affect our daily lives?', 'Because gravitational force acts between all objects of mass and has the ability to act over large distances, the gravitational force can be used to explain much of what we observe and can even describe the motion of objects on astronomical scales!']

['What are some of the challenges that scientists are facing to fully understand gravitational force?', 'That said, gravity is incredibly weak compared to the other fundamental forces and is the weakest of all of the fundamental forces.']
['How is gravity different than the other forces?', 'Consider this:']
['What other examples of gravity are out there?', 'The entire mass of Earth is needed to hold an iron nail to the ground.']
['What can be done with this force?', 'Yet with a simple magnet, the force of gravity can be overcome, allowing the nail to accelerate upward through space.']
['What are some of the functions of an electromagnetic force?', 'The electromagnetic force is responsible for both electrostatic interactions and the magnetic force seen between bar magnets.']
['What is the coulomb force?', 'When focusing on the electrostatic relationship between two charged particles, the electromagnetic force is known as the coulomb force.']

['What is the other function of the electromagnetic force?', 'The electromagnetic force is an important force in the chemical and biological sciences, as it is responsible for molecular connections like ionic bonding and hydrogen bonding.']
['How else is the force utilized?', 'Additionally, the electromagnetic force is behind the common physics forces of friction and the normal force.']
['What is the relationship between these forces?', 'Like the gravitational force, the electromagnetic force is an inverse square law.']
['Can you tell me what the inverse square law says?', 'However, the electromagnetic force does not exist between any two objects of mass, only those that are charged.']
['What is the electromagnetic force?', 'When considering the structure of an atom, the electromagnetic force is somewhat apparent.']
['What is the attraction force?', 'After all, the electrons are held in place by an attractive force from the nucleus.']
['What is the Coulomb force?', 'After all, if all protons are positive, it makes sense that the coulomb force between the protons would repel the nucleus apart immediately.']
['What is the neutron force?', 'Scientists theorized that another force must exist within the nucleus to keep it together.']

['Why do they believe that?', 'They further theorized that this nuclear force must be significantly stronger than gravity, which has been observed and measured for centuries, and also stronger than the electromagnetic force, which would cause the protons to want to accelerate away from each other.']
['what does the strong nuclear force mean?', 'The strong nuclear force is an attractive force that exists between all nucleons.']

['what is the strongest force at short ranges?', 'This force, which acts equally between proton-proton connections, proton-neutron connections, and neutron-neutron connections, is the strongest of all forces at short ranges.']
['what does the diameter of a single proton mean?', 'However, at a distance of 10–13 cm, or the diameter of a single proton, the force dissipates to zero.']
['what is the diameter of the nucleus?', 'If the nucleus is large (it has many nucleons), then the distance between each nucleon could be much larger than the diameter of a single proton.']
['What is the weak nuclear force?', 'The weak nuclear force is responsible for beta decay, as seen in the equation  $$\\[{}_{Z}^{A}X_{N}\\operatorname{~\\rightarrow~}\\']
['What else is in that equation?', '~_{Z + 1}^{A}Y_{N–1}~ + ~e~ + ~v.\\]$$  Recall that beta decay is when a beta particle is ejected from an atom.']
['What is the strong nuclear force?', 'In order to accelerate away from the nucleus, the particle must be acted on by a force.']
['Who was the first to visualize the force?', 'Enrico Fermi was the first to envision this type of force.']
['What else did he understand about the force?', 'While this force is appropriately labeled, it remains stronger than the gravitational force.']
['What is the ionizing radiation?', 'However, its range is even smaller than that of the strong force, as can be seen in Table 23.1.']
['Is there anything else interesting about the study material?', 'The weak nuclear force is more important than it may appear at this time, as will be addressed when we discuss quarks.']

['What were the difficulties?', 'Just as it troubled Einstein prior to formulating the gravitational field theory, the concept of forces acting over a distance had greatly troubled particle physicists.']
["What was Yukawa's contribution?", 'These mysterious interactions were first considered by Hideki Yukawa in 1935 and laid the foundation for much of what we now understand about particle physics.']
["What is Yukawa's focus?", 'Hideki Yukawa’s focus was on the strong nuclear force and, in particular, its incredibly short range.']
['What was his idea?', 'His idea was a blend of particles, relativity, and quantum mechanics that was applicable to all four forces.']

['What is his model?', 'Yukawa proposed that the nuclear force is actually transmitted by the exchange of particles, called carrier particles, and that what we commonly refer to as the force’s field consists of these carrier particles.']

['How are particles exchanged?', 'Specifically for the strong nuclear force, Yukawa proposed that a previously unknown particle, called a pion, is exchanged between nucleons, transmitting the force between them.']
['What is a particle called a pion?', 'Figure 23.3 illustrates how a pion would carry a force between a proton and a neutron.']

["What did Yukawa's strong force have to do with it?", 'In Yukawa’s strong force, the carrier particle is assumed to be transmitted at the speed of light and is continually transferred between the two nucleons shown.']
['What other work does Yukawa do?', 'The particle that Yukawa predicted was finally discovered within cosmic rays in 1947.']
['What is the pion?', 'Its name, the pion, stands for pi meson, where meson means medium mass; it’s a medium mass because it is smaller than a nucleon but larger than an electron.']
['What else is interesting in the article?', 'Yukawa launched the field that is now called quantum chromodynamics, and the carrier particles are now called gluons due to their strong binding power.']
['Why did the particle name change?', 'The reason for the change in the particle name will be explained when quarks are discussed later in this section.']
['What is the strongest force?', 'As you may assume, the strong force is not the only force with a carrier particle.']
['What is the weakest force?', 'Nuclear decay from the weak force also requires a particle transfer.']
['How are these particle particles named?', 'In the weak force are the following three: the weak negative carrier, W–; the weak positive carrier, W+; and the zero charge carrier, Z0.']

['Why did this occur?', 'As we will see, Fermi inferred that these particles must carry mass, as the total mass of the products of nuclear decay is slightly larger than the total mass of all reactants after nuclear decay.']
['What is the carrier particle for the electromagnetic force?', 'The carrier particle for the electromagnetic force is, not surprisingly, the photon.']

['What can a photon be used for?', 'After all, just as a lightbulb can emit photons from a charged tungsten filament, the photon can be used to transfer information from one electrically charged particle to another.']
['What is the carrier particle for gravity?', 'Finally, the graviton is the proposed carrier particle for gravity.']
['Is the graviton currently being researched?', 'While it has not yet been found, scientists are currently looking for evidence of its existence (see Boundless Physics: Searching for the Graviton).']
['What do you find interesting about Figure 23.4?', 'Figure 23.4 shows a virtual photon transmitted from one positively charged particle to another.']
['What is a virtual photon?', 'The transmitted photon is referred to as a virtual particle because it cannot be directly observed while transmitting the force.']
['What is Figure 23.5?', 'Figure 23.5 shows a way of graphing the exchange of a virtual photon between the two positively charged particles.']
['What is a Feynman diagram?', 'This graph of time versus position is called a Feynman diagram, after the brilliant American physicist Richard Feynman (1918–1988), who developed it.']
["What's the purpose of a Feynman diagram?", 'The Feynman diagram should be read from the bottom up to show the movement of particles over time.']

['What else can you tell me about the diagram?', 'In it, you can see that the left proton is propelled leftward from the photon emission, while the right proton feels an impulse to the right when the photon is received.']

["What's some interesting information that you want to share?", 'In addition to the Feynman diagram, Richard Feynman was one of the theorists who developed the field of quantum electrodynamics (QED), which further describes electromagnetic interactions on the submicroscopic scale.']
['Did he receive any awards for this?', 'For this work, he shared the 1965 Nobel Prize with Julian Schwinger and S.I. Tomonaga.']
['What other information about the diagram did you find interesting?', 'A Feynman diagram explaining the strong force interaction hypothesized by Yukawa can be seen in Figure 23.6.']
['What else does the diagram show?', 'Here, you can see the change in particle type due to the exchange of the pi meson.']
['What does this mean?', 'The relative masses of the listed carrier particles describe something valuable about the four fundamental forces, as can be seen in Table 23.2.']

['How is this determined?', 'W bosons (consisting of  $$\\(\\text{W}^{-}\\)$$  and  $$\\(\\text{W}^{+}\\)$$  bosons) and Z bosons ( $$\\(\\text{Z}^{0}\\)$$  bosons), carriers of the weak nuclear force, are nearly 1,000 times more massive than pions, carriers of the strong nuclear force.']

['What else did you find interesting?', 'Simultaneously, the distance that the weak nuclear force can be transmitted is approximately  $$\\(\\frac{1}{1,000}\\)$$  times the strong force transmission distance.']

['What was the next topic of discussion?', 'Unlike carrier particles, which have a limited range, the photon is a massless particle that has no limit to the transmission distance of the electromagnetic force.']
['Does it mean anything else?', 'This relationship leads scientists to understand that the yet-unfound graviton is likely massless as well.']
['What is this study material about?', 'Before looking at all the particles that make up our universe, let us first examine some of the machines that create them.']

['How do accelerators create matter?', 'The fundamental process in creating unknown particles is to accelerate known particles, such as protons or electrons, and direct a beam of them toward a target.']
['What is the target?', 'Collisions with target nuclei provide a wealth of information, such as information obtained by Rutherford in the gold foil experiment.']
['What else can be done with accelerators?', 'If the energy of the incoming particles is large enough, new matter can even be created in the collision.']
['How does the mass energy equivalence work?', 'The more energy input or ΔE, the more matter m can be created, according to mass energy equivalence  $$\\(m = \\text{Δ}E/c^{2}\\)$$ .']
['What else is interesting about this article?', 'Limitations are placed on what can occur by known conservation laws, such as conservation of mass-energy, momentum, and charge.']
['What else is limited by known laws?', 'Even more interesting are the unknown limitations provided by nature.']
['What are the unknown limitations?', 'While some expected reactions do occur, others do not, and still other unexpected reactions may appear.']
['What happens when there are unexpected reactions?', 'New laws are revealed, and the vast majority of what we know about particle physics has come from accelerator laboratories.']
['What is most interesting about accelerators?', 'It is the particle physicist’s favorite indoor sport.']
['When were accelerators developed?', 'Our earliest model of a particle accelerator comes from the Van de Graaff generator.']
['How did it work?', 'The relatively simple device, which you have likely seen in physics demonstrations, can be manipulated to produce potentials as great as 50 million volts.']

['What else did it do?', 'While these machines do not have energies large enough to produce new particles, analysis of their accelerated ions was instrumental in exploring several aspects of the nucleus.']
['What happened in 1929?', 'Another equally famous early accelerator is the cyclotron, invented in 1930 by the American physicist, E.O. Lawrence (1901–1958).']
['What was the figure?', 'Figure 23.8 is a visual representation with more detail.']
['What is the cyclotron?', 'Cyclotrons use fixed-frequency alternating electric fields to accelerate particles.']
['What does the magnetic field do?', 'The particles spiral outward in a magnetic field, making increasingly larger radius orbits during acceleration.']
['What happens after that?', 'This clever arrangement allows the successive addition of electric potential energy with each loop.']
['What happens when it is fully charged?', 'As a result, greater particle energies are possible than in a Van de Graaff generator.']
['What is synchrotron?', 'A synchrotron is a modification of the cyclotron in which particles continually travel in a fixed-radius orbit, increasing speed each time.']
['What is synchrotron used for?', 'Accelerating voltages are synchronized with the particles to accelerate them, hence the name.']
['What else can synchrotron be used for?', 'Additionally, magnetic field strength is increased to keep the orbital radius constant as energy increases.']
['How does synchrotron work?', 'A ring of magnets and accelerating tubes, as shown in Figure 23.9, are the major components of synchrotrons.']
['What is a superconductor?', 'High-energy particles require strong magnetic fields to steer them, so superconducting magnets are commonly employed.']

['What other interesting information do you want to know about the synchrotron?', 'Still limited by achievable magnetic field strengths, synchrotrons need to be very large at very high energies since the radius of a high-energy particle’s orbit is very large.']
['What is acceleration?', 'To further probe the nucleus, physicists need accelerators of greater energy and detectors of shorter wavelength.']
['How is this accomplished?', 'To do so requires not only greater funding but greater ingenuity as well.']

['Is there anything else interesting about the content of this article?', 'Colliding beams used at both the Fermi National Accelerator Laboratory (Fermilab; see Figure 23.11) near Chicago and the LHC in Switzerland are designed to reduce energy loss in particle collisions.']
['What is a stationary particle detector?', 'Typical stationary particle detectors lose a large amount of energy to the recoiling target struck by the accelerating particle.']

['How do colliding beams work?', 'By providing head-on collisions between particles moving in opposite directions, colliding beams make it possible to create particles with momenta and kinetic energies near zero.']
['What happens after that?', 'This allows for particles of greater energy and mass to be created.']
['What else can you tell me about this part of the article?', 'Figure 23.10 is a schematic representation of this effect.']
['How is linear accelerator used?', 'In addition to circular accelerators, linear accelerators can be used to reduce energy radiation losses.']

['Are there any famous linear accelerators?', 'The Stanford Linear Accelerator Center (now called the SLAC National Accelerator Laboratory) in California is home to the largest such accelerator in the world.']
['What did Isaac Newton say about atoms and space?', '“The first principles of the universe are atoms and empty space.']
['What else did he say?', 'Everything else is merely thought to exist…”']

['Is there any information provided about quarks in the article?', '“… Further, the atoms are unlimited in size and number, and they are borne along with the whole universe in a vortex, and thereby generate all composite things—fire, water, air, earth.']
['Does this article go into detail about why all composite things are made of atoms?', 'For even these are conglomerations of given atoms.']
['Is there anything interesting in this article?', 'And it because of their solidity that these atoms are impassive and unalterable.”']
["What was Diogenes Laertius' view of fundamental particles?", 'The search for fundamental particles is nothing new.']

['What were the earlier views on fundamental particles?', 'Atomists of the Greek and Indian empires, like Democritus of fifth century B.C., openly wondered about the most finite components of our universe.']

['What was significant about this view?', 'Though dormant for centuries, curiosity about the atomic nature of matter was reinvigorated by Rutherford’s gold foil experiment and the discovery of the nucleus.']

['What were the smallest particles that scientists have observed?', 'By the early 1930s, scientists believed they had fully determined the tiniest constituents of matter—in the form of the proton, neutron, and electron.']
['What is the relationship among the three sides of a right-angled triangle according to the Py', 'This would be only partially true.']
['what else did the article say?', 'At present, scientists know that there are hundreds of particles not unlike our electron and nucleons, all making up what some have termed the particle zoo.']

['What else did they find in the zoo?', 'While we are confident that the electron remains fundamental, it is surrounded by a plethora of similar sounding terms, like leptons, hadrons, baryons, and mesons.']
["Why isn't every particle considered fundamental?", 'Even though not every particle is considered fundamental, they all play a vital role in understanding the intricate structure of our universe.']
['What is the definition of a fundamental particle?', 'A fundamental particle is defined as a particle with no substructure and no finite size.']
['What are the three types of fundamental particles?', 'According to the Standard Model, there are three types of fundamental particles: leptons, quarks, and carrier particles.']
['What are carrier particles?', 'As you may recall, carrier particles are responsible for transmitting fundamental forces between their interacting masses.']
['What are leptons?', 'Leptons are a group of six particles not bound by the strong nuclear force, of which the electron is one.']
['What are quarks?', 'As for quarks, they are the fundamental building blocks of a group of particles called hadrons, a group that includes both the proton and the neutron.']
['What is the major tenet of his theory of geometry?', 'Now for a brief history of quarks.']
['Who first proposed quarks?', 'Quarks were first proposed independently by American physicists Murray Gell-Mann and George Zweig in 1963.']
['What were the original 3 quarks proposed?', 'Originally, three quark types—or flavors—were proposed with the names up (u), down (d), and strange (s).']
['What is a fact about this chapter?', 'At first, physicists expected that, with sufficient energy, we should be able to free quarks and observe them directly.']

['How did this theory fail?', 'However, this has not proved possible, as the current understanding is that the force holding quarks together is incredibly great and, much like a spring, increases in magnitude as the quarks are separated.']
['What else is known about quarks?', 'As a result, when large energies are put into collisions, other particles are created—but no quarks emerge.']
['What else is known about quarks?', 'With that in mind, there is compelling evidence for the existence of quarks.']

['What is this evidence?', 'By 1967, experiments at the SLAC National Accelerator Laboratory scattering 20-GeV electrons from protons produced results like Rutherford had obtained for the nucleus nearly 60 years earlier.']

['What was the study about?', 'The SLAC scattering experiments showed unambiguously that there were three point-like (meaning they had sizes considerably smaller than the probe’s wavelength) charges inside the proton as seen in Figure 23.12.']
['Why did he suggest this?', 'This evidence made all but the most skeptical admit that there was validity to the quark substructure of hadrons.']
['What are the strange quarks?', 'The inclusion of the strange quark with Zweig and Gell-Mann’s model concerned physicists.']

['How did he know that?', 'While the up and down quarks demonstrated fairly clear symmetry and were present in common fundamental particles like protons and neutrons, the strange quark did not have a counterpart of its own.']
['What was his biggest concern?', 'This thought, coupled with the four known leptons at the time, caused scientists to predict that a fourth quark, yet to be found, also existed.']
['When did the charmed quark first appear?', 'In 1974, two groups of physicists independently discovered a particle with this new quark, labeled charmed.']
['What did this lead to?', 'This completed the second exotic quark pair, strange (s) and charmed (c).']
['Why were the final pair of quarks proposed?', 'A final pair of quarks was proposed when a third pair of leptons was discovered in 1975.']
['What was the final pair of quarks?', 'The existence of the bottom (b) quark and the top (t) quark was verified through experimentation in 1976 and 1995, respectively.']

['Why was it so long between the discovery of the bottom quark and the verification of the top', 'While it may seem odd that so much time would elapse between the original quark discovery in 1967 and the verification of the top quark in 1995, keep in mind that each quark discovered had a progressively larger mass.']
['Why is that?', 'As a result, each new quark has required more energy to discover.']
['What kind of charges are there?', 'One of the most confounding traits of quarks is their electric charge.']

['Why is this?', 'Long assumed to be discrete, and specifically a multiple of the elementary charge of the electron, the electric charge of an individual quark is fractional and thus seems to violate a presumed tenet of particle physics.']

['Are there any other important aspects of the charge?', 'The fractional charge of quarks, which are  $$\\(\\pm \\left( \\frac{2}{3} \\right)q_{e}\\)$$  and  $$\\(\\pm \\left( \\frac{1}{3} \\right)q_{e}\\)$$, are the only structures found in nature with a nonintegral number of charge  $$\\(q\\)$$ .']
['Are there any other important aspects of the charges?', 'However, note that despite this odd construction, the fractional value of the quark does not violate the quantum nature of the charge.']

['Does this violate the quantum nature of the charge?', 'After all, free quarks cannot be found in nature, and all quarks are bound into arrangements in which an integer number of charge is constructed.']
['What are some other quarks?', 'Table 23.3 shows the six known quarks, in addition to their antiquark components, as will be discussed later in this section.']

['What is the distinction between flavor and color?', 'While the term flavor is used to differentiate between types of quarks, the concept of color is more analogous to the electric charge in that it is primarily responsible for the force interactions between quarks.']
['Why does he say the electrostatic force is responsible for flavor?', 'Note—Take a moment to think about the electrostatic force.']
['What is the electrostatic force?', 'It is the electric charge that causes attraction and repulsion.']
['Is that the same as flavor?', 'It is the same case here but with a color charge.']

['What other characteristics of the quarks are accounted for by color?', 'The three colors available to a quark are red, green, and blue, with antiquarks having colors of anti-red (or cyan), anti-green (or magenta), and anti-blue (or yellow).']
['What is an example of a question that you found interesting in this material?', 'After all, the quarks are not actually colored with visible light.']
['Why are quarks described as colors?', 'The reason colors are used is because the properties of a quark are analogous to the three primary and secondary colors mentioned above.']
['What is the analogy to light?', 'Just as different colors of light can be combined to create white, different colors of quark may be combined to construct a particle like a proton or neutron.']
['What else did the writer say?', 'In fact, for each hadron, the quarks must combine such that their color sums to white!']
['What does combining different colors produce?', 'Recall that two up quarks and one down quark construct a proton, as seen in Figure 23.12.']
['What else is important?', 'The sum of the three quarks’ colors—red, green, and blue—yields the color white.']
['What other things did the writer say?', 'This theory of color interaction within particles is called quantum chromodynamics, or QCD.']
['What else does this theory have to do with?', 'As part of QCD, the strong nuclear force can be explained using color.']
['How do we know that?', 'In fact, some scientists refer to the color force, not the strong force, as one of the four fundamental forces.']
['What else did they say?', 'Figure 23.13 is a Feynman diagram showing the interaction between two quarks by using the transmission of a colored gluon.']
['What is a colored gluon?', 'Note that the gluon is also considered the charge carrier for the strong nuclear force.']
['What is the quark color?', 'Note that quark flavor may have any color.']
['What color is it?', 'For instance, in Figure 23.13, the down quark has a red color and a green color.']
["Why can't it have any color?", 'In other words, colors are not specific to a particle quark flavor.']
['What is revealingly grouped according to what forces they feel?', 'Particles can be revealingly grouped according to what forces they feel between them.']
['Are massless particles affected by gravity?', 'All particles (even those that are massless) are affected by gravity since gravity affects the space and time in which particles exist.']

['Are charged particles affected by the electromagnetic force?', 'All charged particles are affected by the electromagnetic force, as are neutral particles that have an internal distribution of charge (such as the neutron with its magnetic moment).']
['What other types of particles are given special names?', 'Special names are given to particles that feel the strong and weak nuclear forces.']
['Are there any other names for these types of particles?', 'Hadrons are particles that feel the strong nuclear force, whereas leptons are particles that do not.']
['What is the weak nuclear force?', 'All particles feel the weak nuclear force.']
['What does this mean?', 'This means that hadrons are distinguished by being able to feel both the strong and weak nuclear forces.']
['What other characteristics do hadrons have?', 'Leptons and hadrons are distinguished in other ways as well.']
['What else is unique about hadrons?', 'Leptons are fundamental particles that have no measurable size, while hadrons are composed of quarks and have a diameter on the order of 10–15 m.']
['What other characteristics distinguish these two types of particles?', 'Six particles, including the electron and neutrino, make up the list of known leptons.']
['Do hadrons have any other characteristics?', 'There are hundreds of complex particles in the hadron class, a few of which (including the proton and neutron) are listed in Table 23.4.']
['What were the major scientific discoveries that led to a new understanding of hadrons?', 'There are many more leptons, mesons, and baryons yet to be discovered and measured.']

['What are the smallest particles in existence?', 'The purpose of trying to uncover the smallest indivisible things in existence is to explain the world around us through forces and the interactions between particles, galaxies and objects.']
['How do scientists get samples of small particles?', 'This is why a handful of scientists devote their life’s work to smashing together small particles.']
['What is a proton made of?', 'The proton, like all hadrons, is made up of quarks.']
['What kind of quarks?', 'A few examples of hadron quark composition can be seen in Figure 23.14.']
['What is shown in the figure?', 'As shown, each hadron is constructed of multiple quarks.']
['What is a hadron?', 'As mentioned previously, the fractional quark charge in all four hadrons sums to the particle’s integral value.']
['What does this mean?', 'Also, notice that the color composition for each of the four particles adds to white.']
['Are there anything else interesting that I should know?', 'Each of the particles shown is constructed of up, down, and their antiquarks.']
['What is most interesting to you about this information?', 'This is not surprising, as the quarks strange, charmed, top, and bottom are found in only our most exotic particles.']
['What did you learn in your last section?', 'You may have noticed that while the proton and neutron in Figure 23.14 are composed of three quarks, both pions are comprised of only two quarks.']
["What's the main point of this article?", 'This refers to a final delineation in particle structure.']
['What does the baryon refer to?', 'Particles with three quarks are called baryons.']
['What does the term W boson mean?', 'These are heavy particles that can decay into another baryon.']
['What is the term meson?', 'Particles with only two quarks—a-quark–anti-quark pair—are called mesons.']
['What does the term Higgs boson mean?', 'These are particles of moderate mass that cannot decay into the more massive baryons.']
['What are some of the important terms associated with hadrons and leptons?', 'Before continuing, take a moment to view Figure 23.15.']
['What does this figure have to do with hadrons and leptons?', 'In this figure, you can see the strong force reimagined as a color force.']
['What are the particles in this figure?', 'The particles interacting in this figure are the proton and neutron, just as they were in Figure 23.6.']
['What is a color force?', 'This reenvisioning of the strong force as an interaction between colored quarks is the critical concept behind quantum chromodynamics.']
['What is the biggest difference between matter and antimatter?', 'Antimatter was first discovered in the form of the positron, the positively charged electron.']
['Who discovered it?', 'In 1932, American physicist Carl Anderson discovered the positron in cosmic ray studies.']

['How did he discover it?', 'Through a cloud chamber modified to curve the trajectories of cosmic rays, Anderson noticed that the curves of some particles followed that of a negative charge, while others curved like a positive charge.']
['What was different about the positive curve?', 'However, the positive curve showed not the mass of a proton but the mass of an electron.']

['How did he determine the mass of an electron?', 'This outcome is shown in Figure 23.16 and suggests the existence of a positively charged version of the electron, created by the destruction of solar photons.']
['what is antimatter?', 'Antimatter is considered the opposite of matter.']
['what is the opposite of matter?', 'For most antiparticles, this means that they share the same properties as their original particles with the exception of their charge.']
['what does the exception of their charge mean?', 'This is why the positron can be considered a positive electron while the antiproton is considered a negative proton.']

['how does this compare to neutral particles?', 'The idea of an opposite charge for neutral particles (like the neutron) can be confusing, but it makes sense when considered from the quark perspective.']

['is this true?', 'Just as the neutron is composed of one up quark and two down quarks (of charge $$\\(+ \\frac{2}{3}\\)$$and $$\\(- \\frac{1}{3}\\)$$, respectively), the antineutron is composed of one anti–up quark and two anti–down quarks (of charge  $$\\(- \\frac{2}{3}\\)$$  and $$\\(+ \\frac{1}{3}\\)$$, respectively).']
['what is important about the neutron?', 'While the overall charge of the neutron remains the same, its constituent particles do not!']
['Did you learn anything about antimatter?', 'A word about antiparticles: Like regular particles, antiparticles could function just fine on their own.']
['What else did you learn about antimatter?', 'In fact, a universe made up of antimatter may operate just as our own matter-based universe does.']
['Are there any other interesting aspects of this article?', 'However, we do not know fully whether this is the case.']
['How come?', 'The reason for this is annihilation.']
['What is annihilation?', 'Annihilation is the process of destruction that occurs when a particle and its antiparticle interact.']
['What do the particles do?', 'As soon as two particles (like a positron and an electron) coincide, they convert their masses to energy through the equation  $$\\(E = mc^{2}\\)$$ .']

['Why is this difficult to study?', 'This mass-to-energy conversion, which typically results in photon release, happens instantaneously and makes it very difficult for scientists to study antimatter.']
['Can you tell me anything else interesting?', 'That said, scientists have had success creating antimatter through high-energy particle collisions.']
['What kinds of antimatter has been created?', 'Both antineutrons and antiprotons were created through accelerator experiments in 1956, and an anti–hydrogen atom was even created at CERN in 1995!']
['What was the purpose of this experiment?', 'As referenced in Figure 22.40, the annihilation of antiparticles is currently used in medical studies to determine the location of radioisotopes.']
['What is the standard model of the atom?', 'The Standard Model of the atom refers to the current scientific view of the fundamental components and interacting forces of matter.']

['What are the fundamental components?', 'The Standard Model (Figure 23.17) shows the six quarks that bind to form all hadrons, the six lepton particles already considered fundamental, the four carrier particles (or gauge bosons) that transmit forces between the leptons and quarks, and the recently added Higgs boson (which will be discussed shortly).']
['How many particles do we have?', 'This totals 17 fundamental particles, combinations of which are responsible for all known matter in our entire universe!']
['Are there any other particles?', 'When adding the antiquarks and antileptons, 31 components make up the Standard Model.']
['What is Figure 23.17?', 'Figure 23.17 shows all particles within the Standard Model of the atom.']
['What is significant about this chart?', 'Not only does this chart divide all known particles by color-coded group, but it also provides information on particle stability.']
['What can you learn from this chart?', 'Note that the color-coding system in this chart is separate from the red, green, and blue color labeling system of quarks.']
['What can you find out about matter from this chart?', 'The first three columns represent the three families of matter.']
['What is Family 1?', 'The first column, considered Family 1, represents particles that make up normal matter, constructing the protons, neutrons, and electrons that make up the common world.']
['What is Family 2?', 'Family 2, represented from the charm quark to the muon neutrino, is comprised of particles that are more massive.']
['What is Family 3?', 'The leptons in this group are less stable and more likely to decay.']
['How is this different than Family 2?', 'Family 3, represented by the third column, are more massive still and decay more quickly.']
['How are these different?', 'The order of these families also conveniently represents the order in which these particles were discovered.']
['What is the Standard Model of the Atom?', 'The Standard Model also summarizes the fundamental forces that exist as particles interact.']
['What do the particles interact with?', 'A closer look at the Standard Model, as shown in Figure 23.18, reveals that the arrangement of carrier particles describes these interactions.']
['What is the model?', 'Each of the shaded areas represents a fundamental force and its constituent particles.']
['what are the forces represented?', 'The red shaded area shows all particles involved in the strong nuclear force, which we now know is due to quantum chromodynamics.']

['which other forces are represented?', 'The blue shaded area corresponds to the electromagnetic force, while the green shaded area corresponds to the weak nuclear force, which affects all quarks and leptons.']
['what happens to the forces?', 'The electromagnetic force and weak nuclear force are considered united by the electroweak force within the Standard Model.']
['are there any more forces?', 'Also, because definitive evidence of the graviton is yet to be found, it is not included in the Standard Model.']
['What is the smallest mass particle?', 'One interesting feature of the Standard Model shown in Figure 23.18 is that, while the gluon and photon have no mass, the Z and W bosons are very massive.']
['What did Peter Higgs believe?', 'In the 1960s, British physicist Peter Higgs and others speculated that the W and Z bosons were actually just as massless as the gluon and photon.']

['Why did they believe the masses of particles were zero?', 'However, as the W and Z bosons traveled from one particle to another, they were slowed down by the presence of a Higgs field, much like a fish swimming through water.']
['How was the bosons slowed down?', 'The thinking was that the existence of the Higgs field would slow down the bosons, causing them to decrease in energy and thereby transfer this energy to mass.']
['Why did they think that?', 'Under this theory, all particles pass through the Higgs field, which exists throughout the universe.']
['Why did the gluon and photon not pass through this field?', 'The gluon and photon travel through this field as well but are able to do so unaffected.']
['What is the Higgs Boson?', 'The presence of a force from the Higgs field suggests the existence of its own carrier particle, the Higgs boson.']
['Who does it interact with?', 'This theorized boson interacts with all particles but gluons and photons, transferring force from the Higgs field.']
['What are some of the particles that it interacts with?', 'Particles with large mass (like the top quark) are more likely to receive force from the Higgs boson.']
['What is an example of a particle?', 'While it is difficult to examine a field, it is somewhat simpler to find evidence of its carrier.']
['When did the discovery take place?', 'On July 4, 2012, two groups of scientists at the LHC independently confirmed the existence of a Higgs-like particle.']
['How did they do this?', 'By examining trillions of proton–proton collisions at energies of 7 to 8 TeV, LHC scientists were able to determine the constituent particles that created the protons.']

['What was the most significant part of the discovery?', 'In this data, scientists found a particle with similar mass, spin, parity, and interactions with other particles that matched the Higgs boson predicted decades prior.']
['What did CERN say about the discovery?', 'On March 13, 2013, the existence of the Higgs boson was tentatively confirmed by CERN.']

['Did they win any awards?', 'Peter Higgs and Francois Englert received the Nobel Prize in 2013 for the “theoretical discovery of a mechanism that contributes to our understanding of the origin and mass of subatomic particles.”']
['What is Understanding the Grand Unified Theory about?', 'Present quests to show that the four basic forces are different manifestations of a single unified force that follow a long tradition.']

['What are the four basic forces?', 'In the nineteenth century, the distinct electric and magnetic forces were shown to be intimately connected and are now collectively called the electromagnetic force.']
['What other forces are involved in the theory?', 'More recently, the weak nuclear force was united with the electromagnetic force.']
['What else is important about the theory?', 'As shown in Figure 23.19, carrier particles transmit three of the four fundamental forces in very similar ways.']

['Are the basic forces all connected?', 'With these considerations in mind, it is natural to suggest that a theory may be constructed in which the strong nuclear, weak nuclear, and electromagnetic forces are all unified.']
['What does this theory mean?', 'The search for a correct theory linking the forces, called the Grand Unified Theory (GUT), is explored in this section.']
['Who came up with the electroweak theory?', 'In the 1960s, the electroweak theory was developed by Steven Weinberg, Sheldon Glashow, and Abdus Salam.']
['What is the electroweak theory?', 'This theory proposed that the electromagnetic and weak nuclear forces are identical at sufficiently high energies.']
['How are these forces identical?', 'At lower energies, like those in our present-day universe, the two forces remain united but manifest themselves in different ways.']

['What were some other consequences of this theory?', 'One of the main consequences of the electroweak theory was the prediction of three short-range carrier particles, now known as the  $$\\(W^{+},\\)$$ $$\\(W^{-},\\)$$ and  $$\\(\\text{Z}^{0}\\)$$  bosons.']

['What other consequences did it have?', 'Not only were three particles predicted, but the mass of each  $$\\(\\text{W}^{+}\\)$$  and  $$\\(\\text{W}^{-}\\)$$  boson was predicted to be 81 GeV/c2, and that of the  $$\\(\\text{Z}^{0}\\)$$  boson was predicted to be 90 GeV/c2.']

['What was evidence of this theory?', 'In 1983, these carrier particles were observed at CERN with the predicted characteristics, including masses having those predicted values as given in Figure 23.17.']
['Are they the same thing?', 'They are definitely distinct under most circumstances.']
['How are they different?', 'For example, they are carried by different particles and have greatly different strengths.']

['What happened when the conditions were altered?', 'But experiments show that at extremely short distances and at extremely high energies, the strengths of the forces begin to become more similar, as seen in Figure 23.20.']
['What was the most important information?', 'As discussed earlier, the short ranges and large masses of the weak carrier bosons require correspondingly high energies to create them.']

['What else did the article cover?', 'Thus, the energy scale on the horizontal axis of Figure 23.20 also corresponds to shorter and shorter distances (going from left to right), with 100 GeV corresponding to approximately 10−18 m, for example.']
['How long is the distance?', 'At that distance, the strengths of the electromagnetic and weak nuclear forces are the same.']
['What was the energy?', 'To test this, energies of about 100 GeV are put into the system.']
['What was the outcome?', 'When this occurs, the  $$\\(\\text{W}^{+}\\)$$,  $$\\(\\text{W}^{-}\\)$$, and  $$\\(\\text{Z}^{0}\\)$$  carrier particles are created and released.']

['What other information was included?', 'At those and higher energies, the masses of the carrier particles become less and less relevant, and the  $$\\(\\text{Z}^{0}\\)$$  boson in particular resembles the massless, chargeless photon.']

['What else is mentioned in the article?', 'As further energy is added, the  $$\\(\\text{W}^{+}\\)$$,  $$\\(\\text{W}^{-}\\)$$, and  $$\\(\\text{Z}^{0}\\)$$  particles are further transformed into massless carrier particles even more similar to photons and gluons.']

['What is the most important point made in the article Understanding the Grand Unified Theory?', 'The extremely short distances and high energies at which the electroweak force becomes identical with the strong nuclear force are not reachable with any conceivable human-built accelerator.']
['How do scientists use the theory to find a new way to measure energy?', 'At energies of about 1014 GeV (16,000 J per particle), distances of about 10 to 30 m can be probed.']

['How are they testing the theory directly?', 'Such energies are needed to test the theory directly, but these are about 1010 times higher than the maximum energy associated with the LHC, and the distances are about 10 to 12 smaller than any structure we have direct knowledge of.']
['Why would this theory be different?', 'This would be the realm of various GUTs, of which there are many, since there is no constraining evidence at these energies and distances.']
['How is the theory different from others?', 'Past experience has shown that anytime you probe so many orders of magnitude further, you find the unexpected.']
['What kind of evidence is available for GUT?', 'While direct evidence of a GUT is not presently possible, that does not rule out the ability to assess a GUT through an indirect process.']
['Why is it not possible to demonstrate a GUT?', 'Current GUTs require various other events as a consequence of their theory.']

['What kind of events?', 'Some GUTs require the existence of magnetic monopoles, very massive individual north- and south-pole particles, which have not yet been proven to exist, while others require the use of extra dimensions.']
['What kind of events?', 'However, not all theories result in the same consequences.']
['What kind of consequences?', 'For example, disproving the existence of magnetic monopoles will not disprove all GUTs.']

['What does it mean that all theories will not result in the same consequences?', 'Much of the science we accept in our everyday lives is based on different models, each with their own strengths and limitations.']
['What is important about strengths and limitations?', 'Although a particular model may have drawbacks, that does not necessarily mean that it should be discounted completely.']
['What is one consequence of GUTs that can theoretically be assessed?', 'One consequence of GUTs that can theoretically be assessed is proton decay.']
['What can you tell me about the hypothesis?', 'Multiple current GUTs hypothesize that the stable proton should actually decay at a lifetime of 1031 years.']

['What time do scientists believe it is?', 'While this time is incredibly large (keep in mind that the age of the universe is less than 14 billion years), scientists at the Super-Kamiokande in Japan have used a 50,000-ton tank of water to search for its existence.']
['What was the purpose of the tank?', 'The decay of a single proton in the Super-Kamiokande tank would be observed by a detector, thereby providing support for the predicting GUT model.']
['How did the experiment go?', 'However, as of 2014, 17 years into the experiment, decay is yet to be found.']
['What does the lack of decay mean?', 'This time span equates to a minimum limit on proton life of  $$\\(5.9\\  \\times \\ 10^{33}\\)$$ years.']
['How would this affect the theory?', 'While this result certainly does not support many grand unifying theories, an acceptable model may still exist.']
['Why was the Universe designed in this manner?', 'Nature is full of examples where the macroscopic and microscopic worlds intertwine.']

['What are some examples of macroscopic and microscopic worlds intertwined', 'Newton realized that the nature of gravity on Earth that pulls an apple to the ground could explain the motion of the moon and planets so much farther away.']
['What are some other examples of the microscopic worlds intertwining?', 'Decays of tiny nuclei explain the hot interior of the Earth.']
['Is there anything else interesting that you learned from reading?', 'Fusion of nuclei likewise explains the energy of stars.']
['What is the most important thing that you learned?', 'Today, the patterns in particle physics seem to be explaining the evolution and character of the universe.']
['What is the nature of the universe?', 'And the nature of the universe has implications for unexplored regions of particle physics.']

['What does this study look at?', 'In 1929, Edwin Hubble observed that all but the closest galaxies surrounding our own had a red shift in their hydrogen spectra that was proportional to their distance from us.']
['What did this discovery mean?', 'Applying the Doppler Effect, Hubble recognized that this meant that all galaxies were receding from our own, with those farther away receding even faster.']
['What did this discovery lead to?', 'Knowing that our place in the universe was no more unique than any other, the implication was clear:']
['What else was discovered?', 'The space within the universe itself was expanding.']
['What does expanding mean?', 'Just like pen marks on an expanding balloon, everything in the universe was accelerating away from everything else.']
['What is the big bang?', 'Figure 23.21 shows how the recession of galaxies looks like the remnants of a gigantic explosion, the famous Big Bang.']
['How long ago was that?', 'Extrapolating backward in time, the Big Bang would have occurred between 13 and 15 billion years ago, when all matter would have been at a single point.']
['How did that change the way things were?', 'From this, questions instantly arise.']
['What questions?', 'For our purposes, the biggest question relating to the Big Bang is this:']
['What did you learn about the Big Bang?', 'To fully understand the conditions of the very early universe, recognize that as the universe contracts to the size of the Big Bang, changes will occur.']
['What will happen?', 'The density and temperature of the universe will increase dramatically.']
['Why would it become so hot?', 'As particles become closer together, they will become too close to exist as we know them.']
['Why do they become too close together?', 'The high energies will create other, more unusual particles to exist in greater abundance.']
['What else do you know about the Big Bang?', 'Knowing this, let’s move forward from the start of the universe, beginning with the Big Bang, as illustrated in Figure 23.22.']
['What was the next chapter?', 'The Planck Epoch $$\\(\\left( {0\\rightarrow 10^{-43}s} \\right)\\)$$']

['What was the next chapter about?', '—Though scientists are unable to model the conditions of the Planck Epoch in the laboratory, speculation is that at this time compressed energy was great enough to reach the immense  $$\\(10^{19}\\)$$  GeV necessary to unify gravity with all other forces.']
['What were the results?', 'As a result, modern cosmology suggests that all four forces would have existed as one force, a hypothetical superforce as suggested by the Theory of Everything.']
['What is a topic that is covered in the study material?', 'The Grand Unification Epoch $$\\(\\left( {10^{-43}\\rightarrow 10^{-36}s} \\right)\\)$$']
['What other interesting information did you find in this section?', '—As the universe expands, the temperatures necessary to maintain the superforce decrease.']
['How does the thermodynamic model help explain gravity?', 'As a result, gravity separates, leaving the electroweak and strong nuclear forces together.']
['What is the Grand Unification?', 'At this time, the electromagnetic, weak, and strong forces are identical, matching the conditions requested in the Grand Unification Theory.']
['What is the next chapter?', 'The Inflationary Epoch $$\\(\\left( {10^{- 36}\\rightarrow 10^{- 32}s} \\right)\\)$$']

['What is significant about the inflationary epoch?', '—The separation of the strong nuclear force from the electroweak force during this time is thought to have been responsible for the massive inflation of the universe.']

['Did anything else happen during the inflationary epoch?', 'Corresponding to the steep diagonal line on the left side of Figure 23.22, the universe may have expanded by a factor of  $$\\(10^{50}\\)$$  or more in size.']
['What was most interesting in the chapter?', 'In fact, the expansion was so great during this time that it actually occurred faster than the speed of light!']

['Can anything be done about the inflationary epoch?', 'Unfortunately, there is little hope that we may be able to test the inflationary scenario directly since it occurs at energies near  $$\\(10^{14}\\)$$  GeV, vastly greater than the limits of modern accelerators.']
['What is the next title of your study material?', 'The Electroweak Epoch $$\\(\\left( {10^{-32}\\rightarrow 10^{-11}s} \\right)\\)$$']
['What did you learn in The Electroweak Epoch?', '—Now separated from both gravity and the strong nuclear force, the electroweak force exists as a singular force during this time period.']

['What else did you learn in The Electroweak Epoch?', 'As stated earlier, scientists are able to create the energies at this stage in the universe’s expansion, needing only 100 GeV, as shown in Figure 23.20.']
['What else is significant about the Electroweak Epoch?', 'W and Z bosons, as well as the Higgs boson, are released during this time.']
['What was the other title?', 'The Quark Era $$\\(\\left( {10^{-11}\\rightarrow 10^{-6}s} \\right)\\)$$']
['What happened during the Quark Era?', '—During the Quark Era, the universe has expanded and temperatures have decreased to the point at which all four fundamental forces have separated.']
['Why did they separate?', 'Additionally, quarks began to take form as energies decreased.']
['what did the model predict?', 'As the universe expanded, further eras took place, allowing for the existence of hadrons, leptons, and photons, the fundamental particles of the standard model.']
['what else was predicted?', 'Eventually, in nucleosynthesis, nuclei would be able to form, and the basic building blocks of atomic matter could take place.']
['what did you learn?', 'Using particle accelerators, we are very much working backwards in an attempt to understand the universe.']
['what did you find interesting?', 'It is encouraging to see that the macroscopic conditions of the Big Bang align nicely with our submicroscopic particle theory.']
Average
